The Contractor shall keep himself fully informed of all 6 such regulations that in any way affect the conduct of the work and shall at all times 7 observe and comply with all such regulations .
In the event of conflict between such 8 regulations and the specifications , the more restrictive requirements shall apply .
9 The Engineer will limit the area over which clearing and grubbing , excavation , borrow 10 and embankment operations are performed whenever the Contractor 's operations do not 11 make effective use of construction practices and temporary measures which will 12 minimize erosion , or whenever construction operations have not been coordinated to 13 effectively minimize erosion , or whenever permanent erosion control features are not 14 being completed as soon as permitted by construction operations .
15 Following completion of any construction phase or operation , on any graded slope or any 16 disturbed area , the Contractor shall provide ground cover sufficient to restrain erosion 17 within 21 calendar days or within a time period specified by the 18 NCG 010000 Construction Permit .
The ground cover shall be either temporary or 19 permanent and the type specified in the contract .
20 ( B ) Erosion and Siltation Control 21 The Contractor shall exercise every reasonable precaution throughout the life of the 22 project to prevent the eroding of soil and the silting of rivers , streams , lakes , reservoirs , 23 other water impoundments , wetlands , ground surfaces or other property .
24 Before suspension of operations on the project or any portion thereof , the Contractor shall 25 take all necessary measures to protect the construction area , including , but not limited to , 26 borrow sources , soil type base course sources and waste areas from erosion during the 27 period of suspension .
28 Unless otherwise approved in writing by the Engineer , construction operations in rivers , 29 streams and water impoundments shall be restricted to those areas where channel changes 30 are shown in the plans and to those areas which must be entered for the construction or 31 removal of temporary or permanent structures .
32 Excavated materials shall not be deposited , nor shall earth dikes or other temporary earth 33 structures be constructed , in rivers , streams , or impoundments .
As an exception to the 34 above , confined earth materials will be permitted when approved in writing by the 35 Engineer .
36 Fording of live streams with construction equipment will not be permitted ; therefore , 37 temporary bridges or other structures shall be used wherever stream crossings are 38 necessary .
Unless otherwise approved in writing by the Engineer , mechanized equipment 39 shall not be operated in live streams except as may be necessary to construct channel 40 changes and to construct or remove temporary or permanent structures .
41 Section 107 1-61 ( C ) Coordination of Erosion Control Operations 1 Temporary and permanent erosion control measures shall be provided as shown in the 2 plans or as directed by the Engineer .
All permanent erosion control work shall be 3 incorporated into the project at the earliest practicable time .
Temporary erosion control 4 measures shall be coordinated with permanent erosion control measures and all other 5 work on the project to assure economical , effective and continuous erosion control 6 throughout the construction and post construction period and to minimize siltation of 7 rivers , streams , lakes , reservoirs , other water impoundments , wetlands , ground surfaces , 8 or other property .
9 Temporary erosion control measures shall include , but not be limited to , the use of 10 temporary berms , dikes , dams , drainage ditches , silt basins , silt ditches , slope drains , 11 structures , vegetation , mulches , mats , netting , gravel , or any other methods or devices 12 that are necessary .
Temporary erosion control measures may include work outside the 13 right-of-way or construction limits where such work is necessary as a result of 14 construction such as borrow operations , haul roads , plant sites , equipment storage sites 15 and disposal of waste or debris .
The Contractor shall be liable for all damages to public 16 or private property caused by silting or slides originating in waste areas furnished by the 17 Contractor .
18 Materials for temporary erosion control measures shall have been approved by the 19 Engineer before being used or shall be as directed by the Engineer .
The Contractor shall 20 acceptably maintain erosion control measures installed .
21 ( D ) Water and Air Pollution 22 Exercise every reasonable precaution throughout the life of the project to prevent 23 pollution of ground waters and surface waters , such as rivers , streams and water 24 impoundments .
Do not discharge onto the ground or surface waters any pollutants such 25 as chemicals , raw sewage , fuels , lubricants , coolants , hydraulic fluids , concrete , bitumens 26 and any other petroleum products .
Operate and maintain equipment on site in a manner 27 as to prevent the potential or actual pollution of surface or ground waters of the State .
28 Dispose of spent fluids in accordance with applicable Federal and State disposal 29 regulations .
Immediately clean up any spilled fluids to the extent practicable and dispose 30 of properly .
31 Manage , control and dispose of litter on site such that no adverse impacts to water quality 32 occur .
Comply with all Federal , State or local air pollution regulations throughout the 33 life of the project .
34 ( E ) Dust Control 35 The Contractor shall control dust throughout the life of the project within the project area 36 and at all other areas affected by the construction of the project , including , but not 37 specifically limited to , unpaved secondary roads , haul roads , access roads , disposal sites , 38 borrow and material sources and production sites .
Dust control shall not be considered 39 effective where the amount of dust creates a potential or actual unsafe condition , public 40 nuisance , or condition endangering the value , utility , or appearance of any property .
41 The Contractor will not be directly compensated for any dust control measures necessary , 42 as this work will be incidental to the work covered by the various contract items .
43 ( F ) Application of Specifications 44 Article 107-12 shall apply to all construction operations .
Further references and detailed 45 requirements concerning erosion , siltation and pollution prevention and control are given 46 in other sections of the Standard Specifications as supplements to the general 47 requirements of this article .
48 Section 107 1-62 ( G ) Sanctions 1 In the event that temporary erosion and pollution control measures become necessary due 2 to the Contractor 's negligence , carelessness , or failure to incorporate permanent erosion 3 control measures into the project at the earliest practicable time , such measures shall be 4 performed by the Contractor as directed by the Engineer at no cost to the Department .
If 5 the Contractor fails to perform such measures as directed , the Engineer may have the 6 work performed in accordance with Article 105-16 .
7 Failure of the Contractor to fulfill any of the requirements of this article may result in the 8 Engineer ordering the stopping of construction operations in accordance with 9 Article 108-7 until such failure has been corrected .
Such suspension of operations will 10 not justify an extension of contract time .
11 Failure on the part of the Contractor to perform the necessary measures to control 12 erosion , siltation and pollution will result in the Engineer notifying the Contractor to take 13 such measures .
In the event that the Contractor fails to perform such measures within 14 24 hours after receipt of such notice with adequate forces and equipment , the Engineer 15 may suspend the work as provided above , or may proceed to have such measures 16 performed with other forces and equipment , or both .
No payment will be made to the 17 Contractor for the performance of this work and the cost of such work so performed will 18 be deducted from monies due the Contractor on his contract .
19 107-13 PROTECTION OF PUBLIC LANDS 20 In the execution of any work within or adjacent to any National or State forest , park or other 21 public lands , the Contractor shall comply with all regulations of all authorities having 22 jurisdiction over such forest , park or lands , governing the protection of public lands and the 23 carrying out of work within public lands and shall observe all sanitary laws and regulations 24 with respect to the performance of work in public lands .
He shall keep the areas in an orderly 25 condition , properly dispose of all refuse and obtain permits for the construction and 26 maintenance of all construction camps , stores , warehouses , residences , latrines , cesspools , 27 septic tanks and other structures in accordance with the regulations of the appropriate 28 authorities .
29 The Contractor shall take all reasonable precaution to prevent and suppress forest fires and 30 shall require his employees and subcontractors , both independently and at the request of forest 31 officials , to do all reasonable within their power to prevent and suppress and to assist in 32 preventing and suppressing forest fires and to make every possible effort to notify a forest 33 official at the earliest possible moment of the location and extent of any fire seen by them .
34 The Contractor shall obtain any construction permits that may be required for his operations , 35 which are not a part of the project , in accordance with the regulations of the appropriate 36 authorities .
37 107-14 RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGE CLAIMS 38 The Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless the Board and its members and the 39 Department , its officers , agents and employees from all suits , actions , or claims of any 40 character brought for any injury or damages received or sustained by any person , persons , or 41 property by reason of any act of the Contractor , subcontractor , its agents or employees , in the 42 performance of the contract .
The Contractor 's liability to save harmless and indemnify shall 43 include , but not by way of limitation , the following : 44 ( A ) Damages or claims for the failure of the Contractor to safeguard the work ; 45 ( B ) Damages or claims by reason of the failure of the Contractor to erect adequate barricades 46 and post adequate warnings to the public of such barricades ; 47 ( C ) Any damage or claims caused through the Contractor 's use of defective materials or by 48 the performance of defective work ; 49 Section 107 1-63 ( D ) Any claims by reason of the Contractor 's infringement of patent , trademark , or copyright ; 1 ( E ) Any amounts paid by the Department by reason of the Contractor 's failure to comply with 2 or for violations of laws , ordinances , orders , or decrees ; 3 ( F ) Any damages or claims caused by blasting operations of the Contractor with or without 4 proof of negligence on the part of the Contractor ; 5 ( G ) Damages or claims caused by the failure of the Contractor to protect private or public 6 property pursuant to Article 107-11 , including damages to public and private property 7 caused by silting and slides from waste areas furnished by the contractor , without proof 8 of negligence ; and 9 ( H ) Damages caused by the failure of the Contractor to control erosion in accordance with the 10 contract .
11 In addition to any remedy authorized by law , the Department shall have a right to retain from 12 monies due the Contractor , as the Department considers necessary until final disposition has 13 been made of the following suits or claims : 14 ( 1 ) For all claims against the Department involving claims or damages that are the 15 Contractor 's responsibility under Section 107 .
The Contractor and the Surety shall 16 remain responsible until such suits or claims against the Department have been 17 settled and until the Department has been indemnified and saved harmless .
18 ( 2 ) In case of claims by third parties against the Contractor involving tort liability for 19 which the Department might be held liable for as a taking of property , or as a tort 20 before the Industrial Commission .
However , monies due the Contractor will not be 21 retained provided the Contractor produces satisfactory evidence to the Department 22 that he is adequately protected from such tort liability by public liability and property 23 damage insurance .
In all other cases involving claims or suits by third parties against 24 the Contractor , amounts due the Contractor will not be withheld provided that the 25 consent of the Surety is furnished and the Surety guarantees payment of any amounts 26 for which the Contractor may be determined to be legally liable .
27 ( 3 ) In cases of damage to property of the Department , such amounts necessary to pay for 28 such damage .
29 In cases where claims are made or suits filed against the Board or its members and the 30 Department , its officers , agents and employees , the Department may retain from any monies 31 due the Contractor , an amount sufficient to indemnify such member of the Board or officer , 32 agent or employee of the Department for any amounts which they may be held liable for but 33 for which the Contractor is responsible under Section 107 .
In the event that there is not 34 sufficient monies available from the final estimate , the Department may collect from the 35 Contractor or its Surety amounts sufficient to indemnify such employee , agent or officer of 36 the Department or member of the Board for such damages incurred .
37 107-15 LIABILITY INSURANCE 38 The Contractor shall be liable for any losses resulting from a breach of the terms of this 39 contract .
The Contractor shall be liable for any losses due to the negligence or willful 40 misconduct of its agents , assigns and employees including any sub-contractors which causes 41 damage to others for which the Department is found liable under the Torts Claims Act , or in 42 the General Courts of Justice , provided the Department provides prompt notice to the 43 Contractor and that the Contractor has an opportunity to defend against such claims .
The 44 Contractor shall not be responsible for punitive damages .
45 Section 107 1-64 The Contractor shall at its sole cost and expense obtain and furnish to the Department 1 an original standard Association for Cooperative Operations Research and 2 Development ( ACORD ) form certificate of insurance evidencing commercial general liability 3 with a limit for bodily injury and property damage in the amount of $ 5,000,000 per 4 occurrence and general aggregate , covering the Contractor from claims or damages for bodily 5 injury , personal injury , or for property damages that may arise from operating under the 6 contract by the employees and agents of the Contractor .
The required limit of insurance may 7 be obtained by a single general liability policy or the combination of a general liability and 8 excess liability or umbrella policy .
The State of North Carolina shall be named as an 9 additional insured on this commercial general liability policy .
The policy may contain the 10 following language as relates to the State as an additional insured : “ This insurance with 11 respect to the additional insured applies only to the extent that the additional insured is held 12 liable for your or your agent ’ s acts or omissions arising out of and in the course of operations 13 performed for the additional insured. ” 14 The Contractor shall maintain all legally required insurance coverage , including without 15 limitation , worker ’ s compensation and vehicle liability , in the amounts required by law .
Prior 16 to beginning services , all contractors shall provide proof of coverage issued by a workers ’ 17 compensation insurance carrier , or a certificate of compliance issued by the Department of 18 Insurance for self-insured subcontractors , irrespective of whether having regularly in service 19 fewer than three employees .
Providing and maintaining adequate insurance coverage is a 20 material obligation of the contractor and is of the essence of this contract .
All such insurance 21 shall meet all laws of the State of North Carolina .
Such insurance coverage shall be obtained 22 from companies that are authorized to provide such coverage and that are authorized by the 23 Commissioner of Insurance to do business in North Carolina .
The Contractor shall at all 24 times comply with the terms of such insurance policies .
25 Upon execution of the contract , provide evidence of the above insurance requirements to the 26 Engineer .
When required by the contract , the Contractor shall carry insurance of the kinds 27 and in the amounts specified therein in addition to any other forms of insurance or bonds 28 required under the terms of the contract , or any other insurance carried by the Contractor .

30 107-25 HAZARDOUS , CONTAMINATED AND TOXIC MATERIAL 31 When the Contractor 's operations encounter or expose any abnormal condition that may 32 indicate the presence of a hazardous , contaminated , or toxic material , such operations shall be 33 discontinued in the vicinity of the abnormal condition and the Engineer shall be notified 34 immediately .
Upon notification by the Contractor , the Engineer will investigate the work , 35 consult the GeoEnvironmental Section of the Geotechnical Engineering Unit and , if 36 necessary , suspend the work in accordance with Article 108-7 .
The presence of storage 37 drums or barrels ; old or abandoned underground storage tanks ; discolored earth , metal , wood , 38 etc .
; visible fumes ; abnormal odors ; excessively hot earth ; smoke ; or anything else that 39 appears abnormal may be indicators of hazardous , contaminated or toxic materials and shall 40 be treated with extraordinary caution as they are evidence of abnormal conditions .
41 The Contractor 's operations shall not resume until so directed by the Engineer .
42 Disposition of the hazardous , contaminated , or toxic material will be made in accordance with 43 Federal , State and local requirements and regulations .
Where the Contractor performs work 44 necessary to dispose of hazardous , contaminated , or toxic material , payment will be made at 45 the unit prices for pay items included in the contract that are applicable to such work .
Where 46 the contract does not include such pay items , the Engineer may have the work performed by 47 others or the Contractor may perform the work in accordance with Article 104-7 for extra 48 work and the following paragraphs .
49 Section 107 1-67 The Contractor shall employ a fully experienced and prequalified geoenvironmental firm to 1 oversee and document the disposal of contaminated material removed from within the project 2 limits .
The Contractor shall furnish and deliver to the Department a digital report including 3 all documents necessary to meet the laws , rules and regulations of the environmental 4 regulatory agency ( ies ) having jurisdiction over each respective site from which contaminated 5 materials are removed .
Reports documenting the Contractor ’ s work and laboratory analyses 6 of collected samples shall be submitted to the Department within 30 calendar days after 7 completion of the removal of the contaminated materials .
If the Contractor removes any 8 underground storage tanks ( UST ) , a UST Closure Report shall be presented to the Department 9 within 25 calendar days after receipt of laboratory data .
The Contractor shall not submit any 10 reports directly to the regulatory agencies .
The Contractor shall provide to the Department a 11 Certificate of Remediation from the disposing/treating facility within 60 calendar days after 12 removal of the materials from the project site unless alternate arrangements are approved in 13 writing by the Department .
14 Contaminated material removed during construction shall be transported to a waste treatment 15 and disposal facility that is fully approved and permitted by all applicable environmental 16 regulatory agencies to receive , treat and/or dispose of the material .
It shall be the Contractor ’ s 17 responsibility to locate such a facility .
Departmental approval of the specific facility 18 identified for use by the Contractor shall occur before removal of any materials from the 19 project limits .
Contaminated material shall only be removed to the extent necessary to 20 complete a task or as directed by the Engineer .
Remaining contamination shall be left in 21 place and documented in reports provided to the Department .
The Contractor shall provide 22 the Department with all transportation manifests and certificates of acceptance from the 23 receiving disposal facility weekly .
The Department will be the regulatory generator of all 24 waste excavated and removed from within the project limits .
The Contractor , with the 25 approval of the Engineer , is authorized to sign all waste transportation and disposal manifests 26 on behalf of the Department .
27 The Contractor shall maintain qualified personnel on-site at all times during removal of 28 materials from within known areas of contamination for field screening and to monitor 29 ambient air quality .
The qualified personnel shall be knowledgeable with the use of 30 an Organic Vapor Analyzer , Flame Ionization Detector , Photo Ionization Detector , or other 31 appropriate monitoring equipment .
In the event that there is a need to stockpile contaminated 32 material , the Contractor shall stockpile all contaminated soil excavated from a parcel in 33 a location within the property boundaries of the source parcel in accordance with the Standard 34 Stockpile Containment Detail .
If the volume of contaminated material exceeds available 35 space on site , the Contractor shall obtain a permit from the NCDEQ UST Section for off-site 36 temporary storage .
37 The Contractor shall be entirely responsible for compliance with all OSHA , EPA , DOT , 38 NCDEQ , and local rules and regulations pertaining to excavation , transportation and 39 treatment/disposal of the contaminated material .
Examples of such rules and regulations 40 include , but are not limited to , 29 CFR 1910 General Industry Standards and 1926 41 Construction Standards , and 40 CFR 260 Hazardous Waste Management System , 261 42 General , Identification and Listing of Hazardous Waste , 262 Standards Applicable to 43 Generators of Hazardous Waste , 263 Standards Applicable to Transporters of Hazardous 44 Waste , 264 Standards for Owners and Operators of Hazardous Waste Treatment , Storage , and 45 Disposal Facilities , 265 Interim Status Standards for Owners and Operators of Hazardous 46 Waste Treatment , Storage , and Disposal Facilities , 49 CFR 173 Shippers-General 47 Requirements for Shipments and Packagings , 49 CFR 178 Specifications for Packagings , 15A 48 NCAC 13A North Carolina Hazardous Waste Management Rules , NCGS § 130A-310 49 Inactive Hazardous Sites , the Federal Comprehensive Environmental Response , 50 Compensation and Liability Act ( CERCLA ) and the Federal Resource Conservation and 51 Recovery Act ( RCRA ) .
It must be noted that inclusion of this paragraph is meant to highlight 52 the Contractor ’ s responsibility for regulatory compliance in all phases of work on this project .

No change 31 will be made in basis of payment for the construction items involved or in the completion date 32 as a result of authorizing a change in methods or equipment under these provisions .

In case such consent is given , the sublet work shall be 39 performed by the subcontractor unless otherwise approved in writing by the Engineer .
Failure 40 of the Contractor to comply with the Standard Specifications will be just cause for the work to 41 be considered unauthorized in accordance with Article 105-12 .

In case such consent is given , the 47 Contractor will be permitted to sublet a portion thereof , but shall perform with his own 48 organization , work amounting to not less than 40 % of the total original contract amount , 49 except : 50 ( A ) Any items designated in the contract as specialty items may be performed by subcontract 51 and the cost of any such special items so performed by subcontract will be deducted from 52 Section 108 1-71 the total amount bid before computing the amount of work required to be performed by 1 the Contractor with his own organization , and 2 ( B ) Any other items sublet to Disadvantaged Business Enterprise ( DBE ) , Minority 3 Business ( MB ) or Women 's Business ( WB ) , up to the value of the contract DBE , MB or 4 WB goal , will be deducted from the total amount bid before computing the amount of 5 work required to be performed by the Contractor with his own organization .

Purchasing materials for subcontractors is not included in the 9 percentage of work required to be performed by the Contractor .
If the Contractor sublets 10 items of work but elects to purchase material for the subcontractor , the value of the material 11 purchased will be included in the total dollar amount considered to have been sublet .
12 Extra work performed in accordance with Article 104-7 will not be considered in the 13 computation of work required to be performed by the Contractor .

6 108-8 FAILURE TO MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY PROGRESS 7 The Engineer will check the Contractor 's progress at the time each partial pay estimate is 8 prepared .
The Contractor 's progress may be considered as unsatisfactory as follows : 9 ( A ) The Contractor 's progress is found to be less than that described in either count below : 10 ( 1 ) The dollar value of the work completed , excluding material payments allowed by 11 Article 109-5 , is less than the dollar value of the work that should have been 12 completed , on the basis of the Contractor 's approved progress schedule , by more than 13 15 % of the current contract amount .
14 The dollar value of the work completed will be the total estimate to date shown in 15 the latest partial pay estimate , excluding material payments allowed by 16 Article 109-5 .
The current contract amount will be the total amount bid plus 17 accumulated overruns less accumulated underruns shown in the latest partial pay 18 estimate .
19 ( 2 ) The percentage of the work completed is less than the percentage of contract time 20 elapsed on the work by more than 15 % .
The percentage of work completed will be 21 the dollar value of the work completed as defined above , divided by the current 22 contract amount as defined above .
23 The percentage of contract time elapsed will be the number of calendar days elapsed 24 as shown in the latest partial pay estimate divided by the total contract time in 25 calendar days .
26 ( B ) The Contractor fails to begin and pursue the work in accordance with Article 108-1 27 before the expiration of 5 % of the original contract time after the date work was 28 scheduled to begin based upon the approved progress schedule .
29 ( C ) The Engineer anticipates the Contractor will not complete the work described in the 30 contract by the intermediate contract time or the contract completion date .
31 When the Contractor 's progress is found to be unsatisfactory as described in 32 Subarticles 108-8 ( A ) , 108-8 ( B ) and 108-8 ( C ) above , the Engineer may make written demand 33 of the Contractor to state in writing the reason for the unsatisfactory progress and produce 34 such supporting data as the Engineer may require or the Contractor may desire to submit .
The 35 Engineer will consider the justifications submitted by the Contractor and extensions of the 36 completion date have or may be allowed in accordance with Subarticle 108-10 ( B ) .
37 When the Contractor can not satisfactorily justify the unsatisfactory progress , the Engineer 38 may invoke one or more of the following sanctions : 39 ( 1 ) Withhold anticipated liquidated damages from amounts currently due or that become 40 due .
41 ( 2 ) Remove the Contractor from the Department 's Prequalified Bidders List .
42 When any of the above sanctions have been invoked , they shall remain in effect until 43 rescinded by the Engineer .
44 Section 108 1-73 108-9 DEFAULT OF CONTRACT 1 ( A ) Declaration of Default 2 The Department shall have the right to declare default of the contract for breach by the 3 Contractor of any material term or condition of the contract as determined by the 4 Department .
Material breach by the Contractor shall include , but specifically shall not be 5 limited to failure to begin work under the contract within the time specified ; failure to 6 provide workmen , equipment , or materials adequate to perform the work in conformity 7 with the contract by the completion date ; unsatisfactory performance of the work ; refusal 8 or failure to replace defective work ; failure to maintain satisfactory work progress ; failure 9 to comply with equal employment opportunity contract requirements ; insolvency or 10 bankruptcy , or any act of insolvency or bankruptcy ; and making an assignment for 11 benefit of creditors .
12 ( B ) Corrective Actions upon Default 13 In the event of a breach of the contract by the Contractor , the Department shall have the 14 right , power and authority , in its sole discretion , without violating the contract or 15 releasing the Surety : to assume full control of the prosecution of the contract in the place 16 and stead of the Contractor in directing Contractor 's agents , employees and 17 subcontractors in the performance of the work and in utilizing all materials , tools , 18 machinery , equipment and structures located on the project ; to perform the work or any 19 part thereof with Department personnel and equipment or to use any or all materials and 20 equipment located on the project that are suitable and acceptable ; to relet the work upon 21 such terms and conditions as the Department shall deem appropriate ; to employ any other 22 methods that it may determine are required for completion of the contract in 23 an acceptable manner ; and to withhold any sums due the Contractor under the contract 24 without penalty or interest until the work is completed and accepted by the Department .
25 ( C ) Notice 26 Before invoking any of the corrective actions provided for herein , the Department will 27 give the Contractor at least 7 calendar days written notice with a copy to the Surety , that 28 will set forth the breach of contract involved and the corrective actions to be imposed .
29 The Department , in its discretion , may grant the Contractor time in excess of 7 calendar 30 days within which to comply with the contract and the time allowed will be set forth in 31 writing .
If the Department determines during such period that the Contractor is not 32 proceeding satisfactorily to compliance , it may impose the corrective actions after 33 24 hours ’ notice to the Contractor .
If the Department determines that the Contractor is 34 not in compliance at the end of the time allowed , it may immediately impose any of the 35 corrective actions set forth herein and will advise the Contractor , in writing , with a copy 36 to the Surety of the corrective actions imposed .
37 ( D ) Payment 38 After declaration of default has been made final , the Contractor will be entitled to receive 39 payment for work satisfactorily completed or portions of work satisfactorily completed , 40 less any sums that may be due the Department from the Contractor but in no event shall 41 payment exceed the contract unit or lump sum price for such work .
The Department , at 42 its election , may retain the sum due the Contractor , or any portion thereof , without 43 interest or penalty , until the contract work is completed ; or it may make payment to the 44 Contractor upon declaration of default for work satisfactorily completed to the date that 45 notice of default is received by the Contractor .
The Contractor may be required by the 46 Engineer to carry to a stage of completion satisfactory to the Engineer any work in 47 progress , the value of which , otherwise , would be lost by immediate cessation of work .
48 Payment for such work will be made upon the basis hereinafter set out .
49 In the event that the Contractor 's employees , equipment , or materials are used in 50 prosecution of the work , or any part thereof , after default is declared , payment to the 51 Section 108 1-74 Contractor may be by contract unit or lump sum prices for the work performed , or , if the 1 Engineer determines that such prices do not represent the value of the work performed , 2 payment for the type of work or services performed will be made on a force account 3 basis , as set forth in Article 109-3 , less any sums that may be due the Department ; but in 4 no event shall payment exceed the contract unit or lump sum price for such work or 5 services .
Determination of the method of payment shall be in the sole discretion of the 6 Engineer , and he will advise the Contractor , in writing , of his determination with 7 reference to the specific type of work or service to be performed .
8 If all costs and expenses incurred by the Department arising out of the breach and 9 imposition of sanctions , together with the total cost to the Department of securing the 10 performance of the work set forth in the contract , exceed the sum that would have been 11 payable under the contract , the Contractor and the Surety shall be liable to the 12 Department for such excess and shall pay such amount to the Department .
13 ( E ) Power of Engineer 14 The Engineer will exercise the powers and discretion vested in him by the contract in 15 carrying out the terms of this article .
He will have full power and authority to carry out 16 any orders , directives , or resolutions issued by the Department in connection with 17 a declaration of default .
In the event that the Department fails to specify the sanctions to 18 be imposed , the notice to be given or the method of completing the work , the Engineer 19 may , at his discretion , impose such sanctions , give such notice and select such methods 20 of completing the work , as are authorized by this article ; and such actions shall have the 21 same effect and validity as if taken pursuant to an express order , directive or resolution of 22 the Department .
23 ( F ) Obligation of Contractor and Surety 24 No term or terms of this article and no action taken pursuant hereto by the Department of 25 Transportation , its agents , or employees , will be construed to release or discharge the 26 Contractor or the Surety upon the obligation set forth in the contract bonds , and the 27 Contractor and the Surety shall remain bound thereon unto the Department until the work 28 set forth in the contract has been completed and accepted by the Department and all 29 obligations of the Contractor and the Surety arising under the contract and contract bond 30 have been discharged .
31 ( G ) Provision Not Exclusive 32 The provisions shall be in addition to and not in place of , any other provisions relating to 33 default , breach of contract and sanctions to be imposed in connection therewith appearing 34 in the contract .

52 Section 108 1-77 108-11 LIQUIDATED DAMAGES 1 The parties acknowledge that time is of the essence for the performance of the work under the 2 contract .
Time is an essential element of the contract .
Delay in completing the work will 3 result in damages including but not limited to public inconvenience , obstruction to traffic , 4 interference with business and the increasing of engineering , inspection and administrative 5 costs to the Department .
It is therefore agreed that in view of the difficulty of making a 6 precise determination of such damages , a sum of money in the amount stipulated in the 7 contract , will be charged against the Contractor for each calendar day , each hour , or portion 8 thereof that the work , or any portion of the work as described in the contract , remains 9 uncompleted after the expiration of the completion date , intermediate completion date , or 10 intermediate completion time shown in the contract , not as a penalty but as liquidated 11 damages .
12 Should the Contractor or , in case of default , the Surety fail to complete the work or any 13 portion of the work by any of the applicable completion dates , intermediate completion dates , 14 or intermediate completion times shown in the contract , a deduction of the amount stipulated 15 in the contract as liquidated damages will be made for each and every calendar day , for each 16 and every hour , or portion thereof that the work or any portion of the work remains 17 uncompleted after the expiration of any completion date , intermediate completion date , or 18 intermediate completion time applicable to the uncompleted work .
This amount will be 19 deducted from any money due the Contractor or his Surety under the contract and the 20 Contractor and his Surety will be liable for any liquidated damages in excess of the 21 amount due .
22 In the event that the contract establishes one or more intermediate completion dates or times 23 in addition to the completion date , each of the liquidated damages stipulated will be 24 considered to be cumulative to any other liquidated damages stipulated .
25 In case of Contractor default of the contract and the completion of the work by the 26 Department , the Contractor and his Surety will be liable for the liquidated damages under the 27 contract , but no liquidated damages will be chargeable for any delay in the final completion of 28 the work by the Department due to any action , negligence , omission , or delay of the 29 Department .
30 In any suit for the collection of or involving the assessment of liquidated damages , the 31 reasonableness of the amount stipulated in the contract will be presumed .
The liquidated 32 damages referred to herein are intended to be and are cumulative and will be in addition to 33 every other remedy now or hereafter enforceable at law by statute or under the contract .
34 Permitting the Contractor to continue and finish the work or any part thereof after the 35 expiration of the completion date , intermediate completion date , or intermediate completion 36 time shall in no way operate as a waiver on the part of the Department of any of its rights 37 under this contract .
38 108-12 EXTENSION OF CONTRACT TIME AND APPORTIONMENT OF 39 LIQUIDATED DAMAGES 40 In accordance with Articles 108-10 and 108-11 , when a contract is not completed by the 41 completion date , intermediate completion date , or intermediate completion time , the 42 Contractor shall be entitled to an extension of the completion date , intermediate completion 43 date , or intermediate completion time and apportionment and remittance of liquidated 44 damages to the extent that the failure to complete was due to the conditions set forth in 45 Article 108-10 .
The Contractor , however , shall be entitled to an extension of the completion 46 date , intermediate completion date , or intermediate completion time , or an apportionment and 47 remittance of liquidated damages only to the extent and in the proportion that such delays 48 were caused by the conditions set forth in Article 108-10 , and it is understood that any 49 extension granted shall not operate to waive any liquidated damages or any claim which the 50 Department has or may have against the Contractor by reason of failure of the Contractor to 51 Section 108 1-78 complete the said contract by the completion date , intermediate completion date , or 1 intermediate completion time specified therein or as revised by authorized extensions .

23 SECTION 109 24 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 25 109-1 MEASUREMENT OF QUANTITIES 26 All work completed under the contract will be measured by the Engineer according to United 27 States standard measures unless otherwise stated in the contract .
28 The method of measurement and computations used in the determination of quantities of 29 material furnished and of work performed under the contract will be those methods generally 30 recognized as conforming to accepted engineering practice .
31 The terms “ gauge ” and “ thickness , ” when used in connection with the measurement of plates , 32 sheets and steel wire , shall be applied as follows : 33 Item Test Method Uncoated Steel Sheets and Light Plates United States Standard Gauge Galvanized Sheets AASHTO M 218 or M 167 Aluminum Sheets AASHTO M 196 or M 197 Steel Wire AASHTO M 32 The term “ ton ” will mean short ton ( mass ) consisting of 2,000 pounds .
34 Trucks used to haul material being paid by weight will be either weighed empty before each 35 loading or weighed empty daily .
When trucks are weighed empty daily , each truck shall be 36 weighed before hauling its first load of the day and shall bear a legible identification mark .
37 Where aggregates that are to be paid by weight have been stockpiled after being produced , 38 measurement for purposes of payment will be made after the aggregates have been loaded on 39 trucks for direct delivery to the project .
40 Section 109 1-80 When a complete structure or structural unit , as may be indicated by the unit , lump sum or 1 each , is specified as the unit of measurement , the unit will be construed to include all 2 necessary fittings and accessories .
3 When standard manufactured items are specified , and these items are identified by gauge , unit 4 weight , section dimensions or other dimensions , such identification will be considered to be 5 nominal weights or dimensions .
Unless more stringently controlled by tolerances in cited 6 specifications , manufacturing tolerances established by the industries involved will be 7 accepted .
8 109-2 SCOPE OF PAYMENT 9 The Contractor shall receive and accept payment provided for in the contract as full payment 10 for furnishing all materials and performing all work under the contract in a complete and 11 acceptable manner and for all risk , loss , damage , or expense of whatever character arising out 12 of the nature of the work or the prosecution thereof , subject to the requirements of 13 Article 107-20 .
Payment to the Contractor will be made only for the actual quantities of the 14 various items that are completed and accepted in accordance with the terms of the contract .
15 If the Measurement and Payment clause in the specifications relating to any unit price or lump 16 sum price in the bid schedule requires that the said unit price or lump sum price cover and be 17 considered compensation for certain work or material essential to the item , this same work or 18 material will not be measured or paid under any other pay item that may appear elsewhere in 19 the contract .
20 109-3 FORCE ACCOUNT WORK 21 All force account work shall be performed as directed by the Engineer including the numbers 22 and types of equipment , the numbers and classifications of labor and foremen and material 23 requirements .
24 All work to be paid on a force account basis shall be paid in the following manner : 25 ( A ) Labor 26 For all authorized labor and foremen in direct charge of the specific operations , the 27 Contractor will receive the rate of base ( actual ) wages ( or scale ) actually being paid by 28 the contractor for each hour that the labor and foremen are actually engaged in the 29 specific force account work .
30 In addition to reimbursement for each hour that the labor and foremen are actually 31 engaged in the specific force account work , the Contractor may receive compensation for 32 travel time to and from the project if and only if the labor and foremen needed are outside 33 a 75 mile radius as included in Subarticle 109-3 ( B ) .
The base location will be established 34 and approved by the Engineer before performing the specific force account work .
If the 35 approved labor and foremen travel to another project upon completion of the specific 36 force account work , payment for travel time may not exceed the travel time that would 37 have been required to return to the point of origin in accordance with 38 Subarticle 109-3 ( B ) .
When travel time is approved by the Engineer , it shall be included 39 in the total hours approved and worked for that specific week .
The Engineer will approve 40 the mode of travel .
41 Before beginning the specific force account work , the Contractor will submit in writing 42 for the Engineer ’ s approval a list of all wage rates applicable to the work .
Approval will 43 not be granted where these wage rates are not actually representative of wages being paid 44 elsewhere on the project for comparable classes of labor performing similar work .
45 Section 109 1-81 Payment for overtime will be allowed when approved by the Engineer before performing 1 the specific force account work .

Verification of such payment will be 3 tracked by submission of weekly payrolls as required on federal projects and as requested 4 on all other projects .
Failure to submit payrolls as required or requested shall act as a bar 5 to the Contractor for payment of overtime for labor and foremen .
If the labor or foremen 6 is employed partly on specific force account work and partly on other work , the amount 7 of overtime to be reimbursed will be prorated based upon the number of hours worked on 8 the specific force account work during the payroll period .
9 An additive amount equal to the Contractor ’ s actual labor burden rate , up to a maximum 10 of 60 % , will be paid to the Contractor for all base ( actual ) wages paid to labor and 11 foremen for the specific force account work .
No additive will be provided for overtime 12 payments .
The labor burden rates will include costs associated with the employee ’ s 13 actual base wages benefits , including Federal Insurance Contributions Act ( FICA ) , 14 unemployment contributions , Social Security and Medicare taxes and company fringe 15 benefits .
Company fringe benefits are the actual costs paid to , or on behalf of , workers 16 by reason of health and welfare benefits , pension fund benefits , or other benefits , when 17 such amounts are required by prevailing wage laws generally applicable to the classes of 18 labor employed on the work .
The Contractor ’ s actual labor burden rates will be 19 submitted to and approved by the Engineer before beginning the work .
When the 20 Contractor can not verify actual labor burden rates , an amount equal to 35 % of the total 21 base ( actual ) wage paid labor and foremen will be added to the total base wages paid to 22 the Contractor .
These percentage additives will be full compensation for overhead , 23 benefits , contingencies and all other costs associated with labor for the specific force 24 account work .
25 ( B ) Subsistence and Travel Allowances 26 The Contractor may receive payment for actual costs paid to , or on behalf of , labor and 27 foremen by reason of subsistence and travel allowances under certain circumstances .
28 When the Contractor is required to mobilize a crew for specific operations , the Engineer 29 may approve reimbursement of subsistence , including meals and overnight lodging , if the 30 specific force account work is determined to be outside of the scope of the original 31 contract and the distance from the Contractor ’ s base location to the project is more than 32 75 miles .
Should the Contractor use forces currently working at the location of the 33 specific force account work , the Engineer may approve the payment of subsistence , 34 including meals and overnight lodging , if the work is determined to be outside of the 35 scope of the original contract , the forces currently working at the location has routinely 36 stayed overnight during the life of the project , and the distance from the Contractor ’ s 37 base location to the project is more than 75 miles .
The Engineer will approve the mode 38 of travel .
39 Payment will be made to the Contractor for subsistence , including meals and overnight 40 lodging , paid in accordance with the Contractor ’ s usual policy for authorized labor and 41 foremen in direct charge of the specific operations .
Subsistence will be limited to the 42 lesser of actual amount paid or the current maximum in-state rate for State employees .
43 Verification of such costs paid to , or on behalf of , labor and foremen will be submitted to 44 the Engineer .
If the labor or foremen are partly employed on specific force account work 45 and partly on other work , the amount of subsistence to be reimbursed will be prorated 46 based upon the number of hours worked on the specific force account work during the 47 payroll period .
48 Section 109 1-82 ( C ) Materials 1 For materials authorized and accepted by the Engineer and used , the Contractor will 2 receive the actual cost of such materials , including sales tax and transportation charges 3 paid by him ( exclusive of equipment rentals as hereinafter set forth ) , to which costs 15 % 4 will be added .

12 ( D ) Equipment 13 For all equipment authorized by the Engineer to be used on the specific force account 14 work the Contractor will receive rental payment .
15 Hourly rental rates paid for equipment in use that is Contractor owned or rented from 16 another Contractor will not exceed 1/176 of the monthly rate listed in the 17 EquipmentWatch Cost Recovery that is current at the time the specific force account work 18 is performed .
19 In determining the hourly rate , the regional adjustment factor and the rate adjustment 20 factor for equipment age , as set forth in the EquipmentWatch Cost Recovery , will both be 21 applied to the basic rate .
An additive payment equal to 100 % of the EquipmentWatch 22 Cost Recovery estimated operating cost per hour will be paid for all hours that equipment 23 is in use .
This additive payment will be full compensation for fuel , lubricants , repairs , 24 servicing ( greasing , fueling and oiling ) , small tools and other incidentals .
25 If rental rates for the equipment actually being used in the work are not listed in the 26 EquipmentWatch Cost Recovery , the Contractor will receive the prevailing rental rates 27 being paid for such equipment in the area where the project is located .
An additive 28 payment equal to 15 % of the prevailing rental rate will be paid for all hours equipment is 29 in use .
This additive payment will be full compensation for fuel , lubricants , repairs , 30 servicing ( greasing , fueling and oiling ) , small tools and other incidentals .
31 Hourly rental rates for equipment held in ready as directed by the Engineer will be 50 % 32 of the rate paid for equipment in use .
An additive payment will not be made for 33 equipment held in ready .
When equipment is in use less than 40 hours for any given 34 week and is held in ready as directed by the Engineer , payment for held in ready time will 35 be allowed for up to 40 hours , less hours in use .
When payment is made for equipment 36 held in ready as directed by the Engineer , the payment for held in ready time will be 37 allowed for up to 8 hours in a day less hours in use .
38 Hourly rental rates for idle equipment that is held in ready in accordance with 39 Article 104-4 will be paid at 50 % of the rate paid for equipment in use .
Hourly rental 40 rates for idle equipment held in ready in accordance with Article 104-4 that is rented 41 from a commercial rental agency will be paid in accordance with the invoice rate for the 42 equipment .
An additive payment will not be made for idle equipment .
When equipment 43 is in use less than 40 hours for any given week and is held in ready as idle equipment in 44 accordance with Article 104-4 , payment for idle equipment time will be allowed for up to 45 40 hours , less hours in use .
When payment is made for idle equipment held in ready in 46 accordance with Article 104-4 , the payment for idle equipment time held in ready will be 47 allowed for up to 8 hours in a day less hours in use .

39 Section 109 1-85 109-4 PARTIAL PAYMENTS 1 ( A ) General 2 Partial payments will be based upon progress estimates prepared by the Engineer at least 3 once each month on the date established by the Engineer .
Partial payments may be made 4 twice each month if in the judgment of the Engineer the amount of work performed is 5 sufficient to warrant such payment .
No partial payment will be made when the total 6 value of work performed since the last partial payment , excluding mobilization , amounts 7 to less than $ 10,000 .
Partial payments will be approximate only and will be subject to 8 correction in the final estimate and payment .
9 Where lump sum items are included in the contract and the applicable section of the 10 Specifications require that fixed percentages of the total amount bid included in partial 11 pay estimates , the Engineer will determine amounts due on partial pay estimate in 12 accordance with the applicable sections of the Specifications .
13 ( B ) Prompt Payments 14 Contractors at all levels , prime , subcontractor , or lower tier subcontractor , shall within 15 seven calendar days of receipt of monies , resulting from the satisfactory completion of 16 work performed , pay subcontractors , all lower tier subcontractors , or material suppliers .
17 This seven-day period begins upon knowledgeable receipt by the contracting firm 18 obligated to make a subsequent periodic or final payment .
This prompt payment 19 requirement will be met if each firm mails the payment to the next level firm by evidence 20 of postmark within the seven-day period .
For the purposes of this section , the 21 satisfactory completion of work performed shall exist when a subcontractor , a lower tier 22 subcontractor or material supplier completes tasks called for in the subcontract and are in 23 conformance with the terms of the Contract as required by the Department .
This 24 specification for prompt payment shall be incorporated into each subcontract or lower tier 25 subcontract issued for work performed on the project or for services provided .
26 The Contractor shall not withhold any payments to a subcontractor , lower tier 27 subcontractor or material supplier for any claim or action arising outside the current 28 contract with the Department .
Notwithstanding the provisions of this section , the 29 Contractor may withhold up to 3 % retainage if any subcontractor does not obtain 30 a payment and performance bond for their portion of the work .
Additionally , this 31 retainage may be increased to a maximum of 10 % where the Contractor and any 32 subcontractor have supplied to the Engineer a satisfactorily executed mutual agreement 33 for an increased amount .
If any retainage is held on subcontractors , all retainage shall be 34 released within seven calendar days of satisfactory completion of all work .
For release of 35 retainage , satisfactory completion is defined as completion of all physical elements and 36 corresponding documentation as defined in the subcontract , as well as agreement between 37 the parties as to the final quantities for all work performed in the subcontract .
The 38 Department will provide internal controls to expedite the determination and processing of 39 the final quantities for the satisfactorily completed subcontract portions of the project .
40 Failure of any entity to make prompt payment as defined herein may result in the 41 Department : 42 ( 1 ) Withholding money from the Contractor due for work performed by that entity in the 43 next partial payment until the necessary assurances are made consistent with this 44 specification ; or 45 ( 2 ) Removing an approved Contractor from the prequalified bidders ’ and 46 subcontractors ’ list , or the removal of other entities from the prequalified 47 subcontractors ’ list .
48 Section 109 1-86 ( C ) Unbalanced Bids 1 Any excess monies included in an unbalanced bid price that the Department determines 2 to be in excess of a reasonable unit or lump sum bid price for the work , shall be retained 3 by the Department until the last partial payment estimate , at which time these funds will 4 be paid to the Contractor .
These retained funds will not be eligible for deposit in any 5 trust account established pursuant to this contract nor for interest for such delay in the 6 payment for the retained portion of the bid price .
Partial payment for work performed on 7 an unbalanced bid item shall be at the reasonable unit or lump sum price determined in 8 accordance with this subarticle .
9 For purposes of this subarticle , a reasonable unit or lump sum price will be deemed to be 10 the average of the Engineer 's Estimate and the individual balanced bid prices received 11 from the other bidders for the item in question .
12 109-5 PAYMENT FOR MATERIAL TO BE USED IN THE WORK 13 ( A ) Material Delivered on the Project 14 When so authorized by the Engineer , partial payments will be made up to 95 % of the 15 delivered cost of materials on hand that are to be incorporated in the work , provided that 16 such materials have been delivered on or in close proximity to the project and stored in 17 an acceptable manner .

The average terminal price is the average of the Freight on Board ( F.O.B . )
price for 32 diesel fuel at the terminals in Charlotte , Wilmington and Selma , North Carolina .
When the 33 average terminal price fluctuates upward or downward from the Base Index Price , an amount 34 will be added to or deducted from the monies due the Contractor as follows .
35 The current quantity for the specified contract items for which partial payment is made will be 36 multiplied by the respective Diesel Fuel Usage Factor contained in the contract to determine 37 the theoretical diesel fuel usage for each specified contract item .
The sum of the theoretical 38 diesel fuel usage for all specified contract items will be multiplied by the algebraic difference 39 between the average F.O.B .
price for diesel fuel at the above specified terminals and the Base 40 Index Price contained in the contract to determine the fuel price adjustment to be made on the 41 partial payment estimate .

5 The Engineer 's estimate of quantities for contract items measured by cross sections shall be 6 used on the various partial payment estimates to determine fuel price adjustments .

The Contractor shall conduct his work in a safe 25 manner that will create a minimum amount of inconvenience to traffic .

As an exception to the above , the Department will be responsible 30 for the removal of ice and snow from all portions of the project open to traffic .

35 Section 200 2-1 DIVISION 2 EARTHWORK SECTION 200 1 CLEARING AND GRUBBING 2 200-1 DESCRIPTION 3 Perform the work of clearing and grubbing in all wooded areas between the construction 4 limits .
Perform the work of clearing and grubbing in all non-wooded areas between the 5 construction limits and the limits of the project right of way or in easements shown on the 6 project plans where seeding and mulching , sprigging , sodding or other work as indicated .
7 “ Clearing ” is defined as the cutting , removal and satisfactory disposal of all wooded 8 vegetation and debris .
9 “ Grubbing ” is defined as the complete removal and satisfactory disposal of all grassy 10 vegetative matter , root mat , ball and root , topsoil material high in organic content and surface 11 debris .
12 200-2 MATERIALS 13 Refer to Division 10 .
14 200-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 15 Perform the following as part of the work of clearing and grubbing : 16 ( A ) Remove and dispose of crops , weeds and other annual growth ; 17 ( B ) Remove and dispose of surface debris such as fences , steps , walls , chimneys , column 18 footings , other footings , foundation slabs , basements , other foundation components , 19 signs , junked vehicles and other rubble and debris ; 20 ( C ) Fill holes and depressions that exist or are created ; 21 ( D ) Cut off and plug at the right-of-way or construction limits any private water or sewer line 22 intercepted during the construction of the project ; 23 ( E ) Cut off and remove from the right-of-way or construction area any septic tank or portion 24 thereof encountered within the right-of-way or construction area during the construction 25 of the project ; and 26 ( F ) Remove materials in wetland areas to a depth of one foot below existing ground to be 27 measured in accordance with Section 225 .
28 Perform clearing and grubbing operations sufficiently before grading operations to prevent 29 any debris from interfering with the excavation or embankment operations .
30 In environmentally sensitive areas shown on the original plans or permit drawings , perform 31 grubbing operations no more than 7 calendar days before beginning continuous grading 32 operations .
33 Perform all work under this section to minimize soil erosion and in accordance with 34 Article 107-12 .
Coordinate the work with other operations such that no more than 17 acres of 35 exposed , erodible surface area will be accumulated at any one time by the clearing and 36 grubbing operation until erosion control measures are provided .
Install temporary or 37 permanent erosion control measures as soon as clearing and grubbing or land disturbing 38 activities begin .
Perform such erosion control work , temporary or permanent , as needed to 39 minimize erosion resulting from clearing and grubbing operations .
40 Section 200 2-2 The Contractor may request an increase in the accumulated acres exposed by clearing and 1 grubbing .
If approved , establish and maintain such erosion control measures as needed .
2 Failure on the part of the Contractor to perform the required erosion control measures will be 3 just cause for the Engineer to direct the suspension of clearing and grubbing operations in 4 accordance with Article 108-7 .
The suspension will be in effect until such time as the 5 Contractor has satisfactorily performed the required erosion control work .
If the Contractor 6 fails to perform the directed work within a reasonable length of time , the Engineer may have 7 the work performed in accordance with Article 105-16 .
8 200-4 CLEARING 9 Perform clearing within the limits established by the clearing method required by the plans 10 and as directed .
11 The Engineer will designate all areas of growth or individual trees that shall be preserved due 12 to their desirability for landscape or erosion control purposes .
When the trees to be preserved 13 are located within the construction limits , they will be shown in the plans or designated by the 14 Engineer .
15 Trim or cut branches of trees that overhang the roadbed , utility easements or obstruct sight 16 distances and that are less than 16 feet above the elevation of the finished grade so as to not 17 endanger the health of the tree .
18 In embankment areas where the depth of the embankment measured under the roadbed 19 exceeds 6 feet in height , cut sound trees at a height of not more than 6 inches above natural 20 ground .
When trees are to be cut outside the construction limits and the Engineer has 21 designated that the area is not to be grubbed , cut the trees reasonably close to the natural 22 ground surface .
Cut trees to approximately 6 inches above low water level in swamp areas .
23 At a bridge site , clear the entire width of the right of way beginning at a station 3 feet back of 24 the beginning extremity of the structure and ending at a station 3 feet beyond the ending 25 extremity of the structure .
26 Prevent limb , bark or root injuries to trees , shrubs or other types of vegetation that are to 27 remain growing and prevent damage to adjacent property .
Repair scarred areas in accordance 28 with generally accepted horticultural practice .
Where plants are damaged by any construction 29 operations to such an extent as to destroy their value for shade or other landscape purposes , 30 cut and dispose of them .
31 200-5 GRUBBING 32 Perform grubbing on all areas cleared , with the following exceptions : 33 ( A ) In embankment areas , when the depth of embankment measured under the roadbed 34 exceeds 6 feet in height , cut off sound stumps not more than 6 inches above the existing 35 ground level and do not grub .
Remove unsound or decayed stumps to a depth of 36 approximately 2 feet below the natural ground surface .
37 ( B ) When authorized , leave stumps outside of construction limits in place .
Cut such stumps 38 off reasonably close to the natural ground surface .
39 ( C ) Cut off stumps in swamp areas to approximately 6 inches above low water level and do 40 not grub .
41 ( D ) Do not grub in areas where waste or unsuitable material is to be deposited unless such 42 areas are to become a part of a future roadway .
43 ( E ) Grub all areas where piles are to be driven regardless of fill height .
44 ( F ) Fill all holes and other depressions within the areas between the construction limits and 45 the limits of clearing and grubbing .
Bring all areas to a uniform contour where later 46 mowing operations will take place .
47 Section 200 2-3 200-6 DISPOSITION OF TIMBER , STUMPS AND DEBRIS 1 The property owner will have no right to use or reserve for their use any timber on the project .
2 All timber cut during the clearing operations shall become the property of the Contractor and 3 shall be removed from the project or shall be satisfactorily disposed of as provided 4 hereinafter .
5 Do not cut any trees and vegetation beyond the clearing limits established .
Do not cut any 6 trees and vegetation that is to be preserved for landscape or erosion control purposes as shown 7 in the plans and permit drawings .
8 Remove from the project and properly dispose of all vegetation , roots , stumps , tree laps , limbs 9 and timber remaining on the project by a satisfactory method .
10 When vegetation is disposed of by burning , burn so as to prevent injury to property within or 11 outside of the right of way .

15 205-2 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 16 Use a Well Contractor certified by the State of North Carolina to perform abandonment .
17 Environmental Ground Water Monitoring Well abandonment should be coordinated with the 18 GeoEnvironmental Section of NCDOT .
19 Seal each well before clearing and grubbing the well site .
Check the well from land surface to 20 the entire depth of the well before it is sealed to ensure freedom from obstructions that may 21 interfere with sealing operations .
Before sealing , place chlorine in the well in sufficient 22 quantities to produce a chlorine residual of at least 100 milligrams per liter in the well .
23 All casing and screen materials may be salvaged except casing that is cemented in place .
In 24 the case of gravel-packed wells in which the casing and screens have not been removed , 25 perforate the casing opposite the gravel pack at intervals not exceeding 10 feet .
26 Completely fill bored wells with cement grout or dry clay compacted in place .
Completely 27 fill wells constructed in unconsolidated formations with cement grout by introducing it 28 through a pipe extending to the bottom and raising it as the well is filled .
Fill wells 29 constructed in consolidated rock formations or that penetrate zones of consolidated rock to at 30 least 5 feet below the top of the consolidated rock with sand , gravel or grout opposite the 31 zones of consolidated rock .
Fill the remainder of the well with cement grout .
32 Complete a certified well abandonment record ( Form GW-30 ) and submit to the Engineer .
33 205-3 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 34 Sealing Abandoned Wells will be measured and paid in units of each for the actual number of 35 wells acceptably sealed .
Work includes , but is not limited to , chlorinating the well before 36 sealing ; perforating the well casing ; filling the well with cement grout , dry clay , sand or 37 gravel ; and furnishing all necessary records .

31 220-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 32 Notify the Engineer and all occupants and owners of residences , businesses and utilities near 33 where blasting will occur of the intention to use explosives .
Inform the Engineer , occupants 34 and owners of blasting at least 48 hours before each blast .
When blasting in the vicinity of 35 an open travel way , provide traffic control in accordance with the contract and Section 1101 .
36 Control blasting to avoid endangering lives or damaging property .
The Contractor is 37 responsible for any injuries and damages due to blasting in accordance with Article 107-11 38 except for damage to wells and springs , unless the Contractor did not use reasonable care to 39 prevent such damage .
Exercise the utmost care when blasting near sensitive environmental or 40 populated areas , urban or sensitive communities or historical structures .
Comply with all the 41 latest applicable Federal , State and local codes , laws and regulations , as well as professional 42 society standards for the storage , transportation and use of explosives .
Keep a copy of all 43 regulations on site and in case of conflict , the more stringent applies .
44 Section 220 2-9 The Blaster-in-Charge has authority over the handling , use and security of explosives and is 1 responsible for designing , planning , coordinating , supervising and monitoring blasting .
2 Assign a Blaster-in-Charge to the project that has at least 5 years of experience with blasting 3 similar to that anticipated for the project .
Use a Blaster-in-Charge approved as a Blaster-in- 4 Charge ( key person ) for the Blasting Contractor .
The Blaster-in-Charge or designated 5 Assistant Blaster-in-Charge shall be on site during blasting .
6 When blasts will be within 1,000 feet of a utility , house , residence , building , business or any 7 other structure , a blasting plan and blast monitoring that meet Subarticles 220-3 ( B ) 8 and 220-3 ( C ) are required .
Otherwise , provide a blasting plan and monitor blasts as needed .
9 ( A ) Vibration and Air Overpressure Limits 10 Define “ peak particle velocity ” ( PPV ) as the maximum ground vibration velocity 11 measured in any direction .
Design blasts so the PPV at any utility or structure does not 12 exceed the “ Alternative Blasting Level Criteria ” from Appendix B of the U.S. Bureau of 13 Mines Report of Investigations 8507 .
Design blasts so the maximum air overpressure at 14 any structure does not exceed 133 dB ( linear ) .
15 If the PPV or air overpressure limits are exceeded at any utility or structure in any 16 direction from blasts , the Engineer may suspend blasting until the post-blast report is 17 reviewed and a new or revised blasting plan is accepted .
Unless required otherwise in the 18 contract or directed , design production , pre-split and trench blasts in accordance with the 19 following : 20 ( 1 ) Production Blasting 21 ( a ) For 1.5:1 ( H : V ) rock cut slopes without pre-splitting , do not use production blast 22 holes more than 4 inches in diameter within 10 feet of finished slope faces or 23 neat lines .
24 ( b ) Do not drill production holes below bottom of adjacent pre-split blast holes 25 ( c ) Use delay blasting to detonate production blast holes towards a free face 26 ( 2 ) Pre-splitting 27 ( a ) Do not use pre-split blast holes more than 3 inches in diameter 28 ( b ) Space pre-split holes no more than 10 hole diameters apart ( wider pre-split blast 29 hole spacing may be approved by the Engineer if test blast results are 30 satisfactory ) 31 ( c ) Limit subdrilling to the offset width between lifts 32 ( d ) Do not subdrill more than 2 feet below finished grade 33 ( e ) Pre-split rock at least 30 feet beyond production blasting lifts or to the end of 34 rock cuts 35 ( f ) Provide benches or lifts with a maximum height of 25 feet .
36 ( g ) Do not use ammonium nitrate fuel oil ( ANFO ) or other bulk loaded products 37 ( h ) Use cartridge explosives or other explosive types design for pre-splitting 38 ( i ) Use charges with a maximum diameter of half the pre-split blast hole diameter 39 except for charges in bottom 2 feet holes 40 ( j ) If pre-split and production blast holes are fired in the same blast , fire pre-split 41 holes at least 25 milliseconds before production holes 42 Section 220 2-10 ( B ) Blasting Plan 1 When required , submit the proposed blasting plan signed by the Blaster-in-Charge for all 2 blasting for acceptance .
Acceptance of this plan does not relieve the Contractor of 3 responsibility and liability for blasting in accordance with the contract .
4 Submit the blasting plan to the Resident Engineer and the appropriate Geotechnical 5 Engineering Unit regional office at least 30 days before starting blasting .
Do not deliver 6 explosives to the project site or begin blasting until a blasting plan is accepted .
Provide 7 detailed project specific information in the blasting plan that includes the following : 8 ( 1 ) Work procedures and safety precautions for storage , transportation , handling and 9 detonation of explosives ; 10 ( 2 ) Explosive products and devices for dry and wet blast holes including explosives , 11 primers and detonators with MSDS ; 12 ( 3 ) Drilling equipment including methods for maintaining blast hole alignment ; 13 ( 4 ) Typical plan , profile and sectional views for blasting showing blasting limits , blast 14 hole diameters , depths , inclinations and spacing , burden , subdrill depths and 15 minimum and maximum charge per delay ; 16 ( 5 ) Initiation and delay methods and delay times ; 17 ( 6 ) Equipment and procedures for blast monitoring with calibration certificates dated 18 within one year of submittal date ; and 19 ( 7 ) Post-blast report format .
20 If alternate blasting procedures are proposed or necessary , a revised blasting plan 21 submittal may be required .
If blasting deviates from the accepted submittal without prior 22 approval , the Engineer may suspend blasting until a revised plan is accepted .
23 ( C ) Blast Monitoring 24 If necessary or required , monitor blasts using seismographs capable of measuring air 25 overpressure and vibration in the vertical , longitudinal and transverse directions .
At 26 a minimum , monitor vibration and air overpressure at the closest utility or structure to 27 each blast and the closest utility or structure in the direction of each blast in accordance 28 with the accepted blasting plan .
Include the following in post-blast reports for each blast 29 monitoring location : 30 ( 1 ) Type , identification and specific location of seismograph , 31 ( 2 ) Distance and direction from blast , 32 ( 3 ) PPV in each direction and peak vector sum , and 33 ( 4 ) Maximum air overpressure level .
34 ( D ) Blasting Requirements 35 Before beginning drilling , a pre-blast meeting may be required to discuss the blasting and 36 if applicable , blast monitoring .
Schedule this meeting after any blast plans have been 37 accepted .
The Resident or District Engineer , Roadway Construction Engineer , 38 Geotechnical Operations Engineer , Contractor and Blaster-in-Charge will attend this pre- 39 blast meeting .
40 Drill and blast in accordance with the contract and if applicable , the accepted blast plan .
41 Use explosives in accordance with all applicable government regulations , professional 42 society standards and manufacturer guidelines and recommendations .
Do not allow 43 ANFO to leach into bodies of water .
44 Section 220 2-11 Before blasting for excavations , remove all overburden material along top of excavations 1 for at least 30 feet beyond blasting or rock limits , whichever is less .
Inspect any free 2 faces to ensure adequate burden .
Drill blast holes within 3 inches of plan location and 3 maintain hole alignment when drilling .
4 Pre-split rock cuts as required so irregularities between pre-split blast holes are less than 5 1 foot from finished slope faces .
Alignment is crucial for pre-split holes .
Maintain pre- 6 split hole alignment within 6 inches of rock cut slopes and parallel to adjacent pre-split 7 blast holes .
Monitor and accurately measure pre-split hole alignment during drilling with 8 a method acceptable to the Engineer .
When rock cut heights require multiple benches or 9 lifts , offset pre-split blast holes horizontally for each lift no more than the clearance 10 necessary for drilling equipment .
11 Cover blast holes after drilling to prevent unwanted backfill and identify and mark each 12 blast hole with hole number and depth .
Blast holes shall be free of obstructions the entire 13 depth .
Load blast holes without dislodging material or caving in hole walls .
Stem blast 14 holes 5 inches or larger in diameter with No .
67 stone and blast holes smaller than 15 5 inches in diameter with No .
78M stone .
Do not stem blast holes with drill cuttings .
16 Contain flyrock within construction limits .
Use matting when blast monitoring or traffic 17 control is required .
Soil cover may be used instead of matting , if approved .
If flyrock 18 occurs outside the construction limits , the Engineer may suspend blasting until the post- 19 blast report is reviewed and a new or revised blasting plan is accepted .
When traffic 20 control is required for blasting , have equipment standing by to remove material that 21 interferes with traffic flow .
Check for misfires immediately after each blast before 22 signaling all clear .
23 Remove all loose , hanging and potentially dangerous material from rock cut slopes by 24 scaling .
The Contractor is responsible for the stability of rock cuts .
If rock cuts are 25 damaged during blasting , stabilize cuts to the satisfaction of the Engineer .
Resume 26 drilling only after scaling is complete .
Adjust blast hole alignments to account for any 27 drift occurring in preceding drilling or lifts .
28 Define “ secondary blasting ” as blasting to reduce the size of naturally occurring boulders 29 or those resulting from initial blasting .
Use an approved method for secondary blasting 30 consisting of small explosive charges in small diameter blast holes .
Define 31 “ mudcapping ” as placing unconfined explosive charges in contact with rock without blast 32 holes and covering charges with mud .
Do not use mudcapping for blasting .

30 225-4 UNDERCUT EXCAVATION 31 When the Engineer determines that the natural soil materials in areas where fills are to be 32 placed are undesirable in their location or condition , the Engineer may require the Contractor 33 to remove the undesirable material and backfill with approved , properly compacted material .

41 Use equipment in undercutting and backfilling operations of such weight , size and capability 42 to efficiently remove and replace the material within the limits established .
Use equipment of 43 a size and weight that will not displace the underlying or adjacent material .
44 All material removed in the work of undercut excavation will be classified by the Engineer as 45 either suitable for other use without excessive manipulation and used elsewhere in the work , 46 or unsuitable for further use and disposed of by the Contractor .

38 The approval of borrow sources furnished by the Contractor is subject to the following 39 conditions : 40 ( 1 ) Proof of Rights 41 Provide written proof of the right to take the material and any rights of access that 42 may be necessary , for locating and developing the source and any clearing and 43 grubbing and drainage ditches necessary .

46 Section 230 2-20 ( 2 ) Sampling and Testing 1 Sampling and testing of contractor furnished borrow material will be in accordance 2 with procedures set forth in the Borrow Pit Sampling Manual in effect on the date of 3 advertisement for the project .
Copies of this document are available from the 4 Materials and Tests Unit .
