6 ( 3 ) Reclamation Plan 7 Except where borrow is to be obtained from a commercial source , jointly submit 8 with the property owner a borrow source development , use and reclamation plan to 9 the Engineer for his approval before engaging in any land disturbing activity on the 10 proposed source other than material sampling that may be necessary .
The 11 Department ’ s borrow and waste site reclamation procedures for contracted projects 12 is available on the website and shall be used for all borrow and waste sites on this 13 project .
Address the following in the plan : 14 ( a ) Topography 15 Detail the existing topography and locations of the proposed access and egress 16 haul roads .
Detail the proposed final topography of the waste or disposal area 17 showing any proposed drainage systems .
Excavate the source according to the 18 plan and dress and shape it in a continuous manner to contours that are 19 comparable to and blend in with the adjacent topography .
Grade the source to 20 drain such that no water will collect or stand .
Provide a functioning drainage 21 system for the source .
If drainage is not practical and the source is to serve as 22 a pond , the minimum depth shall be a least 4 feet as determined from the water 23 table at the time the reclamation plan is executed .
The slope of the soil below 24 the water shall be between 5:1 and 2:1 .
The slope of the sides above the water 25 line shall be 2:1 or flatter .
26 ( b ) Erosion Control 27 Detail the temporary and permanent erosion control measures , along with design 28 calculations , that are intended during use of the site and as part of the 29 reclamation .
Unless considered impractical due to special circumstances , 30 provide in the plan for the use of staged permanent seeding and mulching and 31 appropriate fertilizer topdressing continually during site use and the immediate 32 total reclamation of the site when the site is no longer needed .
Define the seed 33 mixture proposed for establishing temporary and permanent vegetation .
34 Establish permanent stand of vegetation before acceptance of the project .
35 ( c ) Buffer Zones 36 Allocate sufficient area between the nearest property line and the tie-in of the 37 slope to natural ground to allow for the operation of excavation , hauling and 38 seeding equipment and for the installation of any and all erosion control devices 39 required .
Leave additional undisturbed area between the source and any water 40 course or body to prevent siltation of the water course or body and the 41 movement of the shore line either into the water course or body or into the waste 42 areas .
Determine if the adjoining property owners or other government agencies 43 require any additional buffer zones and comply with those requirements .
44 Suggested minimum distances are 10 feet from property lines and 50 feet from 45 water bodies or water courses .
Where it is necessary to drain the borrow source , 46 perform work in accordance with Section 240 .
47 Section 230 2-21 ( d ) Evaluation for Potential Wetlands and Endangered Species 1 Hire an experienced environmental consultant from the approved list to perform 2 an assessment of the borrow site for potential conflicts with wetlands , Areas of 3 Environmental Concern designated by the Coastal Area Management Act and 4 federally protected species .
This evaluation will not be required for permitted 5 commercial sites .
6 Delineate the boundaries of any wetlands , jurisdictional surface waters and 7 streams encountered .
Follow the standard practice for documenting the wetland 8 delineation including completion of the Army Corps of Engineers ’ Approved 9 Jurisdictional Determination Form .
Document information including data 10 regarding soil , vegetation and hydrology .
Maintain a minimum 25 foot buffer 11 adjacent to all sides of the wetland boundary and a minimum 50 foot buffer 12 adjacent to any stream .
Depict the limits of the delineated wetland and 13 surrounding buffer on the Reclamation Plan .
Do not remove borrow material in 14 any area under the Corps of Engineers ’ or any other environmental agencies ’ 15 regulatory jurisdiction unless and until the Department permit has been modified 16 to allow such disposal activity in the jurisdictional area .
17 Perform a site assessment for federally listed threatened or endangered species 18 to include habitats that may support these species .
Provide a detailed technical 19 report on the assessment findings .
If federally listed threatened or endangered 20 species or habitat that may support such species exist on the proposed borrow 21 site , notify the Engineer before continued pursuit of such site .

25 Submit a revised or additional reclamation plan if the non-permitted waste or 26 disposal area is expanded by more than one acre or is significantly changed from the 27 previously approved submittal .
28 If the Contractor proposes a borrow source , the environmental assessment shall 29 include wetland and stream delineation extending 400 feet beyond the proposed 30 borrow source limits .
31 ( a ) If wetlands or streams are present within 400 feet of the borrow source , submit 32 a hydrologic analysis ( Skaggs Method ) or equivalent to determine if lateral 33 effects will permanently impact or cause degradation to wetlands or streams .
34 Perform analysis with an environmental or hydraulics engineer with expertise in 35 this discipline and include : 36 ( i ) Hydric soil type , 37 ( ii ) Average profile depth to restrictive soil layer , 38 ( iii ) Effective hydraulic conductivity or permeability , 39 ( iv ) Average drainable porosity or available water capacity and 40 ( v ) Required buffer width , including safety factor .
41 ( b ) If wetlands or streams are present within 400 feet and the Contractor does not 42 propose to excavate below the seasonal high water table or the water level in the 43 adjacent stream , no documentation will be required .
44 ( c ) If wetlands or streams are not present within 400 feet , no additional 45 documentation will be required .
46 During Department review of the proposed borrow area , the hydrologic analysis will 47 be submitted to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for evaluation .
Obtain copy of 48 Skaggs Method for Determining Lateral Effects of a Borrow Pit on Adjacent 49 Wetlands from the Department ’ s website .

4 230-5 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 5 Borrow Excavation will be measured and paid in cubic yards .

11 ( A ) In-Place Measurement 12 Borrow Excavation to be paid will be the actual number of cubic yards of approved 13 material , measured in its original position by cross sectioning and computed by the 14 average end area method , that has been excavated from the borrow source and 15 incorporated into the completed and accepted work .
No measurement will be made of 16 any overburden , unsuitable material removed from the source or any material excavated 17 before cross sections are taken .
18 ( B ) Truck Measurement 19 Borrow Excavation to be paid will be the actual number of cubic yards of approved 20 material , measured in trucks excavated from the borrow source and incorporated into the 21 completed and accepted work .
Each truck will be measured and shall have a legible 22 identification mark indicating its capacity .
Load each truck to at least its measured 23 capacity at the time it arrives at the point of delivery .
The recorded capacity will be 24 adjusted by making a 25 % deduction to allow for shrinkage and the adjusted capacity will 25 be the quantity to be paid .
26 Topsoil that is stockpiled and placed back on the source as part of the reclamation effort will 27 be measured in the stockpile by cross sectioning and computed by the average end area 28 method and paid per cubic yard for Borrow Excavation .
No in-place measurement will be 29 made of the topsoil .

28 ( A ) Preparation for Embankment 29 Finish clearing and grubbing within an area before starting embankment in accordance 30 with Section 200 .
Remove and waste organic or other unsuitable material unless 31 otherwise directed .
32 Plow mowed sod and leave in place where the height of embankment to be constructed is 33 greater than 6 feet measured under the roadbed .
Plow or scarify and break up cleavage 34 planes of all underlying road surfaces .
Remove or break up existing pavement in 35 accordance with Section 250 .
36 Bench existing slopes steeper than 4:1 measured at right angles to the roadway .
Provide 37 rises of at least 12 inches and no more than 60 inches as embankment is brought up in 38 layers .
Provide sufficient width for the operation of placing and compaction equipment .
39 Begin bench cut at the intersection of the original ground and the vertical side of the 40 previous cut .
Construct benches greater than 60 inches in height only when shown in the 41 plans .
Such benches will be paid in accordance with the contract .
42 Section 235 2-24 ( B ) Embankment Formation 1 Uniformly spread material in successive , approximately horizontal layers of not more 2 than 10 inches depth , loose measurement , for the full width of the cross section .
3 Compact each layer in accordance with Subarticle 235-3 ( C ) .
4 Shape embankment surface to properly drain at all times .
5 Route construction equipment uniformly over the full width of the embankment and 6 prevent deep rutting .
7 May construct the first layer of embankments across saturated or unstable material that 8 does not support the weight of hauling equipment , by successively dumping a uniformly 9 distributed layer of a thickness not greater than necessary to support hauling equipment 10 while placing subsequent layers .
11 When placing material in swamp or in water , keep unsuitable surge material in a fluid 12 state or remove to prevent trapping in or under embankment .
13 When shown in the plans or allowed by the contract , form a satisfactory base by end or 14 side dumping in valleys , ravines and at the foot of slopes on side hills .
15 Where embankments are being constructed principally of rock or broken pavement , place 16 in uniform layers with a maximum depth of 36 inches .
Place rock or broken pavement so 17 larger pieces are evenly distributed and are no larger than 36 inches in any dimension .
18 Fill all voids .
Place rock or broken pavement lifts at least 2 feet below finished subgrade 19 or finished grade whichever is lower .
20 Place select material where indicated in the contract .
Construct the top 6 inches of 21 shoulder and fill slopes with material that meets Article 1019-2 .
Construct stabilized 22 embankment when required by the contract .
23 Install pipe culverts as specified in Section 300 .
Construct subsurface drains adjacent to 24 structures as required by Article 414-8 for box culverts , except for that portion of the 25 drain located below the elevation of the original ground .
Do not disturb existing utilities 26 within the project construction limits until released by the Engineer .
27 Do not place rock or broken pavement in embankment areas where piles or drilled shaft 28 foundations are to be constructed or where underground utilities exist .
This requirement 29 shall include , but not be limited to , piles and foundations for structures , metal signal 30 poles , overhead sign structures and high mount lighting .
31 ( C ) Embankment Compaction 32 Compact each layer for its full width to a density equal to at least 95 % of that obtained by 33 compacting a sample of the material in accordance AASHTO T 99 as modified by the 34 Department .
Copies of these modified procedures are available upon request from the 35 Department ’ s Materials and Tests Unit .
36 Uniformly bond all layers to preceding layers .
Compact all surfaces on embankment 37 slopes , principally constructed of soil , that are flatter than 1.5:1 using tracked equipment 38 or other approved methods .
39 Increase or decrease moisture content of the material before compacting to produce the 40 maximum density that will provide a stable grade .
Exempt portions of rock 41 embankments that can not be tested by approved methods , from density requirements .
42 Section 235 2-25 ( D ) Maintenance 1 Maintain all embankments made under the contract until final acceptance .
Construct and 2 maintain adequate drainage of surface runoff to prevent soil erosion .
Replace damaged 3 or displaced embankment .

6 260-2 EQUIPMENT 7 Provide equipment with the following features : 8 ( A ) Four rubber tired wheels mounted on a rigid steel frame , 9 ( B ) Wheels evenly spaced in one line across the width of the roller and arranged so that all 10 wheels will carry approximately equal loads when operated over an uneven surface , 11 ( C ) Maximum center to center spacing between adjacent wheels is 32 inches , 12 ( D ) Load capacity from 48 to 50 tons unless otherwise permitted in writing , 13 ( E ) Cover or construct the loaded roller to not trap water that will add weight to the ballast , 14 ( F ) Other equipment of equal or better effectiveness may be substituted with written 15 permission , and 16 ( G ) Tire pressures shall be between 68 and 72 lb/sq.in .
unless otherwise permitted in writing .
17 Inflate tires with air only ; use no liquid .
18 Provide ballasts consisting of bulk sand , bulk stone , bags of sand , stone or other materials of 19 known unit weight such that the total weight of the ballast used can be readily determined at 20 all times .
Provide a sufficient amount of ballast to load the equipment to a maximum gross 21 weight of 50 tons .
22 Use rubber tired or other types of tractive equipment for operation of this equipment on the 23 roadbed .
The entire assembly including motivating equipment shall be capable of executing 24 a 180° turn on a 27 feet wide area .
25 260-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 26 After the roadbed has been completed within 0.5 feet of final grade , compact and test the 27 roadbed with one coverage , unless otherwise directed , with a heavy pneumatic tired roller in 28 accordance with Article 260-2 .
Coverage is considered that stage in the rolling procedure 29 when the entire width of the area being proof rolled has been in contact with the pneumatic 30 tires of the roller .
Operate the roller systematically so the number of coverages over all areas 31 to be proof rolled can be readily determined and recorded .
32 Operate the equipment at a speed between 225 feet per minute and 300 feet per minute .
33 Perform proof rolling only in the presence of the Engineer .
Proof roll areas again following 34 the completion of the necessary corrections .
35 Protect all structural facilities on the project , such as , but not limited to , bridges , box culverts , 36 pipe culverts and utilities , from damage by the proof rolling equipment .
Protection may 37 include unloading and reloading of the roller , detouring , protective earth pads or other suitable 38 measure to avoid damage .

3 For all pipes 42 inches in diameter and larger , wrap geotextile around all pipe joints .

6 ( B ) Flexible Pipe 7 Corrugated steel , corrugated aluminum , corrugated HDPE and PVC pipe will be 8 considered flexible pipe .
Place flexible pipe carefully on the prepared foundation starting 9 at the downstream end with the inside circumferential laps pointing downstream and with 10 the longitudinal laps at the side or quarter points .
11 Handle coated corrugated steel pipe with special care to avoid damage to coatings .
12 Join pipe sections with coupling band , fully bolted and properly sealed .
Provide coupling 13 bands for annular and helical corrugated metal pipe with circumferential and longitudinal 14 strength sufficient to preserve the alignment , prevent separation of the sections and 15 prevent backfill infiltration .
Match-mark all pipe 60 inches or larger in diameter at the 16 plant for proper installation on the project .
17 At locations indicated in the plans , join corrugated steel pipe sections together with rod 18 and lug coupling bands , fully bolted .
Use sleeve gaskets in conjunction with rod and lug 19 couplings and seal the joints properly .
Provide coupling bands with circumferential and 20 longitudinal strength sufficient to preserve the alignment , prevent separation of the 21 sections and prevent infiltration of backfill material .
22 300-7 BACKFILLING 23 Loosely place bedding material , in a uniform layer , a depth equal to the inside diameter of the 24 pipe divided by 6 or 6 inches , whichever is greater .
Leave bedding material directly beneath 25 the pipe uncompacted and allow pipe seating and backfill to accomplish compaction .
26 Excavate recesses to receive the bells where bells and spigot type pipe is used .
27 Place fill around the pipe in accordance with the applicable method shown in the plans in 28 layers not to exceed 6 inches loose unless otherwise permitted .
Compact to the density 29 required by Subarticle 235-3 ( C ) .
Approval of the backfill material is required before its use .
30 Use select material as shown in the contract documents .
31 Take care during backfill and compaction operations to maintain alignment and prevent 32 damage to the joints .
Keep backfill free from stones , frozen lumps , chunks of highly plastic 33 clay or other objectionable material .
34 Grade and maintain all pipe backfill areas in such a condition that erosion or saturation will 35 not damage the pipe foundation or backfill .
36 Flowable fill may be used for backfill when approved by the Engineer .
When using flowable 37 fill , ensure that the pipe is not displaced and does not float during backfill .
Submit methods 38 for supporting the pipe and material placement to the Engineer for review and approval .
39 Do not operate heavy equipment over any pipe until it has been properly backfilled with at 40 least 3 feet of cover .
Place , maintain and finally remove the required cover that is above the 41 proposed finished grade .
Remove and replace pipe that becomes misaligned , shows excessive 42 settlement or has been otherwise damaged by the Contractor 's operations .

Such work will be 24 paid as extra work in accordance with Article 104-7 .
25 410-4 COFFERDAMS 26 ( A ) General 27 The term cofferdam designates any temporary or removable structure constructed to hold 28 the surrounding earth , water or both , out of the excavation .
It includes timber cribs , any 29 type of sheet piling , removable steel shells or similar structures , all necessary bracing and 30 the use of pumping wells or well points for the same purpose .
Ensure cofferdams located 31 in bodies of water are designed , detailed and sealed by an engineer licensed by the State of 32 North Carolina when the distance from the water surface to the bottom of the excavation 33 is 5 feet or greater .
34 ( B ) Construction 35 Design and construct cofferdams to adequate depths and heights , safely and as watertight 36 as is necessary for the proper performance of the work .
Provide interior dimensions of 37 cofferdams as to give sufficient clearance for the construction and inspection of forms and 38 to permit pumping outside the forms .
Provide at least 5 feet of clearance between the 39 proposed edge of footing and inside face of cofferdam when a keyed footing is required 40 and at least 3 feet when a keyed footing is not required .
Right , rest or enlarge cofferdams 41 that are tilted or moved laterally during the process of sinking to provide the necessary 42 clearance .
43 Construct cofferdams to protect plastic concrete against damage from a sudden rising of 44 the stream and to prevent damage to the foundation by erosion .
Do not leave timber or 45 bracing in cofferdams that could extend into the substructure concrete without permission .
46 Section 410 4-5 ( C ) Removal 1 After the completion of the substructure , unless otherwise provided in the contract , remove 2 cofferdams with all sheeting and bracing to the stream bed or one foot below existing 3 ground .
Take care not to disturb or damage the finished concrete .
4 410-5 PUMPING 5 Perform pumping operations in accordance with Article 414-5 .
6 410-6 PRESERVATION OF CHANNEL 7 Unless otherwise required by the contract or permitted by the Engineer , do not excavate in 8 stream channels outside of cofferdams .
Do not disturb the natural stream bed adjacent to the 9 structure without permission .
Backfill any excavation or dredging made at the site of the 10 structure outside of the cofferdam limits to the original ground surface or river bed with 11 approved material .
12 Remove materials placed within the stream area and leave the stream in its original condition , 13 unless otherwise permitted .

22 410-8 BACKFILLING AND FILLING 23 Use approved material for backfill that is free from large or frozen lumps , wood or other 24 undesirable material .
Where there is not an adequate quantity of suitable backfill material 25 available from the excavation , provide suitable backfill material compensated in accordance 26 with Article 410-10 .
27 Refill all excavated spaces , not filled with permanent work , with earth up to the ground surface 28 existing before the excavation .
Place backfill to provide adequate drainage as soon as concrete 29 surfaces are finished in accordance with Subarticle 420-17 ( B ) and the concrete has been 30 inspected and approved .
The Engineer has the authority to suspend all operations until such 31 backfilling is acceptably completed .
32 Eliminate any slope adjacent to the excavation for abutments , wingwalls and retaining walls by 33 stepping or serrating to prevent wedge action .
34 Place and compact all portions of the backfill that become a part of roadway typical sections or 35 their foundations in accordance with Subarticles 235-3 ( B ) and 235-3 ( C ) .
Place all other 36 portions of the backfill in layers not more than 10 inches in depth of loose measure and compact 37 to a density comparable to the adjacent undisturbed material .
38 Place backfill or embankment material simultaneously to approximately the same elevation on 39 both sides of an abutment , pier or wall .
If conditions require placing backfill or embankment 40 higher on one side , do not place the additional material on the higher side until the concrete 41 develops the minimum specified strength for the class of concrete required for the structure as 42 specified in Table 1000-1 .
43 Do not place backfill or embankment behind abutments of rigid frame structures such as arch 44 culverts and box culverts without floor slabs , until the top slab is placed and has developed the 45 minimum compressive strength of the class of concrete required for the structure .
Place backfill 46 and embankment simultaneously behind opposite abutments of rigid frames .
47 Section 410 4-6 Place backfill to not cause excess lateral forces against the structure by heavy equipment or 1 from earth masses transmitting pressures caused by earth moving equipment .
Place backfill 2 immediately adjacent to the structure by hand operated mechanical tampers .
Do not operate 3 heavy earth moving equipment within 10 feet of the structure in backfilling operations .
4 410-9 BLASTING ADJACENT TO HIGHWAY STRUCTURES 5 Conduct blasting operations adjacent to highway structures in accordance with the following 6 requirements .
7 Submit a blasting plan for approval before conducting any blasting operation .
8 Do not conduct blasting operations within 60 feet of any structure until the concrete strength 9 reaches 2,400 psi .
After the concrete achieves a strength of 2,400 psi , limit the maximum PPV 10 to 4 in/sec measured at the closest structure extremity .
11 For multi-column bents with column heights up to 40 feet and a combined span length for the 12 2 adjacent spans of 160 feet or less , adhere to the following criteria : 13 ( A ) Do not blast within 6 feet without obtaining prior written approval .
14 ( B ) At distance of 6 feet to 10 feet , do not use a quantity of explosives more than 0.5 lbs .
per 15 delay period .
16 ( C ) From 11 feet to 60 feet , use a maximum charge weight per delay of 0.5 lb .
and 0.5 lb .
of 17 explosives per foot of distance over 10 feet .
18 No vibration measurements are required if the above criteria are met .
If unable to meet the 19 above criteria , monitor the structure for vibrations .
If the 4 in/sec limit is exceeded , the 20 Engineer will evaluate each subsequent blast , and if deemed necessary , will apply more 21 restrictive controls than those above to prevent damage .
22 410-10 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 23 Payment of blasting operations is included in the bid price for Foundation Excavation at the 24 affected substructure unit .
25 ( A ) Foundation Excavation on a Cubic Yard Basis 26 When the contract calls for payment of Foundation Excavation on a cubic yard basis , it 27 will be measured and paid as the actual number of cubic yards of materials , measured in 28 their original position within the limits described below and computed by the average end 29 area method , that are acceptably excavated .
30 The upper limits for measurement are the actual ground surface at the time of starting work , 31 except where the excavation is performed in cut areas excavated under Section 225 , the 32 upper limits are the roadway plan typical section .
For keyed footings the upper limits of 33 the keyed section are as shown in the plans .
Define a “ keyed footing ” as a footing placed 34 without forms for the keyed depth in an excavation whose sides , as near as practical , are 35 located at the neat line dimensions of the footing and are vertical .
36 When the foundation material is other than rock , the lower limits for measurement are the 37 elevation of the bottom of footing as established by the plans or as directed .
When the 38 foundation material is rock , the lower limits for measurement are the actual rock elevations 39 after the foundation is approved .
40 As an exception to the lower limits established above , when in the opinion of the Engineer 41 excess excavation is performed due to carelessness or negligence on the part of the 42 Contractor , the Engineer notifies the Contractor of that portion of the excavation which is 43 not measured for payment .
44 Horizontal limits for measurement are established by vertical planes located 18 inches 45 outside of the neat line dimensions of the footing as established by the plans or directed in 46 Section 410 4-7 writing by the Engineer .
For keyed footings the horizontal limits for measurement of the 1 keyed section are established by vertical planes located at the neat line dimensions of the 2 footing as established by the plans or directed in writing .
3 Measurement includes mud , muck or similar semi-solid material within the limits 4 described above provided such material is present at the time excavation begins and can not 5 be drained away or pumped without the use of a jet or nozzle .
6 ( 1 ) No measurement is made of the following excavation , as such excavation is incidental 7 to the work being performed : 8 ( a ) Excavation necessary to construct end bent caps and the berm adjacent to the cap .
9 ( b ) Excavation necessary to construct pile encasement .
10 ( c ) Excavation outside of the limits described in this subarticle .
11 ( d ) Excavation necessary from heaving of a foundation due to the driving of piles .
12 ( e ) Excavation necessary from overbreaks or slides .
13 ( f ) Mud , muck or similar semi-solid material which can be drained away or pumped 14 without the use of a jet or nozzle .
15 ( g ) Excavation made before the Engineer makes measurements of the undisturbed 16 ground .
17 ( h ) Excavation necessary due to exposure or inundation allowed by the Contractor or 18 negligence on the part of the Contractor .
19 ( 2 ) Foundation Excavation will be paid at the contract unit price per cubic yard for 20 Foundation Excavation except where the Engineer directs the Contractor in writing to 21 excavate below the original plan elevation of the bottom of the footing .
Payment for 22 such excavation will be made as follows : 23 ( a ) For excavation made below the original plan elevation of the bottom of the footing 24 to an elevation 3 feet below such plan elevation , payment will be made at the 25 contract unit price per cubic yard for Foundation Excavation .
26 ( b ) For excavation made below an elevation 3 feet below the original plan elevation 27 of the bottom of the footing but not more than 6 feet below such plan elevation , 28 payment will be made at 150 % of the contract unit price per cubic yard for 29 Foundation Excavation .
30 ( c ) For excavation made below an elevation 6 feet below the original plan elevation 31 of the bottom of the footing , payment will be made as extra work in accordance 32 with Article 104-7 .
33 ( d ) In areas where piles have been driven , removal of material and backfilling with 34 subdrain fine or coarse aggregate in accordance with Article 410-3 will be paid as 35 extra work in accordance with Article 104-7 .

28 Define “ excavation ” and “ hole ” as a drilled pier excavation and “ pier ” as a drilled pier .
Define 29 “ permanent casing ” as a casing that remains in the excavation and acts as a form for Drilled 30 Pier concrete and “ temporary casing ” as any casing that is not permanent .
Define “ rock ” as a 31 continuous intact natural material with a standard penetration resistance of 0.1 foot or less per 32 60 blows or a rock auger penetration rate of less than 2 inches per 5 minutes of drilling at full 33 crowd force or as determined by the Engineer when rock is not encountered as expected based 34 on these criteria .
This definition excludes discontinuous loose natural materials such as 35 boulders and man-made materials such as concrete , steel , timber , etc .
and is not for 36 measurement and payment purposes .
See Article 411-7 for measurement and payment of 37 drilled piers .
38 Section 411 4-9 411-2 MATERIALS 1 Refer to Division 10 .
2 Item Section Grout , Type 2 1003 Portland Cement Concrete , Class Drilled Pier 1000 Reinforcing Steel 1070 Provide Type 3 material certifications in accordance with Article 106-3 for permanent casings 3 and roller , chair , steel pipe and cap materials .
Store steel materials on blocking at least 4 12 inches above the ground and protect it at all times from damage ; and when placing in the 5 work make sure it is free from dirt , dust , loose mill scale , loose rust , paint , oil or other foreign 6 materials .
Load , transport , unload and store drilled pier materials so materials are kept clean 7 and free of damage .
8 ( A ) Steel Casing 9 Define “ casing ” as a temporary or permanent casing .
If permanent casing is required for 10 an excavation , the largest diameter casing in the hole is the permanent casing .
This does 11 not apply to working casings around permanent casings as approved by the Engineer .
Use 12 smooth non-corrugated clean watertight steel casings of ample strength to withstand 13 handling and installation stresses and pressures imposed by concrete , earth , backfill and 14 fluids .
15 ( 1 ) Temporary Casings 16 Provide temporary casings with a nominal wall thickness of at least 0.375 inch and an 17 outside diameter equal to or larger than the design pier diameter for which temporary 18 casing is used .
19 ( 2 ) Permanent Casings 20 Use permanent casings with a yield strength of at least 36 ksi and a nominal wall 21 thickness that meets Table 411-1 .

32 411-4 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 33 Do not excavate holes , install piles or allow equipment loads or vibrations within 20 feet of 34 completed piers until 16 hours after drilled pier concrete reaches initial set .
35 When drilling from a barge , use a fixed template that maintains hole position and alignment 36 during drilled pier construction .
Do not use floating templates or templates attached to barges .
37 Check for correct drilled pier alignment and location before beginning drilling .
Check 38 plumbness of Kelly bars before beginning and frequently during drilling .
39 For drilled piers constructed with slurry or permanent casings , the pier diameter may be 2 inches 40 less than the design pier diameter shown in the plans .
For all other drilled piers , construct piers 41 with the minimum required diameters shown in the plans except for portions of drilled piers in 42 rock with may be 2 inches less than the design pier diameter .
43 Install drilled piers with tip elevations no higher than shown in the plans or approved by the 44 Engineer .
Provide piers with the minimum required tip resistance and , when noted in the plans , 45 penetration into rock .
46 Section 411 4-12 ( A ) Excavation 1 Excavate holes with equipment of the sizes required to construct drilled piers .
Use 2 equipment and methods accepted in the drilled pier construction plan or approved by the 3 Engineer .
Inform the Engineer of any deviations from the accepted plan .
4 Use drill rigs with sufficient capacity to drill through soil , rock , boulders , timbers , man- 5 made objects and any other materials encountered and drill 20 feet deeper or 20 % longer 6 than the maximum drilled pier length shown in the plans , whichever is greater .
Drilling 7 below pier tip elevations shown in the plans may be required to attain sufficient resistance .
8 Do not use blasting to advance drilled pier excavations .
Blasting for core removal is only 9 permitted when approved by the Engineer .
See Articles 107-11 and 107-12 for protection 10 of public and private property and control of siltation , dust and air and water pollution from 11 blasting , drilling and excavating with down-the-hole hammers .
Contain and dispose of 12 drilling spoils and waste concrete as directed and in accordance with Section 802 .
Drilling 13 spoils consist of all materials and fluids removed from excavations .
14 Stabilize excavations with only casings or slurry and casings except , as approved by the 15 Engineer , portions of excavations in rock .
Use casings or slurry in rock if unstable material 16 is anticipated or encountered .
Stabilize excavations from beginning of drilling through 17 concrete placement .
If excavations become unstable , the Engineer may suspend drilling 18 and require a revised drilled pier construction plan .
If it becomes necessary to replace a 19 casing during drilling , backfill the excavation , insert a larger casing around the casing to 20 be replaced or stabilize the excavation with slurry before removing the casing .
21 When noted in the plans , do not dewater drilled pier excavations .
Otherwise , if excavations 22 are in rock , dewater excavations to the satisfaction of the Engineer .
23 ( B ) Casings 24 Provide temporary casings to stabilize holes and protect personnel entering excavations .
25 Permanent casings may be required as noted in the plans .
Install permanent casings with 26 tip elevations no deeper than shown in the plans or approved by the Engineer .
Additional 27 drilled pier length and reinforcing steel may be required if permanent casings are installed 28 below elevations noted in the plans .
29 Install casings in continuous sections .
Overlap telescoping casings at least 24 inches .
30 Remove portions of permanent casings above the ground line or top of piers , whichever is 31 higher , after placing concrete .
Do not cut off permanent casings until Drilled Pier concrete 32 attains a compressive strength of at least 3,000 psi .
33 When using slurry construction without permanent casings , temporary casings at least 34 10 feet long are required at top of excavations .
Maintain top of casings at least 12 inches 35 above the ground line .
36 ( C ) Slurry Construction 37 Unless noted otherwise in the plans , slurry construction or polymer slurry is at the 38 Contractor ’ s option .
39 Use slurry and additives to stabilize holes in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s 40 recommendations .
Provide a technical representative employed by the slurry manufacturer 41 to assist and guide the Drilled Pier Contractor onsite during the construction of the first 42 drilled pier .
If problems are encountered during drilled pier construction , the Engineer may 43 require the technical representative to return to the site .
44 Provide documentation that mixing water is suitable for slurry .
Use slurry equipment that 45 is sufficient for mixing , agitating , circulating and storing slurry .
Thoroughly premix slurry 46 with water in tanks before pumping into excavations .
Allow bentonite slurry to hydrate at 47 least 24 hours in tanks before use .
48 Section 411 4-13 Pump slurry into excavations before encountering water .
Maintain slurry level at least 1 5 feet or one pier diameter , whichever is greater , above the highest piezometric head along 2 the drilled pier length .
The highest piezometric head is anticipated to be the static water or 3 groundwater elevation .
However , the Drilled Pier Contractor is responsible for 4 determining the highest piezometric head for each pier .
5 Maintain the required slurry properties at all times except for sand content .
Desand or 6 replace slurry as needed to meet the required sand content in tanks before pumping slurry 7 into excavations and in excavations immediately before placing concrete .
8 ( 1 ) Time 9 Agitate bentonite slurry in holes at least every 4 hours .
If this 4-hour time limit is 10 exceeded , the Engineer may require holes to be overreamed at least 1 inch and no more 11 than 3 inches below casings .
Overream holes with grooving tools , overreaming 12 buckets or other approved methods .
13 Construct drilled piers so the maximum time slurry is in contact with uncased portions 14 of holes from drilling through concrete placement does not exceed 36 hours .
If this 15 36 hour time limit is exceeded , the Engineer may require the hole diameter to be 16 enlarged at least 6 inches .
If the enlarged hole diameter is greater than the permanent 17 casing diameter , replace casing with a larger permanent casing with an outside 18 diameter equal to the diameter of the enlarged hole .
19 ( 2 ) Slurry Testing 20 Define a “ sample set ” as slurry samples collected from mid-height and within 2 feet 21 of the bottom of slurry tanks or holes .
Take a sample set from slurry tanks to test 22 slurry before beginning drilling .
Do not pump slurry into excavations until both slurry 23 samples from tanks meet the required slurry properties .
Take sample sets from 24 excavations to test slurry at least every 4 hours and immediately before placing 25 concrete .
Do not place Drilled Pier concrete until both slurry samples from 26 an excavation meet the required slurry properties .
If any slurry test results do not meet 27 the requirements , the Engineer may suspend drilling until both samples from a sample 28 set meet the required slurry properties .
29 Sign , date and submit slurry test reports upon completion of each pier .
The 30 Department reserves the right to perform comparison slurry tests at any time .
31 ( 3 ) Disposal 32 Comply with all Federal , State and local regulations , as well as the project permits and 33 commitments , when disposing of slurry and drilling spoils mixed with slurry .
Contain 34 slurry and drilling spoils and keep out of water at all times .
35 ( D ) Cleaning and Inspection 36 Provide clean holes with level bottoms so elevations within bottom of holes do not vary by 37 more than 12 inches .
Remove soft and loose material from bottom of holes using methods 38 accepted in the drilled pier construction plan or approved by the Engineer .
When bottom 39 of holes are not hand cleaned , remove sediment from holes with cleanout buckets , air lifts 40 or pumps .
41 After cleaning is complete , provide all equipment , personnel and assistance required for 42 the Engineer to visually inspect holes from above or by entering excavations .
Remove all 43 cleaning and drilling equipment from holes during inspections and do not interfere with 44 inspections .
45 Section 411 4-14 ( 1 ) Tip Resistance 1 If the Engineer determines that the material below an excavation does not provide the 2 minimum required tip resistance , increase the drilled pier length and lengthen 3 reinforcing steel as directed .
One of the following methods may be required to check 4 the conditions and continuity of material below excavations .
5 ( a ) Test Hole 6 If excavations are in rock , drill a 1.5 inch diameter test hole at least 6 feet below 7 bottom of holes for the Engineer to determine the continuity of rock below holes .
8 ( b ) Standard Penetration Test 9 Standard penetration tests ( SPT ) may be required as noted in the plans .
When 10 required , drive a split-barrel sampler 18 inches below bottom of holes or to refusal 11 in accordance with ASTM D1586 .
Perform SPT in holes at least 12 inches away 12 from casing walls and support drill rods so rods remain vertical and straight .
13 Report the number of blows applied in each 6 inch increment and provide 14 recovered samples to the Engineer .
The Engineer will determine the standard 15 penetration resistance required .
16 ( 2 ) Bottom Cleanliness 17 Holes are clean if at least 50 % of bottom of holes has less than 0.5 inch of sediment 18 and no portions of bottom of holes have more than 1.5 inches of sediment .
If bottom 19 of holes does not meet this cleanliness criteria , remove sediment from holes until the 20 Engineer determines holes are clean .
One or more of the following methods may be 21 required to inspect the bottom cleanliness of holes .
22 ( a ) Steel Probe 23 If drilled pier excavations are not dewatered or as directed , provide a # 10 rebar 24 steel probe that is 24 inches long with a flat tip on one end and a non-stretch cable 25 connected to the other end .
Provide a cable long enough to lower the steel probe 26 to the bottom of holes for the Engineer to determine the amount of sediment in 27 holes .
28 ( b ) Shaft Inspection Device 29 The Engineer may use the shaft inspection device ( SID ) as noted in the plans .
The 30 Engineer provides the SID and personnel to operate it .
Notify the Engineer at 31 least 2 days before finishing holes that will be inspected with the SID .
32 Assist the Engineer in handling the SID and associated equipment and supporting 33 the SID during inspections .
Provide working areas large enough for the SID , 34 associated equipment and SID personnel within reach of the SID cables and clear 35 view of holes being inspected .
If necessary , provide a secure location to store the 36 SID and associated equipment onsite overnight .
37 Approximately one hour is required to inspect a hole with the SID after the SID 38 and associated equipment are set up .
The Engineer will use the SID to measure 39 the amount of sediment at 5 locations around the bottom of holes .
40 ( E ) Reinforcing Steel and Concrete 41 Assemble rebar cages consisting of bar and spiral reinforcing steel shown in the plans .
42 Securely cross tie reinforcing steel at each intersection with double wire .
Attach a chair 43 under each reinforcing bar and rollers near the top and bottom of rebar cages and every 44 10 feet along cages in between .
The number of rollers required at each location along rebar 45 cages is one roller per foot of design pier diameter with at least 4 rollers per location .
Space 46 rollers equally around rebar cages at each location .
Attach rollers so rollers are supported 47 Section 411 4-15 across 2 adjacent reinforcing bars and will freely rotate when rebar cages are lowered into 1 excavations .
2 If CSL tubes are required , securely attach CSL tubes to spiral reinforcing steel on the inside 3 of rebar cages with at least 3 inches of clearance to reinforcing bars .
Extend CSL tubes 4 from 6 inches above pier tip elevations to at least 2 feet above the ground line or top of 5 permanent casings , whichever is greater .
The number of CSL tubes required for each 6 drilled pier is one tube per foot of design pier diameter with at least 4 tubes per pier .
Space 7 CSL tubes equally around rebar cages so distances between tubes measured around spiral 8 reinforcing steel are uniform .
Install CSL tubes as straight and parallel to each other as 9 possible .
Fit caps on top and bottom of CSL tubes .
10 After the Engineer determines that the material below excavations provides the minimum 11 required tip resistance and holes are clean , place rebar cages and then concrete in 12 excavations .
Do not rack or distort rebar cages and CSL tubes when lifting and handling 13 cages .
Set rebar cages directly on bottom of holes or , as approved by the Engineer , hang 14 cages from permanent casings .
When hanging rebar cages , leave devices supporting cages 15 in place until Drilled Pier concrete attains a compressive strength of at least 3,000 psi .
16 Do not delay placing cages or concrete unless excavations are cased to rock or otherwise 17 approved .
If delays occur , the Engineer may require removal of rebar cages to reinspect 18 bottom cleanliness of holes .
If bottom of holes does not meet the cleanliness criteria in 19 Subarticle 411-4 ( D ) ( 2 ) , remove sediment from holes until the Engineer determines holes 20 are clean before resetting rebar cages .
21 After placing rebar cages with CSL tubes , remove top caps , fill tubes with clean water and 22 reinstall caps before placing concrete .
Check for correct cage position before placing 23 concrete and keep rebar cages plumb during concrete placement .
Maintain cage position 24 so rebar cages do not move vertically more than 6 inches and columns or footings have the 25 minimum required concrete cover shown in the plans .
26 Remove all temporary casings during concrete placement .
Do not twist , move or otherwise 27 disturb temporary casings until the concrete depth inside casings is at least 10 feet or half 28 the head , whichever is greater , above the bottom of casing being disturbed .
Define “ head ” 29 as the difference between the highest piezometric head along the drilled pier length and the 30 static water elevation inside the excavation .
31 When removing temporary casings , maintain the required concrete depth above the bottom 32 of casing being removed except when the concrete level is at or above top of piers .
Sustain 33 sufficient concrete depths to overcome pressures imposed by earth , backfill and fluids .
As 34 temporary casings are withdrawn , ensure fluids trapped behind casings is displaced upward 35 and discharged out of excavations without contaminating or displacing concrete .
36 Pour concrete in excavations to form uniform jointless monolithic drilled piers .
Do not 37 trap soil , air , fluids or other contaminants in concrete .
Remove contaminated concrete from 38 top of piers at time of concrete placement .
39 Inform the Engineer of the volume of concrete placed for each pier .
For piers constructed 40 with slurry or as directed , record a graphical plot of depth versus theoretical and actual 41 concrete volumes .
42 Dry or wet placement of concrete is at the Contractor ’ s option for piers constructed with 43 only casings if the water inflow rate into excavations is less than 6 inches per half hour 44 after removing any pumps from holes .
Wet placement of concrete is required for all other 45 drilled pier construction .
46 ( 1 ) Dry Placement 47 If holes are filling with water for dry placement of concrete , dewater excavations as 48 much as possible before placing concrete .
For drilled piers less than 80 feet long , pour 49 concrete down the center of excavations so concrete does not hit reinforcing steel or 50 Section 411 4-16 excavation sidewalls .
For piers longer than 80 feet , place concrete with a tremie or 1 pump pipe down the center of excavations so length of free fall is less than 80 feet .
2 ( 2 ) Wet Placement 3 For wet placement of concrete , maintain static water or slurry levels in holes before 4 placing concrete .
Place concrete through steel tremies or pump pipes .
Use tremies 5 with watertight joints and a diameter of at least 10 inches .
Pump concrete in 6 accordance with Article 420-5 .
Use approved devices to prevent contaminating 7 concrete when tremies or pump pipes are initially placed in excavations .
Extend 8 tremies or pump pipes into concrete at least 5 feet at all times except when the concrete 9 is initially placed .
10 When the concrete level reaches the static water elevation inside the excavation , dry 11 placement of concrete is permitted .
Before changing to dry placement , pump water or 12 slurry out of holes and remove contaminated concrete from the exposed concrete 13 surface .
14 411-5 INTEGRITY TESTING 15 Define “ integrity testing ” as crosshole sonic logging ( CSL ) and pile integrity testing ( PIT ) .
16 Integrity testing may be required as noted in the plans or by the Engineer .
The Engineer will 17 determine how many and which drilled piers require integrity testing .
Do not test piers until 18 Drilled Pier concrete cures for at least 7 days and attains a compressive strength of at least 3,000 19 psi .
20 ( A ) Crosshole Sonic Logging 21 If CSL testing is required , use a prequalified CSL Consultant to perform CSL testing and 22 provide CSL reports .
Use a CSL Operator approved as a Field Engineer ( key person ) for 23 the CSL Consultant .
Provide CSL reports sealed by an engineer approved as a Project 24 Engineer ( key person ) for the same CSL Consultant .
25 ( 1 ) CSL Testing 26 Perform CSL testing in accordance with ASTM D6760 .
If probes for CSL testing will 27 not pass through to the bottom of CSL tubes , the Engineer may require coring to 28 replace inaccessible tubes .
Do not begin coring until core hole size and locations are 29 approved .
Core at least 1.5 inches diameter holes the full length of piers .
Upon 30 completion of coring , fill holes with clean water and cover to keep out debris .
Perform 31 CSL testing in core holes instead of inaccessible tubes .
32 For piers with 4 or 5 CSL tubes , test all tube pairs .
For piers with 6 or more CSL tubes , 33 test all adjacent tube pairs around spiral reinforcing steel and at least 50 % of remaining 34 tube pairs selected by the Engineer .
Record CSL data at depth intervals of 2.5 inches 35 or less from the bottom of CSL tubes to top of piers .
36 ( 2 ) CSL Reports 37 Submit 2 copies of each CSL report within 7 days of completing CSL testing .
Include 38 the following in CSL reports : 39 ( a ) Title Sheet 40 ( i ) Department ’ s TIP number and WBS element number 41 ( ii ) Project description 42 ( iii ) County 43 ( iv ) Bridge station number 44 ( v ) Pier location 45 ( vi ) Personnel 46 ( vii ) Report date 47 Section 411 4-17 ( b ) Introduction 1 ( c ) Site and Subsurface Conditions ( including water table elevation ) 2 ( d ) Pier Details 3 ( i ) Pier and casing diameters , lengths and elevations 4 ( ii ) Drilled Pier concrete compressive strength 5 ( iii ) Installation methods including use of casings , slurry , pumps , tremies , dry or 6 wet placement of concrete , etc .
7 ( e ) CSL Results 8 ( i ) Logs with plots of signal arrival times and energy vs. depth for all tube pairs 9 tested 10 ( f ) Summary/Conclusions 11 ( i ) Table of velocity reductions with corresponding locations ( tube pair and 12 depth ) for all tube pairs tested 13 ( ii ) List of suspected anomalies with corresponding locations ( tube pair ( s ) and 14 depth range ) 15 ( g ) Attachments 16 ( i ) Boring log ( s ) 17 ( ii ) Field inspection forms and concrete curves ( from Engineer ) 18 ( iii ) CSL tube locations , elevations , lengths and identifications 19 ( iv ) CSL hardware model and software version information 20 ( v ) PDF copy of all CSL data 21 ( B ) Pile Integrity Testing 22 If required , the Engineer will perform PIT .
Provide access to and prepare top of piers for 23 PIT as directed .
See ASTM D5882 for PIT details .

For initial CSL 29 testing , the Engineer will typically determine whether further investigation is required 30 based on Table 411-3 .

< 20 % No 20 - 30 % As Determined by the Engineer > 30 % Yes If further investigation is necessary , the Engineer will typically require one or more of the 32 following methods to investigate questionable piers .
33 ( 1 ) CSL Testing 34 If required , use CSL testing as described above to retest questionable piers and as 35 directed , perform testing with probes vertically offset in CSL tubes .
CSL offset data 36 will typically be required for all locations ( tube pair and depth ) with velocity 37 reductions greater than 30 % and at other locations as directed .
Record offset data at 38 depths , intervals and angles needed to completely delineate anomalies .

Provide cores 11 to the Engineer for evaluation and testing .
Sign , date and submit core logs upon 12 completion of each core hole .
13 ( D ) Defective Piers 14 For questionable piers that are exposed or cored , the Engineer will determine if piers are 15 defective based on the results of excavation or coring .
For questionable piers that are not 16 exposed or cored , the Engineer will determine if piers are defective based on the results of 17 integrity testing .
Questionable piers with only CSL testing will be considered defective if 18 any velocity reductions between any tube pairs are greater than 30 % .
19 411-6 DRILLED PIER ACCEPTANCE 20 Drilled pier acceptance is based in part on the following criteria : 21 ( A ) Temporary casings and drilling tools are removed from the drilled pier excavation or the 22 Engineer determines that a temporary casing may remain in the excavation .
23 ( B ) Drilled Pier concrete is properly placed and does not have any evidence of segregation , 24 intrusions , contamination , structural damage or inadequate consolidation ( honeycombing ) .
25 ( C ) Center of pier is within 3 inches of plan location and 2 % of plumb .
Top of pier is within 26 1 inch above and 3 inches below the elevation shown in the plans or approved by the 27 Engineer .
28 ( D ) Rebar cage is properly placed and top and center of cage is within tolerances for center of 29 pier .
Tip of permanent casing does not extend below the elevation noted in the plans or 30 approved by the Engineer .
31 ( E ) Drilled pier is not defective or the Engineer determines the defective pier is satisfactory .
32 A pier will be considered defective based on Subarticle 411-5 ( D ) .
33 Do not grout CSL tubes or core holes , backfill around a pier or perform any work on a drilled 34 pier until the Engineer accepts the pier .
If the drilled pier is accepted , dewater and grout 35 CSL tubes and core holes , and backfill around the pier with approved material to finished grade .
36 If the Engineer determines a pier is unacceptable , remediation is required .
Remediation may 37 include , but is not limited to grouting , removing part or all of unacceptable piers , modifying 38 pier designs or providing replacement or additional piers or piles .
Submit working drawings 39 and design calculations for acceptance in accordance with Article 105-2 .
Ensure remediation 40 submittals are designed , detailed and sealed by an engineer licensed by the State of North 41 Carolina .

21 414-8 SUBSURFACE DRAINAGE AT WEEP HOLES 22 Place a stone drain consisting of one cubic foot of subdrain coarse aggregate contained in a bag 23 of Type 1 geotextile at each weep hole .

25 Connect all drains with a horizontal drain of subdrain fine aggregate at least 1 foot square in 26 cross section .
In the case of abutments and retaining walls , in addition to the above 27 requirements , place a vertical drain of subdrain fine aggregate at least 1 foot square in cross 28 section at each weep hole to an elevation 2 feet below the subgrade or surface of the 29 embankment .

9 ( C ) Forms 10 ( 1 ) General 11 Use forms made of wood or steel except where other materials are specified by the 12 contract or accepted by the Engineer .
13 ( 2 ) Wood Forms 14 Build forms mortar-tight of material sufficient in strength with ample studding , 15 walling and bracing to effectively prevent any appreciable horizontal and vertical 16 deflection .
17 Provide forms with interior dimensions such that the finished concrete is of the form 18 and dimensions shown in the plans .
19 Line forms , except for surfaces permanently in contact with earth fill , with plywood 20 or other approved material .
Provide a lining with a smooth and uniform texture and 21 of such thickness and rigidity that a concrete surface of uniform texture and even 22 appearance results .
Provide joints between form liners that are mortar tight and even 23 and maintain to prevent the opening of joints due to the shrinkage of the lumber .
24 Fillet forms at all sharp corners unless otherwise noted in the plans .
Mill wood 25 chamfer strips from straight grained lumber and surface on all sides .
Maintain an 26 acceptable alignment and no broken edges on all chamfer strips .
27 Give forms for all projections a bevel or draft to insure easy removal .
28 At all times , maintain the shape , strength , rigidity , watertightness and surface 29 smoothness of reused forms .
Resize any warped or bulged lumber before reusing .
Do 30 not reuse any forms that are unsatisfactory in any respect .
Do not use plywood sheets 31 showing torn grain , worn edges , patches , holes from previous use or other defects that 32 impair the texture of concrete surfaces exposed to view .
33 Thoroughly clean forms previously used of all dirt , mortar and foreign material before 34 reusing .
Before placing concrete in forms to be removed , thoroughly coat all inside 35 surfaces of the forms with commercial quality form oil or other equivalent coating 36 which permits the ready release of the forms and does not discolor the concrete .
37 Construct or install metal spacers or anchorages , required within the forms for their 38 support or to hold them in correct alignment and location , in such a way that the metal 39 work can be removed to a depth of at least 1 inch from the exposed surface of the 40 concrete without injury to such surface by spalling or otherwise .
Limit the diameter 41 to not greater than 1.5 times its depth for the recess formed in the concrete .
Cut back 42 all such metal devices in exposed surfaces , upon removal of the forms , to a depth of 43 at least 1 inch from the face of the concrete .
Carefully fill cavities produced by the 44 removal of metal devices with cement mortar of the same mix used in the body of the 45 work immediately upon removal of the forms , and leave the surface smooth , even and 46 as nearly uniform in color as possible .
As an option , break off flush with the concrete 47 Section 420 4-26 surface those metal devices with cross-sectional area not exceeding 0.05 square inches 1 on surfaces permanently in contact with earth fill .
2 Do not weld metal devices to either reinforcing steel or structural steel that is 3 a permanent part of the structure without written approval .
4 ( 3 ) Steel Forms 5 Apply Subarticle 420-3 ( C ) ( 2 ) in regards to design , mortar tightness , filleted corners , 6 beveled projections , bracing , alignment , texture and evenness of appearance of the 7 resulting concrete surface , removal , re-use and oiling to steel forms .
Use steel for 8 forms of such thickness that the forms remain true to shape .
Counter-sink bolt and 9 rivet heads .
Design clamps , pins or other connecting devices to hold the forms rigidly 10 together and allow removal without injury to the concrete .
Do not use steel forms that 11 do not present a smooth surface or line up properly .
Exercise care to keep steel forms 12 free from rust , grease or other foreign matter that will tend to discolor the concrete .

49 Section 420 4-27 Design the prestressed concrete panels in accordance with the following criteria : 1 ( a ) Design details to provide a mating surface joint or a draft not exceeding 1/8 inch 2 resulting in a joint that is closed at the top and no more than 1/4 inch open at 3 bottom of panel .
Detail the joints filled with grout or other methods approved by 4 the Engineer to prevent leakage of the concrete .
Place a chamfer or fillet , with 5 a 3/4 inch horizontal width , along the top edges of the panel parallel with the 6 prestressed girder .
7 ( b ) Design panels to support the dead load of the panel , reinforcement , plastic 8 concrete and a 50 lb/sf construction load .
Design the panel and slab acting 9 compositely to support design live loads and dead loads acting on the composite 10 section .
Include in the design dead load acting on the composite section 11 an additional load of 30 lb/sf for a future asphalt wearing surface .
For bridges up 12 to 44 feet in width , distribute equally to all deck panels superimposed dead loads 13 for such permanent bridge items as barrier rails , medians or any dead load which 14 is applied after the deck is cast .
In the case of bridges over 44 feet wide , distribute 15 these loads equally to the first 2 1/2 panels adjacent to each side of the load .
16 ( c ) The design span of the prestressed concrete panel is the clear distance between 17 edges of girders plus 2 inches measured parallel to the panel edges .
18 ( d ) Limit tension in the precompressed tensile zone to 424 psi unless the plans require 19 0 psi tension .
20 ( 2 ) Fabricated Metal Stay-In-Place Forms 21 Furnish metal stay-in-place forms with closed tapered ends to form the concrete deck 22 slabs as shown in the plans .
Submit complete fabrication and erection drawings for 23 review , comments and acceptance .
Indicate on these plans the grade of steel , the 24 physical and section properties for all permanent steel bridge deck form sheets and a 25 clear indication of locations of form supports .
Do not fabricate the forming material 26 until drawings are accepted .
27 When required by the design plans , detail stay-in-place forms with excluder plates to 28 exclude concrete from the valleys in the forms .
Foam insulation void fillers may be 29 used in stay-in-place metal forms .
Adhesive shall be used on all 3 contacting sides of 30 the foam insulation void fillers rather than on the bottom only .
The adhesive shall be 31 compatible with the foam insulation material to not cause decomposition .
Duct tape 32 shall not be used to hold the foam insulation in place .
Foam insulation shall be placed 33 in one piece across each bay and be trimmed to not extend over the girder .
Foam 34 insulation damaged during placement of reinforcing steel shall be replaced .
35 Design metal stay-in-place forms in accordance with the following criteria : 36 ( a ) Accommodate the dead load of the form , reinforcement and the plastic concrete , 37 including the additional weight of concrete due to the deflection of the metal 38 forms , plus 50 lb/sf for construction loads .
Do not allow the unit working stress 39 in the steel sheet to exceed 72.5 % of the specified minimum yield strength of the 40 material furnished nor 36 ksi .
41 ( b ) Limit the horizontal leg of the support angle to 3 inches .
Design the support angle 42 as a cantilever .
43 ( c ) Limit the deflection under the weight of the forms , the plastic concrete and 44 reinforcement to 1/180 of the form span or 1/2 inch whichever is less .
Do not 45 design for a total loading less than 120 lb/sf .
46 ( d ) Base the permissible form camber on the actual dead load condition .
Do not use 47 camber to compensate for deflection in excess of the foregoing limits .
48 Section 420 4-28 ( e ) The design span of the form sheets is the clear distance between edges of beam or 1 girder flanges minus 2 inches measured parallel to the form flutes .
Design and 2 provide form sheets with a length at least the design span of the forms .
3 ( f ) Compute physical design properties in accordance with requirements of the 4 American Iron and Steel Institute Specification for the Design of Cold-Formed 5 Steel Structural Members .
6 ( g ) Provide a minimum concrete cover of 1 1/4 inches clear above metal stay-in-place 7 form to the bottom mat of reinforcement .
8 ( h ) Maintain the plan dimensions of both layers of primary deck reinforcement from 9 the top of the concrete deck .
10 ( i ) Do not weld to flanges in tension or to structural steel bridge elements fabricated 11 from non-weldable grades of steel .
12 ( j ) Weld metal stay-in-place forms for prestressed concrete girders to embedded clips 13 in the girder flanges .
The embedded clips shall be at least 2 inches x 3 inches and 14 2 inches long .
The clips shall be galvanized , 10 gauge ASTM A653 steel and 15 have a 3/4 inch or 1 inch diameter hole in the 2 inch leg .
The spacing of the clips 16 shall be 12 inches .
All submitted metal stay-in-place form designs shall be able 17 to use the standard size and spacing of the clip described above .
18 Do not unload or handle fabricated metal stay-in-place forming materials so as to 19 damage or alter the configuration of the forms .
Replace damaged materials at no 20 additional cost to the Department .
21 Store fabricated metal stay-in-place forms that are stored at the project site at least 4 22 inches above the ground on platforms , skids or other suitable supports and protect 23 against corrosion and damage from any source .
24 Install all forms in accordance with detailed fabrication plans submitted to the 25 Engineer for review .
Clearly indicate on the fabrication plans the locations where the 26 forms are supported by steel beam flanges subject to tensile stresses .
Do not weld to 27 the flanges within these locations .
Do not allow form sheets to rest directly on the top 28 of the beam or girder .
Securely fasten sheets to form supports with a minimum bearing 29 length of 1 inch at each end .
Center sheets between the form supports .
Place form 30 supports in direct contact with the flange of girder or beam .
Make all attachments by 31 permissible welds , bolts , clips or other approved means .
Weld in accordance with 32 Article 1072-18 except 1/8 inch fillet welds are permitted .
33 In the areas where the form sheets lap , securely fasten the form sheets to one another 34 by screws at a maximum spacing of 18 inches .
Securely attach the ends of the form 35 sheets to support angles with screws at a maximum spacing of 18 inches .
36 Where the galvanized coating is damaged , repair in accordance with Article 1076-7 .
37 Minor heat discoloration in areas of welds is not damage and does not require the 38 above repair .
39 Locate transverse construction joints at the bottom of a flute and field drill ¼ inch 40 weep holes at not more than 12 inches on center along the line of the joint .
41 Use a saw for all cuts .
Do not flame cut forms .
