9 ( 2 ) Design 10 Design falsework and forms for the combined effects of dead load and live load and 11 with appropriate safety factors in accordance with this section and the respective 12 design codes of the materials used .
Include the weight of concrete , reinforcing steel , 13 forms and falsework in the dead load .
Live load includes the actual weight of any 14 equipment the falsework supports , applied as concentrated loads at the points of 15 contact and a uniform load of at least 20 lb/sf applied over the supported area .
16 In addition , apply a line load of 75 lb/ft along the outside edge of deck overhangs .
17 ( 3 ) Inspection 18 Before the form or falsework system is loaded , inspect the erected falsework and forms 19 and submit a written statement certifying that the erected falsework system complies 20 with the accepted detailed drawings .
Submit a separate certification for each span , 21 unit or bridge component .
Any condition that does not comply with the accepted 22 drawings , or any other condition deemed unsatisfactory by the Engineer , is cause for 23 rejection until corrections are made .
24 420-4 PLACING CONCRETE 25 Do not place concrete until the depth of the excavation , character of the foundation material , 26 adequacy of the forms and falsework , placement of reinforcement and other embedded items 27 are inspected and approved .
Do not place concrete without the Department ’ s inspector present .
28 Place concrete in daylight or obtain approval for an adequate lighting system for construction 29 and inspection of the work .
30 In preparation for the placing of concrete , remove all sawdust , chips and other construction 31 debris and extraneous matter from the interior of forms .
Remove hardened concrete and foreign 32 matter from tools , screeds and conveying equipment .
33 Ensure that the concrete temperature at the time of placement in the forms is at least 50°F and 34 no more than 95°F , except where other temperatures are required by Articles 420-7 35 and 420-14 .
36 Do not use concrete that does not reach its final position in the forms within the time stipulated 37 in Subarticle 1000-4 ( E ) .
38 Thoroughly clean and wet surfaces , other than foundation surfaces , immediately before placing 39 concrete to help bonding to those surfaces .
40 Regulate the placement of concrete so the pressures caused by the wet concrete do not exceed 41 those used in the design of the forms .
42 Thoroughly work the external surface of all concrete during the placing with approved tools .
43 During the placing of concrete , take care to use methods of compaction that result in a surface 44 of even texture free from voids , water or air pockets , and that force the coarse aggregate away 45 from the forms to leave a mortar surface .
46 Place concrete to avoid segregation of the materials and the displacement of the reinforcement .
47 Section 420 4-30 Equip chutes on steep slopes with baffle boards or provide chutes in short lengths that reverse 1 the direction of movement .
2 Use all chutes , troughs and pipes made from suitable materials other than aluminum and keep 3 them clean and free from coating of hardened concrete by thoroughly flushing with water after 4 each run .
Discharge the water used for flushing clear of the structure .
5 Confine concrete dropped more than 5 feet by closed chutes or pipes , except in walls of box 6 culverts or retaining walls unless otherwise directed .
7 Take care to fill each part of the form by depositing the concrete as near to its final position as 8 possible .
Work the coarse aggregate back from the forms and around the reinforcement without 9 displacing the bars .
After initial set of the concrete , do not jar the forms and do not place strain 10 on the projecting reinforcement or other items embedded in the concrete .
11 Compact all concrete required to be vibrated with approved high frequency internal vibrators 12 or other approved type of vibrators immediately after depositing concrete in the forms .
In all 13 cases , have available at least 2 vibrators in good operating condition and 2 sources of power at 14 the site of any structure in which more than 25 cubic yard of concrete is required .
Do not attach 15 or hold the vibrators against the forms or the reinforcing steel .
When vibrating concrete 16 containing epoxy coated reinforcing steel , use a vibrator with a protective rubber head as 17 approved by the Engineer .
Vibrate with care and avoid displacement of reinforcement , ducts 18 or other embedded elements .
Vibrate in the appropriate location , manner and duration to secure 19 maximum consolidation of the concrete without causing segregation of the mortar and coarse 20 aggregate and without causing water to flush to the surface .
When placing concrete to a depth 21 in excess of 12 inches and containing one or more horizontal layers of reinforcing steel , place 22 the concrete in horizontal layers not more than 12 inches thick .
Place and compact each layer 23 before the preceding layer takes initial set such that there is no surface of separation between 24 layers .
Do not taper layers of concrete in wedge-shaped slopes but instead place them with 25 reasonably square ends and level tops .
26 If placing additional concrete against hardened concrete , take care to remove all laitance and to 27 roughen the surfaces of the concrete to ensure that fresh concrete is deposited upon sound 28 concrete surfaces and an acceptable bond is obtained .
Thoroughly wet the existing concrete for 29 at least 2 hours before placing additional concrete .
30 Deposit and compact to form a compact , dense , impervious concrete of uniform texture which 31 shows smooth faces on exposed surfaces .
Repair , remove and replace in whole or in part as 32 directed and at no additional cost to the Department , any section of concrete found to be porous , 33 cracked , plastered or otherwise defective .
34 Protect beams and girders during concreting operations .
Remove any concrete that gets on 35 beams or girders immediately by an approved method to restore the surface to the specified 36 condition .
37 420-5 PUMPING CONCRETE 38 Placement of concrete by pumping is permitted only when approved .
Use and locate suitable 39 pumping equipment that is adequate in capacity for the work and so no vibrations result which 40 might damage freshly placed concrete .
Do not use pumping equipment , including the conduit 41 system , which contains any aluminum or aluminum alloy that comes in contact with the 42 concrete .
43 Waste all grout used to lubricate the inner surfaces of the conduit system .
44 Pump so a continuous stream of concrete without air pockets is delivered .
For test purposes , 45 take concrete from the discharge end of the pump .
46 Section 420 4-31 420-6 SLUMP TESTS 1 The slump of the concrete is determined in accordance with AASHTO T 119 .
2 When a slump test is made and the results of the test exceed the specified maximum , a check 3 test is made immediately from the same batch or truck load of concrete .
If a passing result 4 can not be produced on the check test the load will be rejected .
5 420-7 PLACING CONCRETE IN COLD WEATHER 6 ( A ) General 7 Do not place concrete when the air temperature , measured at the location of the concreting 8 operation in the shade away from artificial heat , is below 35°F without permission .
When 9 such permission is granted , uniformly heat the aggregates and water to a temperature not 10 higher than 150°F .
Place the concrete when the temperature of the heated concrete is at 11 least 55°F and not more than 80°F .
12 Use aggregates that are free of ice , frost and frozen particles .
Do not place concrete on 13 frozen foundation material .
14 Protect all concrete with heated enclosures or by insulation whenever any of the following 15 conditions occur : 16 ( 1 ) The concrete is placed when the air temperature , measured at the location of the 17 concreting operation in the shade away from artificial heat , is below 35°F .
18 ( 2 ) The air temperature , measured at the location of the freshly placed concrete in the 19 shade away from artificial heat , is below 35°F and the concrete has not yet attained an 20 age of 72 hours or an age of 48 hours when using high early strength Portland cement 21 concrete .
If the mix contains fly ash or ground granulated blast furnace slag , protect 22 the concrete for 7 days .
23 Provide and place , at directed locations , a sufficient number of maximum-minimum 24 recording thermometers to provide an accurate record of the temperature surrounding the 25 concrete during the entire protection period .
26 Assume all risks connected with the placing of concrete under the cold weather conditions 27 referred to herein .
Permission given to place concrete when the temperature is below 35°F 28 and the subsequent protection of the concrete as required herein does not relieve the 29 Contractor in any way of the responsibility for obtaining the required results .
30 ( B ) Heated Enclosures 31 Immediately enclose Portland cement concrete that is placed when the air temperature is 32 below 35°F and Portland cement concrete that has not yet attained an age of 72 hours .
33 Enclose the concrete before the air temperature falls below 35°F with a housing consisting 34 of canvas or other approved material supported by an open framework .
Maintain the air 35 surrounding the concrete at a temperature of at least 50°F and no more than 90°F for the 36 remainder of the 72-hour period .
Apply these same requirements to high early strength 37 Portland cement concrete except reduce the 72-hour period to 48 hours .
Do not begin these 38 time periods until completing manipulation of each separate mass of concrete .
39 Provide such heating apparatuses as stoves , salamanders or steam equipment and the 40 necessary fuel .
When using dry heat , provide means of preventing loss of moisture from 41 the concrete .
42 ( C ) Insulation 43 As an alternate to the heated enclosure specified in Subarticle 420-7 ( B ) , use insulated 44 forms or insulation meeting all requirements of this subarticle to protect concrete .
Use 45 insulation under the same conditions that require heated enclosures .
Place the insulation 46 on the concrete as soon as initial set permits .
47 Section 420 4-32 When using insulation for cold weather protection , batch concrete for sections 12 inches 1 or less in thickness or diameter as outlined below .
Use Type III Portland cement without 2 any increase in cement content , or use Type I or II Portland cement with the cement content 3 increased to 1.80 barrels per cubic yard .
When the mix includes fly ash , use a mix 4 containing 572 lb/cy of cement and at least 172 lb/cy of fly ash .
When the mix includes 5 ground granulated blast furnace slag , use a mix containing 465 lb/cy of cement and 6 250 lb/cy of ground granulated blast furnace slag .
7 Use insulated materials with a minimum thickness of 1 inch .
Insulate overhang forms both 8 on the outside vertical faces and on the underside with a 1 inch minimum thickness of either 9 rigid or blanket type insulation .
Use insulating materials which provide a minimum system 10 R value of 4.0 in the up mode as determined by ASTM C1363 with a 15 mph wind over 11 the cold side of the material and a minimum differential of 50°F .
Furnish results of tests 12 conducted in accordance with ASTM C1363 by an acceptable commercial testing 13 laboratory for review , comments and acceptance .
Obtain such acceptance before use of 14 the material .
Face or cover insulating blankets , top and bottom , with polyethylene or 15 similar waterproofing material meeting Article 1026-3 except for the length and color 16 requirements .
Place blankets on the concrete to form a waterproof surface for the protected 17 concrete .
Do not use blankets with rips and tears in the waterproofing material unless 18 acceptably repaired .
When the anticipated low temperature expected during the protection 19 period is less than 10°F , provide 2 inches of insulation .
Overlap blanket insulation mats at 20 the edges by at least 6 inches .
Tightly butt rigid type insulation sheets together and seal .
21 Take particular care to provide effective protection of curbs , corners and around protruding 22 reinforcing steel .
23 Should the air under the insulation fall below 50°F during the protection period , 24 immediately cover the concrete with canvas and framework or other satisfactory housing 25 and apply heat uniformly at a rate such that the air surrounding the concrete is at least 50°F 26 for the remainder of the protection period .
27 If insulating materials are removed from the concrete before the expiration of the curing 28 period , cure the concrete for the remainder of the period in accordance with 29 Article 420-15 .
30 420-8 CONSTRUCTION JOINTS 31 Provide construction joints only where located in the plans or shown in the placing schedule , 32 unless otherwise approved in writing .
33 Place the concrete in each integral part of the structure continuously .
Do not start work on any 34 such part unless the concrete supply , forces and equipment are sufficient to complete the part 35 without interruption in the placing of the concrete .
36 In case of emergency , make construction joints or remove the concrete as directed .
37 Make construction joints without keys , except when required in the plans .
Rough float surfaces 38 of fresh concrete at horizontal construction joints sufficiently to thoroughly consolidate the 39 concrete at the surface .
40 After placing concrete to the construction joint and before placing fresh concrete , thoroughly 41 clean the entire surface of horizontal and vertical construction joints of surface laitance , curing 42 compound and other materials foreign to the concrete .
Thoroughly clean and wet concrete 43 surfaces for at least 2 hours before placing additional concrete to help bonding .

Cut existing wingwall reinforcing steel off flush with the concrete surface .
2 Thoroughly roughen , clean off loose material and wet connecting surfaces of the old concrete 3 at least 2 hours before placing new concrete .
4 420-10 EXPANSION JOINTS 5 ( A ) General 6 Locate and construct all joints as shown in the plans .
7 Chamfer or edge the edges of joints as shown in the plans or as directed .
8 Immediately after removing the forms , inspect the expansion joint carefully .

10 ( B ) Filled Joints 11 Use cork , bituminous fiber , neoprene or rubber in accordance with Article 1028-1 in all 12 expansion joint material .
Use an optional second layer to obtain the required thickness , 13 when a thickness of more than 1 inch is required .
14 Cut the joint filler to the same shape and size as the area to be covered except cut it 15 1/2 inch below any surface that is exposed to view in the finished work .
As an option , cut 16 the joint filler the same size and shape as that of the adjoining surfaces and neatly cut back 17 the material 1/2 inch on the surfaces that are exposed to view after the concrete hardens .
18 Cut the joint filler out of as few pieces as practical and , except as noted above , completely 19 fill the space provided .
Fasten the pieces in any one joint together in an approved manner .
20 Do not use loose fitting or open joints between sections of filler or between filler and forms .
21 Do not use joints made up with small strips .
Place 2-ply roofing felt over all joints in the 22 filler material in vertical expansion joints below top of curbs .
Place the felt on the side of 23 the joint adjacent to the new pour .
24 In accordance with Article 1028-3 , seal all expansion joints with a low modulus silicone 25 sealant .

5 420-13 ADHESIVELY ANCHORED ANCHOR BOLTS OR DOWELS 6 ( A ) Description 7 The work covered by this section consists of furnishing all necessary labor , equipment and 8 materials and performing all operations necessary for installing anchor bolts/dowels in 9 concrete using an adhesive bonding system in accordance with the details shown in the 10 plans and with Article 1081-2 .
11 The use of adhesive anchors for overhead installments is not permitted .
12 Submit a description of the proposed adhesive bonding system to the Engineer for review , 13 comments and acceptance .
Include in the description the bolt type and its deformations , 14 equipment , manufacturer ’ s recommended hole diameter , embedment depth , material 15 specifications and any other material , equipment or procedure not covered by the contract .
16 List the properties of the adhesive , including density , minimum and maximum temperature 17 application , setting time , shelf life , pot life , shear strength and compressive strength .
If 18 bars/dowels containing a corrosion protective coating are required , provide an adhesive 19 that does not contain any chemical elements that are detrimental to the coating and include 20 a statement to this effect in the submittal concerning the contents as required by Federal or 21 State laws and regulations .
22 ( B ) Procedure 23 ( 1 ) Drilling of Holes into Concrete 24 When directed , use a jig or fixture to ensure the holes are positioned and aligned 25 correctly during the drilling process .
Upon approval , adjusting hole locations to avoid 26 reinforcing steel is permitted .
27 Drill the holes with a pneumatic drill unless another drilling method is approved .
28 Follow the manufacturer ’ s recommendations regarding the diameter of the drilled 29 hole .
30 Immediately after completion of drilling , blow all dust and debris out of the holes with 31 oil-free compressed air using a wand extending to the bottom of the hole .
Remove all 32 dust from the sides of the holes by brushing the holes with a stiff-bristled brush of 33 a sufficient size and then blow the hole free of dust .
Repeat this procedure until the 34 hole is completely clean .
Check each hole with a depth gauge to ensure proper 35 embedment depth .
36 Repair spalled or otherwise damaged concrete using approved methods .
37 ( 2 ) Inspection of Holes 38 Inspect each hole immediately before placing the adhesive and the anchor 39 bolts/dowels .
Ensure all holes are dry and free of dust , dirt , oil and grease .
Rework 40 any hole that does not meet the requirements of the contract .
41 ( 3 ) Mixing of Adhesive 42 Mix the adhesive in strict conformance with the manufacturer ’ s instructions .
43 Section 420 4-35 ( 4 ) Embedment of Anchor Bolt/Dowel 1 Clean each anchor bolt/dowel so it is free of all rust , grease , oil and other contaminants .
2 Unless otherwise shown in the plans , the minimum anchor bolt/dowel embedment 3 depth is such that the adhesive develops at least 125 % of the anchor bolt/dowel yield 4 load as determined by the manufacturer .
5 Installation of the adhesive anchors shall be in accordance with manufacturer ’ s 6 recommendations and shall occur when the concrete is above 40°F and has reached its 7 28 day strength .
The anchors shall be installed before the adhesive ’ s initial set ( gel 8 time ) .
9 Insert the anchor bolt/dowel the specified depth into the hole and slightly agitate it to 10 ensure wetting and complete encapsulation .
After insertion of the anchor bolt/dowel , 11 strike off any excessive adhesive flush with the concrete face .
Should the adhesive 12 fail to fill the hole , add additional adhesive to the hole to allow a flush strike-off .
Do 13 not disturb the anchor bolts/dowels while adhesive is hardening .
14 ( C ) Field Testing 15 When specified in the plans , test the installed anchor bolts/dowels for adequate adhesive 16 as specified below .
Inform the Engineer when the tests will be performed at least 2 days 17 before testing .
Conduct the tests in the presence of the Engineer .
18 Use a calibrated hydraulic centerhole jack system for testing .
Place the jack on a plate 19 washer that has a hole at least 1/8 inch larger than the hole drilled into the concrete .
20 Position the plate washer on center to allow an unobstructed pull .
Position the anchor 21 bolts/dowels and the jack on the same axis .
Ensure an approved testing agency calibrates 22 the jack within 6 months before testing .
Supply the Engineer with a certificate of 23 calibration .
24 In the presence of the Engineer , field test the anchor bolt or dowel in accordance with the 25 test level shown in the plans and the following : 26 ( 1 ) Level 1 Field Testing 27 Test a minimum of 1 anchor but at least 10 % of all anchors to 50 % of the yield load 28 shown in the plans .
If less than 60 anchors are to be installed , install and test the 29 required number of anchors before installing the remaining anchors .
If more than 30 60 anchors are to be installed , test the first 6 anchors before installing the remaining 31 anchors , then test 10 % of the number in excess of 60 anchors .
32 ( 2 ) Level 2 Field Testing 33 Test a minimum of 2 anchors but at least 10 % of all anchors to 80 % of the yield load 34 shown in the plans .
If less than 60 anchors are to be installed , install and test the 35 required number of anchors before installing the remaining anchors .
If more than 36 60 anchors are to be installed , test the first 6 anchors before installing the remaining 37 anchors , then test 10 % of the number in excess of 60 anchors .
38 Testing should begin only after the manufacturer ’ s recommended cure time has been 39 reached .
For testing , apply and hold the test load for 3 minutes .
If the jack experiences 40 any drop in gauge reading , the test shall be restarted .
For the anchor to be deemed 41 satisfactory , the test load shall be held for 3 minutes with no movement or drop in gauge 42 reading .
43 Record data for each anchor bolt or dowel tested on the report form entitled Installation 44 Test Report of Adhesively Anchored Anchor Bolts or Dowels .
Obtain this form from the 45 Department ’ s Materials and Tests Engineer .
Submit a copy of the completed report form 46 to the Engineer .
47 Section 420 4-36 Final acceptance of the adhesively anchored system is based on the conformance of the 1 pull test .
Failure to meet the criteria of this specification is grounds for rejection .
2 Remove all anchors or dowels that fail the field test without damage to the surrounding 3 concrete .
Redrill holes to remove adhesive bonding material residue and clean the hole in 4 accordance with specifications .
For reinstalling replacement anchors or dowels , follow the 5 same procedures as new installations .
Do not reuse failed anchors or dowels unless 6 approved by the Engineer .
7 420-14 PLACING AND FINISHING BRIDGE DECKS 8 ( A ) Placing Concrete 9 Unless otherwise noted in the plans , use Class AA CIP concrete conforming to Section 10 1000 .
When noted in the plans , use sand lightweight concrete conforming to Section 1000 .
11 Place concrete in accordance with these specifications .
Properly vibrate concrete to avoid 12 honeycombs and voids .
Ensure pouring sequences , procedures and mixes are approved by 13 the Engineer .
14 For metal stay-in-place forms , do not place concrete on the forms to a depth greater than 15 12 inches above the top of the forms .
Do not drop concrete more than 3 feet above the top 16 of the forms , beams or girder .
Keep the top surface of prestressed concrete panels clean .
17 Thoroughly inspect panels and remove any foreign matter , oil , grease or other 18 contaminants either with a high pressure water blast or sand blast .
Saturate the top surface 19 of the prestressed concrete panels by thoroughly wetting the top surface with water for at 20 least 2 hours before placing the CIP concrete slab .
Do not allow the wetted panel surface 21 to dry and remove all puddles and ponds of water from the surface of the panels and top of 22 girder flanges before placing the CIP concrete slab .
23 Obtain a smooth riding surface of uniform texture , true to the required grade and cross 24 section , on all bridge decks .
25 Do not place bridge deck concrete until the Engineer is satisfied that adequate personnel 26 and equipment are present to deliver , place , spread , finish and cure the concrete within the 27 scheduled time ; that experienced finishing machine operators and concrete finishers are 28 employed to finish the deck ; and that weather protective equipment and all necessary 29 finishing tools and equipment are on hand at the site of the work and in satisfactory 30 condition for use .
Between April 15 and October 15 , begin placing the bridge deck 31 concrete as early as practical to allow the work to be accomplished during the cooler hours 32 when forms , beams and reinforcing steel are at ambient air temperatures .
33 Unless otherwise permitted , set the rate of concrete placement and use a set retarder such 34 that the concrete remains workable until the entire operation of placing , screeding , 35 rescreeding , surface testing and corrective measures where necessary are complete .
Use 36 of a set retarder is waived when conditions clearly indicate it is not needed .
37 Place concrete in the deck when the concrete temperature at the time of placement is at 38 least 50°F and no more than 90°F , except where other temperatures are required by 39 Article 420-7 .
40 Place concrete at a minimum rate of 35 cubic yards per hour .
41 Place and firmly secure supports for screeds or finishing machines before beginning 42 placement of concrete .
Set supports to elevations necessary to obtain a bridge roadway 43 floor true to the required grade and cross section , and make allowance for anticipated 44 settlement .
Use supports of a type that upon installation , no springing or deflection occurs 45 under the weight of the finishing equipment .
Locate the supports such that finishing 46 equipment operates without interruption over the entire bridge deck .
47 Immediately before placing bridge deck concrete , check all falsework and make all 48 necessary adjustments .
Provide suitable means such as telltales to permit ready 49 Section 420 4-37 measurement by the Engineer of deflection as it occurs .
Unless otherwise permitted , do 1 not adjust the profile grade-line for any of the forming types used .
2 Cast the concrete in accordance with the pour sequence shown in the plans , unless 3 otherwise approved by the Engineer .
Place concrete in a continuous manner between 4 headers .
Use approved screeds , screed supports and screeding methods .
5 ( B ) Finishing 6 Unless otherwise specified or permitted , use self-propelled mechanically operated 7 longitudinal or transverse screeds for finishing bridge deck .
Do not use vibratory screeds 8 unless specifically approved .
Use readily adjustable screeds with sufficient rigidity and 9 width to strike-off the concrete surface at the required grade .
Do not use aluminum strike- 10 off elements of screeds and hand tools used for finishing concrete .
11 Furnish personnel and equipment necessary to verify the screed adjustment and operation 12 before beginning concrete placement .
13 Unless otherwise permitted , do not use longitudinal screeds for pours greater than 85 feet 14 in length .
Place sufficient concrete ahead of the screeded area to assure all dead load 15 deflection occurs before final screeding .
16 When using a transverse screed on a span with a skew angle less than 75° or more than 17 105° , orient and operate the truss or beam supporting the strike-off mechanism parallel to 18 the skew .
Position the strike-off parallel to the centerline of bridge and make the leading 19 edge of concrete placement parallel to the skew .
If approved , operate at a reduced skew 20 angle on very wide or heavily skewed spans where the distance between screed supports 21 exceeds 100 feet .
22 Orient and operate transverse screeds used on spans with skew angles between 75° and 23 105° parallel to the skew or perpendicular to the centerline of bridge .
Position the strike- 24 off parallel to the centerline of bridge .
Before placing concrete , verify the adjustment and 25 operation of the screed as directed by operating the screed over the entire area and across 26 all end bulkheads .
Check the floor thickness and cover over reinforcing steel shown in the 27 plans and make adjustments as necessary .
For crowned decks that are finished on a skew , 28 use the manufacturer ’ s recommended skew correction device and procedures .
29 During the screeding operation , keep an adequate supply of concrete ahead of the screed 30 and maintain a slight excess immediately in front of the screed .
Operate the screed to 31 obtain a substantially uniform surface finish over the entire bridge deck .
Do not allow 32 workmen to walk on the concrete after screeding .
Use at least 2 approved work bridges to 33 provide adequate access to the work for finishing , testing , straightedging , making 34 corrections , fogging , applying curing medium and for other operations requiring access to 35 the bridge deck .
Support the work bridges outside the limits of concrete placement .
36 The Engineer will take random depth checks of deck thickness and cover over reinforcing 37 steel over the entire placement area and directly behind the screed in the fresh concrete .
If 38 depth checks indicate variations from plan dimensions in excess of 1/2 inch , take corrective 39 action immediately .
40 Immediately following the screed and while the concrete is still workable , test the floor 41 surface for irregularities with a 10 foot straightedge .
Test by holding the straightedge in 42 successive positions parallel to the centerline of bridge and in contact with the floor surface .
43 Test the surface approximately 18 inches from the curb line , at the centerline of each lane 44 and at the centerline of 2 lane bridges .
Advance along the bridge in stages of not more than 45 half the length of straightedge .
Test the surface transversely at the ends , quarter points and 46 center of the span as well as other locations as directed .
47 Immediately correct areas showing depressions or high spots of more than 1/8 inch in 48 10 feet by filling depressions with fresh concrete or by striking off high spots .
Make 49 corrections with hand tools or a combination of hand tools and rescreeding .
Do not use the 50 Section 420 4-38 straightedge as a finishing tool .
Give surfaces adjacent to expansion joints special attention 1 to assure they meet the required smoothness .
2 Provide on-site fogging equipment which is capable of applying water to the concrete in 3 the form of a fine fog mist in sufficient quantity to curb the effects of rapid evaporation of 4 mixing water from the concrete on the bridge deck resulting from wind , high temperature , 5 low humidity or a combination of these factors .
Do not apply the moisture from the nozzle 6 under pressure directly upon the concrete and do not allow it to accumulate on the surface 7 in a quantity sufficient to cause a flow or wash the surface .
Maintain responsibility for 8 determining when to apply the fog mist but apply it when directed .
9 Keep readily available on site an adequate supply of suitable coverings that will protect the 10 surface of the freshly placed bridge deck from rain .
After the water sheen disappears from 11 the surface and before the concrete becomes non-plastic , finish the surface of the floor 12 further by burlap dragging , fine bristle brooming , belting or other acceptable method which 13 produces an acceptable uniform texture .
14 Do not use membrane curing compound unless approved .
Cure the concrete using the 15 water method in accordance with Subarticle 420-15 ( B ) , with the following exceptions .
16 Before reaching initial set , place a curing medium consisting of burlap under polyethylene 17 sheets or another approved material on the deck and keep moist for at least 7 curing days .
18 Wet the burlap or other approved curing medium before placing on the deck .
Apply water 19 to the curing medium through soaker hoses or another approved method .
Apply water in 20 amounts to keep the medium moist but do not allow the water to flow or pond on the deck .
21 After curing the concrete , test the finished surface with an approved rolling straightedge 22 designed , constructed and adjusted to accurately indicate or mark all floor areas which 23 deviate from a plane surface by more than 1/8 inch in 10 feet .
Remove all high areas in 24 the hardened surface in excess of 1/8 inch in 10 feet with an approved grinding or cutting 25 machine .
Where variations are such that the corrections will extend below the limits of the 26 top layer of grout , seal the corrected surface with an approved sealing agent as required .
If 27 approved , correct low areas in an acceptable manner .
Produce corrected areas that have a 28 rough , uniform texture and present neat patterns .
In all cases , maintain at least 2 inches of 29 concrete cover over reinforcement .
30 Unless otherwise indicated in the plans , groove bridge decks .
Produce grooves 31 perpendicular to the centerline of bridge .
Do not start grooving until final straightedging 32 and , when necessary , acceptable corrective measures are complete .
Cut grooves into the 33 hardened concrete using a mechanical saw device , which leaves rectangular grooves 34 1/8 inch wide and 3/16 inch deep .
Produce grooves that have a center to center spacing of 35 3/4 inch .
Do not groove the deck surface within 18 inches of the gutter lines and 2 inches 36 of expansion joints or elastomeric concrete in expansion joint blockouts .
On skewed 37 bridges , ungrooved triangular areas adjacent to the joint are permitted , provided the 38 distance from the centerline joint to the nearest groove , as measured parallel to the 39 centerline of roadway , does not exceed 18 inches .
Between expansion joints on 40 horizontally curved bridges , periodically adjust the grooving operation such that adjacent 41 grooves are separated by no more than 3 inches along the outer radius of the bridge deck .
42 Continuously remove all slurry or other residue resulting from the grooving operation from 43 the bridge deck by vacuum pick-up or other approved methods .
Prevent slurry from 44 flowing into deck drains or onto the ground or body of water under the bridge .
Dispose of 45 all residue by an approved method .
46 ( C ) Inspection 47 After the deck concrete is in place for a minimum period of 2 days , test the concrete for 48 soundness and bonding of the metal stay-in-place forms by sounding with a hammer as 49 directed .
For at least 25 % of the individual form panels , as selected by the Engineer , 50 hammer test over the entire area of the panel .
If areas of doubtful soundness are disclosed 51 Section 420 4-39 by this procedure , remove the forms from such areas for visual inspection after the pour 1 attains a minimum compressive strength of 2,400 psi .
Remove the stay-in-place forms .
2 At locations where sections of the forms are removed , do not replace the forms , but repair 3 the adjacent metal forms and supports to present a neat appearance and assure their 4 satisfactory retention .
As soon as the forms are removed , allow the Engineer to examine 5 for cavities , honeycombs and other defects .
If irregularities are found , and in the opinion 6 of the Engineer these irregularities do not justify rejection of the work , repair the concrete 7 as directed .
If the concrete where the forms are removed is unsatisfactory , remove 8 additional forms , as necessary , to inspect and repair the slab .
Modify the methods of 9 construction as required to obtain satisfactory concrete in the slabs .
Remove and repair all 10 unsatisfactory concrete as directed .
11 Provide all facilities as are reasonably required for the safe and convenient conduct of the 12 Engineer ’ s inspection procedures .
13 420-15 CURING CONCRETE 14 ( A ) General 15 Unless otherwise specified in the contract , use any of the following methods except for 16 membrane curing compounds on bridge deck and approach slab , or on concrete which is 17 to receive epoxy protective coating in accordance with Article 420-18 .
Advise the 18 Engineer before using the proposed method .
Ensure all material , equipment and labor 19 necessary to promptly apply the curing are on the site before placing any concrete .
Cure 20 all patches in accordance with this article .
Improperly cured concrete is considered 21 defective .
22 Define “ curing temperature ” as the atmospheric temperature taken in the shade away from 23 artificial heat , with the exception that it is the temperature surrounding the concrete where 24 the concrete is protected in accordance with Article 420-7 .
25 Define a “ curing day ” as any consecutive 24-hour period , beginning when the manipulation 26 of each separate mass is complete , during which the air temperature adjacent to the mass 27 does not fall below 40°F .
28 After placing the concrete , cure it for 7 full curing days .
29 Take all reasonable precautions to prevent plastic shrinkage cracking of the concrete , 30 including the provision of wind screens , fogging , application of an approved temporary 31 liquid moisture barrier or the early application of temporary wet coverings to minimize 32 moisture loss .
33 Repair , remove or replace as directed concrete containing plastic shrinkage cracks .
34 ( B ) Water Method 35 Keep the concrete continuously wet by the application of water , through soaker hoses or 36 another approved method , for a minimum period of 7 curing days after placing the 37 concrete .
38 When using cotton mats , rugs , carpets , earth blankets or sand blankets to retain the 39 moisture , keep the entire surface of the concrete damp by applying water with a nozzle that 40 so atomizes the flow that a mist and not a spray is formed , until the surface of the concrete 41 is covered with the curing medium .
Do not apply the moisture from the nozzle under 42 pressure directly upon the concrete and do not allow it to accumulate on the concrete in a 43 quantity sufficient to cause a flow or wash the surface .
At the expiration of the curing 44 period , clear the concrete surfaces of all curing mediums .
45 Section 420 4-40 ( C ) Membrane Curing Compound Method 1 Spray the entire surface of the concrete uniformly with a curing compound that is on the 2 NCDOT APL .
Use clear curing compound to which a fugitive dye is added for color 3 contrast on bridge superstructures , substructures and retaining walls .
Use either white 4 pigmented or clear curing compound on culverts .
5 Apply the membrane curing compound after the surface finishing is complete and 6 immediately after the free surface moisture disappears .
During the finishing period , protect 7 the concrete by applying water with the fogging equipment specified in Subarticle 420- 8 15 ( B ) .
9 Seal the surface with a single uniform coating of the specified type of curing compound 10 applied at the rate of coverage recommended by the manufacturer or as directed , but at 11 least one gallon per 150 square feet of surface area .
12 At the time of use , thoroughly mix the compound with the pigment uniformly dispersed 13 throughout the vehicle .
If the application of the compound does not result in satisfactory 14 coverage , stop the method and begin water curing , as set out above , until the cause of the 15 defective work is corrected .
16 At locations where the coating shows discontinuities , pinholes or other defects , or if rain 17 falls on the newly coated surface before the film dries sufficiently to resist damage , apply 18 an additional coat of the compound at the same rate specified herein immediately after the 19 rain stops .
20 Completely remove any curing compound adhering to a surface to which new concrete is 21 to be bonded by sandblasting , steel wire brushes , bush hammers or other approved means .
22 Protect the concrete surfaces to which the compound is applied from abrasion or other 23 damage that results in perforation of the membrane film for 7 curing days after placing the 24 concrete .
If the film of membrane compound is damaged or removed before the expiration 25 of 7 curing days , immediately cure the exposed concrete by the water method until the 26 expiration of the 7 curing days or until applying additional curing compound .
27 If the application of curing compound is delayed , immediately start applying water as 28 provided in Subarticle 420-15 ( B ) and continue until resuming or starting application of the 29 compound .
30 ( D ) Polyethylene Sheeting Method 31 Wet the exposed finished surface of concrete with water , using a nozzle that so atomizes 32 the flow to form a mist and not a spray , until the concrete sets , after which place the white 33 opaque polyethylene sheeting .
Continue curing for 7 curing days after the concrete is 34 placed .
If the sheeting is damaged or removed before the expiration of 7 curing days , 35 immediately cure the exposed concrete by the water method until placing additional 36 sheeting or until after 7 curing days .
37 Use sheeting which provides a complete continuous cover of the entire concrete surface .
38 Lap the sheets at least 12 inches and securely weigh down or cement them together to 39 provide a waterproof joint .
40 If any portion of the sheets is broken or damaged before the expiration of the curing period , 41 immediately repair the broken or damaged portions with new sheets properly secured in 42 place .
43 Do not use sections of sheeting damaged to such an extent as to render them unfit for curing 44 the concrete .
45 Section 420 4-41 ( E ) Forms-in-Place Method 1 As an option , cure surfaces of concrete by retaining the forms in place for at least 7 curing 2 days after placing the concrete .
3 If electing to leave forms in place for a part of the curing period and using one of the other 4 methods of curing included in this article for the remainder of the curing period , keep the 5 concrete surfaces wet during transition between curing methods .
6 420-16 REMOVAL OF FORMS AND FALSEWORK 7 Do not remove forms and falsework for the portions of structures listed in Table 420-1 until the 8 concrete attains the compressive strength shown , as evidenced by approved , nondestructive test 9 methods or by conducting compressive strength tests in accordance with AASHTO T 22 and 10 T 23 .
Furnish approved equipment used for nondestructive tests .
11 TABLE 420-1 MINIMUM CONCRETE STRENGTH FOR REMOVAL OF FORMS AND FALSEWORK Portion of Structure Minimum Compressive Strength , psi Bridge Deck Slabs and overhangs for beam and girder bridges 3,000 Arch culverts , top slabs of box culverts , walls of box culverts when cast monolithically with the top slab or when the wall is 10 ft or more in height , caps and struts of substructures , diaphragms and other members subject to dead load bending 2,400 Remove forms for ornamental work , railing , parapets , walls less than 10 feet in height , curb 12 faces on bridge superstructures and vertical surfaces that do not carry loads , any time after 13 3 hours if the concrete is set sufficiently to permit form removal without damage to the member .
14 Do not remove forms used for insulation before the expiration of the minimum protective period 15 required in Article 420-7 .

As an option , to remove support from bent 18 diaphragms before casting deck concrete , submit for approval a method to prevent the 19 possibility of bent diaphragms slipping downward .

23 420-17 SURFACE FINISH 24 ( A ) General 25 Finish all concrete as required by this article except for bridge decks .
Use the type of finish 26 called for in Subarticles 420-17 ( B ) through 420-17 ( D ) , except where the contract requires 27 a Class 1 or Class 2 surface finish .
Apply epoxy protective coating as required by 28 Article 420-18 .
29 ( B ) Ordinary Surface Finish 30 Apply ordinary surface finish to all formed concrete surfaces either as a final finish or 31 preparatory to a higher class finish .
On surfaces backfilled or otherwise covered , or 32 enclosed surfaces , the removal of fins and form marks , the rubbing of grouted areas to 33 a uniform color , and the removal of stains and discoloration , is not required .
Use 34 an ordinary surface finish , unless otherwise required , as final finish on all surfaces .
35 Section 420 4-42 During the placing of concrete , take care to use methods of compaction that result in 1 a surface of even texture free from voids , water or air pockets , and that the coarse aggregate 2 is forced away from the forms to leave a mortar surface .
3 Immediately after removing the forms , clean and fill with grout all pockets , depressions , 4 honeycombs and other defects as directed .
Remove all form ties or metal spacers to a depth 5 of at least 1 inch below the surface of the concrete then clean and fill the resulting holes or 6 depressions with grout .
As an option , break off flush with the concrete surface those metal 7 devices with exposed cross-sectional area not exceeding 0.05 square inches on surfaces 8 permanently in contact with earth fill .
Unless otherwise required , remove fins and other 9 projections flush with the concrete surface .
Remove stains and discoloration .
10 Use grout for patching which contains cement and fine aggregate from the same sources 11 and in the same proportions as used in the concrete .
Cure the grout in accordance with 12 Article 420-15 .
After the grout has thoroughly hardened , rub the surface with 13 a carborundum stone as required to match the texture and color of the adjacent concrete .
14 Obtain the final finish for railing in one of the following ways : 15 ( 1 ) Brush Finish 16 After striking off the concrete as described above , have skilled and experienced 17 concrete finishers thoroughly work and float the surface with a wooden , canvas or cork 18 float .
Before this last finish sets , lightly stroke the surface with a fine brush to remove 19 the surface cement film , leaving a fine grained , smooth , but sanded texture .
20 ( 2 ) Float Finish 21 Finish the surface with a rough carpet float or other suitable device leaving the surface 22 even , but distinctly sandy or pebbled in texture .
23 ( C ) Unformed Surfaces Not Subjected to Wear 24 Finish all unformed surfaces not subjected to wear by placing an excess of material in the 25 forms and removing or striking off such excess with a wooden template , forcing the coarse 26 aggregate below the mortar surface .
Do not use mortar topping for concrete railing caps 27 and other surfaces falling under this classification .
28 ( D ) Sidewalk , Islands or Stairways on Bridges 29 Strike off and compact fresh concrete until a layer of mortar is brought to the surface .
30 Finish the surface to grade and cross section with a float , trowel smooth and finish with 31 a broom .
If water is necessary , apply it to the surface immediately before brooming .
32 Broom transverse to the line of traffic .
33 ( E ) Class 1 Surface Finish 34 In addition to Subarticle 420-17 ( B ) , as soon as the pointing sets sufficiently to permit , 35 thoroughly wet the entire surface with a brush and rub with a coarse carborundum stone or 36 other equally good abrasive , bringing the surface to a paste .
Continue rubbing to remove 37 all form marks and projections , producing a smooth dense surface without pits or 38 irregularities .
39 Carefully spread or brush uniformly over the entire surface the material ground to a paste 40 by rubbing and allowing it to take a reset .
After rubbing , cure the surface for 7 curing days .
41 Obtain the final finish by thoroughly rubbing with a fine carborundum stone or other 42 equally good abrasive .
Continue this rubbing until the entire surface is of a smooth texture 43 and uniform color .
44 ( F ) Class 2 Surface Finish 45 In addition to Subarticle 420-17 ( B ) , after the pointing sets sufficiently to permit , 46 thoroughly wet and rub the entire surface with a coarse carborundum stone or other equally 47 Section 420 4-43 good abrasive to bring the surface to a smooth texture and remove all form marks .
Finish 1 the paste formed by rubbing as described above by carefully stroking with a clean brush , 2 or spread it uniformly over the surface and allow it to take a reset , then finish it by floating 3 with a canvas , carpet-faced or cork float ; or rub down with dry burlap .
4 420-18 EPOXY COATING 5 ( A ) General 6 Use a Type 4A flexible and moisture insensitive epoxy coating in accordance with 7 Section 1081 .
Provide a Type 3 material certification in accordance with Article 106-3 8 showing the proposed epoxy meets Type 4A requirements .
9 ( B ) Surfaces 10 Apply the epoxy protective coating to the top surface area , including chamfer area of bent 11 caps under expansion joints and of end bent caps , excluding areas under elastomeric 12 bearings .
For cored slab and box beam bridges , do not apply the epoxy protective coating 13 to the bent or end bent caps .
14 Use extreme care to keep the area under the elastomeric bearings free of the epoxy 15 protective coating .
Thoroughly clean all dust , dirt , grease , oil , laitance and other 16 objectionable material from the concrete surfaces to be coated .
Air blast all surfaces 17 immediately before applying the protective coating .
18 Use only cleaning agents approved by the Engineer .
19 ( C ) Application 20 Apply epoxy protective coating only when the air temperature is at least 40°F and rising , 21 but less than 95°F and the surface temperature of the area to be coated is at least 40°F , and 22 in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
Remove any excess or free 23 standing water from the surfaces before applying the coating .
Apply one coat of epoxy 24 protective coating at a rate such that it covers between 100 and 200 square feet per gallon .
25 Under certain combinations of circumstances , the cured epoxy protective coating may 26 develop an oily condition on the surface due to amine blush .
This condition is not 27 detrimental to the applied system .
28 Apply the coating so the entire designated surface of the concrete is covered and all pores 29 are filled .
To provide a uniform appearance , use the exact same material on all visible 30 surfaces .
31 420-19 PROTECTION OF SUBSTRUCTURE CONCRETE FROM RUST STAINS 32 To prevent unpainted structural steel from staining substructure concrete , protect all final 33 exposed areas of the concrete from rust stains until casting the bridge deck and sealing the 34 expansion joints .
Use an approved method for protecting the concrete .
35 Instead of the above , remove the stains by approved methods and cleaning agents .

2 Do not pour walls of culverts until floor slabs develop a minimum compressive strength of 3 2,400 psi .
Unless independently supported , do not pour roof slabs of culverts until the concrete 4 in the culvert walls develops a minimum compressive strength of 2,400 psi .
5 Do not operate heavy equipment over any culvert type until properly backfilling with a 6 minimum cover of 3 feet .
7 Adhere to the following time and strength requirements for erection of forms and construction 8 of superimposed bridge substructure elements : 9 ( A ) Wait at least 12 hours between placing footing or Drilled Pier concrete and erecting column 10 forms .

17 Do not place vehicles or construction equipment on a bridge deck until the deck concrete 18 develops the minimum specified 28 day compressive strength and attains an age of at least 19 7 curing days .
The screed may be rolled across a previously cast bridge deck if the entire pour 20 has not achieved initial set .

Construction equipment is allowed on bridge approach slabs after 23 the slab concrete develops a compressive strength of at least 3,000 psi and attains an age of at 24 least 7 curing days .
See Subarticle 420-15 ( A ) for the definition of “ curing day. ” 25 Provide evidence that the minimum compressive strengths referred to above are satisfied by 26 nondestructive test methods approved in writing or by compressive strength tests made in 27 accordance with AASHTO T 22 and T 23 .
Furnish approved equipment for use in 28 nondestructive tests .
29 Do not place construction equipment , materials or other construction loads on any part of the 30 structure without permission .
Submit the proposed plans for placing construction loads on the 31 structure for review , comments and acceptance .
32 Do not abruptly start or stop concrete trucks on bridge deck .
Do not mix concrete in the truck 33 while on the deck .

20 ( B ) Cored Slabs 21 When erecting prestressed cored slabs , place the 0.6 inch diameter transverse post 22 tensioning strands and tension to 43,950 lbs .
in each span .
Grease the transverse strands 23 and place in a non-corrosive 0.6 inch diameter , 1/16 inch minimum wall thickness black 24 polyethylene pipe meeting ASTM D2239 .
Do not apply grease or extend the pipe in the 25 area of the recesses at the ends of the tensioning strands where grout is applied .
Position 26 the jack and tension along the same axis as the strand .
Utilize a double acting jack which 27 tensions the strand and properly seats the wedges after achieving tension .
Monitor slabs 28 during tensioning operation .
If uplift at bearing location occurs at the bearing location , 29 discontinue tensioning and consult the Engineer .
After tensioning the 0.6 inch diameter 30 transverse strand in a span and before placing any equipment , material or barrier rail on the 31 span , fill the shear key , dowel holes and recesses at the ends of transverse strands with an 32 approved Type 3 grout .
33 After tensioning and curing , obtain approval before placing material and equipment on the 34 cored slab spans .
Support cranes or other equipment exceeding the legal load limit on 35 mats .
Submit for review a detailed drawing for the mats that are intended for use on the 36 cored slabs .
Provide a complete description of the equipment that is intended for placement 37 on the mats .
Supply and construct mats at no additional cost to the Department .
38 ( C ) Box Beams 39 The post tensioning system shall use 0.6 inch diameter strands .
Strands shall be tensioned 40 to 43,950 lb .
Strands shall be placed in a non-corrosive 0.6 inch diameter , 1/16 inch 41 minimum wall thickness black polyethylene pipe meeting ASTM D2239 .
42 Grease the strands and place in the polyethylene pipe .
Do not apply grease or extend the 43 pipe in the area of the recesses at the ends of the tensioning strands where grout is applied .
44 Tension the strands in the diaphragm nearest mid-span first .
Proceed to tension strands in 45 the adjacent diaphragms .
Continue the tensioning operation in a symmetric manner along 46 the length of the span .
At each diaphragm location , maintain a symmetric tension force 47 Section 440 4-52 between each pair of strands in the diaphragm .
Position the jack and tension along the same 1 axis as the strand .
Utilize a double acting jack which tensions the strand and properly seats 2 the wedges after achieving the required tension .
Monitor beams during tensioning 3 operation .
If uplift of the slab occurs at bearing location , discontinue tensioning and 4 consult the Engineer .
After all tensioning in a span is completed and before placing any 5 equipment , material or barrier rail on the span , fill the shear key , dowel holes and recesses 6 at the ends of the diaphragm with an approved Type 3 grout .
7 After tensioning and curing , obtain approval before placing material and equipment on the 8 box beam spans .
Support cranes or other equipment exceeding the legal load limit on mats .
9 Submit for review a detailed drawing for the mats that are intended for use on the box 10 beams .
Provide a complete description of the equipment that is intended for placement on 11 the mats .
Supply and construct mats at no additional cost to the Department .

30 440-6 FIELD ERECTION 31 Report immediately any error in the shop fabrication or deformation resulting from handling 32 and transporting , which prevents the proper assembling and fitting up of parts by more than the 33 moderate use of drift pins or by more than a moderate amount of reaming , chipping or cutting .
34 Correct errors in the presence of the Engineer by approved methods .
35 Do not perform hammering which injures or distorts the members .
36 Section 440 4-54 Limit the drifting during assembly to only that needed to bring the parts into position , and not 1 sufficient to enlarge the holes or distort the metal .
If any holes require enlarging to admit the 2 bolts , ream or correct them by approved methods .
Do not enlarge the holes more than 1/16 inch 3 over the nominal size hole called for without written approval .
4 Before assembling the members , clean and dry to touch all bearing surfaces and permanently 5 contacting surfaces .
6 For bolted splices and field connections , fill 25 % of the holes with bolts and 25 % of the holes 7 with cylindrical erection pins , before placing permanent fasteners .
For continuous units , pin 8 and bolt all beam and girder splices and bring the splices to the correct elevations before 9 permanently fastening .
For bolted connections use fit-up bolts and optional shipping bolts with 10 the same nominal diameter as the permanent fasteners , and use cylindrical erection pins which 11 are 1/32 inch larger .
Use permanent bolts as fit-up bolts if desired .
12 Use temporary bolts , including , but not limited to , shipping and fit-up bolts , supplied with 13 square or hexagon heads and square or hexagon nuts .
The use of hexagon head temporary bolts 14 and nuts is allowed , but paint both the head and nut with a durable yellow paint before 15 installation .
16 Do not reuse permanent bolts for final installation unless the nut is easily turned onto the bolt 17 for the full threaded length by hand and without use of tools .
18 The use of erection bolts for field welded joints is allowed .
Use erection bolts that are 19 galvanized when the finish paint is applied in the structural steel fabrication shop and meet 20 ASTM F3125 Grade A325 .
Supplement these bolts with clamps as necessary to meet the 21 AWS Specifications .
Where unpainted AASHTO M 270 Grade 50W structural steel is used , 22 use erection bolts meeting ASTM F3125 A325 .
23 After field welding the connection , leave the erection bolt in place with at least the minimum 24 bolt tension shown in Table 440-1 .
Use holes that are 3/16 inch larger than the nominal erection 25 bolt diameter .
26 440-7 FIELD WELDING 27 Perform field welding only when called for in the plans and in accordance with 28 Article 1072-18 .
29 Remove paint , galvanizing or other coating at the location of field welds by blast cleaning 30 ( SSPC SP-6 finish ) or power tool cleaning to bare metal , ( SSPC SP-11 finish ) just before 31 welding .
Clean sufficiently to bare metal to prevent contamination of the weld by the coating .
32 440-8 CONNECTIONS USING HIGH STRENGTH BOLTS 33 ( A ) General 34 This article covers the assembly of structural joints using plain or galvanized high strength 35 carbon steel bolts with suitable nuts and washers tightened to a high tension .
Use bolt holes 36 that conform to Article 1072-16 .
37 Protect bolts , nuts and washers from moisture during storage and so they show no signs of 38 rust at the time of installation .
39 Make sure that plain bolts and washers have a thin coat of lubricant at the time of 40 installation .
41 Use nuts that are pre-waxed by the producer or supplier before shipping to the project .
42 Apply beeswax , stick paraffin or other approved lubricant to the threads of galvanized bolts 43 just before installing the bolts .
44 Use bolt , nut and washer ( when required ) combinations from the same rotational-capacity 45 lot .
46 Section 440 4-55 Perform the rotational capacity test described in Subarticle 1072-5 ( D ) ( 4 ) on each 1 rotational-capacity lot before the start of bolt installation .
Use hardened steel washers as 2 required by the test .
3 ( B ) Bolted Parts 4 Make sure that the slope of surfaces of bolted parts in contact with the bolt head and nut 5 does not exceed 1:20 with respect to a plane normal to the bolt axis .
Make sure bolted 6 parts fit solidly together when assembled and are not separated by gaskets or any other 7 interposed compressible material .
Provide contact surfaces , including those adjacent to the 8 bolt heads , nuts or washers , that are free of scale , dirt , burrs , oil , lacquer , loose rust , rust 9 inhibitor , other foreign material and other defects that prevent solid seating of the parts .
10 ( C ) Installation 11 ( 1 ) Bolt Tensions 12 Tighten each fastener to provide at least the minimum bolt tension shown in 13 Table 440-1 .
Tighten fasteners with direct tension indicators in accordance with 14 Subarticle 440-8 ( C ) ( 5 ) , or if permitted , by the use of load indicating bolts as provided 15 in Subarticle 440-8 ( C ) ( 3 ) .
16 TABLE 440-1 REQUIRED BOLT TENSION Bolt Size , Inches Minimum Bolt Tension , Pounds 1/2 12,050 5/8 19,200 3/4 28,400 7/8 39,250 1 51,500 1 l/8 64,900 1 1/4 82,400 1 3/8 98,200 1 1/2 119,500 In situations where the nut can not be properly accessed due to lack of clearance , 17 tighten by turning the bolt while preventing the nut from rotating .
Use impact 18 wrenches , if necessary , with adequate capacity and sufficiently supplied with air to 19 perform the required tightening of each bolt in approximately 10 seconds .
20 ( 2 ) Washers 21 Make sure all fasteners have a hardened washer under the element , nut or bolt head , 22 turned in tightening .
Use galvanized washers when galvanized nuts and bolts are 23 required .
As an exception to the above , use special washers for oversize , short-slotted 24 and long-slotted holes in accordance with Subarticle 1072-16 ( H ) .
25 Where an outer face of the bolted parts has a slope of more than 1:20 with respect to 26 a plane normal to the bolt axis , use a smooth beveled washer to compensate for the 27 lack of parallelism .
28 ( 3 ) Load Indicating Bolts 29 Tightening by use of a load indicating bolt system is permitted provided it can be 30 demonstrated by an accurate direct measurement procedure that the bolt is tightened 31 in accordance with Table 440-1 .
Tighten by approved methods and procedures .
32 ( 4 ) Galvanized High Strength Bolts 33 Use mechanically galvanized high strength bolts in all bolted connections for painted 34 structural steel .
35 Section 440 4-56 Install galvanized high strength bolts carefully so shop painted surfaces are not scarred 1 or otherwise damaged .
2 Repair galvanized surfaces that are abraded or damaged by thoroughly wire brushing 3 the damaged area and removing all loose and cracked coating , after which give the 4 cleaned area 2 coats of non-aerosol organic zinc repair paint , in accordance with 5 Article 1076-7 .
6 ( 5 ) Direct Tension Indicators 7 Supply direct tension indicators in accordance with ASTM F959 and Article 1072-5 .
8 Furnish the Engineer with at least two 0.005 inch metal feeler gauges for each 9 container of direct tension indicators shipped before beginning installation .
10 Make sure that the lot number on the containers of direct tension indicators is for the 11 same lot number tested as indicated on the test documents .
12 Furnish to the Engineer 3 samples of load indicating washers from each lot number , 13 each size and type for tests and 2 each of the metal feeler gauges required for 14 performing the tests .
15 Install the direct tension indicator under the bolt head .
If it is necessary to install the 16 direct tension indicator under the nut , or if the bolt head shall be turned , install 17 additional hardened washers between the nut or bolt head and the direct tension 18 indicator .
19 Provide a tension indicating device on the project for determining the tension imposed 20 on a fastener when the protrusions on direct tension indicator are properly compressed .
21 Test 3 samples from each lot of direct tension indicators in the presence of the 22 Engineer .
Achieve a minimum bolt tension of 5 % greater than that required by 23 Table 440-1 of Article 440-8 .
24 Do not substitute direct tension indicators for hardened steel washers required with 25 short slotted or oversized holes .
If desired , use direct tension indicators in conjunction 26 with hardened steel washers .
27 Install direct tension indicators initially to a snug tight condition .
Snug tight is defined 28 as being attained after a few impacts of an impact wrench or the full effort of an 29 ironworker with an ordinary spud wrench .
After initial tightening , fully tighten 30 beginning at the most rigid part of the joint and continuing toward its free edges .
31 For tightening fasteners containing direct tension indicators , use a clean and lubricated 32 wrench .
Maintain air supply and hoses in good condition and provide air pressure of 33 at least 100 psi at the wrench .
34 When tightening the fasteners , ensure that the part of the fastener being restrained from 35 turning does not rotate during the tightening process .
Ensure that no portion of the 36 direct tension indicator protrusions is accidentally partially flattened before installing 37 in the structural steel joints .
38 Do not reuse direct tension indicators .
If it is necessary to loosen a bolt previously 39 tensioned , discard and replace the direct tension indicator .
40 ( D ) Inspection 41 Allow the Engineer the opportunity to observe installation of bolts to determine that the 42 selected tightening procedure is properly used .
The Engineer determines when bolts are 43 properly tightened and in the case of direct tension indicator bolts that the correct indication 44 of tension is achieved .
After properly tightening bolts , make sure that the end of the bolt 45 is flush with or extended beyond the outer face of the nut .
46 Section 440 4-57 Do not begin painting in the area of tightened bolts until after bolt inspection is complete .

14 Item Section Abrasive Materials for Blast Cleaning 1080-6 Paint and Paint Materials 1080 442-3 DEFINITIONS 15 Define “ corner ” as the intersection of 2 surfaces that are not in the same plane .
Define 16 “ inaccessible areas ” as partially or completely enclosed surfaces , the majority of which are not 17 visible without the use of special devices such as mirrors .
Define “ sharp edge ” as a corner on 18 a steel section that ends in a point or edge and appears able to cut human flesh .
Define “ raised 19 weld ” as fillet welds or groove welds that have not been ground flush .
Define “ stripe coat ” as 20 an additional coat of paint applied to the edges , raised welds , outside corners and areas difficult 21 to coat by spray before or after a full coat is applied to the surface .

21 442-7 SURFACE PREPARATION 22 ( A ) Blast Cleaning 23 The blast profile shall be angular and between 1.0 and 3.0 mils when measured on a smooth 24 steel surface .
The degree of cleaning required shall be SSPC SP-10 unless otherwise noted .
25 SSPC VIS-1 shall be used as a visual standard .
In any dispute , the written definition set 26 forth in the SSPC SP-10 standard shall take precedence over reference photographs and 27 comparators shown in SSPC VIS-1 .
28 Check abrasives daily for contaminants or as otherwise directed by the Engineer .
Prior to 29 any surface preparation the Quality Control inspector shall verify that abrasive material 30 meets the cleanliness requirements of SSPC AB-1 , SSPC AB-2 and or SSPC AB-3 31 depending on the abrasive material used .
32 Blast clean by centrifugal or forced air blasters .
When using forced air blasters use blast 33 nozzles with a minimum 5/16 '' orifice and operate at no less than 100 psi when measured 34 with a needle gauge at the nozzle .
Use dry blasting for all blast cleaning .
Select a size or 35 grade of abrasive that provides the specified finish and profile meeting Article 1080-6 .
36 Perform blast cleaning operations so no damage is done to partially or entirely completed 37 portions of the work .
38 After blasting , brush the surface with clean brushes made of hair , bristle or fiber ; blow off 39 with compressed air ; or clean by vacuum so any traces of blast products from the surface 40 and any abrasive from pockets and corners are removed .
Perform surface inspection once 41 all blast abrasive and dust is removed from surface to be coated .
42 Use compressed air for nozzle blasting that is free of detrimental amounts of water or oil .
43 Provide adequate separators and traps .
Verify cleanliness of air before blasting operations 44 in accordance with ASTM D4285 .
45 Examine the blast cleaned surface for any traces of oil , grease or smudges deposited in the 46 cleaning operations .
If present , remove them by SSPC SP-1 or an approved method .
47 Section 442 4-60 Ensure the degree of cleanliness and profile are approved before painting .
Verify the 1 removal of oil and grease in accordance with ASTM F22 .
2 Seal all journals , bearings , motors and moving parts to the Engineer ’ s satisfaction against 3 entry of abrasive dust before blast cleaning near bridge machinery .
4 Prime all blast cleaned surfaces to be painted no later than 8 hours after blast cleaning is 5 complete .
Re-clean the cleaned surfaces that contain rust or are contaminated with foreign 6 material before painting or bolting to the original surface preparation specifications .
7 ( B ) Hand or Power Tool Cleaning 8 Thoroughly remove loose paint , rust , scale , dirt , oil , grease and other detrimental 9 substances by hand cleaning ( SSPC SP-2 ) , power tool cleaning ( SSPC SP-3 ) or any 10 combination of these methods .
Hand cleaning includes the use of metal brushes , grinders , 11 sanders or any approved combination of these tools .
Use bristle or wood fiber brushes to 12 remove loose dust .
13 442-8 PAINT SYSTEMS 14 Department approved paint systems are found in the Structural Steel Shop Coatings Program .
15 Use all paints and solvents for shop and field application that are produced by the same 16 manufacturer .
17 Use approved/qualified paint products found in Section 1080 .
Apply the paint system required 18 by the plans .
19 442-9 APPLICATION OF PAINT 20 ( A ) General 21 Unless otherwise permitted , apply all paint by spraying , except apply the stripe coat by 22 brush or roller .
The use of a brush or roller is permitted to make minor repairs to the primer .
23 Make sure each coat of paint is in a proper state of cure or dryness before applying the 24 succeeding coat .
25 Before successive coating application remove all contaminates , dry spray/overspray , paint 26 splatter and other non-adherent paint shall be removed before applying successive coating 27 layers .
When necessary , clean each coat of paint in accordance with Subarticle 442-7 ( B ) .
28 When a stripe coat is required , apply a 2 inch stripe by brush or roller to all exposed edges 29 of steel before applying the finish coat .
Locate the edge or corner in the approximate center 30 of the paint stripe .
31 Mechanically or hot dip-galvanized fasteners that exhibit damage during installation or 32 coating operations shall be spot primed with a Department approved zinc rich coating 33 compatible with subsequent coatings .
34 If personnel performing the coating operations does not exhibit reasonable conformance to 35 protect the work during application , storage and/or construction , the Engineer may require 36 a finish coat at no additional cost to the Department .
The final acceptances of all repairs , 37 to include aesthetics , will be approved at the Engineer ’ s discretion .
38 ( B ) Application Conditions 39 Unless the paint manufacturer 's application instructions are more restrictive , obtain written 40 permission to apply paint if the following conditions exist : temperature of the air or metal 41 is not at least 40°F and rising for inorganic zinc primers or 50°F and rising for acrylic paint 42 or coal tar epoxies , when freezing weather is forecast during the drying period , or when 43 the metal is hot enough to cause the paint to blister or produce a porous paint film .
44 Section 442 4-61 Do not apply paint or perform any surface preparation without the Engineer ’ s approval 1 when the air is misty ; in the rain , snow , fog , when wind velocity is continuously greater 2 than 10 mph or when the steel surface temperature is less than 5°F above the dew point .
3 The humidity shall be less than 85 % and lower when applying acrylic paints or until the 4 paint is dry and/or cured or until weather conditions permit its exposure in the open .
5 Obtain written permission from the Engineer to apply field coats of paint between 6 November 15 of one year and April 15 of the following year inclusive .
Do not apply any 7 coating above or below the manufacturers recommended application temperatures or 8 during a period when an ambient temperature outside the recommended range is predicted 9 during the drying and curing period of the paint .
10 Harsh environments as determined by the Engineer may necessitate re-cleaning during or 11 between paint applications .
12 ( C ) Storage Conditions 13 Provide adequate and safe storage for all paint and equipment .
Do not expose paint 14 materials to rain , excessive condensation , long periods of direct sunlight or temperatures 15 above 110°F or below 40°F .
Follow the manufacturer 's storage requirements if more 16 restrictive .
In addition , the Quality Control inspector shall place a device which records the 17 high , low and current temperatures inside the storage location and maintain a daily record 18 and made available to the Engineer .
Replace paint damaged by any cause .
19 Coating material shall arrive at the coating facility in sealed containers clearly marked with 20 the type , batch and/or lot numbers properly labeled on the container .
There shall be no 21 modification of the coating except upon and in accordance with the express written 22 stipulation by an authorized representative of the coating manufacturer and with specific 23 approval of the Engineer .
At the Department ’ s option , the inspector may randomly collect 24 a sample of the coating used on the project if the material has been exposed to extremely 25 high/low temperatures and/or exhibits excessive skinning in the container .
26 ( D ) Mixing Paint 27 Mix paint in accordance with the manufacturer 's instructions and Article 1080-1 .
Do not 28 mix partial kits .
29 ( E ) Thinning 30 Thinning of zinc and coal tar products shall be in accordance with the coating 31 manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
For acrylic applications , there shall be no thinning of 32 coating products .
The paint products specified in Section 1080 do not require thinning 33 when applied under normal conditions .
Obtain written approval for any thinning 34 necessitated by weather conditions or other causes .
Only those thinners approved by the 35 paint manufacturer as described in the application instructions are permitted .
36 ( F ) Spray Application 37 Use equipment for spray application of paint that is suitable for the intended purpose , 38 capable of properly atomizing the paint , and equipped with suitable pressure regulators and 39 gauges .
Use air caps , nozzles and needles recommended by the manufacturer of the 40 equipment for the material being sprayed .
Keep the equipment in satisfactory condition to 41 permit proper paint application .
In closed or recirculating paint spray systems where gas 42 under pressure is used over the liquid , use an inert gas , such as nitrogen .
43 Provide and drain periodically during operations .
Use adequately sized traps or separators 44 to remove oil and water from the compressed air .
Make sure that the air from the spray 45 gun impinging against the surface shows no water or oil .
46 Use a continuously agitated spray pot .
Adjust the agitator to reach within 2 inches of the 47 bottom of the spray pot and be in motion at all times during paint application .
Provide 48 sufficient motion to keep the paint well mixed .
49 Section 442 4-62 ( G ) Stripe Coat 1 When a stripe coat is required , apply a 2 inch stripe by brush or roller to all exposed edges 2 of steel before applying the finish coat .
Locate the edge or corner in the approximate center 3 of the paint stripe .
Brush apply stripe coat application on bolts , nuts , raised welds and other 4 obstructed locations .
Roller apply stripe coat only on structural shape edges .
5 442-10 SHOP PAINTING 6 Shop painting is the painting of structural steel in an enclosed shop or plant before shipment to 7 the site of erection .
Use only NCDOT approved shop coating facilities meeting the 8 requirements outlined in the current edition of the Structural Steel Shop Coatings Program .
9 This program is available on the Materials and Tests website .
The work in this section applies 10 to previously uncoated steel and includes the proper preparation of the metal surfaces and the 11 application , protection and cure/drying of coatings .
Complete all shop fabrication , including 12 welding and attachment of shear connectors , before painting is started .
13 442-11 THERMAL SPRAYED COATINGS 14 Thermal sprayed coatings ( TSC ) and sealer are those coatings applied to metal surfaces in a 15 shop environment .
Use only NCDOT approved shop coating facilities meeting the 16 requirements outlined in the current edition of the Thermal Sprayed Coatings ( Metallization ) 17 Program .
This program is available on the Materials and Tests website .
18 442-12 FIELD PAINTING 19 ( A ) General 20 Field painting is conducted after erection , or when damage to a shop applied coating system 21 is repaired or when steel is otherwise painted outside an enclosed shop environment .
The 22 Structural Steel Shop Coatings Program shall be considered in conjunction with the Project 23 Special Provisions for field applications .
24 Pre-construction meetings as determined by the Engineer may be required prior to 25 beginning field painting operations .
26 When blast cleaning structures open to traffic , provide suitable protective enclosures to 27 prevent damage to public and private property .
Do not blast directly over traffic without 28 prior approval of the Engineer .
If the containment system is not effective in restricting 29 blasting emissions , blasting operations shall cease and deficiencies corrected before work 30 resuming .
