35 Disposal of construction materials to include but not limited to paint products , abrasives 36 and wash water shall be in accordance with all current Federal and State regulations .
Refer 37 to NCDOT Guidelines for Managing Bridge Wash Water .
38 Do not apply paint over traffic without prior written approval from the Engineer .
39 Touch-up of painted steel consists of painting with primer and finish paint over all the 40 previously uncoated exposed metal surfaces .
When the repair area exceeds one square 41 foot , clean , prime and topcoat damaged areas in accordance with Subarticle 442-7 ( A ) ; 42 otherwise , clean , prime and topcoat damaged areas in accordance with Subarticle 442-7 ( B ) .
43 For systems with shop applied topcoats , apply an additional field appearance coat of finish 44 paint to the outside surface of all exterior beams on steel bridges over highways and 45 navigable waterways .
46 Section 442 4-63 When an appearance coat of finish paint is required , paint the portion of galvanized high 1 strength bolts on the outside face of exterior beams or girders with primer and appearance 2 coat of the finish paint .
Apply the primer to the galvanized high strength bolts by brush , 3 so the primer is not applied to the adjacent finish paint .
4 At the location of field welds , satisfactorily remove all paint or galvanizing in accordance 5 with SSPC SP-6 ( Commercial Blast Cleaning ) or SSPC SP-11 ( Power Tool Cleaning to 6 Bare Metal ) .
The surface profile after cleaning and prior to coating application shall be a 7 minimum of 1.0 mil .
8 Final acceptance by the Engineer will be after erection of the structure , when the final coat 9 has been applied , and all repairs effected .
10 Clean all contaminants such as soil , concrete , weld splatter , grease or any other deleterious 11 material from the steel or shop coated surfaces before any painting operations begin .
Harsh 12 environments may necessitate re-cleaning during or between paint applications .

26 442-13 PREPARATION FOR PAINTING GALVANIZED SURFACES 27 When painting galvanized surfaces is required in the plans , smooth , clean and prepare in 28 accordance with Section 1080 and this section .
Provide shop certification in accordance with 29 Structural Steel Shop Coatings Program ( Shop facilities that are currently certified and in good 30 standing with the American Institute Steel Construction ( AISC ) /Sophisticated Paint 31 Endorsement ( SPE ) and/or the Society of Protective Coatings ( SSPC ) Qualification Procedure 32 Three ( QP-3 ) .
33 Do not paint portions of galvanized piles encased in concrete below ground .
34 Prior to coating operations submit for review and approval to the Engineer the specific 35 procedure to be utilized for this work .
This procedure at a minimum shall address the surface 36 preparation outlined below and meet the ASTM D6386 standard .
37 Smooth high spots and rough edges , such as metal drip lines , of galvanized surfaces in 38 accordance with ASTM D6386 .
Clean galvanized surfaces to be painted with a 2,500 psi 39 pressure washer .
Allow surfaces to dry completely before beginning surface preparation .
40 Prepare galvanized surfaces to be painted by sweep blasting in accordance with ASTM D6386 .
41 Use an abrasive material and technique that roughens the surface while leaving base zinc layers 42 intact .
After sweep blasting , blow down blasted surfaces with clean , dry , compressed air free 43 of contamination .
44 Apply paint to clean , dry surfaces free of visible zinc oxides or zinc hydroxides within 8 hours 45 of surface preparation .

24 450-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 25 ( A ) Handling and Storing Piles 26 Handle , transport and store piles so piles are kept clean and undamaged .
Do not use chains , 27 cables or hooks that can damage or scar piles .
Do not damage coatings on steel piles .
28 When handling prestressed concrete piles , support piles at pick-up points shown in the 29 plans .
30 Protect steel piles from corrosion .
Store piles above ground upon platform skids , or other 31 supports , and keep free from dirt , grease , vegetation and other foreign material .
32 ( B ) Pile Installation 33 If applicable , completely excavate for caps or footings before installing piles .
If applicable 34 and unless noted otherwise in the plans , construct embankments to bottom of cap or footing 35 Section 450 4-66 elevations for a horizontal distance of 50 feet from any pile except where fill slopes are 1 within 50 feet of a pile .
2 Install piles with the following tolerances : 3 ( 1 ) Axial alignment within 1/4 in/ft of vertical or batter shown in the plans , 4 ( 2 ) Horizontal alignment within 3 inches of plan location , and 5 ( 3 ) Pile embedment within 3 inches more and 2 inches less of the embedment shown in 6 the plans .
7 If necessary , build up prestressed concrete piles or splice steel piles as shown in the plans .
8 Do not use more than 3 sections ( 2 splices ) of steel piling per pile .
Cut off piles at required 9 elevations along a plane normal to the axis of the pile as necessary .
Do not damage or spall 10 piles when cutting off prestressed concrete piles .
11 ( C ) Pile Accessories 12 When required , use pile accessories including pipe pile plates and steel pile points and 13 splicers shown in the plans .
Weld pipe pile plates to steel pipe piles as shown in the plans .
14 Attach steel pile points to steel piles in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s instructions .
15 Weld a minimum length of twice the flange width for steel H-piles .
16 Use steel pile tips with prestressed concrete piles as shown in the plans .
Use steel pile 17 splicers for splicing steel H-pile tips and composite piles .
Attach steel pile splicers in 18 accordance with the manufacturer ’ s instructions .
19 ( D ) Driven Piles 20 Do not drive piles within 50 feet of CIP concrete until the concrete cures for at least 3 days .
21 Do not use vibratory hammers to install prestressed concrete piles .
22 When predrilling , spudding and installing the initial portions of steel piles with vibratory 23 hammers , submit these pile installation methods with the proposed pile driving methods 24 and equipment for acceptance .
Define “ spudding ” as driving or dropping a steel H-pile 25 and then removing it .
The Engineer will approve the spudding depth and H-pile size , 26 predrilling depth and diameter and depth of pile installation with a vibratory hammer .
27 Limit driving stresses in accordance with the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design 28 Specifications .
Use AASHTO driving stress limits for severe corrosive environments when 29 calcium nitrite corrosion inhibitor is required for prestressed concrete piles .
If a tip 30 elevation is noted in the plans , drive steel and prestressed concrete piles to the minimum 31 required driving resistance and tip elevation .
Otherwise , drive steel and prestressed 32 concrete piles to the minimum required driving resistance and at least 10 feet into natural 33 ground .
Drive composite piles to the minimum required driving resistance and the 34 prestressed concrete and steel H-pile sections to their respective minimum required tip 35 elevations noted in the plans .
36 Drive piles continuously to the required pile penetration unless stopped due to exceeding 37 the maximum blow count or driving stresses , insufficient pile length or other approved 38 reasons .
Redrive piles raised or moved laterally due to driving adjacent piles .
39 Protect coatings in an approved manner when driving coated steel piles through templates .
40 Repair damaged galvanizing in accordance with Article 1076-7 .
41 Section 450 4-67 ( 1 ) Predrilling and Spudding 1 If necessary or required , perform predrilling and spudding as noted in the plans and in 2 accordance with the accepted submittals .
Predrill pile locations to elevations noted in 3 the plans or approved by the Engineer .
When noted in the plans and at the Contractor ’ s 4 option , spudding may be used instead of predrilling .
Do not perform spudding below 5 predrilling elevations noted in the plans or approved by the Engineer .
6 When noted in the plans or predrilling in water or wetlands , use temporary steel 7 casings that meet Subarticle 450-3 ( E ) ( 1 ) , except use steel casings with inside 8 diameters no more than 2 inches larger than predrilling diameters .
Use temporary 9 casings from at least 2 feet above the static water elevation or ground line , whichever 10 is higher , to at least 5 feet below the ground or mud line .
More than 5 feet embedment 11 may be necessary if temporary casings are not stable or predrilling or spudding 12 disturbs material outside casings .
13 Perform predrilling and spudding so spoils are minimized , large ground movements 14 and voids below ground do not occur and piles can be driven to the required resistance 15 and pile penetration .
Do not deposit spoils in water or wetlands .
Remove all 16 temporary casings before driving piles .
17 ( 2 ) Driving Equipment 18 Submit the proposed pile driving methods and equipment ( pile driving equipment data 19 form ) including the pile driving hammer , hammer cushion , pile helmet and cushion 20 for all piles for acceptance in accordance with Article 105-2 .
Do not submit more than 21 2 pile driving hammers per pile type per submittal .
Provide 2 copies of each data form 22 at least 30 days before driving piles .
All equipment is subject to satisfactory field 23 performance .
24 Drive piles with accepted driving equipment and operate pile driving hammers in 25 accordance with the manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
Use hammers that will not 26 overstress piles and attain the required driving resistance between 30 and 180 blows 27 per foot .
Use variable energy hammers to drive prestressed concrete piles .
28 Operate air and steam hammers within 10 % of the manufacturer 's rated speed or a rate 29 approved by the Engineer .
Use a plant and equipment for air or steam hammers with 30 sufficient capacity to maintain , under working conditions , the manufacturer ’ s 31 recommended volume and pressure .
Equip the plant and equipment with accurate 32 pressure gauges that are easily accessible .

and one-third the pile helmet and pile weight .
34 Equip open-end ( single acting ) diesel hammers with a graduated scale ( jump stick ) 35 extending above the ram cylinder , graduated rings or grooves on the ram or an electric 36 sound activated remote measuring instrument to determine the hammer stroke during 37 driving .

42 The Engineer may inspect the hammer cushion before beginning and occasionally 43 during driving .

2 ( 3 ) Required Driving Resistance 3 The Engineer will determine if the proposed pile driving methods and equipment are 4 acceptable and provide the blows per foot and equivalent set for the required driving 5 resistance noted in the plans , i.e. , “ pile driving criteria ” except for structures with pile 6 driving analyzer ( PDA ) testing .
For structures with PDA testing , provide pile driving 7 criteria for any bents and end bents with piles in accordance with Subarticle 450- 8 3 ( F ) ( 4 ) .
9 Stop driving piles when refusal is reached .
Define “ refusal ” as 240 blows per foot or 10 any equivalent set .
11 ( 4 ) Restriking and Redriving Piles 12 After reaching the required pile penetration , the Contractor may choose to or the 13 Engineer may require the Contractor to stop driving , wait and restrike or redrive piles 14 to attain the required driving resistance .
When the Engineer requires restrikes or 15 redrives , the Engineer will determine the number of restrikes or redrives and the time 16 to wait after stopping driving and between restrikes and redrives .
The time to wait 17 will range from 4 to 24 hours .
18 Use the same pile driving methods , equipment and compressed pile cushion from the 19 previous driving to restrike or redrive piles unless the cushion is unacceptable due to 20 deterioration .
Do not use cold diesel hammers for restrikes or redrives , unless it is 21 impractical to do otherwise as determined by the Engineer .
In general , warm up 22 hammers by applying at least 20 blows to a previously driven pile or timber mats on 23 the ground .
24 ( E ) Drilled-in Piles 25 Perform pile excavation to elevations shown in the plans or approved by the Engineer .
26 Excavate holes at pile locations with diameters that will result in at least 3 inches of 27 clearance all around piles .
Before filling holes , support and center piles in excavations and 28 when noted in the plans , drive piles to the required driving resistance .
Remove any fluids 29 from excavations and , at the Contractor ’ s option , fill holes with concrete , grout or flowable 30 fill unless required otherwise in the contract .
31 ( 1 ) Pile Excavation 32 Use equipment with sufficient capacity to drill through soil , rock , boulders , timbers , 33 man-made objects and any other materials encountered .

Drilling spoils consist of all materials and fluids removed from pile 37 excavations .
38 If unstable , caving or sloughing soils are anticipated or encountered , use slurry or 39 temporary steel casings to stabilize holes .

When using temporary casings , use smooth non- 43 corrugated clean watertight steel casings of ample strength to withstand handling and 44 installation stresses and pressures imposed by concrete , earth , backfill and fluids .
Use 45 steel casings with an outside diameter equal to the hole size and a wall thickness of at 46 least 1/4 inch .

Define “ not in soil ” as 19 material with a rock auger penetration rate of less than 2 inches per 5 minutes of drilling at full 20 crowd force .
When not in soil is encountered , seams , voids and weathered rock less than 3 feet 21 thick with a rock auger penetration rate of greater than 2 inches per 5 minutes of drilling at full 22 crowd force will be paid at the contract unit price for Pile Excavation Not in Soil .
Seams , voids 23 and weathered rock greater than 3 feet thick will be paid at the contract unit price for Pile 24 Excavation in Soil where not in soil is no longer encountered .
The contract unit prices for Pile 25 Excavation in Soil and Pile Excavation Not in Soil will be full compensation for stabilizing and 26 filling holes with concrete , grout or flowable fill .
27 PDA Testing will be measured and paid in units of each .
PDA Testing will be measured as one 28 per pile .
The contract unit price for PDA Testing will be full compensation for performing PDA 29 testing the first time a pile is tested , performing CAPWAP analysis on data collected during 30 initial drive , restrikes and redrives , providing PDA reports , performing GRLWEAP analysis 31 and developing and providing pile driving criteria .

Furnish and apply 30 all asphalt , tar , fabric , asphalt plank and any other materials .
31 458-2 MATERIALS 32 Refer to Division 10 .
33 Item Section Asphalt Binder 1020-7 ( B ) Asphalt Primer 1020-7 ( A ) Tar 1020-7 ( C ) Woven Cotton Fabric 1020-7 ( D ) 458-3 METHOD A WATERPROOFING 34 ( A ) General 35 Method A waterproofing consists of one coat of asphalt primer , and 3 mop coats of hot 36 asphalt cement with 2 layers of cotton fabric alternating between the mop coats .
37 Section 458 4-83 ( B ) Preparation of Surface 1 Ensure that concrete surfaces are dry , reasonably smooth and free from projections or holes 2 which are capable of puncturing the membrane .
Immediately before applying the 3 waterproofing , thoroughly clean the surface of dust and loose materials .
4 Make sure that the concrete is at least 14 days old for Class A concrete , at least 10 days old 5 for Class AA concrete , or at least 7 days old for high early strength concrete , before 6 beginning waterproofing .
Do not waterproof in wet weather nor when the temperature is 7 below 35°F , without permission .
8 ( C ) Application 9 Give waterproofed surfaces a thorough coat of asphalt primer , and allow it to set thoroughly 10 before applying the first mop coat .
Heat the asphalt cement for the mop coat to a 11 temperature of at least 300°F and frequently stir to avoid local overheating .
Equip the 12 heating kettles with thermometers .
13 Begin the waterproofing at the low point of the surface .
14 Use a half width first strip of fabric ; and a full width second strip .
Lap the full width of 15 the first strip .
Make the third and each succeeding strip full width and lap so there are 16 2 layers of fabric at all points with laps at least 2 inches wide .
Make sure that the end laps 17 are at least 12 inches .
18 Beginning at the low point of the surface , mop a section about 20 inches wide and the full 19 length of the surface with hot asphalt cement .
Immediately roll the first strip of fabric into 20 the asphalt cement and press into place to eliminate all air bubbles and to provide a firm 21 bond to the surface .
Mop this strip and an adjacent section of the surface of a width equal 22 to slightly more than half the width of the fabric with hot asphalt binder and roll a full 23 width of the fabric into this cement , completely covering the first strip , and press into place .
24 Mop this second strip and an adjacent section of the concrete surface with hot asphalt 25 cement and place the third strip of fabric to lap the first strip at least 2 inches .
Continue 26 this process until the entire surface is covered , each strip of fabric lapping at least 2 inches 27 over the second preceding strip .
Give the entire surface a final mopping of hot asphalt 28 cement .
29 Mop on concrete to completely cover the surface sufficiently heavy on cloth to completely 30 conceal the weave .
Use at least 12 gallons of asphalt on horizontal surfaces for each 31 100 square feet of finished work and at least 15 gallons on vertical surfaces .
Perform the 32 work so , at the close of a day 's work , all laid cloth receives the final mopping of asphalt .
33 Thoroughly seal down all laps .
34 ( D ) Special Requirements 35 At the edges of the membrane and at any points punctured by such appurtenances as drains 36 or pipes , make suitable provisions to prevent water from getting between the waterproofing 37 and the waterproofed surface .
38 Place all membrane flashing at curbs and against girders , spandrel walls , etc. , with separate 39 sheets of membrane lapping the main membrane at least 12 inches .
Closely seal flashing 40 with either a metal counter-flashing or by embedding the upper edges of the flashing in a 41 groove poured full of joint filler .
42 Provide expansion joints , both horizontal and vertical , with water stops and premolded 43 joint filler as called for in the plans .
Seal expansion joints in the face adjacent to the 44 membrane bituminous material .
Carry the membrane continuously across all expansion 45 joints .
46 At the ends of the structure carry the membrane well down on the abutments and make 47 suitable provisions for all movement .
48 Section 460 4-84 ( E ) Repairs 1 Repair any damage that occurs as directed .
Repair by patching when permitted .
Extend 2 the first ply of the patch at least 12 inches beyond the outermost damaged portion of the 3 membrane and extend the second ply at least 3 inches beyond the first .
4 ( F ) Backfilling 5 Do not backfill without permission and until the final mop coat thoroughly hardens .
Place 6 backfill so the waterproofing is not damaged .
7 458-4 METHOD B DAMP PROOFING 8 ( A ) General 9 Method B dampproofing consists of 2 coats of tar , Grade RT 6 .
10 ( B ) Preparation of Surface 11 Make sure the surfaces are dry .
Immediately before applying the first dampproofing coat , 12 thoroughly clean the surfaces of dust and loose materials .
Permit the concrete to cure for 13 at least 14 days for Class A concrete , at least 10 days for Class AA concrete or 7 days for 14 high early strength concrete before dampproofing .
15 ( C ) Application 16 Give the concrete surfaces 2 applications of tar , Grade RT 6 .
Apply the tar with suitable 17 brushes to secure uniform and thorough applications .
Do not apply the second coat of tar 18 until the first coat thoroughly sets .
Do not apply dampproofing during any time that the 19 surface is exposed to any moisture .
Make sure that the temperature of the tar is such that 20 uniform and thorough application is obtained .
Do not backfill until the second coat 21 thoroughly sets .

Dry or add moisture 2 to the subgrade when required to provide a uniformly compacted and acceptable 3 subgrade .
4 Where the subgrade is to be stabilized with lime , aggregate or cement , the above density 5 requirements will not apply before the incorporation of the stabilizing material ; however , 6 perform compaction in accordance with Articles 501-10 , 510-3 or 542-9 , as appropriate .

Prepare the soil layer to be stabilized ; haul , proportion , spread and mix the materials 7 within the depth range as shown on plans ; manipulate , compact and finish the lime-treated 8 soil ; correct , repair and maintain the lime-treated soil ; and apply a sand seal in accordance 9 with the requirements of Article 501-3 .

11 501-2 MATERIALS 12 Refer to Division 10 .
13 Item Section Lime 1052-3 Water 1024-4 Use soil material which consists of material upon which the pavement is to be placed , existing 14 material upon which the embankment is to be placed , approved borrow material or 15 a combination of these materials proportioned as directed .
Remove all vegetation , roots or 16 other objectionable matter from the soil , as well as all aggregate or stone larger than 2 inches 17 for the full depth to be treated .
18 501-3 LIMITATIONS 19 Do not perform lime stabilization when the air temperature is below 45°F .
Do not mix the 20 lime with frozen soils or when the soils contain frost .
Apply lime to such areas as can be 21 initially mixed and sealed during the day of application .
Do not apply lime when wind 22 conditions are such that blowing lime becomes hazardous to traffic , workers or adjacent 23 property owners or when excessive loss of lime may occur .
24 Do not construct lime-treated soil that will not be covered with a layer of pavement or base by 25 December 1 of that same calendar year .
The Engineer may suspend the lime stabilization 26 operations in writing when he determines that the Contractor will not cover the completed 27 stabilization by December 1 as specified above .
28 Failure of the Contractor to cover the lime-treated soil as required will result in the Engineer 29 notifying the Contractor in writing to cover the lime-treated soil with a sand seal .
Apply the 30 sand seal in accordance with Section 660 , except Articles 660-3 and 660-12 will not apply .
If 31 the Contractor fails to apply the sand seal within 72 hours after receipt of such notice , the 32 Engineer may proceed to have such work performed by other forces and equipment .
The 33 application of the sand seal by the Contractor or other forces will in no way relieve the 34 Contractor of the responsibility to maintain or repair the damaged stabilization , no matter 35 what the cause of damage , at no cost to the Department .
36 501-4 EQUIPMENT 37 ( A ) General 38 Use any combination of machines and equipment to produce the required results that meet the 39 approval of the Engineer .
Correct any leakage of fluids or materials promptly or the Engineer 40 may order such equipment removed and replaced with satisfactory equipment .
Use 41 equipment and methods for applying lime , water , curing seal and blotting sand that will not 42 damage the base and in accordance with Article 107-21 .
43 Section 501 5-4 ( B ) Lime Spreaders 1 Spread lime at the required rate by methods and equipment which have been approved .
2 ( C ) Water Distribution Equipment 3 Add water to the soil with a pressure distributor or other suitable equipment capable of 4 uniformly distributing the required amount .
5 ( D ) Mixers 6 Perform mixing with a self-propelled rotary mixer , except that disc harrows , motor 7 graders and other equipment may be used only to supplement the mixing done by the 8 rotary mixer .
9 Use mixing equipment capable of mixing to a compacted depth of at least 10 inches .
10 ( E ) Compaction Equipment 11 Use compaction equipment that is self-propelled .
Perform finish rolling with a pneumatic 12 tired roller , or as permitted , a smooth , steel-wheel roller or a combination of both types .
13 ( F ) Scarifying Equipment 14 Use a grader-scarifier for the initial scarification of the soil .
Use equipment capable of 15 scarifying to the full depth of the stabilized treatment .
When required , use a weeder , 16 spiketooth harrow or nail drag , followed by a broom drag to scarify during finishing 17 operations .
18 501-5 PROTECTION AND SAFETY 19 Take necessary precautions to protect personnel from dust created by the lime application and 20 mixing operation to include eye protection , dust masks and appropriate training .
21 501-6 PREPARATION OF ROADBED 22 Before the addition of any lime to the soil , grade and shape the area to be stabilized in 23 accordance with the typical sections , lines and grades shown on the plans .
Remove all 24 materials such as aggregate larger than 2 inches , roots and turf .
25 501-7 SCARIFYING 26 When required by the method of application , scarify the soil to the required depth and width 27 and then partially pulverize by making one pass through the area with a pulverizing rotary 28 mixer .
Delete the pulverizing portion of the scarifying operation in areas where the soil types 29 or conditions make pulverizing with a rotary mixer impractical .
30 501-8 APPLICATION OF LIME 31 ( A ) General 32 When the Contractor has brought the soil layer to the elevation required by the plans , the 33 Engineer will sample the soil and determine the quantity of lime to be incorporated .
34 Allow 24 calendar days for the Engineer to perform the required sampling , testing and 35 final design of the lime stabilization .
The optimum moisture will be determined by the 36 Engineer .
37 Spread lime or lime slurry only on an area of such size that all primary mixing operations 38 can be completed in the same day during daylight hours , except where the work is to be 39 done at night as required by the contract .
40 Incorporate the lime or lime slurry into the soil mixture at the rates determined by the 41 Engineer .
Distribute the lime at the uniform rate and minimize the scattering by the 42 wind .
Mix the lime into the soil within 2 hours after application .
43 Section 501 5-5 No equipment , except that used in spreading , slaking and mixing , will be allowed to pass 1 over the freshly spread lime until it is mixed with the soil .
2 ( B ) Slurry Method 3 Do not add lime slurry to the soil when the moisture content exceeds 2 % above optimum 4 moisture .
Aerate soil or allow to dry naturally until the soil contains no more than 5 2 % above optimum moisture .
6 Mix hydrated lime applied by this method with water in approved agitating equipment 7 and apply to the soil to be treated as a thin water suspension or slurry .
When quicklime is 8 used to produce the slurry , use equipment specifically manufactured for the slaking of 9 quicklime .
Use distributing equipment that provides continuous agitation of the slurry 10 from the slurry production site until the slurry is applied to the soil .
Proportion the lime 11 so that the dry solids content is at least 30 % by weight .
12 Split the lime application into approximately 2 equal applications with the first being 13 partially mixed into the soil to a minimum depth of 3 inches before applying the second 14 application .
15 ( C ) Quicklime 16 Do not add dry quicklime to the soil when the moisture content exceeds 4 % above 17 optimum moisture .
Aerate soil or allow to dry naturally until it contains no more than 18 4 % above optimum moisture .
19 Where the “ Bottom-Dump ” method of application is used , omit the preliminary 20 scarification of the soil surface .
Apply the quicklime by slowly driving the tanker truck 21 over the coverage area with the bottom discharge valves open creating a windrow of 22 quicklime .
23 Repeat the process until the tanker is empty in order to provide at least 3 , for a 24 foot 24 roadway , reasonably uniform and equally spaced windrows over the area being 25 stabilized .
The number of windrows required will depend on the width of the section 26 being stabilized and will be stipulated by the Engineer .
27 Carefully spread the windrows of quicklime with a motor grader into an equal depth layer 28 over the entire area to be stabilized .
29 After the lime has been spread , follow with a sprinkling of water to slake the lime .
After 30 a complete slaking of the lime , thoroughly mix the lime with the soil .
The Engineer may 31 direct that the lime first be mixed into the soil followed by sprinkling and additional 32 mixing to ensure complete slaking of the lime throughout the layer to be stabilized .
33 ( D ) Hydrated Lime 34 Use hydrated lime only with written permission and do not add to the soil when the 35 moisture content exceeds 6 % above optimum moisture .
36 501-9 MIXING 37 ( A ) Primary Mixing 38 Immediately after the lime has been spread and slaked , if required , mix the lime into the 39 soil for the full depth of treatment .
Mix the lime into the soil to provide a compacted 40 depth of at least 8 inches .
A minimum number of mixing passes will be required to 41 ensure uniform incorporation of the lime .
Add water as necessary and thoroughly mix 42 with the soil lime mixture so that the mixture contains no less than optimum moisture .
43 A tolerance of 3 % above optimum will be allowed .
Incorporate all of the lime 44 thoroughly and uniformly into the soil layer to the full depth of treatment so that the 45 result is a homogeneous , friable mixture of soil and lime , free of clods or lumps 46 exceeding 2 inches in size .
47 Section 501 5-6 After primary mixing operations and before curing , shape and lightly compact the lime- 1 treated area to the approximate section to allow for proper drainage and to minimize 2 evaporation loss .
3 ( B ) Preliminary Curing 4 Following primary mixing operations , cure the stabilized layer for 1 to 4 days .
The 5 actual duration of this curing period will be determined by the Engineer .
During the 6 curing period , keep the surface of the material moist to prevent drying and cracking and 7 maintain in a properly sealed and crowned condition .
Mix , compact , shape and finish the 8 stabilized layer no later than 4 days after primary mixing .
9 ( C ) Final Mixing and Pulverizing 10 Immediately after the completion of the preliminary curing period , mix and pulverize 11 completely the stabilized layer to the full depth of the stabilization .
Continue the final 12 mixing until all of the clods are broken down to pass a 1/2 inch sieve and at least 80 % 13 pass a No .
4 sieve , exclusive of rock .
Add water , as required , during the final mixing to 14 raise the moisture content before compaction .
15 501-10 COMPACTING , SHAPING AND FINISHING 16 Begin compaction of the mixture immediately after completion of the final mixing operations .
17 Aerate or moisten the mixture as necessary during compaction operations to maintain the 18 moisture between optimum and optimum plus 2 % .
Compact the full depth of the mixture to 19 a density equal to at least 97 % of that obtained by compacting a sample of the soil lime 20 mixture in accordance with AASHTO T 99 as modified by the Department .
Copies of these 21 modified procedures are available upon request from Materials and Tests Unit .
Accompany 22 the compaction with sufficient blading to eliminate irregularities .
23 Perform the final rolling of the completed surface with a pneumatic-tired roller or if permitted 24 a smooth , steel-wheel roller .
25 Complete shaping , final mixing , compacting and finishing on the same day upon completion 26 of the preliminary curing .
This work is to be completed no later than 4 days after primary 27 mixing and done during daylight hours , unless otherwise provided in the contract .
If the 28 above work is not completed as specified , rip up the entire section and add additional lime , as 29 directed , at no additional cost to the Department .
30 501-11 THICKNESS 31 The compacted thickness of the completed treated soil layer will be determined by 32 measurements made in test holes located at random intervals not to exceed 500 feet .
Do not 33 deviate the measured thickness from that shown on the plans by more than plus 1 inch or 34 minus 1/2 inch .
35 Where the lime-treated soil layer is deficient in thickness by more than 1/2 inch , remove and 36 replace the area of deficient thickness with lime-treated soil having the required thickness at 37 no cost to the Department .
38 As an exception to the above , if the deficiency is not considered sufficient to seriously impair 39 the required strength of the lime-treated soil layer , the deficient area may , at the discretion of 40 the Engineer , be left in place .

12 Thoroughly mix the cement , aggregates and water in an approved central mixing 13 plant .

or equivalent measure .

28 ( 2 ) Hauling and Placing 29 Haul the mixed base material to the roadway in trucks with protective covers to 30 avoid moisture loss .
Do not exceed one hour between the loading of the haul trucks 31 and the beginning of compaction .
32 Place stringlines for alignment control for placing a layer of base .
33 Place the base in a uniform layer on the moistened , prepared subgrade to produce the 34 depth required by the plans .
To insure homogenous distribution of the base material 35 in each layer , place the material using approved spreaders .
Perform the spreading 36 operations to eliminate pockets of material of non-uniform gradation resulting from 37 segregation in the hauling or discharging operations .
Spread each layer so that 38 compaction can be started without further shaping .
39 A single spreader may be used provided it is capable of placing a uniform , full-depth 40 layer of material across the full width of the base in one pass .
Otherwise , 2 or more 41 spreaders will be required and operate the spreaders so that the spreading progresses 42 along the full width of the base in a uniform manner .
43 Base placed on areas inaccessible to mechanical spreading equipment may be spread 44 in one layer by approved methods .
After spreading , compact the material thoroughly 45 to the required lines , grades and typical sections by means of pneumatic tampers or 46 with other compaction equipment which will constantly obtain the degree of 47 compaction required .
48 Section 540 5-17 ( C ) Road Mixed Cement-Treated Base Course 1 ( 1 ) Equipment 2 Use any combination of machines or equipment that will produce the required results 3 meeting the approval of the Engineer .
Use a cement spreader which has 4 an adjustable rate of flow and the capability of spreading the required amount of 5 cement in one pass .
Mix cement , aggregate and water with a self-propelled rotary 6 mixer capable of mixing to a depth of 10 inches .
Correct any leakage of fluids 7 and/or materials promptly or the Engineer may order such equipment removed and 8 replaced with satisfactory equipment .
Use equipment and methods for applying 9 cement , water , curing seal and blotting sand that does not damage the base and in 10 accordance with Article 107-21 .
11 ( 2 ) Spreading and Mixing 12 Place the required quantity of aggregate on the prepared subgrade in a uniform layer .
13 Spread aggregate on the subgrade in advance of the mixing operations only to the 14 extent that processing can be completed within one week .
Apply the required 15 quantity of cement in a uniform spread on the aggregate in place and immediately 16 blend the aggregate until the cement is uniformly distributed throughout the 17 aggregate .
Maintain the moisture content at or below the optimum moisture at the 18 time of application of the cement .
Do not apply cement on excessively windy days 19 and apply only to such an area that all operations shall be completed on the same day 20 during daylight hours .
21 The Engineer will establish the actual cement content during construction .
22 Immediately after the aggregate and cement have been thoroughly blended , apply 23 water as needed and incorporate into the mixture .
Control the application of the 24 water so that there is no excessive concentration on or near the surface of the 25 mixture .
After the necessary water has been applied , continue mixing until 26 a thorough and uniform mixture is obtained .
27 Maintain the moisture content at the time of final mixing and during compaction 28 within a range of optimum to optimum plus 1.5 % as determined .
Make sure that the 29 moisture content in the mix does not exceed the quantity that will cause the base 30 course to become unstable during compaction or finishing operations .
31 540-6 COMPACTION 32 Begin compaction immediately after the plant mixed base has been placed on the prepared 33 subgrade or immediately after cement and water has been incorporated into the previously 34 placed aggregate .
Compact any one layer of base so the thickness is between 4 inches and 35 8 inches .
36 After spreading , maintain the moisture content of the material within a range of optimum to 37 optimum plus 1.5 % moisture during compaction .
38 Accomplish compaction by the use of approved self-propelled rollers , except do not use 39 a sheep-foot roller for more than 2 passes .
Compact the base by the use of approved 40 self-propelled rollers to a density equal to at least 97 % of the maximum density obtained by 41 compacting a sample of the material in accordance with AASHTO T 180 as modified by the 42 Department .
Copies of these modified testing procedures are available upon request from the 43 Materials and Tests Unit .
The Engineer may , at his option , utilize nuclear methods as 44 described in the NCDOT Nuclear Density Testing Manual – Base Course , FDR and Select 45 Materials to determine the density of the base instead of the methods required above .
Copies 46 of this manual are available upon request from the Materials and Tests Unit .
47 Complete final compaction , including that necessary due to correction of high or low areas , 48 within 3 hours after water has been added to the mixture .
Do not leave any cement-aggregate 49 Section 540 5-18 mixture undisturbed for more than 30 minutes if it has not been compacted and finished .
1 When rain causes excessive moisture , reconstruct the entire section .

When the base course will be used under concrete pavement 16 the tolerance will be ± 1/4 inch .
17 Construct the base so that the maximum differential between the established grade and the 18 base within any 100 foot section is 1/2 inch or 1/4 inch when used as a base course under 19 concrete pavement .
20 540-9 CURING 21 After the cement-treated base has been finished as specified herein , cure it in accordance with 22 Section 543 .
23 540-10 AGGREGATE FOR CEMENT-TREATED BASE 24 Use aggregate for cement-treated base course from an approved source participating in the 25 Department ’ s Aggregate Quality Control/Quality Assurance Program ( Aggregate QC/QA 26 Program ) which has been sampled , tested and approved in accordance with Section 1006 .
27 540-11 TRAFFIC 28 Completed sections of the base may be opened when necessary to lightweight local traffic , 29 provided the base has hardened sufficiently to prevent marring or distorting of the surface and 30 provided the curing is not impaired .
Do not operate construction equipment on the base , 31 except as necessary to discharge into the spreader during paving operations .
32 540-12 MAINTENANCE 33 Maintain the base in an acceptable condition until final acceptance of the project .
Include 34 immediate repair of any defects or damage that may occur in any maintenance operation .
35 Perform this maintenance at no cost to the Department and repeat as often as may be 36 necessary to keep the base in an acceptable condition .
Perform repairs to the base by 37 replacing the base for its full depth rather than by adding a thin layer of cement-stabilized 38 material to the existing layer of base .

Proportion , spread and mix the 27 materials on the roadway ; manipulate , compact and finish in accordance with the Standard 28 Specifications and the lines , grades , depths and typical sections shown on the plans or 29 established by the Engineer .
30 542-2 MATERIALS 31 Refer to Division 10 .
32 Item Section Aggregate , ABC Table 1005-1 Portland Cement , Type I 1024-1 Water 1024-4 Use soil material that consists of material existing in the area to be paved , approved borrow 33 material or a combination of these materials proportioned as directed by the Engineer that is 34 free from vegetation , roots or other objectionable matter ; and does not contain aggregate or 35 stone larger than 2 inches .
36 542-3 LIMITATIONS 37 Do not construct the soil-cement base when the air temperature is below 40°F nor when 38 conditions indicate that the temperature may fall below 40°F within 24 hours .
Do not place or 39 mix materials with frozen subgrade .
Protect the base from freezing for 7 days after 40 Section 542 5-20 completion .
Perform the work only during daylight hours except as otherwise provided in the 1 contract .
2 Do not construct soil-cement base that will not be covered with a layer of base or pavement 3 by December 1st of the same year .
Failure of the Contractor to cover the soil-cement base as 4 required above will result in the Engineer notifying the Contractor in writing to cover the 5 soil-cement base with a sand seal .
Apply the sand seal in accordance with Section 660 except 6 Articles 660-3 and 660-12 will not apply .
If the Contractor fails to apply the sand seal within 7 72 hours after a receipt of such notice , the Engineer may proceed to have the work performed 8 with other forces and equipment .
The application of the sand seal by the Contractor or other 9 forces will in no way relieve the Contractor of the responsibility to maintain or repair the 10 damaged base , no matter what the cause of damage .
11 542-4 EQUIPMENT 12 ( A ) General 13 Use any combination of machines or equipment that will produce the required results 14 meeting the approval of the Engineer .
Correct any leakage of fluids and/or materials 15 promptly or the Engineer may order such equipment removed and replaced with 16 satisfactory equipment .
Use equipment and methods for applying cement , water , curing 17 seal and blotting sand that will not damage the base and in accordance with Article 107- 18 21 .
19 ( B ) Cement Spreaders 20 Use mechanical spreaders that have an adjustable rate of flow and the capability of 21 spreading the required amount of cement in one pass .
22 ( C ) Water Distribution Equipment 23 Add water to the soil with a pressure distributor or other suitable equipment capable of 24 uniformly distributing the required amount .
25 ( D ) Mixers 26 Perform all mixing with a self-propelled rotary mixer .
Disc harrows , motor graders and 27 other equipment may be used only to supplement the mixing done by the rotary mixer .
28 Use mixing equipment that is capable of mixing to a compacted depth of at least 29 10 inches .
30 ( E ) Compaction Equipment 31 Use self-propelled compaction equipment .
Accomplish finish rolling with a pneumatic- 32 tire roller or if permitted by the Engineer , a smooth steel-wheel roller .
33 ( F ) Scarifying Equipment 34 Use a grader-scarifier for the initial scarification of the soil .
Use equipment capable of 35 scarifying the soil to the full depth of the stabilized treatment .
When required by the 36 Engineer , use a weeder , spiketooth harrow or nail drag , followed by a broom drag when 37 scarifying during finishing operations .
38 542-5 PREPARATION OF ROADBED 39 Before the addition of any cement to the soil , grade and shape the area to be stabilized in 40 accordance with the typical sections , lines and grades shown on the plans .
Perform drying or 41 addition of moisture where necessary before the application of cement .
Create the subgrade 42 so it is firm and able to support the construction equipment and compaction operations 43 specified .
Correct and make stable , soft or yielding subgrade before construction proceeds .
44 Section 542 5-21 542-6 SCARIFYING 1 Scarify the soil in the area to be stabilized to the required depth and width before application 2 of cement .
Pulverizing with a rotary mixer will follow scarifying , except it may be deleted in 3 areas where , if determined , the soil types or conditions make pulverizing with a rotary mixer 4 impractical .
5 542-7 APPLICATION OF CEMENT 6 When the Contractor has brought the subgrade to the elevation required by the plans , the 7 Engineer will sample the soil to be stabilized in order to determine the quantity of cement to 8 be incorporated .
Incorporate 24 calendar days into the schedule to allow the Engineer 9 sufficient time to perform the required sampling , testing and final design of the cement 10 stabilization .
11 Before spreading cement , aggregate shall be spread at the rate shown in the plans .
12 Incorporate cement into the mix at the rate directed by the Engineer .
Uniformly spread the 13 quantity of cement required for the full depth of treatment over the surface in one pass .
Do 14 not apply cement on excessively wet grade or on windy days .
15 Apply cement to the soil when the percentage of moisture in the soil material is the correct 16 amount that assures a uniform mixture of soil material and cement during the mixing 17 operation .
Do not exceed the optimum moisture content established by the Engineer for the 18 soil cement moisture except by permission .
19 The optimum moisture content and density will be determined in the field by a moisture- 20 density test on representative samples of soil-cement mixture ; however , preliminary moisture- 21 density values may be determined by laboratory tests using soils from the project .
Moisture 22 content will be determined by the Engineer in accordance with standard test procedures used 23 by the Department .
24 Apply cement only to such an area that all operations shall be completed in the same day 25 during daylight hours .
Complete finishing the soil-cement mix within 4 hours of adding water 26 to the soil-cement mixture .
No equipment , except that used in spreading and mixing , will be 27 allowed to pass over the freshly spread cement until it is mixed with the soil .
Replace all 28 spread cement that has been displaced before mixing is started .
29 542-8 MIXING 30 Immediately after the cement has been spread , mix it with the loosened soil material for the 31 full depth of the treatment until a homogenous and uniform mixture is produced .
Mixing will 32 be sufficient when 100 % of the mixture passes a 1/2 inch sieve and at least 80 % passes 33 a No .
4 sieve , exclusive of any aggregate .
34 Immediately after mixing the soil and cement , add any additional water that is necessary to 35 bring the moisture content between optimum and optimum plus 2 % as determined by the 36 Engineer .
If moisture content exceeds the specified range , the soil-cement mixture may , if 37 approved by the Engineer , be manipulated by remixing or blading to reduce the moisture 38 content to within the specified range .
Avoid excessive concentrations of water as well as wet 39 spots or streaks on or near the surface .
After all mixing water has been applied , continue 40 mixing until a uniform mixture is obtained at the required moisture content .
Perform the 41 operations of cement spreading , water application and mixing so that they result in a uniform 42 soil , cement and water mixture for the full depth and width of the area being treated .
Remix 43 any soil and cement mixture that has not been compacted and finished within 30 minutes .
44 542-9 COMPACTION 45 Begin compaction of the mixture immediately after the mixing operation is completed .
At the 46 start of compaction , make sure that the moisture in the mixture is no more than 2 % above or 47 below the optimum moisture content and is less than the quantity which will cause the soil- 48 cement mixture to become unstable during compaction and finishing .
Compact the mixture to 49 Section 542 5-22 at least 97 % of that obtained by a moisture-density test using AASHTO T 134 as modified by 1 the Department .
Copies of these modified testing procedures are available upon request from 2 the Materials and Tests Unit .
3 Before compaction , prepare the mixture in a loose condition for its full depth .
Compact the 4 loose mixture uniformly to the specified density .
During the compaction operations , initial 5 shaping may be required to obtain uniform compaction and required grade and cross section .
6 542-10 FINISHING 7 When initial compaction is nearing completion , shape the surface of the soil-cement to the 8 required lines , grades and cross section .
Maintain the moisture content of the surface material 9 at optimum or higher during finishing operations .
10 If necessary , lightly scarify the surface to remove any tire imprints or smooth surfaces left by 11 equipment .
Continue compaction until a uniform and adequate density is obtained .
12 Perform the compaction and finishing to produce a dense surface free of compaction planes , 13 cracks , ridges or loose material .
14 When rain causes excessive moisture , reconstruct the entire section .
Where such 15 reconstruction is necessary , furnish all work and cement required .
16 542-11 THICKNESS 17 The compacted thickness of the completed soil-cement base will be determined by 18 measurements made in test holes located at random intervals not to exceed 500 feet .
19 Construct the soil-cement base so that the measured thickness does not deviate from that 20 shown on the plans by more than + 1 inch or - 1/2 inch .
21 Where the base is deficient in thickness by more than 1/2 inch , remove and replace the area of 22 deficient base with base of the required thickness .
23 As an exception to the above , if the deficiency is not considered sufficient to seriously impair 24 the required strength of the soil-cement base , the deficient area may , at the discretion of the 25 Engineer , be left in place .
26 542-12 CURING 27 After the cement-treated base has been finished as specified herein , cure it in accordance with 28 Section 543 .
29 542-13 CONSTRUCTION JOINTS 30 Build soil-cement for large wide areas in a series of parallel lanes of convenient length and 31 width meeting the approval of the Engineer .
Form straight longitudinal joints at the edge of 32 each day 's construction by cutting back into completed work to form a true vertical face free 33 of loose or shattered material .
34 Construct joints to provide a vertical joint having adequately mixed properly compacted 35 material immediately adjacent to the joint .
A longitudinal joint adjacent to partially hardened 36 soil-cement built the preceding day may be formed by cutting back into the previously 37 constructed area during mixing operations .
Set guide stakes for cement spreading and mixing 38 if deemed necessary .
39 542-14 TRAFFIC 40 Completed sections of the base may be opened when necessary to light-weight local traffic , 41 provided the base has hardened sufficiently to prevent marring or distorting of the surface and 42 provided the curing is not impaired .
Do not use construction equipment on the base for 43 hauling except as necessary to discharge into the spreader during paving operations .
44 Section 543 5-23 542-15 MAINTENANCE 1 Maintain the soil-cement base in an acceptable condition until final acceptance of the project .
2 Include , in maintenance operations , immediate repair of any defects or damage that may 3 occur .
Repeat as often as may be necessary to keep the base in an acceptable condition .
4 Perform repairs to the base by replacing the base for its full depth rather than by adding a thin 5 layer of soil-cement mixture to the existing layer of base .

6 543-4 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 7 Continuously moisten the finished stabilized layer or base course until the asphalt curing seal 8 is placed .
Place the curing seal as soon as possible , but no later than 24 hours after 9 completing finishing operations except where delayed by wet weather .
If wet weather delays 10 application of the curing seal , apply the curing seal as soon as the surface becomes 11 sufficiently dry .
12 At the time the asphalt curing seal is applied , prepare the surface of the stabilized layer or 13 base so that it is free of all loose or extraneous material and contains sufficient moisture to 14 prevent excessive penetration of the asphalt material .
If deemed necessary , sweep the base 15 surface clean of loose material before applying the curing seal .
Apply the curing seal in 16 accordance with Section 600 .
17 Apply the asphalt material to the surface of the completed stabilized layer or base at a target 18 rate of 0.14 +/- 0.04 gal/sy with approved equipment .
Apply the asphalt material at the exact 19 rate and temperature of application as established by the Engineer .
20 Cure the underlying materials for 7 curing days .
Curing time will be counted in at least 21 1/2 day units and only when the air temperature measured at the location of the operation is at 22 least 50°F .
Complete the curing before placement of subsequent layers of pavement .
23 Maintain the curing material during the curing period so that all of the stabilized layer or base 24 will be covered effectively during the period .
Provide sufficient protection from freezing to 25 the stabilized layer or base during the entire curing period and until it has hardened .
Replace 26 excessive loss of curing seal caused by heavy rains within 8 hours of placement .
27 If the Engineer determines that it is necessary to allow local traffic to use parts of the 28 stabilized layer or base before the asphalt material has cured sufficiently , protect those areas 29 by applying blotting sand in accordance with Section 818 .

26 Section 607 6-4 TABLE 605-2 APPLICATION TEMPERATURE FOR TACK COAT Asphalt Material Temperature Range Asphalt Binder , Grade PG 58-28 or PG 64-22 350 - 400°F Emulsified Asphalt , Grade RS-1H 130 - 160°F Emulsified Asphalt , Grade CRS-1 130 - 160°F Emulsified Asphalt , Grade CRS-1H 130 - 160°F Emulsified Asphalt , Grade HFMS-1 130 - 160°F Emulsified Asphalt , Grade CRS-2 130 - 160°F 605-8 APPLICATION OF TACK COAT 1 Apply only as much tack coat material as can be covered with base , intermediate or surface 2 course material during the next day 's operation except where public traffic is being 3 maintained .
4 If public traffic is being maintained , cover the tack coat in the same day 's operation .
Provide 5 safe traffic conditions .
If needed , apply suitable granular material so it bonds to the tack coat .
6 In addition , the Engineer may limit the application of tack coat in advance of the paving 7 operation depending on traffic conditions , project location , proximity to business or 8 residential areas or other reasons .
9 Take necessary precautions to limit the tracking or accumulation of tack coat on either 10 existing or newly constructed pavements .
Excessive accumulation of tack coat requires 11 corrective measures .
12 Apply tack coat with a distributor spray bar that can be adjusted to uniformly coat the entire 13 surface at the directed rate .

Cover these areas uniformly and completely .
15 Apply tack coat as directed by and in the presence of the Engineer .
Do not place any asphalt 16 mixture until the tack coat has sufficiently cured .
17 Apply tack coat to all exposed transverse and longitudinal edges of each course before 18 mixture is placed adjacent to such surfaces .
Apply tack coat to contact surfaces of headers , 19 curbs , gutters , manholes and vertical faces of old pavements .
20 Cover bridge floors , curbs and handrails of structures and all other appurtenances to protect 21 them from tracking or splattering tack coat material .
22 605-9 PROTECTION OF TACK COAT 23 After the tack coat has been applied , protect it until it has cured for a sufficient length of time 24 to prevent it from being picked up by traffic .

29 SECTION 607 30 MILLING ASPHALT PAVEMENT 31 607-1 DESCRIPTION 32 Perform the work covered by this section including , but not limited to , milling and re-milling 33 the pavement at locations , depths , widths and typical sections indicated in the contract ; 34 cleaning the milled surface ; loading , hauling and stockpiling the milled material for use in 35 recycled asphalt mixtures ; and disposal of any excess milled material .
36 Section 607 6-5 Except where the milled material is used in the work or where otherwise directed , provide 1 areas outside the right of way to dispose of milled material , which shall be property of the 2 Contractor .
3 607-2 EQUIPMENT 4 Use a self-propelled unit capable of removing the existing asphalt pavement to the depths , 5 widths and typical sections shown in the contract .
Use milling machines designed and built 6 exclusively for pavement milling operations and with sufficient power , traction and stability 7 to accurately maintain depth of cut and slope .
Use milling machines equipped with 8 an electronic control system that will automatically control the longitudinal profile and cross 9 slope of the milled pavement surface .
Accomplish this through the use of a mobile grade 10 reference , an erected string line , joint matching shoe , slope control systems or a combination 11 of approved methods .
Use an erected fixed stringline when required by the contract .
12 Otherwise , use a mobile grade reference system capable of averaging the existing grade or 13 pavement profile over at least 30 feet .
Use either a non-contacting laser or sonar type ski 14 systems with at least 4 referencing stations mounted on the milling machine at a length of at 15 least 24 feet .
Coordinate the position of the grade control system such that the grade sensor is 16 at the approximate midpoint of the mobile reference system .
Use a machine capable of 17 leaving a uniform surface suitable for handling traffic without damage to the underlying 18 pavement structure .
Use a milling machine and other loading equipment capable of loading 19 milled material to be used in other parts of the work without segregation .
20 Provide additional equipment necessary to satisfactorily remove the pavement in the area of 21 manholes , water valves , curb , gutter and other obstructions .
22 Equip the milling equipment with a means of effectively limiting the amount of dust escaping 23 from the removal operation in accordance with Federal , State and local air pollution control 24 laws and regulations .
25 607-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 26 Mill the existing pavement to restore the pavement surface to a uniform longitudinal profile 27 and cross section in accordance with typical sections shown in the plans .
Where indicated in 28 the contract , remove pavement to a specified depth and produce a specified cross slope .
Mill 29 intersections and other irregular areas unless otherwise directed by the Engineer .
30 The Contractor may elect to make multiple cuts to achieve the required depth of cut or cross 31 slope required by the plans .
32 Establish the longitudinal profile of the milled surface by a mobile string line on the side of 33 the cut nearest the centerline of the road .
Establish the cross slope of the milled surface by 34 an automatic cross slope control mechanism or by a second skid sensing device located on the 35 opposite edge of the cut .
The Engineer may waive the requirement for automatic grade and 36 cross slope controls where conditions warrant .
37 Operate the milling equipment so as to prevent damage to the underlying pavement structure , 38 utilities , drainage facilities , curb and gutter , paved surfaces outside the milled area and any 39 other appurtenances .
Produce milled pavement surfaces that are reasonably smooth and free 40 of excessive scarification marks , gouges , ridges , continuous grooves or other damage .
Repair 41 any leveling or patching required as a result of negligence by the Contractor with hot asphalt 42 plant mix in a manner acceptable to the Engineer .
Coordinate the adjustment of manholes , 43 meter boxes and valve boxes with the milling operation in accordance with Article 858-3 44 including a temporary asphalt ramp .
45 Section 607 6-6 When necessary , the contractor may remove the top section of a utility and use a bridge steel 1 plate placed to cover the entire width of the structure , ensuring no debris is dropped inside the 2 structure .
Backfill with compacted material and hot mix asphalt as a temporary riding surface 3 as well as any further necessary requirements of the utility owner .
This steel plate must be 4 capable of carrying any traffic load carried by the facility .
Where necessary , double-reference 5 the location of each structure that has been removed and maintain a map of their location .
6 Construct a temporary ramp of asphalt plant mix to extend a minimum of 3 feet around raised 7 structures before opening to traffic .
8 The Engineer may require re-milling of any area exhibiting laminations or other defects .
9 Thoroughly clean the milled pavement surface of all loose aggregate particles , dust and other 10 objectionable material .
Disposing or wasting of oversize pieces of pavement or loose 11 aggregate material will not be permitted within the right of way .
12 Conduct pavement removal operations so as to effectively minimize the amount of dust being 13 emitted .
Plan and conduct the operation so it is safe for persons and property adjacent to the 14 work including the traveling public .
15 607-4 TOLERANCE 16 Remove the existing pavement to the depth required by the contract .
The Engineer may vary 17 the depth of milling .

Apply these Standard Specifications to all materials 16 and work performed in accordance with Division 6 .
Perform all quality control ( QC ) 17 activities in accordance with the Department ’ s Asphalt Mixture Quality Management System 18 ( QMS ) Manual in effect on the date of contract advertisement .
19 ( A ) Quality Control ( QC ) 20 Define a “ quality control ( QC ) program ” as all activities , including mix design , process 21 control , plant and equipment calibration , sampling and testing and necessary adjustments 22 in the process that are related to production of a pavement that meet the Standard 23 Specifications .
Provide and conduct a QC program in accordance with this section .
24 ( B ) Quality Assurance ( QA ) 25 Define a “ quality assurance ( QA ) program ” as all activities , including inspection , 26 sampling and testing related to determining that the quality of the completed pavement 27 conforms to specification requirements .
The Department will conduct a QA program in 28 accordance with Article 609-10 .
29 609-2 MIX DESIGN/JOB MIX FORMULA REQUIREMENTS 30 Apply all requirements of Article 610-3 .
31 609-3 FIELD VERIFICATION OF MIXTURE AND JOB MIX FORMULA 32 ADJUSTMENTS 33 Conduct field verification of the mix at each plant within 45 calendar days before initial 34 production of each mix design , when required by the Allowable Mix Adjustment Policy and 35 when directed as deemed necessary .
36 Field verification testing consists of performing a minimum of one full test series on mix 37 sampled and tested in accordance with Subarticle 609-6 ( B ) .
Mix obtained from Department 38 or non-Department work may be used for this purpose provided it is sampled , tested and the 39 test data handled in accordance with the Asphalt QMS Manual and this article .
40 Section 609 6-8 Obtain the mix verification sample and split in accordance with procedures in the Asphalt 1 QMS Manual .
Do not begin normal plant production until all field verification test results 2 have been completed and the mix has been satisfactorily verified by the Contractor ’ s 3 Level II technician .
4 In addition to the required sampling and testing for field verification , perform all preliminary 5 inspections and plant calibrations as outlined in the Asphalt QMS Manual .
Retain records of 6 these calibrations and mix verification tests at the QC laboratory .
Furnish copies to the 7 Engineer for review and approval within one working day after beginning production of the 8 mix .
9 Failure by the Contractor to fully comply with the above mix verification requirements will 10 result in immediate production stoppage by the Engineer .
Do not resume normal production 11 until all mix verification sampling , testing , calibrations and plant inspections have been 12 performed and approved .
13 609-4 CONTRACTOR 'S QUALITY CONTROL PERSONNEL REQUIREMENTS 14 Obtain all certifications in accordance with the Department ’ s QMS Asphalt Technician 15 Certification Program as outlined in the Asphalt QMS Manual .
Perform all sampling , testing , 16 data analysis and data posting by or under the direct supervision of a certified QMS asphalt 17 plant technician .
18 Provide a certified asphalt plant technician Level I to perform QC operations and activities at 19 each plant site at all times during production of material for the project .
A plant operator who 20 is a certified asphalt plant technician Level I may be used to meet this requirement when daily 21 production for each mix design is less than 100 tons provided the randomly scheduled 22 increment sample as defined in Section 7.3 of the Asphalt QMS Manual is not within that 23 tonnage .
When performing in this capacity , the plant operator will be responsible for all QC 24 activities that are necessary and required .
Absences of the Level I technician , other than those 25 for normal breaks and emergencies shall be pre-approved by the appropriate Engineer or his 26 designated representative .
Any extended absence of the technician that has not been approved 27 will result in immediate suspension of production by the Engineer .
All mix produced during 28 this absence will be accepted in accordance with Article 105-3 .
29 Provide and have readily available a certified asphalt plant technician Level II to supervise , 30 coordinate and make any necessary adjustments in the mix QC process in a timely manner .
31 The Level II technician may serve in a dual capacity and fulfill the Level I technician 32 requirements specified above .
33 Provide a certified QMS roadway technician with each paving operation at all times during 34 placement of asphalt .
This person is responsible for monitoring all roadway paving operations 35 and all QC processes and activities , to include stopping production or implementing 36 corrective measures when warranted .
Provide a certified density gauge operator when density 37 control is being used .

22 In any case , remove and replace this mix with materials that comply with the Standard 23 Specifications , unless otherwise approved .

16 ( B ) Limited Production Procedures 17 Define “ resurfacing ” as the first new uniform layer placed on an existing pavement .
18 Proceed on limited production when , for the same mix type and on the same contract , one 19 of the following conditions occur ( except as noted below ) .
20 ( 1 ) Two consecutive failing lots , except on resurfacing , 21 ( 2 ) Three consecutive failing lots on resurfacing , or 22 ( 3 ) Two consecutive failing density gauge control strips .
23 As exceptions to the above , pavement within each construction category ( New and 24 Other ) , as defined in Section 10.3.3 of the Asphalt QMS Manual , and pavement placed 25 simultaneously by multiple paving crews will be evaluated independently for limited 26 production purposes .
27 Limited production is defined as the production , placement and compaction of a 28 sufficient quantity of mix to construct a 300 feet control strip plus 100 feet of pavement 29 adjacent to each end of the control strip .
30 Remain on limited production until such time as satisfactory density results are attained 31 or until two control strips have been attempted without achieving acceptable density test 32 results .
If the Contractor fails to achieve satisfactory density after two control strips have 33 been attempted , cease production of that mix type until such time as the cause of the 34 failing density test results can be determined .
As an exception , the Engineer may grant 35 approval to produce a different mix design of the same mix type if Quality Control and 36 Quality Assurance plant mix test indicate the failing densities are attributed to the mix 37 problem ( s ) rather than compaction related problems and limited production startup would 38 Section 609 6-13 not be required .
The determination of whether a mix problem exists at this time will be 1 made by QA personnel .
2 If the Contractor does not operate by the limited production procedures when conditions 3 as specified in Section 10.9 of the Asphalt QMS Manual , all mix produced thereafter will 4 be unacceptable .
Remove this material and replace with material that complies with the 5 Standard Specifications , at no additional cost to the Department .

7 Payment at the contract unit prices for the various asphalt items will be full compensation for 8 all work covered by these specifications .
9 If the mix or pavement represented by the falsified results is removed and replaced , payment 10 will be made for the actual quantities of materials required to replace the falsified quantities , 11 not to exceed the original amounts .
12 SECTION 610 13 ASPHALT CONCRETE PLANT MIX PAVEMENTS 14 610-1 DESCRIPTION 15 Perform the work covered by this section including , but not limited to , the construction of one 16 or more courses of asphalt mixture placed on a prepared surface in accordance with these 17 Specifications and in reasonably close conformity with the lines , grades , thickness and typical 18 sections shown on the plans .
This work includes producing , weighing , transporting , placing 19 and compacting the plant mix ; furnishing aggregate , asphalt binder , anti-strip additive and all 20 other materials for the plant mix ; furnishing and applying tack coat as specified ; furnishing 21 scales ; maintaining the course until final acceptance of the project ; making any repairs or 22 corrections to the course that may become necessary ; providing and conducting QC as 23 specified in Section 609 ; and surface testing of the completed pavement .
The design 24 requirements for the various mix types are given in Section 610 for dense-graded mix types , 25 Section 650 for OGFC , Section 652 for PADC and Section 661 for UTBWC .
26 Perform all activities in accordance with the Department ’ s Asphalt Quality Management 27 System ( QMS ) Manual in effect on the date of contract advertisement 28 Provide and conduct the QC and required testing for acceptance of the asphalt mixture in 29 accordance with Section 609 .
30 Define “ warm mix asphalt ( WMA ) ” as additives or processes that allow a reduction in the 31 temperature at which asphalt mixtures are produced and placed .
Use only WMA additives or 32 processes listed on the NCDOT APL maintained by the Materials and Tests Unit .

Size , uniformly grade and 4 combine the several aggregate fractions in such proportions that the resulting mixture 5 meets the grading and physical requirements of the Specifications for the specified mix 6 type .

8 At least 10 days before start of asphalt mix production , submit the mix design and 9 proposed JMF targets for each required mix type and combination of aggregates to the 10 Engineer for review and approval .
Prepare the mix design using a Department certified 11 mix design technician in an approved mix design laboratory and in accordance with the 12 procedures outlined in Section 4.5 of the Asphalt QMS Manual .
13 For the final surface layer of the specified mix type , use a mix design with an aggregate 14 blend gradation above the maximum density line on the 2.36 mm and larger sieves .
15 The Contractor has the option to use a recycled plant mix in lieu of virgin plant mix .
16 However , all provisions of the Specifications for virgin mixes apply to recycled mixes .
17 This means that the same design criteria tests , test frequencies , and quality control 18 requirements will apply .
19 Reclaimed Asphalt Pavement ( RAP ) or Reclaimed Asphalt Shingles ( RAS ) may be 20 incorporated into asphalt plant mixes in accordance with Article 1012-1 and the 21 following applicable requirements .
However , use of RAP materials is not allowed in 22 Open Graded Friction Course ( OGFC ) mixes or Ultra-Thin Bonded Wearing Course 23 ( UBWC ) mixes .
Use of RAS materials is not allowed in Ultra-Thin Bonded Wearing 24 Course ( UBWC ) mixes .
25 RAS material may constitute up to 6 % by weight of total mixture , except for Open 26 Graded Friction Course ( OGFC ) mixes , which are limited to 5 % RAS by weight of total 27 mixture .
Also , when the percentage of RAP is greater than 30 % by weight of total 28 mixture , use Fractionated RAP ( FRAP ) meeting the requirements of Subarticle 1012- 29 1 ( F ) ( c ) .
30 When RAP , RAS , or a combination of both is used in asphalt mixtures , the recycled 31 binder replacement percentage ( RBR % ) shall not exceed the amounts specified in Table 32 610-4 for the mix type .
For recycled mixtures , the virgin binder Performance Grade ( PG ) 33 grade to be used is specified in Table 610-5 for the mix type based on the recycled binder 34 replacement percentage ( RBR % ) .
35 If the Contractor wishes to submit mix designs containing recycled material amounts 36 exceeding the specified maximums , additional testing will be required to verify the 37 Performance Grade ( PG ) of the reclaimed binder .
Also , the Contractor has the option to 38 have additional testing performed to determine if the mix can be approved using a virgin 39 binder grade different than specified in Table 610-5 .
The Engineer will determine if the 40 binder grade is acceptable for use based on the test data submitted with the mix design .
If 41 the mix design is acceptable , the Engineer will establish and approve the grade and 42 percentage of virgin asphalt binder to be used .
43 If a change in the source of RAP or RAS be made , a new mix design and JMF may be 44 required in accordance with Article 1012-1 .
Samples of the completed recycled mixture 45 may be taken by the Department on a random basis to determine the PG grading on the 46 recovered asphalt binder in accordance with AASHTO M 320 .
If the grading is 47 determined to be a value other than required for the specified mix type , the Engineer may 48 require the Contractor to adjust any combination of the grade , the percentage of 49 Section 610 6-17 additional asphalt binder or the blend of reclaimed material to bring the grade to the 1 specified value .
2 ( B ) Mix Design Criteria 3 Design and produce asphalt concrete mixtures that conform to the gradation requirements 4 and design criteria in Table 610-2 and Table 610-3 for the mix type specified .
The mix 5 type designates the nominal maximum aggregate size and the design traffic level .
6 Surface mix designs will be tested by the Department for rutting susceptibility .
Rut depth 7 requirements for each surface mix type and traffic level are specified in Table 610-3 .
8 Mix designs that fail to meet these requirements will be unacceptable and shall be 9 redesigned by the Contractor such that rut depths are acceptable .
10 Table 610-2 provides gradation control points to be adhered to in the development of the 11 design aggregate structure for each mix type .
Aggregate gradations shall be equal to or 12 pass between the control points .
Table 610-3 provides the mix design criteria for the 13 various mix types .
14 Use an anti-strip additive in all asphalt mixes .
It may be hydrated lime or a chemical 15 additive or a combination of both as needed to meet the retained strength requirements as 16 specified in Table 610-3 .
When a chemical additive is used , add at a rate of not less than 17 0.25 % by weight of binder in the mix , or as approved by the Engineer .
When hydrated 18 lime is used , add at a rate of not less than 1.0 % by weight of the total dry aggregate .
19 ( C ) Job Mix Formula ( JMF ) 20 Establish the JMF gradation target values within the design criteria specified for the 21 particular type of asphalt mixture to be produced .
Establish the JMF asphalt binder 22 content at the percentage that will produce voids in total mix ( VTM ) at the midpoint of 23 the specification design range for VTM , unless otherwise approved .
The formula for 24 each mixture will establish the following : blend percentage of each aggregate fraction , 25 the percentage of reclaimed aggregate , if applicable , a single percentage of combined 26 aggregate passing each required sieve size , the total percentage and grade of asphalt 27 binder required for the mixture ( by weight of total mixture ) , the percentage and grade of 28 asphalt binder to be added to the mixture ( for recycled mixtures ) , the percentage of 29 chemical anti-strip additive to be added to the asphalt binder or percentage of hydrated 30 lime to be added to the aggregate , the temperature at that the mixture is to be discharged 31 from the plant , the required field density and other volumetric properties .
32 When WMA is used , document the additive or process used and recommended rate on 33 the JMF submittal .
Verify the JMF based on plant produced mixture from the trial batch .
34 The mixing temperature at the asphalt plant will be established on the JMF .
The JMF 35 mix temperature shall be within the ranges shown in Table 610-1 unless otherwise 36 approved .

3 610-4 WEATHER , TEMPERATURE AND SEASONAL LIMITATIONS FOR 4 PRODUCING AND PLACING ASPHALT MIXTURES 5 Do not produce or place asphalt mixtures during rainy weather , when the subgrade or base 6 course is frozen or when the moisture on the surface to be paved would prevent proper bond .
7 Do not place asphalt material when the air or surface temperatures , measured at the location 8 of the paving operation away from artificial heat , do not meet Table 610-6 .
9 Do not place surface course material that is to be the final layer of pavement between 10 December 15 and March 16 of the next year if it is 1 inch or greater in thickness , or between 11 November 15 and April 1 of the next year if it is less than 1 inch in thickness , unless 12 otherwise approved .
13 As an exception to the above , when in any day 's operations the placement of a layer of asphalt 14 base course material or intermediate material 2 inches or greater in thickness has started , it 15 may continue until the temperature drops to 32°F .
16 Do not place plant mix base course that will not be covered with surface or intermediate 17 course during the same calendar year or within 15 days of placement if the plant mix is placed 18 in January or February .
Failure by the Contractor to cover the plant mix as required above 19 will result in the Engineer notifying the Contractor in writing to cover the plant mix with a 20 sand seal .
Apply the sand seal in accordance with Section 660 , except that Articles 660-3 and 21 660-12 will not apply .
In the event the Contractor fails to apply the sand seal within 72 hours 22 of receipt of such notice , the Engineer may proceed to have such work performed with 23 Department forces and equipment .
