2 610-5 ASPHALT MIXTURE PRODUCTION 3 Use plants that are either of the batch mixing , continuous mixing or drum mixing type , 4 and so designed , equipped and operated that the weighing , proportioning and mixing of 5 the materials will result in a uniform and satisfactory asphalt mixture meeting these 6 Specifications .
All plants shall conform to requirements of Sections 5 and 6 of the 7 Asphalt QMS Manual .
8 Before production of the mix , stockpile aggregates for a sufficient period of time to 9 facilitate the drainage of free moisture .
Keep the different aggregate sizes separated until 10 they have been delivered to the cold feeders .
Keep the separate stockpiles readily 11 accessible for sampling .
When mineral filler is required in the mix , feed or weigh-in 12 separately from the other aggregates .
13 Introduce the asphalt binder and other additives , when required , into the mixture at the 14 amounts and percentages specified by the JMF .
No working tolerance will be allowed .
15 Introduce the hot and dry aggregates , mineral filler , and recycled materials , in amounts 16 and at temperatures such that the mixture produced is within the production control limits 17 of Subarticle 609-6 ( D ) .
Provide a positive means of controlling mixing time to obtain 18 complete and uniform coating of the aggregate particles and thorough distribution of the 19 asphalt binder throughout the aggregate .
Produce the mixture at the asphalt plant within 20 ±25 °F of the JMF mix temperature .
The temperature of the mixture , when discharged 21 from the mixer , shall not exceed 350°F .
22 All asphalt plants shall be certified by the Department .
Certification is effective from the 23 date of issuance and is non-expiring subject to continued compliance .
The Department 24 will check the plant on an annual basis or as deemed necessary by the Engineer .
Any 25 plant that is relocated , modified or changes ownership shall be recertified before use .
26 Any completely automatically controlled asphalt plant that , due to the basic design of the 27 plant , does not meet all these Specifications for conventional batch mixing , continuous 28 mixing or drum mixing may be used on a project by project basis provided a uniformly 29 consistent mix meeting all mix requirements can be produced and the plant has been 30 approved in writing .
31 Any asphalt plant that can not consistently produce a high quality mix meeting these 32 Specifications will be in non-compliance with these Specifications and may have its 33 certification revoked .
34 Upon a malfunction of required automatic equipment on a batch mixing plant , the plant 35 may continue to operate manually for the following 2 consecutive working days , 36 provided acceptable mixture is being produced .
37 When a malfunction of required automatic equipment on a drum mixer or continuous 38 plant occurs , manual operation of the plant will not be allowed except that if , in the 39 opinion of the Engineer , an emergency traffic condition exists , the plant may be allowed 40 to operate manually until the unsafe traffic condition is corrected .
All mix produced by 41 manual operation will be subject to Section 609 .
42 Section 610 6-21 610-6 HOT MIX STORAGE SYSTEMS 1 When a storage system is used , provide a system capable of conveying the mix from the plant 2 to the storage bin and storing the mix without a loss in temperature , segregation or oxidation 3 of the mix .
Limit storage time to the ability of the storage system to maintain the mix within 4 the Specification requirements .
Material may be stored in storage bins without an approved 5 heating system for no more than 24 hours .
6 Provide a continuous type or skip bucket type conveyor system .
Enclose continuous type 7 conveyors so that the mix temperature is maintained within specification requirements .
8 Provide a system designed in such manner as to prevent segregation of the mix during 9 discharge from the conveyor into the bins and equipped with discharge gates that will not 10 cause segregation of the mix while loading the mix into trucks .
11 610-7 HAULING OF ASPHALT MIXTURE 12 Transport the mixture from the mixing plant to the point of use in vehicles that have tight , 13 clean , smooth beds approved by the Department , that have been sprayed with an approved 14 release agent material to prevent the mixture from adhering to the beds .
Remove excess 15 release agent before loading .
Cover each load of mixture with a solid , waterproof tarp 16 constructed of canvas , vinyl , or other suitable material .
Provide a 3/8 inch to 5/8 inch 17 diameter hole on each side of the vehicle body near the center of the body and above the bed 18 of the vehicle for the purpose of inserting a thermometer .
19 Assure temperature of the mixture immediately before discharge from the hauling vehicle is 20 within a tolerance of ±25°F of the specified JMF mix temperature .
21 610-8 SPREADING AND FINISHING 22 Apply tack coat in accordance with Section 605 .
23 Mixtures produced simultaneously from different plant sources can not be intermingled by 24 hauling to the same paver on the roadway unless the mixtures are being produced from the 25 same material sources and same JMF .
26 As referenced in Section 9.6.3 of the Asphalt QMS Manual , use the automatic screed controls 27 on the paver to control the longitudinal profile .
Where approved by the Engineer , the 28 Contractor has the option to use either a fixed or mobile string line .
29 Perform this work in accordance with and using equipment meeting Section 9 of the Asphalt 30 QMS Manual .
31 Use a material transfer vehicle ( MTV ) when placing all asphalt concrete plant mix pavements 32 which require the use of asphalt binder grade PG 76-22 and for all types of OGFC , unless 33 otherwise approved .
Use a MTV for all surface mix regardless of binder grade placed on 34 Interstate and US routes that have 4 or more lanes and median divided .
Where required 35 above , use the MTV when placing all full width travel lanes and collector lanes .
Use MTV 36 for all ramps , loops , Y-line travel lanes , full width acceleration lanes , full width deceleration 37 lanes and full width turn lanes that are greater than 1,000 feet in length .
Use a MTV meeting 38 Section 9.5 ( E ) of the Asphalt QMS Manual .
39 Place asphalt concrete base course material in trench sections with asphalt pavement 40 spreaders made for the purpose or with other equipment approved by the Engineer .
41 Request the Engineer to waive the requirement for use of pavers for spreading and finishing 42 where irregularities or obstacles make their use impractical .
Spread , rake and lute the mixture 43 by hand methods or other approved methods in these areas .
44 Operate the paver as continuously as possible .
Pave intersections , auxiliary lanes and other 45 irregular areas after the main line roadway has been paved , unless otherwise approved .
Place 46 a wedge course at locations ahead of the paving operation as required by the Engineer .
47 Section 610 6-22 Repair any damage caused by hauling equipment across structures at no additional cost to the 1 Department .
2 610-9 COMPACTION 3 Immediately after the asphalt mixture has been spread , struck off and surface and edge 4 irregularities adjusted , thoroughly and uniformly compact the pavement .
Compact the mix to 5 the required degree of compaction for the type of mixture being placed .
6 Provide sufficient number and weight of rollers , except as noted , to compact the mixture to 7 the required density while it is still in a workable condition .
Obtain approval of equipment 8 used in compaction from the Engineer before use .
Where uniform density is not being 9 obtained throughout the depth of the layer of material being tested , change the type and/or 10 weight of the compaction equipment as necessary to achieve uniform density even though 11 such equipment has been previously approved .
12 Compact all final wearing surfaces , except OGFC , using a minimum of two steel-wheel 13 tandem rollers , unless otherwise approved .
Pneumatic-tire rollers with two tandem axles and 14 smooth tread tires may be used for intermediate rolling .
15 Limit rolling for OGFC to one coverage with a tandem steel-wheel roller weighing a 16 maximum of 10 tons , with additional rolling limited to one coverage with the roller where 17 necessary to improve the riding surface .
18 Steel-wheel tandem vibratory rollers specifically designed for the compaction of asphalt 19 pavements may be used on all layers 1 inch or greater in thickness during the breakdown and 20 intermediate rolling phase .
Do not operate vibratory rollers in the vibratory mode during the 21 finish rolling phase on any mix type or pavement course , OGFC or on PADC .
22 When vibratory rollers are used , use rollers that have variable amplitude and frequency 23 capabilities and that are designed specifically for asphalt pavement compaction .
Provide 24 rollers equipped with controls that automatically disengage the vibration mechanism before 25 the roller stops when being used in the vibratory mode .
26 The Engineer may prohibit or restrict the use of vibratory rollers where damage to the 27 pavement being placed , the underlying pavement structure , drainage structures , utilities or 28 other facilities is likely to occur or is evident .
29 Do not use rolling equipment that results in excessive crushing of the aggregate or excessive 30 displacement of the mixture .
31 In areas inaccessible to standard rolling equipment , thoroughly compact the mixture by the 32 use of hand tampers , hand operated mechanical tampers , small rollers or other approved 33 methods .
34 Use rollers that are in good condition and capable of being reversed without backlash to 35 compact the mixture .
Operate rollers with the drive wheels nearest the paver and at uniform 36 speeds slow enough to avoid displacement of the mixture .
Equip steel-wheel rollers with 37 wetting devices that will prevent the mixture from sticking to the roller wheels .
38 Begin compaction of the material immediately after the material is spread and shaped to the 39 required width and depth .
Carry out compaction in such a manner as to obtain uniform 40 density over the entire section .
Perform compaction rolling at the maximum temperature at 41 which the mix will support the rollers without moving horizontally .
Complete the compaction 42 ( including both intermediate rolling ) before the mixture cooling below a workable 43 temperature .
Perform finish rolling to remove roller marks resulting from the compaction 44 rolling operations .

12 610-11 JOINTS 13 ( A ) Transverse Joints 14 When the placing of the mixture is to be suspended long enough to permit the mixture to 15 become chilled , construct a transverse joint .
16 If traffic will not pass over the end of the paving , a butt joint will be permitted , provided 17 proper compaction is achieved .
If traffic will pass over the joint , construct a sloped 18 wedge ahead of the end of the full depth pavement to provide for proper compaction and 19 protection of the full depth pavement .
Construct the joint square to the lane alignment 20 and discard all excess material .
Place a paper parting strip beneath this wedge to 21 facilitate joint construction unless waived by the Engineer .
22 Before paving operations are resumed , remove the sloped wedge and cut back into the 23 previously constructed pavement to the point of full pavement depth .
Coat the exposed 24 edge of the previously constructed pavement with tack coat .
25 When laying of the mixture is resumed at the joint , complete and then test the 26 construction of the joint in accordance with Article 610-12 while the mixture is still in 27 a workable condition .
28 ( B ) Longitudinal Joints 29 Tack the exposed edge of all longitudinal joints before placing the adjoining pavement .
30 Form longitudinal joints by allowing the paver to deposit the mixture adjacent to the joint 31 to such depth that maximum compaction can be obtained along the joint .
Pinch the joint 32 by rolling immediately behind the paver .
33 When multi-lane multi-layer construction is required , offset the longitudinal joints in 34 each layer from that in the layer immediately below by approximately 6 inches .
35 Construct the joints in the final layer , where possible , between designated travel lanes of 36 the final traffic pattern .
37 Section 610 6-24 610-12 SURFACE REQUIREMENTS AND ACCEPTANCE 1 Construct pavements using quality-paving practices as detailed herein .
Construct the 2 pavement surface smooth and true to the plan grade and cross slope .
Immediately correct any 3 defective areas with satisfactory material compacted to conform with the surrounding area .
4 Pavement imperfections resulting from unsatisfactory workmanship such as segregation , 5 improper longitudinal joint placement or alignment , non-uniform edge alignment or excessive 6 pavement repairs will be unsatisfactory .
Pavement imperfections will be evaluated for 7 acceptance in accordance with Article 105-3 .
8 When directed due to unsatisfactory laydown or workmanship , operate under the limited 9 production procedures .
Limited production for unsatisfactory laydown is defined as being 10 restricted to the production , placement , compaction and final surface testing ( if applicable ) of 11 a sufficient quantity of mix necessary to construct only 2,500 feet of pavement at the laydown 12 width .
13 Remain on limited production until such time as satisfactory laydown results are obtained or 14 until three consecutive 2,500 feet sections have been attempted without achieving satisfactory 15 laydown results .
If the Contractor fails to achieve satisfactory laydown results after 16 three consecutive 2,500 feet sections have been attempted , cease production of that mix type 17 until such time as the cause of the unsatisfactory laydown results can be determined .
18 As an exception , the Engineer may grant approval to produce a different mix design of the 19 same mix type if the cause is related to mix problems rather than laydown procedures .
20 Mix placed under the limited production procedures for unsatisfactory laydown or 21 workmanship will be evaluated for acceptance in accordance with Article 105-3 .
22 Each pavement layer will be tested by the Contractor and the Engineer using a 10 foot 23 stationary straightedge furnished by the Contractor .
Any location on the pavement selected 24 by the Department shall be tested as well as all transverse joints .
Apply the straightedge 25 parallel to the centerline of the surface .
Do not exceed 1/8 inch variation of the surface being 26 tested from the edge of the straightedge between any two contact points .
Correct areas found 27 to exceed this tolerance by removal of the defective work and replacement with new material , 28 unless other corrective measures are permitted .
Provide the work and materials required in 29 the correction of defective work .

3 The Inertial Profiler shall be calibrated and verified in accordance with the most current 4 version of AASHTO M 328 .
Provide certification documentation that the profiler meets 5 AASHTO M 328 to the Engineer before the first day the Inertial Profiler is used on the 6 project .

Do not use 8 the profiler ’ s internal IRI calculation mode .
The profile data shall be filtered with 9 a cutoff wavelength of 300 feet .

11 Provide IRI data in accordance with most current version of ASTM E1926 .
Use 12 personnel trained to record and evaluate IRI data .

17 Remove all objects and foreign material on the pavement surface prior to longitudinal 18 pavement profile testing .
19 Operate the profiler at any speed as per the manufacturer ’ s recommendations to collect 20 valid data .
Operate the Inertial Profiler in the direction of the final traffic pattern .
21 Collect IRI data from both wheel paths during the same run .
Define a “ wheel path ” as 22 the 3 feet from the edge of the travel lane .
MRI values are the average of the IRI values 23 from both wheel paths .
When using an inertial profiler that collects a single trace per 24 pass , take care to ensure that the measurements from each trace in a travel lane start and 25 stop at the same longitudinal locations .
Unless otherwise specified , multiple runs are not 26 necessary for data collection .
27 Operate the automatic triggering method at all times unless impractical .
A tape stripe or 28 traffic cone wrapped with reflective material may be used to alert the profiler ’ s automatic 29 triggering sensor to begin data collection .
The profiler shall reach the intended operating 30 speed before entering the test section .
The runup and runout distances should be 31 sufficient to obtain the intended operating speed and to slow down after testing is 32 completed .
33 Divide the pavement surface for the project into sections which represent a continuous 34 placement ( i.e .
the start of the project to bridge , intersection to intersection ) .
Terminate 35 a section 50 feet before a bridge approach , railroad track , or similar interruption .
36 ( Separate into 0.10-mile sections ) .
37 The evaluation of the profiles will be performed on a section basis .
A section is 38 0.10 mile of a single pavement lane .
For any section , which is less than 0.10 mile in 39 length , the applicable pay adjustment incentive will be prorated on the basis of the actual 40 length .
41 Mark the limits of structures and other special areas to be excluded from testing using the 42 profiler ’ s event identifier such that the exact locations can be extracted from the profile 43 data file during processing .

Perform smoothness tests within 7 days after receiving authorization .

28 ( B ) Option 2 - North Carolina Hearne Straightedge 29 Push the straightedge manually over the pavement at a speed not exceeding 2 miles per 30 hour .
For all lanes , take profiles in the right wheel path approximately 3 feet from the 31 right edge of pavement in the same direction as the paving operation , unless otherwise 32 approved due to traffic control or safety considerations .
As an exception , lanes adjacent 33 to curb and gutter , expressway gutter , or shoulder berm gutter may be tested in the left 34 wheel path .
Make one pass of the straightedge in each full width travel lane .
The full 35 lane width should be comparable in ride quality to the area evaluated with the Hearne 36 Straightedge .
If deviations exist at other locations across the lane width , use a 10 foot 37 non-mobile straightedge or the Hearne Straightedge to evaluate which areas may require 38 corrective action .
Take profiles as soon as practical after the pavement has been rolled 39 and compacted , but no later than 24 hours following placement of the pavement , unless 40 otherwise authorized by the Engineer .
Take profiles over the entire length of final 41 surface travel lane pavement exclusive of Y-line travel lanes less than or equal to 42 1,000 feet in length , ramps less than or equal to 1,000 feet in length , turn lanes less than 43 or equal to 1,000 feet in length , structures , approach slabs , paved shoulders , loops and 44 tapers or other irregular shaped areas of pavement , unless otherwise approved by the 45 Engineer .
Test in accordance with this provision all mainline travel lanes , full width 46 Section 610 6-28 acceleration or deceleration lanes , Y-line travel lanes greater than 1,000 feet in length , 1 ramps , full width turn lanes greater than 1,000 feet in length and collector lanes .
2 At the beginning and end of each day 's testing operations , and at such other times as 3 determined by the Engineer , operate the straightedge over a calibration strip so that the 4 Engineer can verify correct operation of the straightedge .
The calibration strip shall be 5 a 100 foot section of pavement that is reasonably level and smooth .
Submit each day ’ s 6 calibration graphs with that day ’ s test section graphs to the Engineer .
Calibrate the 7 straightedge in accordance with the current NCDOT procedure titled North Carolina 8 Hearne Straightedge - Calibration and Determination of Cumulative Straightedge Index .
9 Copies of this procedure may be obtained from the Department 's Pavement Section in the 10 Construction Unit .
11 Plot the straightedge graph at a horizontal scale of approximately 25 feet per inch with 12 the vertical scale plotted at a true scale .
Record station numbers and references ( bridges , 13 approach slabs , culverts , etc . )
on the graphs .
Distances between references/stations shall 14 not exceed 100 feet .
Have the operator record the Date , Project No. , Lane Location , 15 Wheel Path Location , Type Mix and Operator ’ s Name on the graph .
16 Upon completion of each day 's testing , evaluate the graph , calculate the Cumulative 17 Straightedge Index ( CSI ) and determine which lots , if any , require corrective action .
18 Document the evaluation of each lot on a QA/QC-7 form .
Submit the graphs along with 19 the completed QA/QC-7 forms to the Engineer , within 24 hours after profiles are 20 completed , for verification of the results .
The Engineer will furnish results of their 21 acceptance evaluation to the Contractor within 48 hours of receiving the graphs .
In the 22 event of discrepancies , the Engineer ’ s evaluation of the graphs will prevail for acceptance 23 purposes .
The Engineer will retain all graphs and forms .
24 Use blanking bands of 0.2 inch , 0.3 inch and 0.4 inch to evaluate the graph for 25 acceptance .
The 0.2 inch and 0.3 inch blanking bands are used to determine the 26 Straightedge Index ( SEI ) , which is a number that indicates the deviations that exceed 27 each of the 0.2 inch and 0.3 inch bands within a 100 foot test section .
The Cumulative 28 Straightedge Index ( CSI ) is a number representing the total of the SEIs for one lot , which 29 consist of not more than 25 consecutive test sections .
In addition , the 0.4 inch blanking 30 band is used to further evaluate deviations on an individual basis .
The CSI will be 31 determined by the Engineer in accordance with the current procedure titled North 32 Carolina Hearne Straightedge - Calibration and Determination of Cumulative 33 Straightedge Index .
34 The pavement will be accepted for surface smoothness on a lot by lot basis .
A test 35 section represents pavement one travel lane wide not more than 100 feet in length .
A lot 36 will consist of 25 consecutive test sections , except that separate lots will be established 37 for each travel lane , unless otherwise approved by the Engineer .
In addition , full width 38 acceleration or deceleration lanes , ramps , turn lanes and collector lanes will be evaluated 39 as separate lots .
For any lot that is less than 2,500 feet in length , the applicable pay 40 adjustment incentive will be prorated on the basis of the actual lot length .
For any lot 41 which is less than 2,500 feet in length , the applicable pay adjustment disincentive will be 42 the full amount for a lot , regardless of the lot length .
43 If during the evaluation of the graphs , five lots require corrective action , then proceed on 44 limited production for unsatisfactory laydown in accordance with Article 610-12 .
45 Proceeding on limited production is based upon the Contractor ’ s initial evaluation of the 46 straightedge test results and shall begin immediately upon obtaining those results .
47 Additionally , the Engineer may direct the Contractor to proceed on limited production in 48 accordance with Article 610-12 due to unsatisfactory laydown or workmanship .
49 Section 610 6-29 Limited production for unsatisfactory laydown is defined as being restricted to the 1 production , placement , compaction and final surface testing of a sufficient quantity of 2 mix necessary to construct only 2,500 feet of pavement at the laydown width .
Once this 3 lot is complete , the final surface testing graphs will be evaluated jointly by the Contractor 4 and the Engineer .
Remain on limited production until such time as acceptable laydown 5 results are obtained or until three consecutive 2,500 foot sections have been attempted 6 without achieving acceptable laydown results .
The Engineer will determine if normal 7 production may resume based upon the CSI for the limited production lot and any 8 adjustments to the equipment , placement methods , and/or personnel performing the work .
9 Once on limited production , the Engineer may require the Contractor to evaluate the 10 smoothness of the previous asphalt layer and take appropriate action to reduce and/or 11 eliminate corrective measures on the final surface course .
Additionally , the Contractor 12 may be required to demonstrate acceptable laydown techniques off the project limits 13 before proceeding on the project .
14 If the Contractor fails to achieve satisfactory laydown results after three consecutive 15 2,500 foot sections have been attempted , cease production of that mix type until such 16 time as the cause of the unsatisfactory laydown results can be determined .
17 As an exception , the Engineer may grant approval to produce a different mix design of 18 the same mix type if the cause is related to mix problem ( s ) rather than laydown 19 procedures .
If production of a new mix design is allowed , proceed under the limited 20 production procedures detailed above .

5 620-3 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 6 The requirements of Section 610 that pertain to handling of asphalt binder will be applicable 7 to the work covered by this section .
8 Add silicone to all asphalt binder used in surface courses and open-graded asphalt friction 9 course , unless otherwise directed .
The amount of silicone added will range from one ounce 10 per 2,000 gal of asphalt binder to one ounce per 2,500 gal .
Add silicone to the asphalt binder 11 at the plant site unless added at the source and it is so noted on the delivery ticket .
12 Do not heat the asphalt binder to a temperature in excess of the supplier ’ s recommendation 13 while stored or when being used in production of mix at the asphalt plant .
14 Introduce the actual quantity of asphalt binder at the established percentage shown on the 15 applicable JMF into the mix by the plant weighing or metering system .

17 When required , incorporate an anti-strip additive .

19 Furnish the brand name of the type ( lime or chemical ) , supplier and shipping point of 20 anti-strip additive .
Note on the asphalt binder delivery ticket the rate ( or quantity ) , brand of 21 chemical additive when added at the supplier ’ s terminal .
Introduce and mix chemical anti- 22 strip additive into the asphalt binder at either the supplier 's terminal or at the asphalt plant site 23 at the dosage required by the JMF .
Use in-line blending equipment at either location .
When 24 added at the asphalt plant , use equipment that meets Sections 5 and 6 of the Asphalt QMS 25 Manual .
When added at the supplier 's terminal , use equipment that in-line blends with a 26 constant flow of the additive for a minimum of 80 % of the asphalt binder loading time .
When 27 hydrated lime is used , use equipment to introduce the lime that meets Sections 5 and 6 of the 28 Asphalt QMS Manual .
Thoroughly mix chemical anti-strip additive and asphalt binder 29 together before incorporating into the asphalt plant mix .

Accurately control the proportion of fibers to within ± 10 % of the 9 amount required .
Provide flow indicators or sensing devices for the fiber system that are 10 interlocked with plant controls such that mixture production will be interrupted if introduction 11 of the fiber fails .
12 When a batch type plant is used , add the fiber to the aggregate in the weigh hopper or as 13 approved .
Increase the batch dry mixing time by 8 to 12 seconds , or as directed , to assure the 14 fibers are uniformly distributed before the injection of asphalt binder into the mixer .
15 When a continuous mix or dryer-drum type plant is used , add the fiber to the aggregate and 16 uniformly disperse at the point of injection of asphalt binder .
Add the fiber in such a manner 17 that it will not become entrained in the exhaust system of the drier or plant .

21 Do not place OGFC between October 31 and April 1 of the next year , unless otherwise 22 approved .
The minimum air and road surface temperature for placing Type FC-1 Modified 23 mix will be 60°F .

Use an approved dense graded mixture of similar type material for the 29 repair .

20 Payment will be made under : 21 Pay Item Pay Unit Asphalt Plant Mix , Pavement Repair Ton SECTION 657 22 SEALING EXISTING PAVEMENT CRACKS AND JOINTS 23 657-1 DESCRIPTION 24 The work consists of sealing existing longitudinal and transverse pavement cracks and joints 25 with hot applied joint sealer at locations as directed by the Engineer .
The Contractor will not 26 be required to seal the existing edge joints .
27 28 657-2 MATERIALS 29 Refer to Division 10 .
30 Item Section Hot Applied Joint Sealer 1028-2 657-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 31 Install the sealant so that it forms a complete watertight bond with a high degree of elasticity , 32 with maximum flexibility and longevity under extreme temperature ranges .
33 Clean cracks and joints using a hot compressed air lance to blast out any vegetation , dirt , 34 dampness and loose materials from the cracks and joints .
Equip the air compressor with 35 suitable traps and filters to remove moisture and oil from the compressed air .
Use the hot air 36 lance to dry and warm the adjacent pavement immediately before sealing .
Direct flame dryers 37 are not allowed .
38 Section 660 6-42 Heat and apply the sealant material according to the manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
Use 1 a portable melting kettle for heating the material that is equipped with indirect heating 2 ( air-jacketed flow ) and is capable of constantly agitating the joint sealer to maintain a uniform 3 temperature .
Equip the kettle with either mechanically operated paddles and/or a continuous 4 circulating pump to maintain agitation .
Use heating equipment capable of controlling the 5 sealant material temperature within the manufacturer ’ s recommended temperature range and 6 that is thermostatically-control calibrated between 200°F to 600°F .
Locate a thermometer on 7 the kettle so the Engineer can safely check the temperature of the sealant material .
8 Overheating of the sealant material will not be permitted .
9 Apply sealant in the prepared cracks and joints within the manufacturer ’ s recommended 10 temperature range , using a pressure screed shoe to completely fill the crack or joint , leaving 11 a sealed 2 inch overband .
Excessive overbanding or waste of sealant materials will not be 12 tolerated .
Immediately squeegee the crack seal material to minimize the height of the 13 overband .
All sealed cracks and joints shall have a minimum of 1/8 inch depth of sealant 14 installed .
15 Do not apply the hot applied joint sealer when the surface temperature of the pavement is 16 below 32°F .
Follow manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
17 After the crack or joint has been sealed , promptly remove any surplus sealer on the pavement .
18 Do not permit traffic over the sealed cracks and joints without approval by the Engineer .
19 When approved by the Engineer , place sand or other approved material over the crack or joint 20 to prevent tracking .
21 657-4 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 22 Sealing existing pavement cracks and joints will be measured and paid as the actual number 23 of pounds of material that has satisfactorily been used to seal pavement cracks and joints in 24 the designated highway .
Any material spilled , used in excessive overbanding , wasted , 25 misapplied or unsatisfactorily used in any way will be deducted in determining quantities for 26 payment .
The Engineer will determine the quantity , if any , to be deducted .
The Engineer 's 27 decision on the quantity to be deducted will be final and binding .

31 ( A ) Asphalt Seal Coat 32 Use the type of seal coat as required by the contract .
Seal coat aggregates shall be 33 drained of free moisture and have an amount passing the # 200 sieve no greater than 1.5 % 34 in accordance with Table 1005-1 before use .
Place the seal coat in full-lane widths .
35 Adjust the aggregate rates to provide a sufficient quantity of cover material to be spread 36 over the surface of the seal coat preventing traffic damage , where it is necessary to permit 37 traffic on sections of a completed seal coat .
38 Perform rolling of each layer immediately after the aggregate has been uniformly spread .
39 Rolling will consist of at least three complete coverages with one pneumatic-tire roller 40 followed by at least one complete coverage with a 5 to 8 ton steel-wheel roller .
All roller 41 coverages shall be completed within 5 minutes of the asphalt emulsion being placed .
Do 42 not allow crushing of the aggregate or picking up of the material by the rollers .
43 Section 660 6-44 The use of a combination steel-wheel and pneumatic-tire roller will be permitted instead 1 of the 5 to 8 ton steel-wheel roller .
2 After the aggregate is thoroughly seated , broom all excess aggregate off of the surface of 3 the seal coat after 3 calendar days but no more than 7 calendar days .
If necessary , use a 4 vacuum truck as directed by the Engineer .
Traffic may be permitted on the seal coat 5 immediately after the rolling is complete .
6 Clean driveways , ditches , turn lanes , and areas adjacent to the AST construction of 7 excess aggregate , excess emulsion run off , over spray or debris from construction .
8 Blotting sand may be required as directed by the Engineer and shall be applied in 9 accordance with Section 818 .
10 The construction of the various types of seal coats will be in accordance with the 11 following additional requirements : 12 ( 1 ) Single Seal 13 Apply emulsion to the existing surface followed immediately by an application of 14 aggregate as specified in the contract .
Uniformly spread the full required amount of 15 aggregate in one application and correct all non-uniform areas before rolling .
16 Immediately after the aggregate has been uniformly spread , perform rolling as 17 previously described .
18 ( 2 ) Double Seal 19 Apply emulsion to the existing surface followed immediately by an application of 20 aggregate as specified in the contract ensuring each is uniformly placed over the 21 existing surface and rolled as previously described .
22 Immediately after the first application of seal aggregate has been made uniform and 23 rolled , apply the second application of the required amount of emulsion and seal coat 24 aggregate and roll as previously described .
25 ( 3 ) Triple Seal 26 Follow the procedure outlined in Subarticle 660-8 ( A ) ( 2 ) and apply emulsion and 27 aggregate as a third layer and roll as previously described .
28 ( 4 ) Sand Seal 29 Place the fully required amount of asphalt material in one application and 30 immediately cover with the seal coat aggregate .
Uniformly spread the fully required 31 amount of aggregate in one application and correct all non-uniform areas before 32 rolling .
33 Immediately after the aggregate has been uniformly spread , perform rolling .
34 Broom excess aggregate material from the surface of the seal coat .

43 Section 660 6-45 ( C ) Asphalt Mat Coat for Soil Subgrade 1 The surface on which the mat coat is to be applied shall be approved by the Engineer 2 before the mat coat emulsion is applied .
3 Place a string line guide for application equipment .
Place the mat coat in full-lane widths .
4 Existing surface shall be damp prior to placement of the mat coat .
5 Immediately follow the application of emulsion with the spreading of the aggregate .
6 No more than 5 minutes can elapse from the time the emulsion is applied and the rolling 7 is completed when using CRS-2L or CRS-2P .
8 Mat coat aggregate shall be drained of free moisture and have an amount passing the 9 # 200 sieve no greater than 1.5 % in accordance with Table 1005-1 before use .
Spread the 10 aggregate uniformly at the required rate and correct all non-uniform areas before rolling .
11 Roll immediately after the aggregate is uniformly spread .
Rolling consists of at 12 least three complete coverages with two 5 to 10 ton steel-wheel rollers .
Continue rolling 13 until the aggregate is thoroughly keyed into the emulsion .
Do not allow crushing of the 14 aggregate or picking up of the material by the rollers .
A combination steel-wheel and 15 pneumatic-tire roller will not be permitted .
Use two individual steel-wheel rollers .
The 16 three coverages shall be completed within 5 minutes of the spraying of the emulsion .

45 Section 660 6-46 ( A ) Warranty Period 1 The Department will conduct an inspection of the work and provide written 2 acceptance in accordance with Article 105-17 .
Written acceptance of the work will 3 constitute the start date for the 12 month AST warranty period .
4 ( B ) Situations Affecting the Warranty 5 During the warranty period , the Contractor will not be held responsible for distresses 6 that are caused by factors not related to materials and workmanship .
These include , 7 but are not limited to , chemical and fuel spills , vehicle fires , base failures , and snow 8 plows .
Other factors considered to be beyond the control of the Contractor , which 9 may contribute to pavement distress , will be considered by the Engineer on a case by 10 case basis upon receipt of a written request from the Contractor .
Maintaining traffic 11 on the pavement surface prior to the Engineer ’ s acceptance will not be a condition 12 for voiding the warranty .
13 ( C ) Emergency Repairs 14 If , in the opinion of the Department , a pavement condition covered by the warranty 15 requires immediate attention for the safety of the traveling public , the Contractor will 16 be notified immediately .
If the Contractor can not perform the work in a timely 17 manner , the Department may directly perform or have the corrective work performed 18 by another entity at the Contractor ’ s expense .
Any emergency work performed will 19 not alter the requirements , responsibilities , or obligations of the warranty .

exhibits the desired cross slope of the final surface .

Manual 20 screed operation will be permitted in the construction of irregularly shaped and minor 21 areas , subject to approval .

Do not resume work thereafter until the automatic system is 26 functional .

11 Use any combination of equipment that shall effectively perform the necessary construction 12 operations .

18 700-2 CONCRETE PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT 19 Use batch plants , central mix plants and truck mixers that meet Section 1000 .
20 700-3 CONCRETE HAULING EQUIPMENT 21 Transport concrete to the point of placement either in a truck agitator , a truck mixer operating 22 at agitating speed or in non-agitating equipment meeting the provisions below .
Bottom or 23 belly dump equipment is prohibited .
Provide and secure material covers on the equipment 24 bodies for protection against detrimental environmental conditions .
25 Prevent the accumulation of hardened concrete in the delivery vehicles .
Discharge all 26 flushing water before charging with the next concrete load .
27 When using non-agitating hauling equipment , provide bodies which are smooth , watertight , 28 metal containers with rounded internal corners equipped with vibrators and gates to discharge 29 the concrete without segregation or damage .
30 For concrete hauled in a transit mix ( ready mix ) truck , use Table 1000-2 to determine the 31 maximum elapsed time .
For concrete hauled in other equipment , the elapsed time shall be 32 60 minutes or less , unless otherwise approved .
Define the “ elapsed time ” as the period from 33 first contact between mixing water and cement until the completion of the entire operation 34 including placing , finishing , micro-surfacing and any necessary corrective work .
35 Deliver the concrete to the work site in a thoroughly mixed and uniform mass .
36 If at discharge , the concrete is not thoroughly mixed and homogeneous , the hauling distance , 37 charging sequence , size of load , mixing time or any combination thereof shall be altered to 38 meet these requirements ; otherwise , use other equipment capable of delivering a thoroughly 39 mixed and uniform concrete mass .
40 Section 700 7-2 700-4 PREPARATION OF SUBGRADE AND BASE 1 Prepare the subgrade and base beneath Portland cement concrete pavement in accordance 2 with the applicable sections of these Specifications and with a grading tolerance of ± 1/4 inch 3 from the established grade on mainline lanes and a grading tolerance of ± 1/2 inch in all other 4 areas .
Use approved automatically controlled grading and paving equipment to produce final 5 subgrade and base surfaces meeting the lines , grades and cross sections required by the plans 6 or as directed .
When in the judgment of the Engineer the use of such equipment is 7 impractical , this requirement will be waived .
8 Dampen the surface of the base at the time the concrete is placed .
Sprinkle the base when 9 necessary to provide a damp surface .
Ensure that no free water or ponding is present at the 10 time of concrete placement .
Correct all damaged areas in the subgrade or base before placing 11 concrete .
12 Do not allow traffic on the underlying asphalt courses other than necessary local traffic and 13 essential construction equipment as authorized by the Engineer .
14 Unless otherwise approved , use and maintain a braided metal cable stringline reference to 15 control the profile and alignment of the concrete pavement .
Monitor the stringline for 16 accuracy and tautness .
Set pins at a distance no farther than 50 feet apart .
When located on 17 a vertical curve , set pins no farther than 25 feet apart .
18 700-5 PLACING CONCRETE 19 ( A ) General 20 Use a slip form paver to place concrete except where impractical due to irregular areas or 21 areas of existing pavement adjacent to the proposed pavement .
22 Place concrete only in the presence of the Engineer or his authorized representative .
23 Handle concrete so as to prevent segregation and keep free from mud , soil or any other 24 foreign matter .
25 Where finishing operations must be completed after dark , provide acceptable artificial 26 light in accordance with Section 1413 .
27 Do not pave when any of the following conditions exist : 28 ( 1 ) A descending air temperature at the location of the concrete paving operation and 29 away from artificial heat reaches 35°F .
Paving may resume when the weather 30 forecast is projected to reach a high of 40°F on that day ’ s operation and the morning 31 ambient temperature is above 32°F .
32 ( 2 ) The subgrade or base course is frozen .
33 ( 3 ) Aggregates to be used in the mix contain frozen particles .
34 ( 4 ) Air temperature in the shade is 90°F and rising or the concrete temperature is greater 35 than 95°F .
36 Where additional pavement , aggregate or soil must be placed adjacent to new pavement 37 by machine methods , do not place it until the concrete has attained a compressive 38 strength of at least 3,000 psi .
39 Construction equipment or hauling equipment will not be allowed over the pavement 40 until the concrete has attained a compressive strength of 3,000 psi .
41 Spread the concrete uniformly over the entire area without segregation .
Perform the 42 spreading with a mechanical spreader independent of the paver except where hand 43 methods are necessary due to pavement design , equipment breakdown or other 44 emergencies .
45 Section 700 7-3 ( B ) Slip Form Paver Method 1 Use a slip form paver that is an approved self-propelled machine designed to spread , 2 consolidate , screed and float finish the concrete in one complete pass of the machine to 3 provide a smooth , dense and homogeneous pavement with minimal hand finishing .
Use 4 a slip form paver equipped with forms of sufficient length and rigidity to support the 5 edges of the slab to minimize hand finishing .
Use a slip form paver equipped with both 6 horizontal and vertical automatic controls .
Operate the paver with continuous forward 7 movement and coordinate all operations of mixing , delivering and spreading the concrete 8 to provide uniform progress and minimize stopping and starting of the paver .
9 Provide concrete that has sufficient cohesion to prevent appreciable slumping at the edges 10 of each slab .
Longitudinal straight edge tolerance of 1/4 inch in 10 feet shall apply to the 11 area within 6 inches of the edge .
Edge slump shall be limited to no more than 1/4 inch .
12 ( C ) Fixed Form Method 13 Apply this section to all paving operations where a slip form paver is not being used .
14 Use forms made of metal and of such section and design that they will adequately support 15 the concrete and the construction equipment .
16 Use forms that have a depth not less than the edge thickness of the pavement to be 17 constructed and not more than 1 inch greater than the edge thickness of the pavement to 18 be constructed .
Use a form which has the base width at least equal to the height of the 19 form .
20 Use a form in which the top face does not vary from a true plane more than 1/8 inch in 21 10 feet and the upstanding leg does not vary more than 1/4 inch .
22 Use straight forms that have at least 3 pin pockets per 10 feet in length and at least 2 pin 23 pockets per 5 feet in length .
24 Use form pins that are metal and capable of holding the forms rigidly in place during 25 construction operations .
The Engineer may require pinholes in the base to be sealed 26 before placing subsequent pavement .
27 Connect the form sections by a locking joint that will keep the forms free from vertical 28 and horizontal movement .
29 Use straight forms 10 feet in length on tangents and on curves having a radius of 200 feet 30 or more .
For curves having a radius of between 50 feet and 200 feet use either straight 31 forms 5 feet in length or flexible forms .
Use flexible forms for curves having a radius of 32 less than 50 feet .
33 Clean all forms before they are set .
Oil all forms before placing concrete .
Check the 34 bearing of the forms and correct all areas of inadequate bearing .
35 Remove all rejected forms immediately from the project .
36 Set forms a sufficient distance in advance of the point where the concrete is being placed 37 to provide for a continuous operation in placing the concrete and for proper inspection of 38 line and grade .
39 All forms used for construction joints shall meet this section except provisions shall be 40 made for inserting dowel bars where required .
41 700-6 VIBRATING CONCRETE 42 Uniformly vibrate the concrete after it has been spread .
Consolidate the full width and depth 43 of the concrete in a single pass .
44 Section 700 7-4 Vibrators for full width vibration of concrete may be either the surface pan type or the internal 1 type with either immersed tube or multiple spuds .
Attach the vibrators to the spreader or the 2 finishing machine , or mount the vibrators on a separate carriage .
3 Furnish an electronic vibrator monitoring device , displaying the operating frequency of each 4 individual vibrator on the paving equipment .
Operate the electronic vibrator monitoring 5 device in areas where the mainline , ramp or loop pavement exceeds 600 feet in length .
6 Record the time , station location , paver track speed and operating frequency of each 7 individual vibrator after every 25 feet of paving or after each 5 minute time interval has 8 elapsed .
Provide a report of the vibrator data to the Engineer daily for the first 3 days of 9 paving and weekly thereafter .
The Engineer may determine that more frequent submissions 10 are necessary , particularly if equipment is malfunctioning .
11 Set the internal vibrators to approximately mid slab depth and provide a locking device to 12 avoid contact with any joint , load transfer device , tie bar , subgrade or side form .
Provide an 13 operating position locking device so that no part of the vibrating unit can be lowered to the 14 extent that it will come in contact with dowel bars , dowel bar assemblies or tie bars while 15 paving .
16 Set the horizontal spacing of vibrators to the manufacturer 's recommendations , but in no case 17 exceed 16 inches from center to center .
18 Operate internal and spud vibrators within a frequency range of 3,500 to 8,000 vpm and 19 surface vibrators within a frequency range of 3,500 to 6,500 vpm .
Operate vibrators to avoid 20 separation of the mix ingredients .
A reduction in vibrator frequency may be required when 21 the forward motion of the paver is reduced to avoid separation of the mix .
Either discontinue 22 the use or remove from contact with the concrete , the machine mounted vibrators , whenever 23 the forward motion of the machinery is stopped .
24 Should the electronic monitoring device fail to operate properly , immediately check the 25 vibrators manually in the presence of the Engineer .
If the vibrators are functioning properly , 26 paving may continue .
Repair the monitoring device within 3 production days or suspend 27 paving .
28 700-7 FINISHING 29 Finish concrete pavement or concrete shoulders in accordance with Article 710-6 or 720-7 , 30 respectively .
Do not use excessive water for finishing .
31 700-8 PROTECTION OF PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE PAVEMENT 32 ( A ) General 33 Protect the concrete pavement from environmental conditions .
Remove and replace 34 concrete pavement damaged as a result of environmental conditions .
35 Use protective covering that will protect the surface of the freshly placed pavement from 36 rain or cold weather readily available each day at the location of each proposed day 's 37 operation before beginning work .
Store an adequate quantity of these materials at the 38 paving train .
39 ( B ) Cold Weather 40 When the temperature is projected to drop below 35°F for more than four hours , insulate 41 the concrete pavement to prohibit the concrete surface temperature from dropping below 42 35°F during the curing period .
43 ( C ) Hot Weather 44 When the anticipated daily high temperature is above 90°F , place the concrete at the 45 coolest temperature practical .
Control concrete temperatures to assure proper placing , 46 consolidation , finishing , curing and to prevent plastic shrinkage cracking .
47 Section 700 7-5 ( D ) Rain 1 When rain appears imminent , stop all paving operations , and ensure all available 2 personnel protect the surface of the unhardened concrete .
Failure to properly protect the 3 concrete pavement may constitute cause for removal and replacement of the damaged 4 pavement .
5 700-9 CURING 6 ( A ) General 7 Immediately after finishing operations have been completed and surface water has 8 disappeared , cover all exposed surfaces of the pavement by one of the curing methods 9 herein or as approved by the Engineer .
10 Apply the selected curing method to the edges of the pavement immediately after the 11 forms are removed .
12 Curing is required until the concrete compressive strength has exceeded 3,000 psi using 13 the maturity method in accordance with Article 700-13 .
14 ( B ) Membrane Curing Compound 15 After final finish and immediately after the free surface moisture has disappeared , use 16 a minimum application rate of 0.0067 gal/sf when the application equipment is 17 mechanically operated .
Provide an inline flow-metering device to ensure the proper rate 18 is applied .
Apply the curing compound such that puddling or ponding does not occur on 19 the fresh concrete surface .
20 Use mechanically operated application equipment designed to apply a uniformly agitated 21 continuous flow of the curing compound at the prescribed rate to all concrete surfaces .
22 Hand spraying shall only be permitted for irregular widths or shapes and surfaces 23 exposed by removal of forms .
The rate of application for these areas shall be 0.01 gal/sf .
24 Do not expose newly placed concrete for more than 30 minutes before being covered 25 with curing compound .
Failure to cover the surfaces of the concrete shall be cause for 26 immediate suspension of the paving operation .
27 Protect the membrane curing compound film at all times during the curing period and 28 repair any damage immediately .
Ensure a sufficient amount of polyethylene film , burlap 29 or other approved material is available to provide for protection of the concrete during 30 rain or when the application equipment fails to apply the curing compound uniformly to 31 all surfaces .
32 Reapply curing compound to any concrete surfaces that received heavy rainfall within 33 3 hours after initial application .
34 ( C ) Polyethylene Film 35 Spread the sections of the film in a manner that will not damage the finished pavement 36 surface .
Securely tape or provide lap joints for the sections that are at least 12 inches 37 wide , and take suitable precautions to prevent the circulation of air beneath the film .
38 Cover all exposed surfaces and beyond the edge of the pavement surface .
39 Use black or dark plastic sheets when the daily high ambient temperature is between 40 40°F and 60°F .
Use white opaque reflective plastic sheet when the daily ambient 41 temperature is above 60°F .
Plastic sheets will meet ASTM C171 .
42 Check the film for damage when it is spread and during the curing period .
Repair or 43 replace any damaged sections immediately .
44 Section 700 7-6 ( D ) Burlap 1 Spread the sections of burlap in a manner that will not damage the finished pavement 2 surface .
Provide lap joints that are at least 6 inches wide .
3 Use an amount of burlap that is not less than 12 ounces per running yard based on a 4 40 inch width .
Use either one layer of Class 4 burlap or 2 layers of Class 1 , 2 or 3 burlap .
5 Saturate the burlap thoroughly before placing on the concrete and keep thoroughly wet 6 throughout the curing period .
7 700-10 REMOVING FORMS 8 Do not remove forms from freshly placed concrete for at least 12 hours after placement and 9 until the concrete has hardened sufficiently to resist spalling , cracking or any other damage .
10 Repair any honeycombed areas along the sides or edges of the slab by filling with mortar 11 immediately after the forms have been removed .
Use mortar consisting of one part cement to 12 2 parts fine aggregate .
13 700-11 JOINT CONSTRUCTION 14 ( A ) General 15 Construct all joints in accordance with these Standard Specifications and the details 16 shown on the plans .
Saw all transverse joints and seal them with joint sealer in 17 accordance with the dimensions and details shown in the contract .
Seal joints in 18 accordance with Article 700-12 .
19 Saw the concrete pavement as soon as it can support the weight of the equipment and 20 operator without disturbing the final finish .
Saw joints in a neat , vertical straight line 21 without chipping , spalling , tearing or disturbing the final finish .
22 Ensure an adequate amount of sawing equipment is available to match the production and 23 concrete paving operations .
At least one standby sawing unit is recommended .
24 Construct the joint groove using a 1/8 inch saw blade to a minimum depth of 4 inches or 25 the design thickness divided by 3 whichever is less .
Perform sawing as soon as the 26 concrete has hardened sufficiently without undercutting , spalling and raveling to control 27 random cracking .
To estimate the time of sawing , it is recommended to use the latest 28 version of FHWA ’ s High Performance Paving software entitled HIPERPAV .
29 Immediately after sawing the joint to the dimensions shown on the plans , completely 30 remove the resulting slurry from the joint without damaging the adjacent concrete .
31 Immediately reapply curing membrane to areas damaged by the sawing operation .
32 Deviations from the method of joint construction specified in the contract requires prior 33 approval in writing .
Such approval is conditional and is subject to obtaining satisfactory 34 results .
35 The Engineer may order any concrete pavement or shoulder where uncontrolled cracking 36 has occurred before final acceptance to be removed and replaced at no cost to the 37 Department .
Where permitted , the Contractor may be allowed to repair the cracking in 38 a manner acceptable to the Engineer .
39 Before placing either concrete pavement or concrete shoulders adjacent to a previously 40 placed pavement , cover the transverse joint opening on the edge of the existing slab to 41 prevent intrusion of grout into the opening .
42 ( B ) Transverse Contraction Joints 43 Construct transverse contraction joints in accordance with the details , dimensions and 44 intervals as shown on the plans .
45 Section 700 7-7 ( C ) Longitudinal Contraction Joints 1 Construct longitudinal contraction joints in all pavements wider than 16 feet in 2 accordance with the details and dimensions shown on the plans .
3 ( D ) Transverse Construction Joints 4 ( 1 ) General 5 Construct transverse construction joints by use of an approved form at the end of 6 each day 's operations ( planned joint ) or whenever the placing of concrete is 7 suspended for more than 30 minutes ( emergency joint ) .
8 ( 2 ) Planned Transverse Construction Joints 9 Locate this type of joint at the same spacing required for contraction joints .
Use 10 dowel bars of the size and spacing shown on the plans .
11 ( 3 ) Emergency Transverse Construction Joints 12 Use this type of joint when the placing of concrete is suspended for more than 13 30 minutes .
Use tie bars of the size and spacing shown on the plans .
14 Do not change the spacing of contraction joints due to emergency construction joints .
15 Locate the emergency construction joints at least 6 feet from any contraction joint or 16 planned construction joint .
17 ( E ) Longitudinal Construction Joints 18 Construct longitudinal construction joints using tie bars in accordance with the details 19 shown on the plans .
20 ( F ) Transverse Expansion Joints 21 Construct transverse expansion joints in accordance with the details shown on the plans 22 utilizing an approved joint assembly .
23 ( G ) Verification of Dowel Bar Alignment 24 Use either properly secured dowel baskets or a dowel bar inserter , provided the ability to 25 correctly locate and align the dowels at the joints is demonstrated as described below .
26 Provide a calibrated magnetic imaging device that will document dowel bar location and 27 alignment .
Calibrate the magnetic imaging device to the type and size dowel bar used in 28 the work .
Use this device as a process control and make necessary adjustment to ensure 29 the dowels are placed in the correct location .
30 Scan at least 25 % of the joints in the initial placement or 1.0 mile of pavement , 31 whichever is greater , at random intervals , as selected by the Engineer , throughout the 32 pavement each time the paving train is mobilized .
Mark scanned joints on the pavement .
33 Scan all joints in this initial placement if the dowel bars exhibit longitudinal translation 34 ( side shift ) , horizontal translation , vertical translation ( depth ) , horizontal skew or vertical 35 tilt , above the allowable tolerances defined below .
In addition , continue scanning no less 36 than 25 % of the joints until it is established that the dowel bar inserter or secured dowel 37 basket assemblies are consistently placing the dowel bars at the correct location and 38 meeting the tolerances defined in Table 700-1 .
Once the engineer determines that 39 consistency is established , the contractor may reduce the percentage of scanned joints to 40 no less than 10 % .
Any time inconsistency in the placement of the dowel bars becomes 41 evident , additional scanning may be required up to 100 % of the joints .
Materials and 42 Tests Unit will provide Quality Assurance and random verification scans during the 43 initial concrete placement to verify the Contractor ’ s scan results .
The QA frequency will 44 be at least 10 % of the Contractor ’ s scan .
45 Section 700 7-8 If consistency of the proper dowel bar alignment can not be established within 1 a reasonable time frame , the Engineer will have the option of suspending the paving 2 operation .
3 Provide a report of the scanned joints within 48 hours of completing the day ’ s 4 production .
The report should include the station and lane of the joint scanned , as well as 5 the horizontal location , depth , longitudinal translation ( side shift ) , horizontal skew and 6 vertical tilt , and total misalignment , of each dowel bar in the joint .
If a dowel bar inserter 7 is used , the joint score described below should also be provided in the report .
8 Longitudinal translation ( side shift ) is defined as the position of the center of the dowel 9 bar in relation to the sawed joint .
The maximum allowable longitudinal translation ( side 10 shift ) is 2 inches .
11 Horizontal translation is defined as difference in the actual dowel bar location from its 12 theoretical position as detailed in the standard details .
The maximum allowable 13 horizontal translation is 2 inches .
14 Vertical translation ( depth ) is the difference in the actual dowel bar location from the 15 theoretical midpoint of the slab .
The maximum allowable vertical translation is 1/2 inch 16 higher than the theoretical midpoint and 1inch lower than the theoretical midpoint .
17 Dowel bar misalignment , either vertical tilt or horizontal skew is defined as the difference 18 in position of the dowel bar ends with respect to each other .
Vertical tilt is measured in 19 the vertical axis whereas horizontal skew is measured in the horizontal axis .
20 If a dowel bar inserter is used , determine a joint score for each joint scanned .
The joint 21 score is a measure of the combined effects from the dowel ’ s horizontal skew or vertical 22 tilt .
The joint score is determined by summing the product of the weight shown in the 23 Table 700-1 and the number of bars in each misalignment category and adding one .
The 24 vertical tilt and horizontal skew should be evaluated and the total misalignment shall be 25 used in determining the joint score .
26 TABLE 700-1 TOLERANCE FOR DOWEL BAR ALIGNMENTA Misalignment Category , inches ( mm ) Weight 0 ≤ d ≤ 0.6 ( 15 ) 0 0.6 ( 15 ) < d ≤ 0.8 ( 20 ) 2 0.8 ( 20 ) < d ≤ 1.00 ( 25 ) 4 1.00 ( 25 ) < d ≤ 1.50 ( 38 ) 5 1.50 ( 38 ) ≤ d 10 A .
Where d is the individual dowel bar misalignment .
27 A joint that has a joint score of 12 or greater will be considered locked .
28 When a locked joint as defined above is discovered , scan the 2 joints immediately 29 adjacent to the locked joint .
If either of the adjacent joints are deemed to be locked , 30 provide a written proposal to address the dowel misalignment for each locked joint .
31 No corrective action should be performed without written approval .
32 700-12 SEALING JOINTS 33 ( A ) General 34 Seal all joints with an approved low modulus silicone sealant in the presence of the 35 Engineer .
36 Install backer rod and sealant in accordance with the details shown in the plans and the 37 manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
38 Section 700 7-9 Any failure of the joint material will be cause for rejection .
Repair the failed joint 1 material as approved by the Engineer .
2 When requested , have a representative of the silicone sealant manufacturer present on the 3 project during the sealing operation .
4 ( B ) Age of Pavement 5 Do not seal the joints until the concrete is at least 7 calendar days old and concrete is dry 6 based on sealant manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
7 Do not perform final sawing and sealing of concrete pavement joints until after surface 8 testing , correction of surface deficiencies and all adjacent earth and paved shoulder 9 construction has been completed .
10 ( C ) Temperature 11 Do not place joint sealant when the air temperature near the joint is less than 45°F or 12 is 45°F and falling .
13 ( D ) Sealing the Joint 14 Immediately after sawing the joint to the dimensions as shown on the plans , completely 15 remove the resulting slurry from the joint by flushing with a jet of water under pressure .
16 Use sand blasting to clean joint faces before applying sealant .
Make as many passes with 17 a sand blaster as are necessary to provide a clean joint wall .
18 Blow all joints clear of deleterious materials with air using a nozzle pressure of at least 19 90 psi before installing the backer rod .
Use rotary screw compressors for this purpose 20 that are equipped with traps capable of removing water and oil from the air .
Maintain the 21 traps in accordance with manufacturer 's instructions .
22 Apply sealer only on thoroughly clean and dry joints .
Place the sealer to closely conform 23 to dimensions shown on the plans .
Any unreasonable deviation will be cause for 24 rejection .
25 ( E ) Cleaning Pavement 26 After a joint has been sealed , remove surplus joint sealer on the pavement as soon as 27 possible .
28 700-13 USE OF NEW PAVEMENT OR SHOULDER 29 Traffic or other heavy equipment will not be allowed on the concrete pavement or shoulder 30 until the estimated compressive strength of the concrete using the maturity method has 31 exceeded 3,000 psi .
Estimate the compressive strength of concrete pavement in accordance 32 with ASTM C1074 unless otherwise specified .
33 Furnish thermocouples or thermistors and digital data logging maturity meters that 34 automatically compute and display the maturity index in terms of a temperature-time 35 factor ( TTF ) .
The maturity meters must be capable of storing at least 28 days worth of data 36 and exporting data into an Excel® spreadsheet .
Install loggers in slabs after every 2 lots 37 approximately 4 inches from the concrete surface .
Submit the proposed equipment to the 38 Engineer for approval .
39 When establishing a strength-maturity relationship , perform compressive tests at ages 1 , 3 , 7 , 40 14 and 28 days in accordance with AASHTO T 22 .
41 Use the TTF maturity function to compute the maturity index from the measured temperature 42 history of the concrete .
Set the datum temperature at -10°C to calculate the TTF in 43 Equation 1 of ASTM C1074 .
44 Section 700 7-10 Establish and submit a strength-maturity relationship in conjunction with each concrete 1 pavement mix design .
Determine the TTF corresponding to the strength-maturity relationship 2 at 3,500 psi , TTF .
Any changes to plant operations , material sources or mix proportions will 3 affect the strength-maturity relationship .
If any changes occur during production , develop 4 a new strength-maturity relationship unless otherwise directed .
5 Validate the strength-maturity relationship and the correlation between cylinders and beams 6 during the first day ’ s production by casting cylinders and beams and performing strength 7 tests .
Use the TTF developed during the mix design process to verify the strength-maturity 8 relationship .
9 Validate the strength-maturity relationship and the correlation between cylinders and beams 10 by casting cylinders and beams and performing strength tests at least every 30 calendar days , 11 or when the TTF varies by more than 10 % from the latest approved maturity curve or there is 12 a material change from the approved concrete mix design .
If the verification sample ’ s 13 compressive strength when tested at TTF is less than 3,000 psi , immediately suspend early 14 opening of traffic on pavement that has not obtained TTF until a new strength-maturity 15 relationship is developed .
16 No permanent traffic will be allowed on the pavement until construction of the joints , 17 including all sawing , sealing and curing that is required , has been completed .
18 Take particular care to protect the exposed pavement edges and ends .

14 710-4 ACCEPTANCE OF CONCRETE 15 The Department will test the concrete pavement for acceptance with respect to compressive 16 strength and thickness on a lot by lot basis in accordance with Article 700-15 and the 17 requirements herein .
18 For all concrete pavement , including mainline , shoulders , ramps , tapers , intersections , 19 entrances , crossovers and irregular areas not otherwise defined , produce a lot consisting of 20 1,333.3 sy or fraction thereof placed within 28 calendar days .
From each lot , the Engineer 21 will make at least one set of two 6 inch x 12 inch cylinders from a randomly selected batch of 22 concrete .
The average compression strength of the 2 cylinders is considered one test .
If 23 Department personnel make and test additional sets of cylinders for a lot , all sets will be 24 averaged with the original set to determine the strength .
In the case of low strength , the 25 Engineer will perform an investigation .
26 710-5 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 27 Construct concrete pavement in accordance with Section 700 .
28 Place concrete in 2 lane minimum widths in a single operation except as follows : 29 ( A ) Where the total number of lanes is an odd number , in which case one of the lanes may be 30 placed in a separate operation .
31 ( B ) Areas such as ramps or auxiliary lanes where the total width is less than 2 lanes .
32 710-6 FINISHING 33 Screed and float finish the concrete to the required cross section that minimizes or eliminates 34 hand finishing .
Additional water for finishing will not be allowed .
Hand finishing will not be 35 permitted except under the following conditions : 36 ( A ) Narrow widths or irregular areas , where operation of mechanical equipment is 37 impractical .
38 Section 710 7-13 ( B ) If a breakdown of mechanical equipment occurs , hand methods may be used to finish 1 only that concrete deposited on the base before the breakdown .
2 ( C ) Abnormal circumstances of short duration subject to approval .
3 Produce a final finish on the pavement surface true to grade and uniform in appearance and 4 free of irregular , rough or porous areas .
5 Following the finishing of the pavement by screeding , floating and checking with 6 straightedges , further finish the surface of the pavement by burlap dragging or other 7 acceptable method to produce a uniform surface texture .
Pull the burlap drag in a longitudinal 8 direction .
9 Produce the final surface finish on all mainline pavement , auxiliary lanes , and ramps by 10 mechanical equipment for longitudinally tined grooves while the concrete is plastic .
The 11 tining shall be done with a mechanical device such as a wire comb .
The comb shall have a 12 single row of tines .
Each shall have a nominal width of 5/56 inch to 1/8 inch .
The nominal 13 spacing of the tines shall be 3/4 ± 1/8 inch center-to-center .
The nominal depth of tined 14 groove in the plastic concrete shall be 1/8 ± 1/32 inch .
15 Longitudinal tining shall be accomplished by equipment with automated horizontal and 16 vertical controls to ensure straight , uniform depth tined grooves .
The texture geometry shall 17 be the same as imparted throughout the length of the tining comb .
A 2 inch to 3 inch wide 18 strip of pavement surface shall be protected from tining for the length of and centered about 19 longitudinal joints .
20 The tining operation shall be done so that the desired surface texture will be achieved while 21 minimizing displacement of the larger aggregate particles and before the surface permanently 22 sets .
Where abutting pavement is to be placed , the tining shall extend as close to the edge as 23 possible without damaging the edge .
If abutting pavement is not to be placed , the 6 inch area 24 nearest the edge or 1 foot from the face of the curb shall not be tined .
Hand-operated tining 25 equipment that produces an equivalent texture may be used only on small or irregularly 26 shaped areas .
Tines shall be thoroughly cleaned at the end of each day ’ s use and damaged or 27 worn tines replaced .
28 When surface corrections for pavement smoothness are made in the hardened concrete , no 29 additional texturing is required .
30 After final finishing , hand finishing may be required on the edges of pavement and joints 31 whenever irregularities in surface texture or alignment occur .
Care should be taken in hand 32 finishing pavement edges to avoid ridges or high places that will prevent water from draining 33 out of the transverse grooves .
34 The use of excessive water during the finishing operations will not be permitted .
35 Provide a textured surface with an average texture depth of 0.8 mm as tested in accordance 36 with ASTM E965 with no single test having a texture depth of 0.5 mm or less .
Perform4 37 randomly located tests in accordance with ASTM E965 within the initial pavement lot of each 38 mobilization in the presence of the Engineer .
A “ lot ” is defined in Article 710-4 .
If the 39 average of the 4 tests does not meet the above criteria , make appropriate changes to the 40 surface texture operations and test the next lot as detailed above .
Once the surface texture 41 process is established to meet minimum texture requirements , maintain consistency within the 42 operation to provide the above minimum texture depth .
Perform additional sand patch tests in 43 accordance with ASTM E965 when directed .
44 If the surface texture becomes damaged or reduced by rain or any other action , reestablish or 45 restore surface texture by an approved method .
46 710-7 FINAL SURFACE TESTING 47 Use an Inertial Profiler to measure the longitudinal pavement profile for construction quality 48 control and smoothness acceptance .
Use a profiler with line laser technology as single-point 49 Section 710 7-14 laser technology will not be allowed .
Produce International Roughness Index ( IRI ) and Mean 1 Roughness Index ( MRI ) values for measuring smoothness .
2 Use testing and recording software to produce electronic inertial road profiles in a format 3 compatible with the latest version of FHWA ’ s ProVAL ( Profile Viewing and Analysis ) 4 software .
5 The Inertial Profiler shall be calibrated and verified in accordance with the most current 6 version of AASHTO M 328 .
Provide certification documentation that the profiler meets 7 AASHTO M 328 to the Engineer before the first day the Inertial Profiler is used on the 8 project .
9 Configure the profiler to record the actual elevation of the pavement surface .
Do not use the 10 profiler ’ s internal IRI calculation mode .
The profile data shall be filtered with a cutoff 11 wavelength of 250 feet .
The interval at which relative profile elevations are reported shall be 12 a maximum of 1 inch .
13 Provide IRI data in accordance with most current version of ASTM E1926 .
Use personnel 14 trained to record and evaluate IRI data .
15 Provide a competent operator , trained in the operation of the Inertial Profiler .
Operation of 16 the Inertial Profiling system shall conform to AASHTO R 57 .
17 Provide the user selected Inertial Profiler settings to the Engineer for the project records .
18 Certification of the Inertial Profiling system shall conform to AASHTO R 56 .
19 Remove all objects and foreign material on the pavement surface prior to longitudinal 20 pavement profile testing .
21 Operate the profiler at any speed as per the manufacturer ’ s recommendations , however , the 22 speed must be constant to within ± 3 mph of the intended speed and any required acceleration 23 should be as gradual as possible .
For example , if the intended speed were 30 mph , the 24 acceptable range of speed for testing would be 27 to 33 mph .
25 Operate the Inertial Profiler in the direction of the final traffic pattern .
Collect IRI data from 26 both wheel paths during the same run .
It is permissible to collect data one wheel path at a 27 time if each wheel path is tested and evaluated separately .
Define a “ wheel path ” as the 3 feet 28 from the edge of the travel lane .
MRI values are the average of the IRI values from both 29 wheel paths .
When using an inertial profiler that collects a single trace per pass , take care to 30 ensure that the measurements from each trace in a travel lane start and stop at the same 31 longitudinal locations .
Unless otherwise specified , multiple runs are not necessary for data 32 collection .
33 Operate the automatic triggering method at all times unless impractical .
A tape stripe or 34 traffic cone wrapped with reflective material may be used to alert the profiler ’ s automatic 35 triggering sensor to begin data collection .
The profiler shall reach the intended operating 36 speed before entering the test section .
The runup and runout distances should be sufficient to 37 obtain the intended operating speed and to slow down after testing is completed .
38 Divide the pavement surface for the project into sections which represent a continuous 39 placement ( i.e .
the start of the project to bridge , intersection to intersection ) .
Terminate 40 a section 50 feet before a bridge approach , railroad track , or similar interruption .
( Separate 41 into 0.10-mile sections ) .
42 The evaluation of the profiles will be performed on a section basis .
A section is 0.10 mile of 43 a single pavement lane .
For any section , which is less than 0.10 mile in length , the applicable 44 pay adjustment incentive will be prorated on the basis of the actual length .
45 Mark the limits of structures and other special areas to be excluded from testing using the 46 profiler ’ s event identifier such that the exact locations can be extracted from the profile data 47 file during processing .
