43 Section 710 7-17 When the measurement of any core , original core or additional cores taken to calculate the 1 average , is less than the plan thickness by more than 1.0 inch , the extent of the removal area 2 due to thickness deficiency will be determined by taking additional exploratory cores at 3 approximately 10 foot intervals parallel to the center line in each direction from the deficient 4 core until an exploratory core is found in each direction which is within 1.0 inch of the plan 5 thickness .
The pavement between these exploratory cores will be removed full lane width 6 wide and replaced with concrete of the thickness shown on the plans .
Exploratory cores for 7 deficient thickness will not be used in averages for adjusted unit price .
8 When the measurement of the core from a lot is deficient by 0.2 inch or less from the plan 9 thickness , no pay reduction will be made for thickness .
When such measurement is deficient 10 by more than 0.2 inch from the plan thickness , take 2 additional cores at random locations 11 within the lot and calculate the average thickness of the lot from the 3 cores .
12 In determining the average thickness of the pavement lot , the Engineer will use all 3 core 13 measurements .
Individual core measurements which are greater than the plan thickness + 0.2 14 inch will be considered as the plan thickness + 0.2 inch .
Individual cores which are less than 15 the plan thickness - 1.0 inch will be considered as the plan thickness - 1.0 inch .
If the average 16 measurement of the 3 cores is within 0.2 inch from the plan thickness , full payment will be 17 made .
If the average measurement of the 3 cores is deficient by more than 0.2 inch from the 18 plan thickness , an adjusted unit price in accordance with Subarticle 710-10 ( B ) will be paid for 19 the lot represented .
20 Areas found deficient in thickness by more than 1.0 inch shall be removed and replaced with 21 concrete of the thickness shown on the plans .
Any full lane or full shoulder width repairs to 22 the concrete pavement shall be performed in accordance with the North Carolina Department 23 of Transportation Partial and Full Depth Repair Manual and not be less than 1/2 of the slab 24 length .
25 Patch all core holes within 72 hours of taking the core , using a Department approved 26 nonshrink grout compatible with the pavement concrete .

26 ( pay factor rounded to nearest 0.1 % ) 27 ( 2 ) Flexural Strength 28 The pay factor for pavement achieving a flexural strength in 28 days of 650 psi or 29 greater is 100 % .
The pay factor for pavement achieving a flexural strength in 30 28 days between 600 psi and 650 psi is determined by the following formula : 31 Pay Factor ( % ) = ( 100 0 .
− 650 − Flexural Strength ) 32 ( pay factor rounded to nearest 0.1 % ) 33 The quantities of Portland cement concrete pavement that meet these criteria , will be paid 34 at an adjusted unit price per square yard for __ '' Portland Cement Concrete Pavement , 35 Through Lanes , ( with dowels ) , __ '' Portland Cement Concrete Pavement , Ramps , ( with 36 dowels ) or __ '' Portland Cement Concrete Pavement , Miscellaneous , ( without dowels ) 37 completed in place and accepted .
The adjusted contract unit price will be determined by 38 multiplying the contract unit price by the pay factor level determined for the average 39 strength of concrete in each lot and will be applicable to the total square yards of concrete 40 in each lot .

6 723-3 METHODS OF PRODUCTION 7 ( A ) Repair of Jointed Concrete Pavement Slabs 8 Repair the slabs in accordance with Section 700 .
9 The concrete shall meet the requirements of Article 723-4 .
Repair of the slabs shall be 10 conducted in one lane at a time and be accomplished with other operations in progress in 11 the same area .
12 For all cases of slab removal , remove the entire 12 feet width and a minimum of 6 feet in 13 the travel direction .
Any remaining portion of a slab that is removed shall not be less 14 than 6 feet in the travel direction .
15 As a result of the full depth sawing of the existing pavement to remove the distressed 16 area , saw cuts that extend into the adjacent pavement shall be filled with epoxy prior to 17 placing traffic on the new area .
The epoxy shall meet the requirements of Section 1081 , 18 Type 3 .
19 Take necessary measures to protect the exposed subgrade and base form damage 20 resulting from surface water or rain during the period between the pavement removal and 21 replacement .
The Contractor shall submit his plan for removing the pavement areas to 22 the Engineer for approval .
The removal method shall minimize damage to the subgrade 23 and to adjacent pavement and shoulders .
24 At locations as directed by the Engineer , the Contractor shall : 25 ( 1 ) Remove unsuitable aggregate base material and backfill with Select Material , Class 26 IV as directed by the Engineer ; or 27 ( 2 ) Remove unsuitable aggregate base material , undercut the subgrade , place Geotextile 28 for Soil Stabilization per Section 270 , and backfill with Select Material , Class IV as 29 directed by the Engineer .
30 Thoroughly tamp any loosened subgrade or base material to the satisfaction of the 31 Engineer before the pavement is replaced .
New pavement shall be cast to match the 32 thickness of the adjacent slabs .
33 Pneumatic or hydraulic drills and bits that will drill a hole in the existing concrete faces 34 for placement of the dowels at location specified on the Plans shall be used .
The 35 equipment shall be operated so as to prevent damage to the pavement being drilled .
The 36 drilling procedure shall be approved by the Engineer .
The drilled holes shall be 37 thoroughly cleaned of all contaminants and the dowels of specified type and size shall 38 then be set into the hardened concrete face of the existing pavement with an epoxy 39 bonding compound meeting the requirements of a Type 3A epoxy detailed in Section 40 1081 .
The specified dowels shall be placed at locations noted on Plan details with one- 41 half of dowel protruding beyond the hardened face of existing pavement and placed at 42 correct horizontal and vertical alignment with misalignment not to exceed 0.4 inches in 43 the vertical or oblique plane .
The epoxy shall be allowed to harden sufficiently prior to 44 placing concrete to prevent any movement of the dowels during the placement of the 45 concrete .
A sufficient amount of epoxy must be placed in the back of the hole so that the 46 entire cavity around the dowel is completely filled upon insertion of the dowel bars .
Any 47 excess epoxy shall be removed .
The epoxy adhesive must be packaged in a cartridge 48 with a mixing nozzle that thoroughly mixes the two components as they are dispensed 49 Section 723 7-23 ( the mixing nozzle must be a minimum of 8 inches long ) or may be placed with a 1 machine which mixes the two components thoroughly and to the proper ratio as the 2 material is being placed .
3 Use dowels of the type , size , spacing , and at the location specified in the Roadway 4 Standard Drawing .
At no time shall dowels be driven into a dowel hole with sledge 5 hammers or other devices .
In all cases , any dowel which can not be freely inserted into a 6 dowel hole will be rejected for use .
7 Prior to placing concrete , the vertical exposed faces of the existing slabs shall be 8 thoroughly cleaned of contaminates using wire brushing or other methods approved by 9 the Engineer .
Extra care must be taken to remove all existing silicone or other joint 10 sealant from the exposed concrete faces .
11 The concrete shall be deposited within the slab replacement area in such manner as to 12 require as little re-handing as possible , to prevent segregation of the mix .
Hand spreading 13 shall be minimized as much as possible , but where necessary , shall be done with shovels , 14 not rakes .
Workers will not be allowed to walk in the fresh concrete with shoes coated 15 with earth or other foreign substances .
The replaced slab area shall be filled with 16 concrete and thoroughly consolidated by rodding , spading , and sufficient vibration to 17 form a dense homogeneous mass throughout the area .
The final surface area shall be 18 uniform in appearance and free of irregularities and porous areas .
19 The finished surface , including joints , shall meet a surface tolerance of 1/8 inch in 10 feet 20 in any direction .
Any necessary corrections shall be done by grinding .
Any replaced slab 21 which is low in relation to adjacent slabs may be ordered replaced by the Engineer .
22 Replacement of such a slab would generally be required if , in the opinion of the 23 Engineer , excessive grinding of the adjacent pavement is necessary to match the profile 24 of the full depth slab replacement or if a drainage problem would be created by grinding 25 the adjacent pavement .
26 The surface finish of the proposed concrete pavement shall be a burlap drag finish and 27 conform to the cross-section of adjacent pavement .
The method of finishing shall be 28 approved by the Engineer .
Immediately after finishing operations have been completed 29 and surface water has disappeared , all exposed surfaces of the pavement shall be cured in 30 accordance with the applicable provisions of Section 700-9 and Section 1026 .
31 ( B ) Patching Concrete Pavement Spalls 32 When the Contractor is working under a lane closure , concrete patching operations shall 33 be conducted in one lane at a time or as directed by the Engineer .
The work shall be 34 accomplished with other operations in progress within the same area .
35 Clean surfaces within the repair area free of oil , dust , dirt , deteriorated concrete and other 36 contaminates immediately before placement of the epoxy and patching material .
Apply 37 epoxy to the vertical and flat surface of the cleaned spall areas prior to placing concrete .
38 The pavement shall not be opened to traffic until the concrete is appropriately cured per 39 the manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
40 723-4 Very High Early Strength Concrete for Concrete Pavement Repair 41 Submit mix designs for Very High Early Strength Concrete for Concrete Pavement Repair in 42 terms of saturated surface dry weights on M & T Form 312U for acceptance at least 30 days 43 before proposed use .
44 Use a mix sufficient to obtain at least a flexural strength of 400 psi at 4 hours or prior to 45 opening to traffic .
Entrain 5 % ± 1.5 % air in the freshly mixed concrete .
Produce the mix 46 with a maximum slump of 1.5 inches for placement by a fully mechanized paving train and a 47 maximum slump of 3 inches for hand placement .
48 Section 723 7-24 Use cement , fine aggregate , coarse aggregate , admixtures and , optionally , pozzolan as shown 1 on NCDOT ’ s APL .
2 Submit 4 hour flexural strength results of at least 6 beams made and tested in accordance with 3 AASHTO T126 and T97 with M & T Form 312U .
In addition , submit 4 hour compressive 4 strength results of at least six 4 inch by 8 inch or 6 inch by 12 inch cylinders and maturity test 5 results of the mix .
With permission of the Engineer , compressive strength testing and maturity 6 testing may be used in lieu of or concurrent with flexural strength testing to determine the 7 acceptability of the concrete in the field .
8 Design and produce the mix in accordance a concrete system that can produce 400 psi flexural 9 strength in approximately 4 hours or a comparable equal system .
The timing of the addition of 10 hydration control admixtures is critical to the performance of this concrete ; therefore , an 11 admixture representative shall be present on the job when Very High Early Strength Concrete 12 is batched .

1 724-3 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 2 A trained and experienced installer , certified by the Geotextile Manufacturer , shall be present 3 on-site during the installation of the geotextile and until the crew has a comfort level working 4 with this material .
5 Ensure that any potential for keying of the two cementitious layers is minimized through 6 proper repair techniques .
Clean the underlying surface to remove loose debris before 7 applying the interlayer .
Roll the geotextile out on the underlying layer .
The geotextile shall 8 be tight and without excess wrinkles and folds .
No more than 650 feet of geotextile shall be 9 installed in advance of the paving operation at a given time .
The interlayer shall be placed no 10 more than 3 days before concrete placement .
11 Keep driving on the interlay to a minimum .
Tight radius turns and excessive acceleration and 12 braking shall be avoided .
13 The geotextile shall be secured to the underlying layer with pins or nails punched through 14 2 to 2.75 inch galvanized washers or disks every 6 feet or less .
Additional fasteners shall be 15 used as needed to ensure that the geotextile does not shift or fold before or during concrete 16 placement .
Edges of the geotextile shall overlap by 8 inches ± 2 inches .
No more than 3 17 Section 725 7-27 layers of geotextile shall overlap at any location .
Transverse seams of adjacent rolls shall be 1 staggered to prevent 4 layers from coinciding at any location .
The free edge of the geotextile 2 shall extend beyond the edge of the new concrete into a location that facilitates drainage .

31 ( C ) Horizontal and Vertical Control 32 The Department will provide azimuth pairs to be used as primary horizontal and vertical 33 control at approximately 1 mile intervals along the project corridor , and secondary 34 horizontal baseline control on approximate 1,000 foot intervals and secondary vertical 35 control on approximate 2,500 foot intervals within the project limits .

37 Clearing limits may be established during original traverse of baseline control provided 38 the accuracy ratio does not exceed 1 foot per 5,000 feet of perimeter and all Department 39 established baseline control is protected and preserved during clearing operations .
Before 40 performing any additional construction layout , verify the horizontal baseline control by 41 a closed traverse survey or alternate approved method based on the established azimuth 42 pairs .
The horizontal accuracy ratio shall not exceed an error of closure of 1 foot per 43 20,000 feet of perimeter .
Verify the vertical control by performing a closed loop survey 44 using differential leveling .

23 Payment will be made under : 24 Pay Item Pay Unit Construction Surveying Lump Sum Supplemental Field Surveying Hour Supplemental Surveying Office Calculations Hour SECTION 802 25 DISPOSAL OF WASTE AND DEBRIS 26 802-1 DESCRIPTION 27 The work consists of the disposal of waste and debris including , but not limited to , furnishing 28 any waste areas ; providing and implementing a Development , Use and Reclamation Plan ; any 29 right of access to waste areas ; disposing of waste and debris ; dressing and shaping of waste 30 areas ; furnishing and spreading earth material over debris , rock , broken pavement and 31 masonry ; clearing and grubbing of waste areas ; hauling waste and debris to waste areas or 32 permitted landfills ; assessment for wetlands and endangered species ; obtaining required 33 permits or certifications ; and any tipping fees required for disposal in permitted landfills .
34 Define “ waste ” as all excavated materials that are not used in the construction of the project , 35 including overburden from borrow sources and soil-type base course sources .
36 Define “ debris ” as all undesirable material encountered on the project .
37 802-2 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 38 Follow the most recent reclamation procedures found on the Department ’ s website for all 39 waste sites .
Before the removal of any waste from any project , obtain certification from the 40 State Historic Preservation Officer of the State Department of Cultural Resources certifying 41 Section 802 8-8 that the deposition of the waste material to the proposed waste area will have no effect on any 1 known district , site building , structure or object , architectural or archaeological , that is 2 included , or eligible for inclusion , in the National Register of Historic Places .
Furnish a copy 3 of this certification to the Engineer before performing any work in the proposed waste site .
4 Provide an area and dispose of waste and debris outside of the right of way , unless otherwise 5 allowed by written request .
Limit the materials placed in non-permitted disposal areas to 6 clean soil , rock , concrete , brick , other inert materials and bituminous asphalt when placed at 7 least 4 feet above the water table .
Mixtures of soil and vegetation , that are primarily soil , may 8 be placed in non-permitted disposal areas .
Place all other debris in sites permitted by the 9 Solid Waste Management Division of NCDEQ , unless otherwise approved .
10 Maintain the earth surfaces at all waste areas in a manner that will effectively control erosion 11 and siltation until final acceptance of the project .
12 Shape the waste or disposal area to drain such that no water will collect or stand .
Provide 13 a functioning drainage system .
14 Shape rock and earth waste to contour and blend with the adjacent topography .
Cover all 15 rock , concrete , broken pavement and masonry with a minimum 6 inch thick layer of earth 16 material from the project or borrow .
Earth material should be tested to insure it will support 17 long-term growth of the proposed ground cover and should be amended as necessary to 18 support permanent growth .
As an exception , side slopes constructed of all rock material will 19 not require earth covering .
Construct all slopes , other than rock , 2:1 or flatter .
Construct rock 20 slopes on a stable angle of repose .
21 Where the Engineer has granted permission to dispose of waste within the right of way , the 22 Engineer will have the authority to establish whatever additional requirements may be 23 necessary to insure the satisfactory appearance and drainage of the completed project .
24 Where electing to dispose of waste or debris in active public waste or disposal sites , provide 25 evidence satisfactory to the Engineer that the Solid Waste Management Division of NCDEQ 26 has permitted the proposed area or site .
27 Where electing to dispose of waste in a waste or disposal area , other than active public waste 28 or disposal areas permitted by the Solid Waste Management Division of NCDEQ or on the 29 Department ’ s right of way or an existing borrow pit , submit jointly with the property owner 30 a notarized Development , Use and Reclamation Plan for each waste or disposal area proposed 31 for use .
32 As part of the Reclamation Plan , perform the following before wasting : 33 ( A ) Material Description 34 Detail the type of waste material proposed in the area .
Only material originating from the 35 Department ’ s projects and complying with the Solid Waste Disposal Act will be 36 permitted within the proposed waste or disposal area .
37 ( B ) Topography 38 Detail the existing topography and locations of the proposed access and egress haul 39 roads .
Detail the proposed final topography of the waste or disposal area showing any 40 proposed drainage systems .
If a pond is to be constructed or remain , the minimum depth 41 shall be at least 4 feet as determined from the water table at the time the reclamation plan 42 is executed .
The slope of the soil below the water shall be between 5:1 and 2:1 .
The 43 slope of the sides above the water line shall be 2:1 or flatter .
44 ( C ) Slopes 45 Rock and earth waste shall be shaped to contours that are compatible to and blend with 46 the adjacent topography .
Cover all rock with a minimum 6 inch layer of earth material 47 either from project waste or from borrow .
As an exception , side slopes constructed of all 48 Section 802 8-9 rock material will not require earth covering .
Construct all slopes at a 2:1 or flatter 1 except rock slopes that shall be on a stable angle of repose .
2 ( D ) Construction Debris 3 Cover construction debris and all broken pavement and masonry with a minimum 4 6 inch thick layer of earth waste material from the project or borrow .
Shape the 5 completed waste area as required above for the disposal of earth or rock waste .
6 ( E ) Erosion Control 7 Detail the temporary and permanent erosion control measures , along with design 8 calculations , that are intended during use of the site and as part of the reclamation .
9 Unless considered impractical due to special circumstances , provide in the plan for the 10 use of staged permanent seeding and mulching and appropriate fertilizer topdressing on 11 a continual basis during site use and the immediate total reclamation of the site when the 12 site is no longer needed .
Define the seed mixture proposed for establishing temporary 13 and/or permanent vegetation .
Establish permanent stand of vegetation before acceptance 14 of project .
15 ( F ) Evaluation for Potential Wetlands and Endangered Species 16 Hire an experienced environmental consultant on the Department ’ s approved list to 17 perform an assessment of the waste site for potential conflicts with wetlands , areas of 18 environmental concern , federally listed threatened or endangered species , and federal 19 species of concern .
20 Delineate the boundaries of any wetlands or jurisdictional surface waters ( streams ) 21 encountered .
Follow the standard practice for documenting the wetland delineation 22 including completion of the US Army Corps of Engineer ’ s approved Wetland 23 Determination Data Form .
Document information including data regarding soil , 24 vegetation and hydrology .
Maintain a minimum 25 foot buffer adjacent to all sides of the 25 wetland boundary and a minimum 50 foot buffer adjacent to any stream .
Depict the 26 limits of the delineated wetland and surrounding buffer on the Reclamation Plan .
Do not 27 dispose of waste and debris in any area under the Corps of Engineers ’ or any other 28 environmental agencies ’ regulatory jurisdiction unless and until the NCDOT permit has 29 been modified to permit such disposal activity in the jurisdictional area .
30 Perform a site assessment for federally listed threatened or endangered species to include 31 habitats that may support these species .
Provide to the Engineer a detailed report on the 32 assessment findings .
If federally listed threatened or endangered species , or habitat that 33 may support such species , exist on the proposed waste site , notify the Engineer before 34 continued pursuit of such site .
35 ( G ) Buffer Zones 36 Allocate sufficient area between the nearest property line and the tie-in of the slope to 37 natural ground to allow for the operation of excavation , hauling , and seeding equipment 38 and for the installation of any and all erosion control devices required .
Leave additional 39 undisturbed area between the source and any watercourse or body to prevent siltation of 40 the watercourse or body and the movement of the shore line either into the watercourse or 41 body or into the waste areas .
Determine if the adjoining property owners or other 42 government agencies require any additional buffer zones and comply with those 43 requirements .
[ Suggested minimum distances are 10 feet from property lines and 50 feet 44 from water bodies or watercourses . ]
Do not place waste material within the 100-year 45 floodplain unless superseded by an environmental permit .
46 ( H ) Approval 47 Obtain written approval from the Engineer before wasting within the proposed waste or 48 disposal area .

The provisions of Sections 838 , 840 , 846 , 848 , 850 , 852 , 853 , 854 , 855 , 857 5 and 858 will prevail over any conflicting requirements of this section .
6 825-2 FORMS 7 ( A ) General 8 Maintain forms true to the required lines , grades and dimensions .
Construct forms with 9 material of such strength and with sufficient rigidity to prevent any appreciable deflection 10 between supports .
Provide mortar-tight forms with a fillet at sharp corners when 11 indicated in the plans .
12 Design clamps , pins , metal spacers , anchorages and other connecting devices to hold the 13 forms rigidly together .
Construct or install any metal spacers or anchorages that are 14 required within the forms so that the metal work can be removed to a depth of at least 15 1 inch from the exposed surface of the concrete without injury to the surface .
The recess 16 thus formed in the concrete shall have a diameter no greater than 1.5 times the depth .
17 Maintain the shape , strength , rigidity and surface smoothness of forms that are to be 18 re-used at all times .
Thoroughly clean all dirt , mortar and foreign material from forms 19 before reusing .
Thoroughly coat all inside form surfaces with commercial quality form 20 oil or other equivalent coating before placing concrete .
21 ( B ) Wood Forms 22 Provide forms with a smooth and uniform texture .
Make joints between forms tight and 23 even so that no appreciable form marks remain after the forms are removed .
24 Do not use plywood sheets showing torn grain , worn edges , patches or other defects that 25 impair the texture of concrete surfaces exposed to view .
26 ( C ) Metal Forms 27 Use metal forms of such thickness and rigidity that the forms will remain true to shape .
28 Counter-sink bolt and rivet heads .
Use only metal forms that present a smooth surface 29 and line up properly .
Keep metal forms free from all foreign matter that will discolor the 30 concrete .
31 825-3 REINFORCEMENT 32 Furnish and place reinforcement as shown in the plans and in accordance with Section 425 .
33 825-4 PLACING CONCRETE 34 Do not place concrete until the foundation , the adequacy of the forms , the placing of 35 reinforcement and other embedded items have been inspected and approved .
36 Place concrete in daylight unless an approved lighting system is provided .
37 Remove all debris from the interior of forms in preparation for placing concrete .
Moisten 38 earth or base course surfaces on which concrete is to be placed immediately before placing 39 concrete .
Do not place concrete on excessively wet or frozen surfaces .
40 Place concrete in its final position in the forms within the time stipulated in 41 Subarticle 1000-4 ( E ) .
42 Section 825 8-18 Place concrete to avoid segregation of the materials and the displacement of the 1 reinforcement .
Thoroughly work the concrete during placement .
Bring mortar against the 2 forms to produce a smooth finish , substantially free from water and air pockets or 3 honeycombs .
4 Do not place concrete when the air temperature , measured at the location of the concrete 5 operation in the shade away from artificial heat , is below 35°F unless permission is otherwise 6 granted .
When such permission is granted , uniformly heat the aggregates and water to 7 a temperature no higher than 150°F .
Place the heated concrete at a temperature of at 8 least 55°F and no more than 80°F .
9 825-5 SLUMP TESTS 10 Test the slump of the concrete in accordance with Article 420-6 .
11 825-6 FINISHING 12 ( A ) General 13 Provide the type of finish required by the contract directly applicable to the work being 14 constructed .
15 ( B ) Ordinary Surface Finish 16 Remove all form ties or metal spacers to a depth of at least 1 inch below the surface of 17 the concrete and clean and fill the resulting holes or depressions with grout .
Metal 18 devices with exposed cross-sectional area not exceeding approximately 0.05 sq .
inches on 19 surfaces permanently in contact with earth fill may be broken off flush with the surface of 20 the concrete .
21 Remove all fins caused by form joints and other projections .
Remove stains and 22 discoloration .
Clean all pockets and fill with grout as directed .
Thoroughly soak the 23 surface of all concrete with water before the application of a grout repair .
24 Use grout consisting of one part cement and two parts sand .
Use cement from the same 25 source as originally incorporated in work .
Cure the grout for at least 3 days .
After the 26 grout has thoroughly hardened , rub the patch with a carborundum stone as required to 27 match the texture and color of the adjacent concrete .
28 On surfaces that are to be backfilled or surfaces that are enclosed , the removal of form 29 marks , fins and pockets ; the rubbing of grouted areas to uniform color ; and the removal 30 of stains and discoloration will not be required .
31 ( C ) Sidewalk Finish 32 Strike off fresh concrete and compact until a layer of mortar is brought to the surface .
33 Finish the surface to grade and cross section with a float , trowel smooth and finish with 34 a broom .
35 ( D ) Rubbed Finish 36 After the ordinary surface finish has been completed , thoroughly wet and rub the entire 37 surface .
Use a coarse carborundum stone or other equally good abrasive to bring the 38 surface to a smooth texture and remove all form marks .
Carefully stroke the surface with 39 a clean brush to finish the paste formed by rubbing .
Alternatively , spread the paste 40 uniformly over the surface and allow it to take a reset .
Finish by floating with a canvas , 41 carpet-faced or cork float or rub down with dry burlap .
42 ( E ) Float Finish 43 Finish the surface with a rough carpet float or other suitable device leaving the surface 44 even but distinctly sandy or pebbled in texture .
45 Section 825 8-19 825-7 REMOVING FORMS 1 Do not remove forms from freshly placed concrete until it has hardened sufficiently to resist 2 spalling , cracking or any other damage .
3 825-8 PROTECTION FROM COLD WEATHER 4 When it is anticipated that the atmospheric temperature will fall below 35°F , protect concrete 5 in accordance with Subarticle 420-7 ( C ) .
Protect concrete containing fly ash or ground 6 granulated blast furnace slag for at least 7 curing days .
Protect all other concrete for at 7 least 3 curing days .
8 825-9 CURING 9 Cure concrete in accordance with Subarticle 700-9 ( B ) immediately after finishing operations 10 are completed and surface water has disappeared .
Where forms are removed before the 11 expiration of the required curing period , apply the curing compound immediately after the 12 forms are removed .
13 Cure each mass for 7 curing days .
A “ curing day ” shall be defined as any consecutive 14 24 hour period , after finishing operations of the mass is completed , when the air temperature 15 adjacent to the mass does not fall below 40°F .
16 825-10 JOINTS 17 ( A ) General 18 Construct joints at right angles to the surface of the concrete .
Locate joints at right angles 19 to the longitudinal centerline of curb , curb and gutter , gutter , island , median , median 20 barrier and all paved areas , except where different joint locations are called for in the 21 plans .
22 Where concrete is to be placed adjacent to any existing slab or pavement that has 23 a broken or irregular edge , provide a reasonably vertical edge by sawing .
24 ( B ) Grooved Contraction Joints 25 Form grooved contraction joints by a tool specifically constructed for this purpose or by 26 sawing with an approved concrete saw .
27 Groove contraction joints to the depth shown in the plans and to a width between 28 1/4 inch and 1/2 inch , unless otherwise shown in the plans .
If formed by a tool , make a 29 radius of 1/8 inch at the corners of the adjacent concrete .
30 ( C ) Expansion Joints 31 Fill construction joints with an expansion joint filler .
Cut the filler into the shape 32 necessary to fill the joint .
Make the filler 1/2 inch thick unless indicated otherwise in the 33 plans .
After the concrete has hardened cut the filler away to a depth of 1/2 inch to 34 provide space for the joint sealer .
35 Install an expansion joint adjacent to any existing slab , pavement or structure against 36 which new concrete is placed and at other locations detailed in the plans .
37 ( D ) Construction Joints 38 Construct construction joints as shown in the plans or where otherwise approved .
39 ( E ) Sawing Joints 40 Saw joints after the concrete has hardened sufficiently to be sawed without spalling and 41 raveling but no more than 24 hours after the concrete has been placed .
42 Section 828 8-20 ( F ) Sealing Joints 1 Seal all contraction and expansion joints , except otherwise specified , before the backfill 2 is placed .
3 Thoroughly clean the joint to remove all foreign matter .
Dry joints before sealing .
4 Entirely fill joints to within 1/8 inch to 1/4 inch of the surface of the concrete with joint 5 sealer .
Immediately remove any sealer spilled on the surface of the concrete .
6 Place joint sealer with equipment meeting the specifications of the manufacturer of the 7 sealer material .

8 Item Section Curing Agents 1026 Joint Fillers 1028-1 Joint Sealers 1028-2 , 1028-3 Portland Cement Concrete , Class B 1000 Detectable warning for curb ramps shall consist of raised truncated domes .
Use material for 9 detectable warning systems as shown herein .
Material and coating specifications must be 10 stated in the Manufacturers Type 3 Certification and all Detectable Warning systems must be 11 on the NCDOT APL .
12 Install detectable warnings created from one of the following materials : precast concrete 13 blocks or bricks , clay paving brick , gray or ductile iron castings , mild steel , stainless steel , 14 and engineered plastics , rubber or composite tile .
Only one material type for detectable 15 warning will be permitted per project , unless otherwise approved by the Engineer .
16 Detectable Warnings shall consist of a base with integrated raised truncated domes , and when 17 constructed of precast concrete they shall conform to the material requirements .
18 Detectable Warnings shall consist of a base with integrated raised truncated domes , and may 19 be comprised of other materials including , but not limited to , clay paving brick , gray iron or 20 ductile iron castings , mild steel , stainless steel , and engineered plastics , rubber or composite 21 tile , which are applied directly to the curb ramps by incorporating into or attaching to the 22 existing ramp floor .
The material shall have an integral color throughout the thickness of the 23 material .
The detectable warning shall include fasteners , anchors , or adhesives for attachment 24 in the existing ramp and shall be furnished as a system from the manufacturer .
25 Prior to installation , the Contractor shall submit to the Engineer assembling instructions from 26 the manufacturer for each type of system used .
The system shall be furnished as a kit 27 containing all consumable materials and consumable tools , required for the application .
They 28 shall be capable of being affixed to or anchored in the concrete curb ramp , including green 29 concrete ( concrete that has set but not appreciably hardened ) .
The system shall be solvent 30 free and contain no volatile organic compounds ( VOC ) .
The static coefficient of friction shall 31 be 0.8 or greater when measured on top of the truncated domes and when measured between 32 the domes in accordance with ASTM C1028 ( dry and wet ) .
The system shall be resistant to 33 deterioration due to exposure to sunlight , water , salt or adverse weather conditions and 34 impervious to degradation by motor fuels , lubricants and antifreeze .

7 Item Section Barbed Wire 1050-4 Chain Link Fabric 1050-6 Fence Materials 1050-1 Fittings and Accessories 1050-7 Metal Posts and Rails 1050-3 Organic Zinc Repair Paint 1076-7 Timber Posts and Braces 1050-2 Woven Wire 1050-5 Use Class B concrete for anchors .

11 866-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 12 ( A ) Clearing and Grubbing 13 Only clear the ground that is necessary to erect a clear fence line .
Clearing includes 14 satisfactory removal and disposal of all trees , brush , stumps , existing fence or other 15 objectionable material .
Erect the fence to conform to the general contour of the ground .
16 Place the bottom of the fabric or wire no more than 6 inches above the natural ground , 17 except where the Engineer directs that ditches and depressions are to be spanned by using 18 extra length posts in conjunction with additional barbed wire installed between the 19 bottom of the fence wire or fabric and the ground surface .
Grade along the fence line to 20 meet the above requirement such that no obstructions to proper drainage are created .
21 ( B ) Setting Posts and Braces 22 Set and maintain all posts in a vertical position .
Line posts may be hand set or set with 23 a post driver .
Thoroughly tamp all backfilled material if hand set .
If power driven , wood 24 posts may be sharpened to a dull point .
Remove and replace posts that are damaged by 25 power driving .
26 Set posts in concrete anchors to maintain the position and alignment of the post when 27 required in the plans or where dictated by soil conditions .
Forms are not required for the 28 concrete .
Trowel the top of the concrete to a smooth finish and slope to drain away from 29 the post .
The concrete anchors require at least a 3 day curing period before any load is 30 placed on the post .
31 Instead of setting roll formed steel line posts in concrete , such posts may be driven 32 provided they are not part of a line brace assembly .
Drive the posts at least 3 feet into the 33 ground .
Provide adequate protection to the post tops to prevent damage from the driving 34 operations .
Repair damage to the zinc coating in accordance with Article 1076-7 .
Set 35 posts in concrete anchors where soil conditions are such that the posts can not be driven 36 without deformation , or where soils are encountered that does not provide adequate 37 in-ground stability .
38 Section 866 8-47 Where rock or concrete pavement or slabs are encountered within the required depth 1 where fence posts are to be erected , drill a hole in the rock or concrete of a diameter 2 slightly larger than the largest dimension of the post in the rock or concrete and grout in 3 the post .
The depth of post embedment shown in the plans will not be required and the 4 post may be shortened as necessary , provided the post is embedded within the rock or 5 concrete pavement or slab to a minimum depth of 12 inches .
6 Do not fabricate extra length posts by welding short sections of posts together .
7 Place line braces at the end of each roll or piece of woven wire .
8 Do not use pieces of woven wire fabric less than 100 feet in length , unless otherwise 9 directed .
When the use of short pieces of woven wire is permitted , furnish and install the 10 additional required brace posts and braces .
Approved splicing sleeves may be used 11 instead of providing such brace posts and braces .
12 ( C ) Installing Fabric and Wire 13 ( 1 ) Chain Link Fence 14 Attach chain link fabric to tubular end , gate , corner or brace posts with stretcher bars 15 and stretcher bar bands as shown in the plan .
Fasten the fabric to line posts and to 16 top and brace rails with wire fasteners spaced and wound as shown in the plans .
17 Fasten the fabric to the tension wire by hog rings spaced at 24 inch intervals or 18 weave the tension wire through the fabric .
Make hog ring ties at fabric joints with 19 the hog ring passing completely around the fabric joint .
20 Place chain link fabric by securing or fastening on end and applying sufficient 21 tension to remove all slack before making permanent attachments elsewhere .
Apply 22 the tension for stretching by mechanical fence stretchers designed for this purpose .
23 Connect rolls and pieces of chain link fabric to each other by field weaving provided 24 that such weaving is identical in appearance and strength as the machine weaving 25 done at the factory .
26 Attach barbed wire used in conjunction with chain link fabric , to the post by eyebolt 27 or by a tie wire passing through holes drilled in the metal post to prevent any vertical 28 movement of the barbed wire .
Wrap the ends and beginnings of strands around the 29 post twice and securely fasten by winding the end around the wire near the post .
30 Splice barbed wire only at posts .
31 Install additional barbed wire when shown in the plans or where directed .
32 ( 2 ) Woven Wire Fence 33 Stretch woven wire fabric taut and securely attach to each post with one or more 34 staples in each line of wire .
Use as many staples as required to firmly secure the 35 wire at the location and elevation required by the plans .
When woven wire is 36 attached to metal posts , use at least five clips at each post to fasten the individual 37 strands of wire to the post except where wrapping of the strand around the post is 38 required .
Stretch with an approved stretcher that will produce equal tension in each 39 line of wire .
40 At each end or gate post , at the center post in each line brace and at corner posts 41 except as otherwise shown in the plans , cut out all vertical strands of wire and wrap 42 each horizontal strand of wire around the post and securely fasten by winding the 43 end around the strand of wire near the post .
44 Do not splice fabric between the posts of a brace post assembly .
Do not splice 45 between other posts , unless the splicing sleeves are approved .
46 Section 866 8-48 Pull woven wire taut and securely attach to each post by methods described for 1 woven wire when used in conjunction with woven wire fabric .
Do not splice woven 2 wire between posts .
3 Install additional woven wire as shown in the plans or where directed .
4 ( 3 ) Barbed Wire Fence 5 Install barbed wire fence in accordance with the plans and as directed .
6 Pull barbed wire taut and securely attach to each post by methods described for 7 woven wire .
Do not splice barbed wire between posts .

15 ( D ) Aluminum 16 ( 1 ) Thickness Requirements 17 TABLE 901-2 ALUMINUM THICKNESS REQUIREMENTS FOR SIGNS Vertical or Horizontal Dimension Minimum Thickness Inches Inches 0-11.9 0.032 12-35.9 0.063 36-47.9 0.080 48 and larger 0.125 Milemarkers 0.080 Overlays 0.063 ( 2 ) Preparation of Aluminum Sign Surfaces 18 Do not handle any metal , except by appropriate handling devices or by workmen 19 wearing clean gloves , between the beginning of the coating operations and the 20 completion of the application of the retroreflective sheeting .
Retreat aluminum sign 21 surfaces that come into contact with grease , oils or other contaminants before the 22 application of retroreflective sheeting .
23 Before applying retroreflective sheeting to the aluminum , treat the aluminum sign 24 surfaces with a chromate conversion coating .
Such coating shall be applied 25 according to the manufacturer 's instruction and shall conform to ASTM B449 , 26 Class 2 , and should range in color from silvery iridescent to pale yellow .
The 27 coating weight shall be 10 mg/sf to 35 mg/sf on the entire surface area including 28 along the edges of the sign substrate with a median of 25 mg/sf as the optimum 29 coating weight .
Ensure the coating does not appear dusty when wiped with a clean , 30 lint-free cloth and does not show excessive buildup at edges .
Sand smooth all burrs 31 and scratches before applying retroreflective sheeting .
Sheet all sanded aluminum 32 within the same day to prevent the formation of corrosion on the metal .
Do not sand 33 or use abrasive materials on sheeted faces .
Aluminum products shall be randomly 34 tested .
35 Section 901 9-5 ( E ) Supporting Frames 1 Use supporting frames for Types A and B signs consisting of 2 or more horizontal 2 aluminum Z-stringers with vertical aluminum bar stiffeners in accordance with the details 3 and dimensions shown in the contract .

19 If a sign panel needs to be replaced after sign fabrication , the replacement panel may be 20 sheeted with retroreflective materials from a different lot or drum number than the 21 remainder of the sign ; however , use material that visually color matches and meets 22 Article 1092-2 .

25 Overlap all splices of any encapsulated or enclosed lens sheeting to allow water to run off 26 without running into the splice .
All prismatic sheeting will be butt spliced .
27 Remove all foreign materials on the sheeted face with compressed air .
28 Keep a sample of each roll of sheeting and test for retroreflective compliance .
29 Patch wrinkles in the sheeting around thru bolts by removing the affected sheeting from 30 the metal .
Then patch this area with a circular patch encompassing an area 1/4 31 inch outside the affected area .
This patch shall not exceed the standard patching limits 32 shown in Table 901-3 .
33 Ensure that all patches on the sign have a 1 inch minimum width or as recommended by 34 the sheeting manufacturer .

May apply all legends and borders on 43 Type E and F signs using digital printing .

46 Section 901 9-9 Retroreflective sheeting shall consist of white or colored sheeting having a smooth outer 1 surface and that essentially has the property of a retroreflector over its entire surface .
2 Retroreflective sheeting shall conform to all requirements to the FHWA Color Tolerance 3 Charts and AASHTO M 268 when thoroughly dry Digital printed ink systems used to 4 print traffic signs must meet and comply with daytime and nighttime chromaticity ( color 5 standards ) as recognized in ASTM D4956 “ Standard Specification for retroreflective 6 Sheeting ” .
7 Digital printed ink systems must meet 70 % of the initial retroreflectivity in Table 1092-3 8 and the coefficient of retroreflectivity for color and type of sheeting in Tables 1092-3 , 9 1092-4 and 1092-5 .
10 All digital inks and digital reflective sheeting shall be listed on the NCDOT APL and 11 tested on AASHTO NTPEP test deck for 3 years prior to consideration to insure the 12 digital printed ink system meets the warrant obligation listed in Subarticle 1092-2 ( B ) for 13 the respective sheeting grade .
14 Permanent traffic signs printed with digital ink systems will be fabricated with a full sign 15 Protective Overlay Film designed to protect the entire sign from fading and UV 16 degradation .
The over laminate will comply with the retroreflective sheeting 17 manufacturer ’ s recommendations to ensure proper adhesion and transparency and will 18 also meet the reflective film durability in Subarticle 1092-2 ( B ) .
19 Temporary signs printed with black ink only will not require a Protective Overlay Film as 20 long as the finished sign is warranted for a minimum outdoor durability of three years by 21 the sheeting manufacturer .
22 901-4 SIGN QUALITY 23 Provide signs that present a uniform appearance free from color match problems , non-uniform 24 color , streaks , spots , abrasions , blistering or other defects in the sheeting .
25 Sheeting may be inspected before application to sign blanks , after installation to sign blanks , 26 after completion of the sign in the sign fabricator 's facility and after installation .
Clean all 27 installed signs before final field inspection .
28 The retroreflective sheeting will be unsatisfactory if it has deteriorated due to any cause 29 except defacement resulting from vandalism or damage resulting from impact by a motor 30 vehicle or other object to the extent that : 31 ( A ) The sign is ineffective for its intended purpose when viewed from a moving vehicle 32 under normal day and night driving conditions , or 33 ( B ) The coefficient of retroreflection is less than the minimum specified for that sheeting as 34 shown in Tables 1092-3 , 1092-4 and 1092-5 when measured by a Department approved 35 retroreflectometer , or 36 ( C ) The screened message and border or reverse screened background has stained , 37 discolored , streaked , faded , turned dark or has developed cracks , scaling , pitting and/or 38 blistering , or 39 ( D ) The sign is unsatisfactory with regard to uniform appearance due to cracking , streaking , 40 delamination , blistering , crazing or discoloration of the sheeting , or 41 ( E ) The sign is unsatisfactory with regard to remaining uniform in color over the entire 42 reflecting surface both day and night and displaying the same color both in daylight and 43 under lights at night .
44 ( 1 ) For glass bead material , sheeting will be subjected to a visual test with the human 45 eye as the test instrument .
Objectionable non-uniformity of color and reflectivity 46 ( retroreflection ) under light at night is cause for the sign to be tested for 47 retroreflection to determine compliance with the following requirements : 48 Section 902 9-10 The retroreflection values on any sign shall not vary from each other by more than 1 a ratio of 1.10 ( 1.20 white ) at any 2 points at least 12 inches apart , nor more than 2 1.30 ( 1.30 white ) at any 2 points anywhere on the sign , nor more than , 3 1.10 ( 1.20 white ) at any 2 points on the border or between any 2 adjacent letters , 4 numerals or symbols .
Failure to meet the above requirements will result in sign 5 rejection .
Retroreflection will be tested using a Delta RetroSign retroreflectometer .
6 ( 2 ) For prismatic material , sheeting will be subjected to a visual test with the human eye 7 as the test instrument .
8 901-5 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 9 Sign fabrication will be measured and paid as the actual number of square feet of sign face 10 areas of each type , including milemarkers and overlays acceptably fabricated .
In measuring 11 this quantity , the sign face areas will be calculated to the nearest 1/100 of a sf , using the 12 dimensions shown in the contract .
13 The areas of odd-shaped signs ( e.g .
stop signs and shield-shaped route markers ) will be 14 calculated as squares or rectangles using the dimensions shown in the contract .
The areas of 15 round , diamond and triangular signs will be calculated for their true shapes using plan 16 dimensions .

20 ( C ) Design and Fabrication 21 ( 1 ) The following criteria govern the design of overhead sign assemblies : 22 Design shall be in accordance with the AASHTO Standard Specifications for 23 Structural Structures for Highway Signs , Luminaires and Traffic Signals , 6th 24 Edition , 2013 and 2015 Interim Revisions .
25 There are several design criteria that are specified .
They include : 26 ( a ) Overhead cantilever sign structures shall include galloping loads ( exclude four- 27 chord horizontal trusses ) 28 ( b ) The Yearly Mean Velocity , Vmean , in North Carolina shall be assumed to be 11.6 29 mph .
30 ( c ) The Fatigue Importance Category used in the design , for each type of structure , 31 shall be for : 32 ( i ) Cantilevered structures with span greater than 50 feet - Fatigue Importance 33 Category I .
34 ( ii ) Cantilevered structures with span less than or equal to 50 feet - Fatigue 35 Importance Category II .
36 ( iii ) Non-Cantilevered structures – Fatigue Importance Category II .
37 ( 2 ) The following interpretations or criteria shall be used in the design of overhead sign 38 assemblies : 39 ( a ) For design of supporting upright posts or columns , the effective length factor for 40 columns “ K ” , as provided for in Appendix B , Section B.5 of the AASHTO 41 Standard Specifications for Structural Structures for Highway Signs , Luminaires 42 and Traffic Signals , 6th Edition , 2013 and 2015 Interim Revisions , shall be 43 taken as the following , unless otherwise approved by the Engineer : 44 ( i ) Case 1 : For a single upright post of cantilever or span type overhead sign 45 structure , the effective column length factor , “ K ” , shall be taken as 2.0 .
46 Section 906 9-19 ( ii ) Case 2 : For twin post truss-type upright post with the post connected to one 1 chord of a horizontal truss , the effective column length factor for that column 2 shall be taken as 2.0 .
3 ( iii ) Case 3 : For twin post truss-type upright post with the post connected to two 4 truss chords of a horizontal tri-chord or box truss , the effective column length 5 factor for that column shall be taken as 1.65 .
6 ( b ) For twin post truss-type uprights , the unbraced length of the post shall be from the 7 chord to post connection to the top of base plate .
8 ( c ) For twin post truss-type uprights , when the post is subject to axial compression , 9 bending moment , shear , and torsion , the post shall satisfy the AASHTO Standard 10 Specifications for Structural Structures for Highway Signs , Luminaires and Traffic 11 Signals , 6th Edition , 2013 and 2015 Interim Revisions Equations 5.12.2.1-1 , 12 5.12.2.1-2 and 5.12.2.1-5 .
To reduce the effects of secondary bending , in lieu of 13 Equation 5.12.2.1-2 , the following equation may be used : 14 15 Where = Computed axial compression stress at base of post 16 ( d ) The base plate thickness for all uprights and poles shall be a minimum of 2 inches 17 but not less than that determined by the following criteria and design : 18 ( i ) Case 1 : Circular or rectangular solid base plates with the upright pole welded to 19 the top surface of the base plate with full penetration butt weld , and where no 20 stiffeners are provided .
A base plate with a small center hole , which is less than 21 1/5 of the upright diameter , and located concentrically with the upright pole , 22 may be considered as a solid base plate .
23 The magnitude of bending moment in the base plate , induced by the anchoring 24 force of each anchor bolt shall be calculated as 25 M = ( PxD1 ) /2 .
26 ( ii ) Case 2 : Circular or rectangular base plate with the upright pole socketed into 27 and attached to the base plate with two lines of fillet weld , and where no 28 stiffeners are provided , or any base plate with a center hole that is larger in 29 diameter than 1/5 of the upright diameter .
The magnitude of bending moment 30 induced by the anchoring force of each anchor bolt shall be calculated as 31 M = P x D2 Where : M = Bending moment at the critical section of the base plate induced by one anchor bolt P = Anchoring force of each bolt D1 = Horizontal distance between the center of the anchor bolt and the outer face of the upright , or the difference between the radius of the bolt circle and the radius of the upright D2 = Horizontal distance between the face of the upright and the face of the anchor bolt nut ( e ) The critical section shall be located at the face of the anchor bolt and perpendicular 32 to the radius of the bolt circle .
The overlapped part of two adjacent critical sections 33 shall be considered ineffective .
34 Section 906 9-20 ( f ) The thickness of Case 1 base plate shall not be less than the calculated based on 1 formula for Case 2 .
2 ( g ) Uprights , foundations , and trusses that support overhead signs shall be designed in 3 accordance with the contract for the effects of torsion .
Torsion shall be considered 4 from dead load eccentricity of these attachments , as well as for the attachments such 5 as supporting brackets , lights , etc. , that add to the torsion in the assembly .
Truss 6 vertical and horizontal truss diagonals in particular and any other assembly members 7 shall be appropriately sized for these loads .
8 ( h ) Uprights , foundations , and trusses that support overhead mounted signs shall be 9 designed for the proposed sign wind area as noted in the contract drawings .
Truss 10 vertical and horizontal truss diagonals in particular and any other assembly members 11 shall be appropriately sized for these loads .

Produce Portland cement concrete composed of Portland 5 cement , fine and coarse aggregates , water and supplementary cementitious material 6 ( optional ) .
Include chemical admixtures as required or needed .
Ground granulated blast 7 furnace slag , fly ash or silica fume may be substituted for a portion of the Portland cement .
8 Type IL , IP , IS or IT blended cement may be used instead of Portland cement .
9 Mixes for all Portland cement concrete shall be designed by a Certified Concrete Mix Design 10 Technician or an Engineer licensed by the State of North Carolina .
11 When concrete for any one pour is furnished by multiple concrete plants , use the same mix 12 design for all concrete , including sources and quantities of ingredients .
13 If any major change is made to the mix design , submit a new mix design ( with the exception 14 of an approved pozzolan source change ) .
15 If any change is made to the mix design , also submit new test results showing the mix design 16 conforms to the criteria .
Define a major change to the mix design as : 17 ( A ) A source change in coarse aggregate , fine aggregate or cement .
18 ( B ) A pozzolan class or type change ( e.g .
Class F fly ash to Class C fly ash ) 19 ( C ) A quantitative change in course aggregate ( applies to an increase or decrease greater than 20 5 % ) , fine aggregate ( applies to an increase or decrease greater than 5 % ) , water ( applies to 21 an increase only ) , cement ( applies to a decrease only ) , or pozzolan ( applies to an increase 22 or decrease greater than 5 % ) .
23 Use materials which do not produce a mottled appearance through rusting or other staining of 24 the finished concrete surface .
25 1000-2 MATERIALS 26 Refer to Division 10 .
27 Item Section Air Entraining Agent 1024-3 Calcium Nitrite Corrosion Inhibitor 1024-3 Chemical Admixtures 1024-3 Coarse Aggregate 1014-2 Fine Aggregate 1014-1 Fly Ash 1024-5 Ground Granulated Blast Furnace Slag 1024-6 Portland Cement 1024-1 Silica Fume 1024-7 Type IL Blended Cement 1024-1 Type IP Blended Cement 1024-1 Type IS Blended Cement 1024-1 Type IT Blended Cement 1024-1 Water 1024-4 Section 1000 10-2 1000-3 PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE FOR PAVEMENT 1 ( A ) Composition and Design 2 Submit concrete paving mix design in terms of saturated surface dry weights on Materials 3 and Tests Form 312U for approval at least 30 days before proposed use .
Use a mix that 4 contains at least 526 lbs .
of cement per cubic yard , a maximum water cement ratio of 5 0.559 , an air content in the range of 4.5 % to 5.5 % , a maximum slump of 1.5 inches , a 6 minimum flexural strength of 650 psi at 28 days and a minimum compressive strength of 7 4,500 psi at 28 days .
8 Fly ash may be substituted for cement in the mix design up to 30 % at a rate of 1.0 lb .
of 9 fly ash to each pound of cement replaced .
10 The cement content of the mix design may be reduced by no more than 50 % and replaced 11 with blast furnace slag pound for pound .
12 Include in the mix design the source of aggregates , cement , fly ash , slag , water and 13 admixtures ; the gradation and specific gravity of the aggregates ; the fineness modulus of 14 the fine aggregate ; and the dry rodded unit weight and size of the coarse aggregate .
15 Submit test results showing that the mix design conforms to the criteria , including the 16 1 , 3 , 7 , 14 and 28-day strengths of the average of two 6 inch x 6 inch x 20 inch beams and 17 the average of two 6 inch x 12 inch cylinders for each age made and tested in accordance 18 with AASHTO R 39 , T22 and T97 from a certified laboratory .
Design the mix to produce 19 an average strength sufficient to indicate that a minimum strength of 650 psi in flexure 20 and 4,500 psi in compression will be achieved in the field within 28 days .
21 Where concrete with a higher slump for hand methods of placing and finishing is 22 necessary , submit an adjusted mix design for approval to provide a maximum slump of 23 3 inches and to maintain the water-cementitious material ratio established by the original 24 mix design .
25 ( B ) Air Entrainment 26 Entrain air in the concrete by the use of an approved air entraining agent dispensed with 27 the mixing water , unless prohibited .
28 Provide an air content of 5.0 % ± 1.5 % in the freshly mixed concrete .
The air content will 29 be determined in accordance with AASHTO T 121 , T152 or T196 .
At the option of the 30 Engineer , the air content may be measured by the Chace Indicator , in which case 31 sufficient tests will be made to establish correlation with the test methods of AASHTO 32 T 121 , T152 or T196 .
Concrete will not be rejected based on tests from the Chase 33 Indicator .
34 ( C ) Slump 35 Provide concrete with a maximum slump of 1.5 inches where placed by a fully 36 mechanized paving train and no more than 3 inches where placed by hand methods .
37 The sample taken for determination of slump will be obtained immediately after the 38 concrete has been discharged onto the road .
39 ( D ) Set Retarding Admixture and Water Reducing Admixture 40 With permission , the Contractor may use an approved set retarding admixture , 41 an approved water reducing admixture or both to facilitate placing and finishing .
Use 42 a quantity of set retarding admixture or water reducing admixture within the range shown 43 on the current list of approved admixtures maintained by the Materials and Tests Unit .
44 Section 1000 10-3 ( E ) Contractor ’ s Responsibility for Process Control 1 Before or at the preconstruction conference , submit a plan detailing the process control 2 and the type and frequency of testing and inspection necessary to produce concrete that 3 meets the Specifications .
During all batching and delivery operations assign a Certified 4 Concrete Batch Technician on site whose sole duty is to supervise the production and 5 control of the concrete .
This duty includes the following : 6 ( 1 ) Tests and inspections necessary to maintain the stockpiles of aggregates in 7 an unsegregated and uncontaminated condition .
8 ( 2 ) Calibration of admixture dispensing systems , weighing systems and water gauges .
9 ( 3 ) Tests and adjustments of mix proportions for moisture content of aggregates .
10 ( 4 ) Mixer performance tests before reducing mixing time of central mix plant to less 11 than 90 seconds and at other times when deemed necessary by the Engineer .
12 ( 5 ) Verifying the actual mixing time of the concrete after all materials are introduced 13 into the mixer at the beginning of paving operations and at least once each month .
14 ( 6 ) Testing all vibrators .
15 ( 7 ) Tests necessary to document the slump and air content of the mix produced .
16 Determine air content at least twice each day .
17 ( 8 ) Tests for depth of the pavement in the plastic state .
18 ( 9 ) Furnishing data to verify that the approved theoretical cement content has been met 19 at intervals not to exceed 50,000 sy of pavement .
20 ( 10 ) Signing all plant reports , batch tickets and delivery tickets .
21 The Department certifies technicians who satisfactorily complete examinations prepared 22 and administered by the Department .
23 Perform all test procedures in compliance with the appropriate articles of Section 1000 .
24 Tests may be witnessed by the Engineer .
Document the results of all tests and inspections 25 and make a copy available to the Engineer upon request .
Take prompt action to correct 26 conditions that have resulted in or could result in the submission of materials , products , 27 or completed construction that do not conform to the Standard Specifications .
28 ( F ) Contractor Not Relieved of Responsibility for End Result 29 The Contractor will not be relieved of his obligation to produce a uniform pavement 30 meeting Specifications by reason of : 31 ( 1 ) The acceptance or approval by the Engineer of the concrete mix design or any 32 adjustments ; 33 ( 2 ) Compliance with the concrete mix design and compliance with the testing 34 requirements and other process control requirements by the Contractor ; or 35 ( 3 ) The failure of the Engineer to perform any tests in the process control , nor the 36 performance of any tests in the process control that indicate compliance with the 37 Specifications .

Copies of these modified test procedures are 41 available upon request from the Materials and Tests Unit .
42 Section 1000 10-5 When the average compressive strength of the concrete test cylinders is less than the 1 minimum strength specified in Table 1000-1 and the Engineer determines it is within 2 reasonable close conformity with strength requirements , concrete strength will be 3 considered acceptable .
When the Engineer determines average cylinder strength is below 4 the specification , the in-place concrete will be tested .
Based on these test results , the 5 concrete will either be accepted with no reduction in payment or accepted at a reduced 6 unit price or rejected as set forth in Article 105-3 .
7 ( D ) Temperature Requirements 8 The concrete temperature at the time of placement shall be not less than 50°F nor more 9 than 95°F except where other temperatures are required by Articles 420-4 , 420-7 , 420-14 10 and 420-15 .
11 Do not place concrete without permission when the air temperature measured at the 12 location of the concrete operation in the shade away from artificial heat is below 35°F .
13 When such permission is granted , uniformly heat the aggregates and/or water to 14 a temperature not higher than 150°F .
Heated concrete shall be between 55°F and 80°F at 15 the time of placement .

17 ( H ) Use of Calcium Chloride 18 Calcium chloride may be used as a set accelerating agent where permitted by the 19 Engineer .
Use one lb .
of calcium chloride per 100 lbs .
of cement except where lesser 20 amounts are directed .
Do not use calcium chloride where steel reinforcement , metal 21 conduit or other metals will be in contact with the concrete .
Do not use calcium chloride 22 in concrete that has a temperature higher than 70°F , or when the air temperature is greater 23 than 70°F .
Provide cold weather protection for concrete containing calcium chloride in 24 the same manner as is provided for concrete without calcium chloride .
25 Use calcium chloride in liquid form .
Use a solution of one lb .
or less of calcium chloride 26 per one quart of water and mix well .
To avoid incompatibility with other additives , add 27 the calcium chloride to the batch after all other ingredients have been put into the mixer .

37 Section 1000 10-8 ( K ) Use of Calcium Nitrite Corrosion Inhibitor 1 Units with calcium nitrite in a quantity less than specified are subject to rejection .

C-20.0 .

( B ) Equipment 18 Before beginning any work , obtain approval for all equipment to be used for deck 19 preparation , mixing , placing , finishing and curing the latex modified concrete .

For proportioning and mixing , use self-contained , mobile 1 and continuously mixing equipment that meets the following requirements : 2 ( 1 ) Use a self-propelled mixer that is capable of carrying sufficient unmixed dry , bulk 3 cement , sand , coarse aggregate , latex modifier and water to produce at least 6 cy of 4 concrete on site .

33 1000-8 MEASURING MATERIALS 34 ( A ) Weighing Cement 35 Measure cement by weight on scales separate from those used for other materials and in 36 a hopper that is entirely free and independent of the hoppers used for weighing the 37 aggregates .
When the quantity of cement in a batch exceeds 30 % of the full capacity of 38 the scale , ensure the quantity of cement as indicated by the scale is within ± 1 % of the 39 required weight .
For smaller batches , ensure the quantity of cement as indicated by the 40 scale be not less than the required amount or more than 4 % in excess .
Equip all beam 41 type scales with a tare beam .
42 Section 1000 10-12 ( B ) Weighing Aggregates 1 Measure aggregates by weight .
Base batch weights on saturated surface dry materials 2 which is the required weight plus the total weight of surface moisture contained in the 3 aggregate .
Ensure the individual aggregates , as weighed , are within ± 2 % of the required 4 weights .
5 ( C ) Water 6 Measure water by volume or by weight .
Ensure the quantity of water measured is 7 within ± 1 % of the required amount .
8 ( D ) Admixture Dispensing Systems 9 Provide a separate dispensing system with separate fill and discharge lines for each type 10 of admixture to be used , except that admixtures may be measured and introduced into the 11 mix manually if approval has been obtained .
Ensure each system is capable of 12 measuring , displaying and discharging the required amount of admixture into the mix .
13 Keep dispensing systems clean and in good operating condition .
Use a dispensing system 14 that is either : 15 ( 1 ) Manually operated , self-contained ; or 16 ( 2 ) Semi-automatic or automatic , self-contained ; or 17 ( 3 ) Interfaced to operate automatically with the concrete batching control panel .
18 Have the admixture dispenser dispense the required quantity of admixture for each 19 concrete batch within an accuracy of ± 3 % .
Check the accuracy of the dispenser as 20 provided below .
Check the accuracy at the point of discharge , or through a bypass valve 21 suitable for obtaining a calibrated sample of admixture and at the volumes normally used 22 for one half mixer capacity and for full mixer capacity .
Determine the accuracy at the 23 time of installation and check daily during the early part of each day ’ s operation .
24 Include in each system a graduated measuring unit into which the admixture is batched to 25 permit a quick visual check of accuracy before its discharge .
Ensure the measuring unit 26 is clearly graduated and be of sufficient size to hold the maximum anticipated dose for 27 one batch .
Clearly mark the measuring unit for the type of admixture to be used .
28 Control the discharge sequence so an admixture will not be brought into contact with raw 29 cement or another admixture before being diluted through contact with the mixing water 30 in the mixer .
Where 2 types of admixtures are being used , do not discharge them into the 31 mix simultaneously .
Add the air entraining agent with the first addition of water and add 32 any other chemical admixture with the final addition of water , unless otherwise 33 permitted .
34 Construct the discharge lines to completely empty after each cycle .
Locate the admixture 35 dispensing systems so the batching plant operator will have a visual verification of the 36 actual quantity of admixture batched .
37 Use air entraining admixtures in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s recommendations 38 and in such quantity to provide the specified air content in freshly mixed concrete .
Use 39 a quantity of set retarding admixture and of water reducing admixture per 100 lbs .
of 40 cement that is within the range recommended on the current list of approved admixtures 41 issued by the Materials and Tests Unit .
42 1000-9 BATCHING PLANT 43 ( A ) General 44 Plants located on the Department rights of way shall conform to Article 107-3 .

47 Section 1000 10-13 Plants shall meet all the applicable requirements of these Standard Specifications , and in 1 addition , ensure each ready mix plant provides at least three acceptable truck mixers or 2 truck agitators available for use .
