7 ( B ) Bins and Hoppers 8 Provide bins with separate compartments for fine aggregates and for each required size of 9 coarse aggregate in the batching plant .
Design each compartment to discharge efficiently 10 and freely into the weighing hopper .
Provide control so , as the quantity desired is being 11 approached , the material may be added slowly and shut off with precision .
Construct 12 weighing hoppers to eliminate accumulation of tare materials and to discharge fully 13 unless otherwise permitted .
Provide a port or other opening for removing an overload of 14 any one of the several materials from the hopper .
15 ( C ) Scales 16 Use either the beam type , load cell type or the springless dial type scales for weighing 17 aggregates and cement .
Ensure the minimum graduation on beam or dial is not more than 18 0.1 % of the total capacity of the scale .
Methods of weighing , other than beam or 19 springless dial scales , may be approved by the Engineer provided they meet the required 20 weighing tolerances .
Ensure the scales are accurate within 0.5 % under operating 21 conditions .
Make available ten 50 lb .
test weights at the plant for checking accuracy .
22 Use test weights which meet the U.S. Bureau of Standards requirements for calibrating 23 and testing equipment .
Keep all exposed fulcrums , clevises and similar working parts of 24 scales clean .
When beam type scales are used , make provisions for indicating to the 25 operator that the required load in the weighing hopper is being approached .
Ensure the 26 device indicates at least the last 50 lbs .
of load and design it to give a positive indication 27 of overload of the scales .
During charging of the hopper , have all indicating devices in 28 full view of the operator and provide convenient access to all controls .
Ensure the 29 indicating devices are in the immediate vicinity of the operator and easily readable by the 30 operator .
31 ( D ) Water Measuring Devices 32 Use devices for measurement of the water which are readily adjustable and are capable of 33 being set to deliver the required amount and cut off the flow automatically when this 34 amount has been discharged .
Under all operating conditions the device shall have 35 accuracy within 1 % of the quantity of water required for the batch .
Arrange the device so 36 variable pressures in the water supply line will not affect the measurements .
Use 37 measuring tanks of adequate capacity to furnish the maximum mixing water required and 38 equip them with outside taps and valves to provide for checking their calibration unless 39 other means are provided for readily and accurately determining the amounts in the tank .
40 1000-10 MIXERS AND AGITATORS 41 ( A ) General 42 Mixers are defined as equipment to mix concrete and may be stationary or truck 43 mounted .
Agitators are defined as equipment used to haul central mixed concrete and 44 may be truck mixers or truck agitators .
Provide a metal plate or plates attached to each 45 mixer and agitator in a prominent place on which the manufacturer has plainly marked 46 the mixing speed of the drum or paddles and the maximum capacity of the drum or 47 container in terms of volume of mixed concrete .
On truck mixers and agitators , show the 48 manufacturer ’ s recommended agitating and mixing speed of rotation of the mixing drum 49 or blades .
Equip stationary mixers with an acceptable timing device that will not permit 50 the batch to be discharged until the specified mixing time has elapsed .
Equip truck 51 Section 1000 10-14 mixers with counters to verify the number of revolutions of the drum or blades .
Actuate 1 the counters at the initial time the drums have reached mixing speed .
2 Examine mixers and agitators periodically for changes in condition due to accumulation 3 of hard concrete or mortar , wear of blades or any other condition which decreases mixing 4 efficiency .
Mixers are unacceptable when the radial height or other dimension of the 5 blade has worn below 90 % of the original dimension .
This radial height excludes any 6 lips on the blade and is the height of the blade running perpendicular to the shell of the 7 drum .
Where such conditions are found , do not use the units until they are corrected .
8 Also examine mixers and agitators periodically for general mechanical condition , 9 including water measuring and discharge apparatus , identifying number on trucks , 10 condition of the blades , speed of rotation of the drum and condition of the drum .
11 ( B ) Mixer Capacity 12 Do not load truck mixers with concrete with more than 63 % of the gross volume of the 13 drum .
Use mixers capable of combining the ingredients of the concrete into a thoroughly 14 mixed and uniform mass and of discharging the concrete with a satisfactory degree of 15 uniformity .
Use stationary mixers , when loaded at the manufacturers guaranteed mixing 16 capacity and the concrete mixed for the prescribed mixing time , capable of combining the 17 ingredients of the concrete into a thoroughly mixed and uniform mass and discharging 18 the concrete with satisfactory uniformity .
19 Use at least 20 % of the rated mixing capacity as the minimum quantity of concrete 20 permitted to be mixed or agitated in any mixer .
21 ( C ) Agitator Capacity 22 Load the agitator to not exceed 80 % of the gross drum volume and have it be capable of 23 maintaining the concrete in a thoroughly mixed and uniform mass and of discharging the 24 concrete with a satisfactory degree of uniformity .
25 ( D ) Consistency Tests 26 The Engineer may , from time to time , make slump tests to measure consistency of the 27 concrete .
Take individual samples at approximately the 1/5th point , the midpoint and the 28 4/5th point of the load , using AASHTO T 119 .
Such tests will be made within 29 20 minutes of discharge of that portion of the load .
If the results vary by more than 1 30 inch in slump , do not use the mixer or agitator unless the condition is corrected .
31 1000-11 MIXING AND DELIVERY 32 ( A ) General 33 Mix and deliver concrete to the site of the work by one of the following methods , except 34 where other methods are approved .
Maintain responsibility for controlling the materials 35 and operations as to produce uniform concrete meeting Specifications requirements .
36 When concrete is being produced for structures and incidental construction in accordance 37 with Article 1000-4 , have present during all batching operations a Certified Concrete 38 Batch Technician employed by the Contractor or concrete supplier .
During batching and 39 delivery , the sole duty of this employee is to supervise the production and control of the 40 concrete .
Perform moisture tests , adjust mix proportions of aggregates for free moisture , 41 complete and sign Batch Tickets ( Materials and Tests Form 903 ) or approved delivery 42 tickets and assure quality control of the batching .
Delivery tickets will be permitted 43 instead of batch tickets ( Materials and Tests Form 903 ) provided they have been 44 reviewed and approved by the Materials and Tests Unit .
The Department certifies 45 technicians who satisfactorily complete examinations prepared and administered by the 46 Department .
47 Section 1000 10-15 ( 1 ) Central Mixed Concrete 1 Concrete that is mixed completely in a stationary mixer and the mixed concrete 2 transported to the point of delivery in a truck agitator or in a truck mixer operating at 3 agitating speed or in non-agitating equipment approved by the Engineer .
Perform 4 mixing within the capacity and at the mixing speeds recommended by the 5 manufacturer .
6 ( 2 ) Transit Mixed Concrete 7 Concrete that is mixed completely in a truck mixer while at the batching plant , in 8 transit , or at the work site .
9 ( 3 ) Shrink Mixed Concrete 10 Concrete that is mixed partially in a stationary mixer at a central mixing plant and 11 completed as transit mixed concrete .
Place all ingredients for a batch in the 12 stationary mixer , partially mix before any concrete is discharged to the truck mixer 13 and do not exceed the rated capacity of the equipment for the batch size .
The mixing 14 time at the stationary mixer may be reduced to the minimum necessary to 15 intermingle the ingredients , and the mixing may be completed in the truck mixer .
16 Use the number of mixing revolutions in the truck mixer as specified for transit 17 mixed concrete or reduce as indicated by mixer performance tests .
18 ( B ) Mixing Time for Central Mixed Concrete 19 Mixing time begins when all solid materials are in the mixing compartment and ends 20 when any part of the concrete begins to discharge .
In charging the mixer , water will enter 21 in advance of cement and aggregate .
Ensure all the water is substantially in the drum 22 before 1/3 of the specified mixing time has elapsed .
Count transfer time in multiple drum 23 mixers as part of the mixing time .
24 Where mixer performance tests are not made , use a minimum mixing time of 90 seconds , 25 providing that blending of materials during charging is achieved to the satisfaction of the 26 Engineer .
The minimum mixing time for an individual mixer is that which , as shown by 27 mixer performance tests , will produce concrete in accordance with Table 1000-5 , except 28 that the mixing time shall not be less than 50 seconds under any circumstances .
29 Maximum mixing time excluding discharge time is 150 seconds .
30 Sampling and testing for mixer performance tests will be done as provided below .
31 Charge the mixer to its rated capacity with the materials and proportions to be used in the 32 work and mixed at the recommended mixing speed to the target time .
Stop mixing and 33 begin discharging .
Two samples of sufficient size to make the required tests will be 34 taken after discharge of approximately 15 % and 85 % of the load .

6 The Engineer may recheck mixer performance at any time when , in his opinion , 7 satisfactory mixing is not being accomplished .

11 ( C ) Truck Mixers and Truck Agitators 12 When a truck mixer is used for complete mixing , mix each batch of concrete for at least 13 70 revolutions of the drum or blades at the rate of rotation designated by the 14 manufacturer of the equipment as mixing speed , unless otherwise directed by the 15 Engineer .
Unless the mixer is equipped with a counter which will distinguish between 16 mixing and agitating speeds , perform the minimum required number of revolutions of the 17 drum at mixing speed as directed , either at the batching plant before the mixer leaves 18 for the work site and/or at the work site before the concrete is discharged .
19 Perform any additional mixing at the speed designated by the manufacturer of the 20 equipment as agitating speed .
Put all materials including mixing water in the drum 21 before actuating the revolution counter for determining the number of revolutions of the 22 drum .
23 When a truck mixer or truck agitator is used to transport concrete that has been 24 completely mixed in a stationary mixer , perform mixing during transport at agitating 25 speed .
26 Provide concrete , when discharged from truck mixers or truck agitators , of the 27 consistency and workability required for the work .
Control the rate of discharge of the 28 plastic concrete from the mixer drum by the speed or rotation of the drum in the 29 discharge direction with the discharge gate fully open .
If additional mixing water is 30 necessary to produce the slump necessary for proper placement , add it only with 31 permission and rotate the truck mixer drum at least 25 revolutions at mixing speed before 32 discharge of any concrete .
Additional mixing water will be allowed only if the maximum 33 specified water content per cubic yard is not exceeded .
34 ( D ) Delivery 35 Use a ticket system for recording the transportation of batches from the proportioning 36 plant to the site of the work .
Use tickets furnished by the Engineer and fill it out in 37 accordance with instructions issued by the Engineer .
Issue the tickets to the truck 38 operator at the proportioning plant for each load and have them signed by the plant 39 inspector , which will signify that the concrete in the truck has been inspected before 40 departure .
Ensure each ticket shows the time batching was completed and if transit 41 mixed , the number of revolutions at mixing speed , if any , at the plant .
Deliver the tickets 42 to the inspector at the site of the work .
Do not use loads which do not carry such tickets 43 and loads which do not arrive in satisfactory condition within the time limits specified in 44 the work .
45 1000-12 VOLUMETRIC MIXED CONCRETE 46 Upon written request by the contractor , the Department may approve the use of concrete 47 proportioned by volume .
The volumetric producer must submit and have approved a process 48 control plan and product quality control plan by the Materials and Tests Unit .
If concrete is 49 proportioned by volume , the other requirements of these specifications with the following 50 Section 1000 10-17 modifications will apply .
Unless otherwise approved by the Department , use of concrete 1 proportioned by volume shall be limited to Class B concrete and no more than 30 cy per unit 2 per day .
3 ( A ) Materials 4 Use materials that meet the requirements for the respective items except that they will be 5 measured by a calibrated volume-weight relationship .
6 Storage facilities for all material shall be designed to permit the Department to make 7 necessary inspections before the batching operations .
The facilities shall permit 8 identification of approved material at all times and shall be designed to avoid mixing 9 with , or contaminating by , unapproved material .
Coarse and fine aggregate shall be 10 furnished and handled so variations in the moisture content affecting the uniform 11 consistency of the concrete is avoided .
12 Moisture content of the coarse and fine aggregate will be made available onsite for the 13 Engineer ’ s review for each load .
The frequency of moisture testing will be dependent on 14 certain variables such as weather , season and source ; however , moisture tests should be 15 performed at least once at the beginning of the work day for each source material .
16 Additional daily moisture tests for the coarse and fine aggregate shall be performed if 17 requested by the Engineer .
18 Unused materials should be emptied from hopper daily .
Concrete should not be mixed 19 with materials left in the hopper overnight .
20 ( B ) Equipment 21 Provide volumetric mixers with rating plates indicating that the performance of the mixer 22 is in accordance with the Volumetric Mixer Manufacturer Bureau or equivalent .
Mixers 23 must comply with ASTM C685 .
Unless otherwise specified , all mixing operations must 24 be in strict accordance with the manufacturer ’ s recommended procedures .
Such 25 procedures shall be provided to the Department for review upon request .
26 The volumetric mixer shall be capable of carrying sufficient unmixed dry bulk cement , 27 supplementary cementitious material ( if required ) , fine aggregate , coarse aggregate , 28 admixtures and water , in separate compartments and accurately proportioning the 29 specified mix .
Each batching or mixing unit ( or both ) shall carry in a prominent place a 30 metal plate or plates on which are plainly marked the gross volume of the unit in terms of 31 mixed concrete , discharge speed and the weight-calibrated constant of the machine in 32 terms of a revolution counter or other output indicator .
33 The concrete mixing device shall be an auger-type continuous mixer used in conjunction 34 with volumetric proportioning .
The mixer shall produce concrete , uniform in color and 35 appearance , with homogeneous distribution of the material throughout the mixture .
36 Mixing time necessary to produce uniform concrete shall be established by the contractor 37 and shall comply with other requirements of these specifications .
Only equipment found 38 acceptable in every respect and capable of producing uniform results will be permitted .
39 Each volumetric mixer shall be equipped with an onboard ticketing system that will 40 electronically produce a record of all material used and their respective weights and the 41 total volume of concrete placed .
Alternate methods of recordation may be used if 42 approved by the Engineer .

12 SECTION 1002 13 SHOTCRETE PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY 14 1002-1 DESCRIPTION 15 This section addresses shotcrete to be used for temporary support of excavations and other 16 applications in accordance with the contract .
Produce shotcrete by either the dry-mix or 17 wet-mix process composed of Portland cement , fine and/or coarse aggregates , water and at the 18 Contractor ’ s option , supplementary cementitious materials .
Include chemical admixtures as 19 required or needed for shotcrete produced by the wet-mix process .
Ground granulated blast 20 furnace slag , fly ash or silica fume may be substituted for a portion of the Portland cement .
21 Type IL , IS , IP or IT blended cement may be used instead of Portland cement .
22 Mixes for all shotcrete shall be designed by a Certified Concrete Mix Design Technician or an 23 engineer licensed by the State of North Carolina .
Shotcrete shall be applied by a nozzelman 24 certified as an ACI Shotcrete Nozzelman in accordance with ACI Certification 25 Publication CP-60 .
Nozzlemen shall be certified in either dry-mix or wet-mix shotcrete 26 based on the process to be used for the work .

Apply shotcrete with the same 36 equipment and methods as used for the preconstruction test panels .
37 The shotcrete temperature at the time of shooting shall be not less than 50°F nor more 38 than 90°F .
Do not apply shotcrete during heavy rains or runoff or high winds so the 39 nozzle stream separates during shooting .
Do not apply shotcrete if surface to receive 40 shotcrete is frozen or the air temperature measured at the location of the shotcreting 41 operation in the shade away from artificial heat is below 40°F .
Apply shotcrete before 42 the time between adding the mixing water to the shotcrete mix and shooting the shotcrete 43 exceeds 60 minutes .

8 SECTION 1003 9 GROUT PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY 10 1003-1 DESCRIPTION 11 This section addresses cement grout to be used for structures , foundations , retaining walls , 12 concrete barriers , embankments , pavements and other applications in accordance with the 13 contract .
Produce non-metallic grout composed of Portland cement and water and at the 14 Contractor ’ s option or as required , aggregate and supplementary cementitious materials .
15 Include chemical admixtures as required or needed .
Provide sand cement or neat cement 16 grout as required .
Define “ neat cement grout ” as grout without aggregate .
17 The types of grout with their typical uses are as shown below : 18 Type 1 – A cement grout with only a 3 day strength requirement and a fluid consistency that 19 is typically used for filling subsurface voids .
20 Type 2 – A nonshrink grout with strength , height change and flow conforming to ASTM 21 C1107 that is typically used for foundations , ground anchors and soil nails .
22 Type 3 – A nonshrink grout with high early strength and freeze-thaw durability requirements 23 that is typically used in pile blockouts , grout pockets , shear keys , dowel holes and recesses for 24 concrete barriers and structures .
25 Type 4 – A neat cement grout with low strength , a fluid consistency and high fly ash content 26 that is typically used for slab jacking .
27 Type 5 – A low slump , low mobility cement grout with minimal strength that is typically 28 used for compaction grouting .

Measure the elapsed time as the time between 19 adding the mixing water to the grout mix and placing the grout .

25 SECTION 1005 26 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR AGGREGATE 27 1005-1 GENERAL 28 Obtain aggregates from sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate QC/QA Program 29 as described in Section 1006 .
Obtain aggregates from pre-approved sources , or have the 30 source approved before use .
Approval of such sources is based not only on the quality of the 31 aggregate , but also on satisfactory production facilities and procedures .
A list of approved 32 aggregate sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate QC/QA Program in North 33 Carolina and adjoining states is available from the Materials and Tests Unit .
This list includes 34 aggregates meeting Specification requirements but whose use is restricted due to history of 35 unsatisfactory service performance .
Use of aggregates is allowed in the work provided they 36 have been properly stockpiled in units of not less than 300 tons , tests of representative 37 samples of these aggregates indicate satisfactory compliance with the Specifications and the 38 source meets all the requirements of the Aggregate QC/QA Program .
39 Section 1005 10-25 Separate aggregate containing rock of more than one identifiable rock type or particles of 1 visibly different degrees of weathering in amounts of 10 % or more into each individual type .
2 Aggregate is acceptable only if each type does not exceed the percentage of wear specified for 3 a particular use .
4 Blended aggregates from different sources are allowed if all aggregates meet the 5 Specifications for soundness or resistance to abrasion .
6 1005-2 HANDLING AND STORING AGGREGATES 7 Handle and stockpile aggregates in such a manner to minimize segregation .
8 Provide sites for aggregate stockpiles that are cleared , grubbed and cleaned with a firm , 9 smooth and well drained ground surface .
Maintain a cover of at least 3 inches of aggregate 10 over the ground surface to avoid the inclusion of soil or foreign material .
Operate trucks or 11 other equipment on a stockpile in an acceptable manner .
12 Space or separate with suitable walls or partitions stockpiles of different types or sizes of 13 aggregates to prevent the mixing of the aggregates .
Do not allow the stockpile to become 14 contaminated with foreign matter or degrade excessively .
Failure of aggregate samples to 15 meet all gradation requirements due to excessive degradation will be determined by sieve tests 16 of samples taken from any portion of the stockpile and is cause for discontinuance of such 17 stockpiling procedure .
18 Use material that consists mainly of rock dust produced through normal handling of the 19 aggregate and that is essentially free from clay or shale .
20 1005-3 GRADATION 21 Grade all standard sizes of aggregate to meet Tables 1005-1 or 1005-2 .
22 1005-4 TESTING 23 Aggregates will be tested in accordance with the test methods below except where other test 24 procedures are required by other articles covering a particular application .

31 Section 1010 10-28 SECTION 1006 1 AGGREGATE QUALITY CONTROL/QUALITY ASSURANCE 2 The Aggregate QC/QA Program is designed to give aggregate producers more responsibility 3 for controlling the quality of material they produce and to use the quality control information 4 they provide in the acceptance process by the Department .
It requires aggregate producers to 5 perform quality control sampling , testing and record keeping on aggregates they ship for use 6 by the Department .
It requires the Department to perform quality assurance sampling , testing 7 and record keeping confirming the performance of the producers ’ control plan .
The program 8 is described in the Aggregate QC/QA Program Manual .
9 Participation in this program does not relieve the producer of the responsibility of complying 10 with all requirements of the Department ’ s Standard Specifications .
11 SECTION 1008 12 AGGREGATE FOR STABILIZATION 13 1008-1 AGGREGATE STABILIZATION 14 ( A ) General 15 Aggregates consist of crushed stone , crushed gravel , uncrushed gravel or other similar 16 material having hard , strong , durable particles free of adherent coatings .
17 Supply aggregates from approved sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate 18 QC/QA Program in accordance with Sections 1005 and 1006 .
Sources will not be 19 approved unless the material has satisfactory soundness and satisfactory resistance to 20 abrasion .
Satisfactory soundness will be a loss in weight of not greater than 15 % when 21 subject to 5 alternations of the soundness test .
Satisfactory resistance to abrasion will be 22 a percentage of wear of not greater than 55 % .
23 ( B ) Sampling and Acceptance 24 Sampling and acceptance for the determination of gradation , LL and PI will be performed 25 as described in the Aggregate QC/QA Program Manual and the Aggregate Sampling 26 Manual using the versions in effect at the time material is shipped .
27 SECTION 1010 28 AGGREGATE FOR NON-ASPHALT TYPE BASES 29 1010-1 AGGREGATE BASE COURSE 30 ( A ) General Requirements 31 Aggregate base course material consists of crushed stone , crushed gravel , uncrushed 32 gravel or other similar material having hard , strong , durable particles free of adherent 33 coatings .
34 Provide aggregates from approved sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate 35 QC/QA Program in accordance with Sections 1005 and 1006 .
Sources will not be 36 approved unless the material has satisfactory soundness and resistance to abrasion .
37 Satisfactory soundness will be a weighted average loss of not greater than 15 % when 38 subjected to five alternations of the soundness test .
Satisfactory resistance to abrasion 39 will be a percentage of wear of not greater than 55 % .
40 ( B ) Sampling and Acceptance 41 Sampling and acceptance for the determination of gradation , LL and PI will be performed 42 as described in the Aggregate QC/QA Program Manual and the Aggregate Sampling 43 Manual using the versions in effect at the time material is shipped .
44 Section 1012 10-29 1010-2 AGGREGATE FOR PLANT MIXED CEMENT TREATED BASE COURSE 1 Provide aggregate meeting Article 1010-1 , except as modified herein .

3 SECTION 1012 4 AGGREGATE FOR ASPHALT PAVEMENTS 5 AND SURFACE TREATMENTS 6 1012-1 AGGREGATE FOR ASPHALT PLANT MIXES 7 ( A ) General 8 Design the asphalt plant mix with coarse and fine aggregate that meet Section 1005 , 9 except as noted herein .
Size , uniformly grade and combine the aggregate fractions in 10 such proportions that the resulting mixture meets the grading and physical requirements 11 of these Specifications for the specified mix type .
Materials that will not produce 12 a mixture within the design criteria required by these Specifications will be rejected , 13 unless otherwise approved .

15 Source property criteria apply to individual aggregate sources .
16 For all dense-graded surface course mixes , that are the top or final layer , limit the amount 17 of coarse aggregate or fine aggregate produced from crystalline limestone , crystalline- 18 dolomitic limestone or marble to no more than 50 % of the total amount of coarse 19 aggregate or fine aggregate in the asphalt mixture .
For open-graded asphalt friction 20 course and ultra-thin bonded wearing course , do not use aggregates produced from 21 crystalline limestone , crystalline-dolomitic limestone or marble .
22 ( B ) Coarse Aggregate 23 ( 1 ) General 24 Use coarse aggregate consisting of crushed stone , crushed gravel , a mixture of 25 uncrushed gravel with either crushed stone or crushed gravel or other inert material 26 having similar characteristics .
Provide coarse aggregate composed of clean , tough , 27 durable fragments free from an excess of flat or elongated pieces and free of organic 28 matter and deleterious substances .
29 Use coarse aggregate from sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate 30 QC/QA Program as described in Section 1006 .

4 sieve and larger with a 5:1 aspect 42 ratio ( maximum to minimum ) for all pavement types , except there is no requirement 43 for Types S4.75A , SF9.5A and S9.5B .

26 Section 1012 10-31 Use fine aggregate from sources participating in the Department ’ s Aggregate 1 QC/QA Program as described in Section 1006 .
A list of sources participating in the 2 Department ’ s QC/QA Program in North Carolina and adjoining states is available 3 from the Department ’ s Materials and Tests Unit in Raleigh .
If a natural sand source 4 is owned by the same owner as the asphalt plant where the material is used , 5 participation in the Aggregate QC/QA Program is not required .
6 Furnish sand from approved sources .
Do not use sources contaminated by industrial 7 waste .
A sufficient number of samples of fine aggregate , but in no case less than 8 three , will be taken to indicate any variation within any stockpile or source of supply .
9 Do not use fine aggregate containing sticks , roots , trash , visible lumps of clay , or 10 other unsatisfactory material unless all undesirable material is removed to the 11 satisfaction of the Engineer before the aggregate is used in the asphalt mixture .
12 Use natural sand that is non-plastic when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 90 .
13 Produce stone screenings from stone that has a maximum percentage of wear of 55 % 14 when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 96 using test grading A .
15 ( 2 ) Gradation 16 Use stone screenings that are consistently graded with not more than 20 % by weight 17 passing the No .
200 sieve when tested by dry sieving in accordance with 18 AASHTO T 27 .
Use natural sand that is consistently graded .
19 ( 3 ) Clay Content ( Sand Equivalent ) 20 Use a fine aggregate blend that has a minimum sand equivalent percentage as 21 indicated in Table 1012-1 when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 176 .
22 ( 4 ) Soundness 23 The maximum weighted average soundness loss of individual fine aggregate sources 24 when subjected to 5 cycles using sodium sulfate shall be 15 % when tested in 25 accordance with AASHTO T 104 .
26 Natural sand that contains grains of questionable hardness will be subjected to 27 5 cycles of the soundness test .
The weighted average loss shall be not more 28 than 15 % .
The soundness test will be performed before establishing the mix design .
29 ( 5 ) Deleterious Materials 30 The maximum percentage by weight of clay lumps and friable particles in individual 31 fine aggregate sources shall be 0.3 % when tested in accordance with 32 AASHTO T 112 .
33 ( 6 ) Fine Aggregate Angularity 34 Use a fine aggregate blend that has a minimum fine aggregate angularity as indicated 35 in Table 1012-1 when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 304 , Method A .
36 ( D ) Mineral Filler 37 Use mineral filler consisting of limestone dust , dolomite dust , Portland cement , or other 38 inert mineral matter that conforms to AASHTO M 17 .
39 ( E ) Reclaimed Asphalt Shingles ( RAS ) 40 For use in asphalt mix , Reclaimed Asphalt Shingles ( RAS ) can be either manufacturer- 41 waste shingles or post-consumer shingles that have been processed into a product that 42 meets the requirements of this section .
43 Section 1012 10-32 Manufacturer-waste RAS ( MRAS ) are processed shingle materials discarded from the 1 manufacturing of new asphalt shingles .
It may include asphalt shingles or shingle tabs 2 that have been rejected by the shingle manufacturer .
3 Post-consumer RAS ( PRAS ) are processed shingle materials recovered from mixed 4 roofing material scrap removed from existing structures .
Tear-off shingle scrap must be 5 sorted and other roofing debris , including nails , plastic , metal , wood , coal tar epoxy , 6 rubber materials , or other undesirable components , shall be removed .
This sorting of the 7 scrap must be done prior to grinding of the PRAS for use in asphalt production .
8 Sample and test PRAS for asbestos and provide results demonstrating that the bulk 9 samples contain less than one percent of asbestos containing material in accordance with 10 Federal , State of North Carolina , and Local regulations .
Use NC-accredited Asbestos 11 Inspectors or Roofing Supervisors to sample the PRAS to meet the above criteria .
12 Maintain records on-site indicating shingle source ( s ) , asbestos operation plan approved 13 by Division of Public Health ’ s Health Hazards Control Unit , and all asbestos analytical 14 reports .
All documentation will be subject to review by the Department .
15 Process RAS by ambient grinding or granulating methods such that 100 % of the particles 16 will pass the 9.50 mm ( 3/8 inch ) sieve when tested in accordance with AASHTO T27 .
17 Perform sieve analysis on processed asphalt shingles prior to ignition or solvent 18 extraction testing .
19 RAS shall contain no more than 0.5 % by total cumulative weight of deleterious materials .
20 These materials include , but are not limited to , excessive dirt , debris , concrete , metals , 21 glass , paper , rubber , wood , plastic , soil , brick , tars , or other contaminating substances .
22 Blend RAS with fine aggregate or RAP , meeting the requirements of this Section , if 23 needed to keep the processed material workable .
24 MRAS and PRAS shall not be blended together for the production of hot mix asphalt .
25 ( 1 ) Mix Design RAS 26 Incorporate RAS from stockpiles that have been tested for uniformity of gradation 27 and binder content prior to use in an asphalt mix design .
28 ( 2 ) Mix Production RAS 29 New Source RAS is defined as acceptable material which was not included in the 30 stockpile when samples were taken for mix design purposes .
Process new source 31 RAS so that all materials will meet the gradation requirements prior to introduction 32 into the plant mixer unit .
33 After a stockpile of processed RAS has been sampled and mix designs made from 34 these samples , do not add new source RAS to the original stockpile without prior 35 field testing to insure gradation and binder uniformity .
Sample and test new source 36 RAS before blending with the existing stockpile .
37 Store new source RAS in a separate stockpile until the material can be sampled and 38 tested for comparison with the original recycled mix design data .
New source RAS 39 may also be placed against the existing stockpile in a linear manner provided it is 40 sampled for mix design conformity prior to its use in the recycled mix .
Store RAS 41 materials in such a manner as to prevent contamination .
42 Field approval of new source RAS will be based on the table below and volumetric 43 mix properties on the mix with the new source RAS included .
Provided these 44 tolerances are met , volumetric properties of the new mix will then be performed .
If 45 all volumetric mix properties meet the mix design criteria for that mix type , the new 46 source RAS may continue to be used .

9 1012-2 AGGREGATES FOR ASPHALT SURFACE TREATMENT 10 ( A ) General 11 Use coarse aggregate consisting of crushed stone , crushed gravel , crushed slag , or other 12 inert material having similar characteristics .
Adequately wash coarse aggregate so it is 13 free from clay , loam , dust and other adherent materials .
14 Adequately clean all fine aggregate so it is free from sticks , roots , visible lumps of clay or 15 other unsatisfactory material before use .
16 ( B ) Gradation 17 Use coarse aggregate for mat and seal coat and AST as required by Section 660 , unless 18 otherwise required by the contract .
Use aggregate meeting the applicable gradation 19 requirements of Table 1005-1 .
20 Remix aggregate that has become segregated until it meets the applicable gradation 21 requirements .
22 ( C ) Fractured Faces 23 Use coarse aggregate that contains at least 75 % by weight of crushed pieces having 2 or 24 more fractured faces and at least 90 % by weight of crushed pieces having one or more 25 fractured faces on that portion retained on the No .
4 sieve .
26 ( D ) Soundness 27 The maximum weighted average loss of either coarse or fine aggregate when subjected 28 to 5 cycles using sodium sulfate when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 104 is 15 % .
29 ( E ) Toughness ( Resistance to Abrasion ) 30 The maximum percentage loss of course aggregate for asphalt surface treatment when 31 tested in accordance with AASHTO T 96 is 55 % .
32 ( F ) Blending of Aggregates 33 Blending of two or more aggregates will not be permitted regardless of the origin of the 34 aggregates if any one of the aggregates fails to meet the requirements for soundness or 35 resistance to abrasion .
36 ( G ) Weight of Slag 37 The minimum weight of crushed slag is 70 lbs/cf as determined in accordance with 38 AASHTO T 19 .
39 1012-3 BLOTTING SAND 40 Blotting sand is fine aggregate consisting of natural sand , commercial sand , manufactured 41 sand , coarse screenings , or other inert material having similar characteristics .
42 Subarticles 1012-2 ( D ) and 1012-2 ( F ) will be applicable to blotting sand .
Adequately clean 43 the fine aggregate so it is free from sticks , roots , visible lumps of clay or other unsatisfactory 44 material before use .

29 ( B ) Soundness 30 When subjected to 5 cycles of the soundness test , the weighted average loss shall not be 31 more than 15 % .

The amount of deleterious substances shall not exceed 35 2.0 % by weight for natural sand or 1.0 % by weight for manufactured sand .
36 Section 1014 10-38 ( D ) Organic Impurities 1 The color of each source of fine aggregate will be determined annually in accordance 2 with AASHTO T 21 .
Should the fine aggregate show a darker color than samples 3 previously approved from the same source , withhold its use until tests have been made to 4 determine the quality of the sand .
5 ( E ) Mortar Strength 6 Mortar made with the fine aggregate shall have a compressive strength at the age of 7 3 and 7 days using Type III Portland cement , or 7 and 28 days using Type I or II Portland 8 cement , of not less than 95 % of that developed by a comparison mortar .
Make the 9 comparison mortar with the same cement , graded Ottawa sand with a fineness modulus of 10 2.40 ± 0.05 , and the same water-cement ratio and consistency as the test mortar .
Test the 11 mortar strength in accordance with AASHTO T 106 .
12 Fine aggregate that fails the mortar strength may be used with the approval of the 13 Engineer , provided that when it is tested in concrete cylinders the compressive strength of 14 the concrete at 14 days is equal to or greater than the strength of cylinders made with 15 an identical mix using an acceptable sand .
16 ( F ) Gradation 17 Natural sand shall meet the gradation for standard size No .
2S fine aggregate .
18 Manufactured sand shall meet the gradation for standard size No .
2MS fine aggregate .
19 ( G ) Blending Fine Aggregate 20 Blending fine aggregates to obtain the required gradation will be permitted if test results 21 of each aggregate meet the durability requirements and test results of the combination 22 indicate acceptable quality .
Blend aggregates by weighing them separately at the time of 23 batching or by other means acceptable to the Engineer .
24 When natural sand is blended with natural sand , the blend shall meet the gradation for 25 No .
2S fine aggregate .
When manufactured sand is blended with natural sand or with 26 manufactured sand , the blend shall meet the gradation for No .
2MS fine aggregate and 27 neither component shall exceed the gradation limits on the No .
200 sieve shown in 28 Table 1005-2 .

19 1020-6 PERFORMANCE GRADED ASPHALT BINDER AND ASPHALT 20 EMULSION QUALITY CONTROL/QUALITY ASSURANCE 21 The Performance Graded Asphalt Binder and Asphalt emulsion QC/QA Programs are 22 designed to give asphalt binder and asphalt emulsion producers/suppliers ( henceforth 23 Producer designates Producer/Supplier ) more responsibility for controlling the quality of 24 material they produce and to use the quality control information they provide in the 25 acceptance process by the Department .
It requires asphalt binder and asphalt emulsion 26 producers to perform quality control sampling , testing and record keeping on materials they 27 ship for use by the Department .
It documents that the Department will perform quality 28 assurance sampling , testing and record keeping confirming the performance of the producers ’ 29 control plan .
In addition , the Producer is required to participate in independent assurance 30 comparative sample activities .
The program is described in the Performance Graded Asphalt 31 Binder and Asphalt Emulsion QC/QA Program Manuals .
An electronic copy of the program 32 manuals may be obtained by accessing the Materials and Tests website .
33 The types of samples and the lot sizes required by the Producers and the Department are 34 described in detail in the Performance Graded Asphalt Binder and Asphalt Emulsion 35 QC/QA Program Manuals .
36 Acceptance or rejection of material will be based on the total program .
Therefore , 37 a comparison of the quality control , quality assurance and other sample data may be used by 38 the Department for acceptance or rejection of a lot of material .
39 Participation in this program does not relieve the producer of the responsibility of complying 40 with all requirements of the Standard Specifications .

4 1020-8 ANTI-STRIP ADDITIVES 5 Anti-strip additives may either be hydrated lime or a chemical additive or a combination of 6 both .
Use an anti-strip additive capable of preventing the separation of the asphalt binder 7 from the aggregate and achieving the required tensile strength ratio ( TSR ) on the asphalt mix 8 when tested in accordance with AASHTO T 283 as modified by the Department .
9 Use hydrated lime conforming to AASHTO M 303 .
Add hydrated lime used of anti-strip 10 purposes at a rate of not less than 1.0 % by weight of the total dry aggregate .
11 Add chemical anti-strip additives to the asphalt binder before introduction into the mix .
Do 12 not use any chemical additive or particular concentration of chemical additive found to be 13 harmful to the asphalt material or which causes the performance grading of the original 14 asphalt binder to be out of specifications for the grade required .
15 1020-9 SILICONE 16 Silicone additives shall be pre-approved by the Materials and Tests Unit .

SECTION 1024 9 MATERIALS FOR PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE 10 1024-1 PORTLAND CEMENT 11 Supply Portland cement that meets AASHTO M 85 for Type I , II or III except that the 12 maximum fineness requirements of AASHTO M 85 do not apply to cement used in precast 13 concrete products .
Throughout these Specifications Types I and II cement are referred to as 14 regular Portland cement and Type III as high early strength Portland cement .
15 Certain combinations of cement and aggregate exhibit an adverse alkali-silica reaction .
The 16 alkalinity of any cement , expressed as sodium-oxide equivalent , shall not exceed 1.0 % .
For 17 mix designs that contain non-reactive aggregates and cement with an alkali content less than 18 0.6 % , straight cement or a combination of cement and fly ash , cement and ground granulated 19 blast furnace slag or cement and microsilica may be used .
The supplementary cementitious 20 material ( SCM ) quantity shall not exceed the amount shown in Table 1024-1 .
For mixes that 21 contain cement with an alkali content between 0.6 % and 1.0 % and for mixes that contain a 22 reactive aggregate documented by the Department , use a supplementary cementitious material 23 in the amount shown in Table 1024-1 .
24 Section 1024 10-50 Obtain the list of reactive aggregates documented by the Department at the Materials and 1 Tests Unit website .
2 TABLE 1024-1 SUPPLEMENTARY CEMENTITIOUS MATERIAL FOR USE IN PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE SCM Rate Class F Fly Ash 20 % - 30 % by weight of required cement content with 1.0 lb Class F fly ash per lb of cement replaced Ground Granulated Blast Furnace Slag 35 % -50 % by weight of required cement content with 1.0 lb slag per lb of cement replaced Microsilica 4 % -8 % by weight of required cement content with 1.0 lb microsilica per lb of cement replaced Type IP or IS blended cement is allowed for the cement-and-fly-ash or cement-and-slag 3 portion of the mix .
Type IT may be allowed for the cement-and- supplementary cementitious 4 portion of the mix with the permission of the Engineer .
Do not substitute fly ash or slag for a 5 portion of Type IP , IS or IT cement or for Portland cement in high early strength concrete .
6 Use white cement that meets ASTM C150 , except that the ferric oxide content is limited 7 to 0.5 % .
8 Use Type IP blended cement that meets AASHTO M 240 , except that the pozzolanic content 9 is limited to between 17 and 23 % by weight and the constituents shall be interground .
10 Use Type IS blended cement that meets AASHTO M 240 except that the slag content is 11 limited to between 35 % and 50 % by weight and the constituents are interground .
12 Use Type IT blended cement that meets AASHTO M 240 .
The Engineer will evaluate the 13 blend of constituents for acceptance in Department work .
14 Use Type IL blended cement that meets AASHTO M 240 , except the constituents shall be 15 interground .
Class F fly ash can replace a portion of Type IL blended cement and shall be 16 replaced as outlined in Subarticle 1000-4 ( I ) for Portland cement .
For mixes that contain 17 cement with alkali content between 0.6 % and 1.0 % and for mixes that contain a reactive 18 aggregate documented by the Department , use a pozzolan in the amount shown in Table 19 1024-1 .
20 Do not use air-entraining Portland cement .
Do not mix different types of cement , different 21 brands of cement , or the same brand from different mills nor use them alternately except 22 when authorized in writing by the Engineer .
23 Protect cement from contamination or damage during handling and storage .
Do not use 24 cement that is damaged , partially set , lumpy or caked .
25 All cement is sampled and tested by the Department as it arrives on the project or at the 26 precasting plant at such frequency as established by the Department .

29 1024-3 ADMIXTURES 30 ( A ) Basis of Acceptance 31 Admixtures from an approved source are accepted without prior testing .
Do not use 32 admixtures that are not from an approved source until the admixture is approved by the 33 Department .
34 Section 1024 10-51 ( B ) Approved Sources 1 An approved source is considered to be any manufacturer of admixtures who complies 2 with this subarticle .
3 The manufacturer shall submit to the Product Evaluation Program an application and 4 certified reports of tests that show that the admixture meets the applicable Specifications .
5 Tests shall be performed by AASHTO ’ s designated National Transportation Product 6 Evaluation Program ( NTPEP ) laboratory for concrete admixture testing .
Admixtures that 7 contain chloride other than calcium chloride as provided herein are not permitted .
The 8 manufacturer is required to state in writing that no chloride was added during the 9 manufacture of the admixture .
10 After an admixture is accepted , the manufacturer is required to submit to the Product 11 Evaluation Program on or before February 1 of each year a notarized certification that 12 shows that the material is of the same composition as originally accepted and has not 13 been changed or altered .
If an admixture is changed or altered , approval of the source in 14 accordance with the above requirements is necessary before using the admixture .
15 The Engineer has the option to perform tests deemed desirable to verify the 16 manufacturer ’ s certification .
Failure of the admixture in such tests is cause for 17 discontinuation of its use .
Failure of an admixture to perform satisfactorily under job 18 conditions is cause for rejection of the source .
19 The Engineer maintains a list of approved sources on file .
20 ( C ) Air Entraining Agent 21 Provide air entraining agents that meet AASHTO M 154 .
22 ( D ) Chemical Admixtures 23 ( 1 ) Set Retarding Admixtures 24 Use set retarding admixtures that meet AASHTO M 194 for Type D , water reducing 25 and retarding admixtures .
26 ( 2 ) Water Reducing Admixtures 27 Use water reducing admixtures that meet AASHTO M 194 for Type A admixtures .
28 ( 3 ) Calcium Chloride 29 Provide calcium chloride that meets AASHTO M 144 for Type 2 , concentrated flake , 30 pellet or other granular calcium chloride .
The Engineer may waive the gradation 31 requirement .
32 ( 4 ) High-Range Water Reducing Admixtures 33 Use high-range water reducing admixtures that meet AASHTO M 194 for Type F or 34 Type G. 35 ( 5 ) Calcium Nitrite Corrosion Inhibitor 36 Use an approved calcium nitrite corrosion inhibitor that contains 30 % solids .
37 ( E ) Other Admixtures 38 Admixtures not otherwise classified will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis by the 39 Materials and Tests Unit .

24 Section 1026 10-53 SECTION 1026 1 CURING AGENTS FOR CONCRETE 2 1026-1 GENERAL 3 All curing agents shall be free from impurities that may be detrimental to the concrete .
Do 4 not use curing agent until the applicable tests have been performed for each batch and the 5 Engineer has approved the curing agent .
6 1026-2 LIQUID MEMBRANE CURING COMPOUNDS 7 ( A ) General 8 Liquid membrane curing compounds shall meet ASTM C 309 , except that when tested in 9 the water retention test described in AASHTO T 155 the curing compound shall restrict 10 the loss of water in the test specimen at the time of application of the compound to not 11 more than 0.007 ounces per square inch .
12 The curing compound shall be Type 2 , white pigmented , except where clear type is 13 required for a particular application , the curing compound shall be Type 1D , clear or 14 translucent with fugitive dye .
15 Deliver curing compound in the manufacturer ’ s original clean , sealed containers .
16 Legibly mark each container with the name of the manufacturer , the name of the 17 compound , the type of compound , the manufacturer ’ s batch number , the date of 18 manufacture and the manufacturer ’ s recommended shelf life .
19 Do not use curing compound that has been in storage for more than one year from the 20 date of manufacture or more than the manufacturer ’ s recommended shelf life , whichever 21 is less .
22 ( B ) Test Procedures 23 Curing compound will be tested in accordance with ASTM C 309 , except the size of 24 molds for making test specimens will be approximately 5.5 inches in diameter by 25 approximately 1 inch deep , or any other size selected by the Engineer .
26 1026-3 POLYETHYLENE FILM 27 Polyethylene film shall meet ASTM C 171for white opaque polyethylene film , except that 28 when tested for moisture retention efficiency the loss shall not be more than 0.007 oz./sq.in of 29 surface area .
30 1026-4 WATER 31 All water used for curing concrete shall meet Article 1024-4 and Table 1024-2 .
Water from 32 wells , streams , ponds or public water systems may be used .

7 1050-2 TIMBER POSTS AND BRACES 8 ( A ) General 9 Use treated southern pine meeting Articles 1082-2 and 1082-3 for all timber posts and 10 braces , except as otherwise specified herein .
Posts and braces may be either round or 11 square provided that the same shape is used throughout the project for both the posts and 12 the braces .

16 Cut round wood posts and braces from sound solid trees , free from short or reverse bends 17 in more than one plane .
Do not use log veneer cores for posts and braces unless they 18 contain at least 1 inch of sapwood for their entire circumference on both ends .
The post 19 or brace shall not deviate more than 1 inch at any point from a straightedge held 20 longitudinally against the piece .
21 All posts shall be free from ring shake , season cracks more than 1/4 inch wide , splits in 22 the ends and contain no unsound knots .
Sound knots will be permitted provided the 23 width of the knot does not exceed 1/3 the diameter of the post where it occurs .
Groups of 24 knots or any combination of defects that will impair the strength of the piece will not be 25 permitted .
The pieces shall show not less than 3 annual rings per inch and not less than 26 30 % of summer wood .

The 48 Section 1050 10-73 anchor plate shall be sufficiently sturdy to withstand the strain of driving with no loss of 1 effectiveness , and have a minimum area of 14.0 square inches .
2 Steel posts used instead of 5 inch timber posts may be either tubular posts or angle posts .
3 They shall be 8 feet long and be embedded in a concrete anchor at least 3.3 feet deep and 4 10 inches in diameter .
Fit tubular posts with ornamental tops that fit over the top of the 5 post to cap against moisture .
Fabricate the tubular posts from 2 inch diameter pipe 6 meeting AASHTO M 181 for Grades 1 or 2 metallic coated posts and rails .
Fabricate 7 angle posts from angle sections measuring 2 1/2 inches x 2 1/2 inches x 1/4 inch , 8 ± 1/16 inch on the 2 1/2 inch dimensions and ± 0.015 inch on the 1/4 inch dimension and 9 weighing 4.10 lbs/ft .
10 Use steel braces with steel posts and either tubular braces or angle braces to match the 11 posts .
Furnish the braces with suitable metal connections to fasten them securely to the 12 posts .
Fabricate tubular braces from 1 1/4 inch diameter pipe meeting AASHTO M 181 13 for Grades 1 or 2 metallic coated posts and rails .
Fabricate angle braces from angle 14 sections measuring 2 inches x 2 inches x 1/4 inch ± 3/64 inch on the 2 inch dimensions 15 and ± 0.010 inch on the 1/4 inch dimension and weighing 3.19 lbs/ft .
16 A 10 % minimum weight tolerance will be allowed for all steel posts and braces .
17 For pipe 1.90 inches O.D .
and under , the outside diameter at any point shall not vary 18 more than 1/64 inch over nor more than 1/32 inch under the standard specified .

and over , the outside diameter shall not vary more than ± 1 % from the 20 standard specified nor shall the minimum wall thickness at any point be more than 12.5 % 21 under the nominal wall thickness specified .

24 1050-4 BARBED WIRE 25 Barbed wire shall meet ASTM A121 except as otherwise provided in this subarticle .
26 The barbed wire may be either galvanized steel or aluminum coated steel except that where 27 aluminum chain-link fabric is used , galvanized steel barbed wire shall not be used .
Use the 28 same type of material throughout the project .
All barbed wire shall have 4 point barbs spaced 29 not more than 5 inches apart .
Single strand barbed wire will not be acceptable .
30 Two strand galvanized steel barbed wire shall be fabricated from either 12 1/2 gauge or 31 15 1/2 gauge strand wire with 4 point galvanized steel 14 gauge barbs .
The 12 1/2 gauge shall 32 be Standard Grade with a Class 3 coating on the wire and a Class 1 coating on the barbs .
33 The 15 1/2 gauge shall be Chain Link Fence Grade with a Class 3 coating on both the wire 34 and barbs .
35 Two strand aluminum coated steel barbed wire shall be fabricated from two strands of 36 12 1/2 gauge aluminum coated steel wire with the 4-point barbs being either 14 gauge 37 aluminum coated steel or aluminum alloy wire .

Space vertical strands 42 at 6 inch intervals .

with a Class 3 coating .

38 Section 1056 10-77 SECTION 1056 1 GEOSYNTHETICS 2 1056-1 DESCRIPTION 3 Provide geosynthetics for subsurface drainage , separation , stabilization , reinforcement , 4 erosion control , filtration and other applications in accordance with the contract .
Use 5 geotextiles , geocomposite drains and geocells that are on the NCDOT APL .
Prefabricated 6 geocomposite drains include sheet , strip and vertical drains ( PVDs ) , i.e. , “ wick drains ” 7 consisting of a geotextile attached to and/or encapsulating a plastic drainage core .
Geocells 8 are comprised of ultrasonically welded polymer strips that when expanded form a 3D 9 honeycomb grid that is typically filled with material to support vegetation .
Define 10 geotextiles , geogrids , geocomposite drains and geocells as geosynthetics .
11 If necessary or required , hold geotextiles , geogrids and sheet drains in place with new wire 12 staples , i.e. , “ sod staples ” that meet Subarticle 1060-8 ( D ) or new anchor pins .
Use steel 13 anchor pins with a diameter of at least 3/16 inch and a length of at least 18 inches and with a 14 point at one end and a head at the other end that will retain a steel washer with an outside 15 diameter of at least 1.5 inches .
16 1056-2 HANDLING AND STORING 17 Load , transport , unload and store geosynthetics so geosynthetics are kept clean and free of 18 damage .
Label , ship and store geosynthetics in accordance with Section 7 of 19 AASHTO M 288 .
Geosynthetics with defects , flaws , deterioration or damage will be 20 rejected .
Do not unwrap geosynthetics until just before installation .
Do not leave 21 geosynthetics exposed for more than 7 days before covering except for geotextiles for 22 temporary wall faces and erosion control .
23 1056-3 CERTIFICATIONS AND IDENTIFICATION 24 Provide Type 1 , Type 2 or Type 4 material certifications in accordance with Article 106-3 for 25 geosynthetics except certifications are not required for Type 1 through Type 4 geotextiles 26 marked with the product name .
Define “ machine direction ” ( MD ) , “ cross-machine direction ” 27 ( CD ) and “ minimum average roll value ” ( MARV ) in accordance with ASTM D4439 .
Provide 28 certifications with MARV for geosynthetic properties as required .
Test geosynthetics using 29 laboratories accredited by the Geosynthetic Accreditation Institute ( GAI ) to perform the 30 required test methods .
Sample geosynthetics in accordance with ASTM D4354 .
31 Geotextiles will be identified by the product name printed directly on the geotextile by the 32 Manufacturer .
For all other geosynthetics and when geotextiles are not marked with a product 33 name , geosynthetics will be identified by the product label attached to the original packaging 34 or the geosynthetic itself by the Manufacturer .
35 Allow the Engineer to visually verify geosynthetic products before installation .
Open 36 packaged geosynthetics just before use in the presence of the Engineer to confirm the correct 37 product .
Geotextile rolls without the product name printed on the geotextile or the product 38 label affixed to the geotextile or roll core by the Manufacturer will be rejected .
Any other 39 geosynthetics that are unwrapped , missing original packaging or previously opened may not 40 be used unless approved by the Engineer .

15 1060-2 FERTILIZER 16 The quality of all fertilizer and all operations in connection with the furnishing of this material 17 shall comply with the North Carolina Fertilizer Law and with the rules and regulations , 18 adopted by the North Carolina Board of Agriculture in accordance with said law , in effect at 19 the time of sampling .
All fertilizer will be subject to sampling and testing by the Engineer , or 20 by an authorized representative of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture and 21 Consumer Services , or both .
22 Dry fertilizer shall be manufactured from cured stock .
Care for the fertilizer during handling 23 and storing in such a manner that it will be protected against hardening , caking or loss of plant 24 food values .
Pulverize any hardened or caked fertilizer to its original condition before using .
25 1060-3 LIMESTONE 26 The quality of all limestone and all operations in connection with the furnishing of this 27 material shall comply with the North Carolina Agricultural Liming Materials and Landplaster 28 Act , and with the rules and regulations , adopted by the North Carolina Board of Agriculture 29 and Consumer Services in accordance with said law , in effect at the time of sampling .
All 30 Section 1060 10-81 limestone will be subject to sampling and testing by the Engineer , or by an authorized 1 representative of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture , or both .
2 Limestone shall be agricultural grade ground limestone .
Either dolomitic or calcitic limestone 3 may be used .
4 All limestone shall contain not less than 90 % calcium carbonate equivalents .
Dolomitic 5 limestone shall contain not less than 10 % of magnesium .
Grade dolomitic limestone so at 6 least 90 % will pass through a U.S. Standard 20 mesh screen and at least 35 % will pass 7 through a U.S. Standard 100 mesh screen .
Grade calcitic limestone so at least 90 % will pass 8 through a U.S. Standard 20 mesh screen and at least 25 % will pass through a U.S. Standard 9 100 mesh screen .
Where the current grading requirements of the North Carolina Board of 10 Agriculture are different from the above , the requirements of the Board of Agriculture will 11 apply .
12 During handling and storing , care for the limestone in such manner that it will be protected 13 against hardening or caking .
Pulverize any hardened or caked limestone to its original 14 condition before using .
15 1060-4 SEED 16 The quality of all seed and all operations in connection with the furnishing of this material 17 shall comply with the North Carolina Seed Law and with the rules and regulations , adopted 18 by the North Carolina Board of Agriculture and Consumer Services in accordance with said 19 law , in effect at the time of sampling , and with the quality requirements of the Standard 20 Specifications .
All seed will be subject to sampling by the Engineer , or by an authorized 21 representative of the North Carolina Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services , or 22 both ; and will be tested by the North Carolina Department of Agriculture .
Supplementary 23 testing for seed germination may be performed by the Engineer .
24 The quality of all seed will be based on the percentage of pure live seed , which will be 25 computed by multiplying the percentage of purity by the percentage of germination and 26 dividing the result by 100 .
27 Seed shall have been approved by the North Carolina Department of Agriculture and 28 Consumer Services before being sown .
No seed will be accepted with a date of test more than 29 eight months before the date of sowing , excluding the month in which the test was completed .
30 Such testing , however , will not relieve the Contractor from responsibility for furnishing and 31 sowing seed that meets these Standard Specifications at the time of sowing .
The Engineer 32 may retest seed for germination after 5 months of storage ; at the beginning of each normal 33 seeding season for the particular kind of seed involved or at any time that the condition of the 34 seed appears to have deteriorated .
35 When a low percentage of germination causes the quality of the seed to fall below the 36 minimum pure live seed specified , the Contractor may elect , subject to the approval of the 37 Engineer , to increase the rate of application sufficiently to obtain the minimum pure live seed 38 content specified , provided that such an increase in the rate of application does not cause the 39 quantity of noxious weed seed per acre or square yard , as the case may be , to exceed the 40 quantity that would be allowable at the regular rate of application .
41 Furnish and deliver each of the species or varieties of seed in separate bags .
If seed is to be 42 mixed before sowing , perform such mixing in a commercial seed mixing machine , or by 43 an equally thorough means , after sampling and testing have been completed .
44 During handling and storing , care for the seed in such a manner that it will be protected from 45 damage by heat , moisture , rodents or other causes .
46 1060-5 MULCH FOR EROSION CONTROL 47 Mulch for erosion control shall consist of grain straw , or other acceptable material , and be 48 approved by the Engineer before being used .
All mulch shall be reasonably free from mature 49 Section 1060 10-82 seedbearing stalks , roots or bulblets of Johnson Grass , Nutgrass , Sandbur , Wild Garlic , Wild 1 Onion , Crotalaria , Witchweed and an excessive amount of restricted noxious weeds as 2 defined by the North Carolina Board of Agriculture at the time of use of the mulch .
Loose 3 and separate straw mulch that is matted or lumpy before being used .
4 Material for holding mulch in place shall be asphalt or other approved binding material .
5 1060-6 SPRIGS 6 Sprigs shall consist of freshly dug live stolons or rhizomes of perennial grasses , at least 2 7 inches in length , and be first class representatives of the required species or varieties specified 8 in the specifications .
The areas from which sprigs are to be obtained shall be free from 9 Johnson Grass , Nutgrass , Sandbur , Wild Garlic , Wild Onion , Crotalaria , Witchweed and an 10 excessive amount of restricted noxious weeds as defined by the North Carolina Board of 11 Agriculture at the time of digging the sprigs .
The areas shall have been mowed and raked , 12 burned off , or otherwise prepared in a manner acceptable to the engineer before digging of 13 sprigs begins .
14 1060-7 SOD 15 Sod shall consist of a live , dense , well-rooted growth of permanent grasses , free from Johnson 16 Grass , Nutgrass , Sandbur , Wild Garlic , Wild Onion , Crotalaria , Witchweed and an excessive 17 amount of restricted noxious weeds as defined by the North Carolina Board of Agriculture 18 and Consumer Services at the time of cutting the sod .
Mow the area from which sod is to be 19 obtained to a height of not more than 2 inches .
Rake free of grass clippings and debris and 20 otherwise prepared in a manner satisfactory to the Engineer before cutting of sod begins .
21 Cut the sod into rectangular sections of sizes convenient for handling without breaking or loss 22 of soil .
Cut it with a sod cutter or other acceptable means to a depth that will retain in the sod 23 practically all of the dense root system of the grass .
24 During wet weather , allow the sod to dry sufficiently before lifting to prevent tearing during 25 handling and placing .
During extremely dry weather , water it before lifting if such watering 26 is necessary to insure its vitality and to prevent loss of soil during handling .
27 1060-8 MATTING FOR EROSION CONTROL 28 ( A ) General 29 Matting for erosion control shall be excelsior matting or straw matting .
Furnish 30 a Type 3 material certification in accordance with Article 106-3 certifying that the 31 matting meets this article .
Other acceptable material manufactured especially for erosion 32 control may be used when approved by the Engineer in writing before being used .
33 Matting for erosion control shall not be dyed , bleached or otherwise treated in a manner 34 that will result in toxicity to vegetation .
35 ( B ) Excelsior Matting 36 Excelsior matting shall consist of a machine produced mat of curled wood excelsior at 37 least 47 inches in width and weigh 0.975 lb/sy with a tolerance of ± 10 % .
At least 80 % 38 of the individual excelsior fibers shall be 6 inches or more in length .
Evenly distribute 39 the excelsior fibers over the entire area of the blanket .
Cover one side of the excelsior 40 matting with an extruded plastic mesh .
The mesh size for the plastic mesh shall be no 41 more than 1 inch x 1 inch .
42 ( C ) Straw Matting 43 Straw matting shall consist of a machine produced mat of 100 % grain straw .
The straw 44 matting shall have a width of at least 48 inches and no more than 90 inches and weighing 45 at least 0.50 lb/sy and no more than 0.75 lb/sy .
Evenly distribute the straw over the entire 46 area of the blanket .
Cover one side of the blanket with photodegradable netting with 47 Section 1060 10-83 a maximum mesh ( netting ) size of 0.75 inch x 0.75 inch sewn together with a degradable 1 thread .
The grain straw shall contain no weed seeds .
Package each roll separately .
2 ( D ) Wire Staples 3 Staples shall be machine made of No .
11 gauge new steel wire formed into a U-shape .
4 The size when formed shall be not less than 6 inches in length with a throat of not less 5 than 1 inch in width .
6 1060-9 WATER 7 Water used in the planting or care of vegetation shall meet Class C fresh waters as defined 8 in 15 NCAC 2B.0200 .
9 1060-10 NURSERY GROWN PLANT MATERIALS 10 ( A ) General 11 Use all plants as called for by the contract .
12 Container grown plants may be used instead of balled and burlapped plants or bare rooted 13 plants provided written approval for such use has been obtained from Engineer .
14 Grading of plants , size of root balls and type and minimum dimensions of containers 15 shall conform to the American Standard for Nursery Stock .
Do not cut back plants from 16 larger sizes to meet the sizes called for in the contract .
17 Botanical names referred to in the contract are taken from Hortus Third , the Bailey 18 Hortorium ( MacMillan Publishing Co. , Inc. ) .
All plants delivered shall be true to name .
19 Each plant , or group of the same species , variety and size of plant , shall be legibly tagged 20 with the name and size of the plant .
21 All plants shall be first-class representatives of their species or varieties .
The root system 22 shall be vigorous and well developed .
The branch systems shall be of normal 23 development and free from disfiguring knots , sun scald injuries , abrasions of the bark , 24 dead or dry wood , broken terminal growth or other objectionable disfigurements .
Trees 25 shall have reasonably straight stems and be well branched and symmetrical in accordance 26 with their natural habits of growth .
27 All plants shall be free from plant diseases and insect pests .
All shipments of plants shall 28 comply with all nursery inspection and plant quarantine regulations of the states of origin 29 and destination , as well as with Federal regulations governing interstate movement of 30 nursery stock .
Any nursery stock used on highway landscape projects shall be 31 accompanied by a valid copy of a certificate of inspection , which has been granted by the 32 North Carolina Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services , Entomology 33 Division .
Fire ant treatment certification , where applicable , is required .
34 When nursery stock from other states is used on projects in North Carolina , this stock 35 shall be accompanied by a tag or certificate stating that the nursery stock has been 36 inspected and certified by an authorized official of the state of origin as apparently free 37 from injurious plant pests .
38 All plant materials are subject to inspection at any time by the Engineer .
Any such 39 inspection before or during planting operations , however , will not be construed as final 40 acceptance of the plants involved .
41 All geophytes ; bulbs , corms and tuberous plants ; shall be synonymous to the term “ plant ” 42 within the contract .
Examples include , but are not limited to , Narcissi ( Daffodil ) , Tulipa 43 ( Tulip ) , Iris and Canna ; the terms “ bulb ” , “ corm ” , “ tuber ” ; and specific plant names such 44 as “ Daffodil ” , “ Tulip ” , “ Canna lily ” , etc .
45 Section 1060 10-84 ( B ) Balled and Burlapped Plants 1 Dig plants to be balled and burlapped so as to retain a firm ball of soil and the plant ’ s 2 fibrous root system .
The soil in the ball shall be the original and undisturbed soil in 3 which the plant has been grown .
Dig , wrap , transport and handle the plant so the soil in 4 the ball shall not become frozen , loosened , cause stripping of the small feeding roots nor 5 movements of the soil away from contact with such roots .
6 ( C ) Container Grown Plants 7 Container grown plants shall be healthy , vigorous , well-rooted and established in the 8 container in which they are delivered .
These plants shall be in the container long enough 9 for the fibrous roots to have developed so the root mass will retain its shape and hold 10 together when removed from the container .
The container shall be sufficiently rigid to 11 firmly hold the soil protecting the root mass during transporting , handling and planting .
12 The soil shall not be allowed to become frozen .
13 ( D ) Bare Root Plants 14 Bare root plants shall have a heavy fibrous root system that has been developed by proper 15 cultural treatment .
Dig , package , transport and handle bare root plants in a manner that 16 will prevent injury to or drying out of the trunks , branches or roots , or freezing of the 17 roots .
Bare root plants damaged through improper handling , freezing , drying out , etc .
18 will result in rejection of material .
19 ( E ) Plant Substitution 20 No change in the Standard Specifications ( species , variety , size , caliper , furnish ) will be 21 made without written approval of the Engineer .
Present all requests for substitutions in 22 writing and include a listing of the sources contacted in an attempt to secure specified 23 plant material .
Requests for substitutions shall include the botanical name , common 24 name , cultivar , where applicable , size , caliper and furnish description of the proposed 25 substitute .
No increase in compensation will be made to the Contractor as a result of the 26 use of approved substitute plants .
The Department reserves the right to locate specified 27 plant material for the project when it has knowledge that specified material is available .
28 ( F ) Geophytes 29 Geophytes ; bulbs , corms and tuberous plants ; shall be healthy and free of disease caused 30 by fungi , nematodes , bacteria and wilt .
Plants that are lightweight and lacking adequate 31 mass will result in rejection .
Plants shall be firm and absent of discolored patches with 32 soft or spongy areas or signs of rot , slime or mold .
Plants with new root growth will 33 result in rejection .
34 Dig , package , transport and handle these plants as to prevent injury , drying out , excessive 35 wetness or freezing .
Damaged plants through improper handling , freezing , drying out or 36 excessive moisture will result in rejection .
37 All geophytes , bulbs , corms and tuberous plants shall be inspected for size and condition 38 and rejected plants shall be removed from the supply before planting .

24 1060-14 COIR FIBER MAT 25 Coir fiber mat shall consist of 100 % coconut fiber ( coir ) twine woven into high strength 26 matrix .
The coir fiber mat shall have a thickness of at least 0.30 inch and weigh at least 20 27 ounces per square yard .
The coir fiber mat shall have a tensile strength of at least 1,348 x 626 28 lbs/ft and elongation of no more than 34 % x 38 % .
The coir fiber mat shall have a flexibility 29 of 65,030 x 29,590 mg-cm .
The coir fiber mat shall have an observed flow velocity of 11 feet 30 per second .
The coir fiber mat shall have a C-Factor of 0.002 .
The size of the coir fiber mat 31 shall be 6.6 feet x 164 feet and the measured open area shall be 50 % .
32 1060-15 SPECIAL STILLING BASIN 33 The special stilling basin shall be a bag constructed to a minimum size of 10 feet x 15 feet 34 made from a nonwoven fabric .
It shall have a sewn-in 8 inches ( maximum ) spout for 35 receiving pump discharge .
The bag seams shall be sewn with a double needle machine using 36 a high strength thread .
The seams shall have a minimum wide width strength of 60 lbs .
per 37 inch tested in accordance with ASTM D4884 .

7 ( C ) Coated Reinforcing Steel 8 Use coated steel reinforcing bars meeting AASHTO M 31 , Grade 60 and free of 9 contaminants such as oil , grease and paint .

11 ( D ) Handling , Storage and Transportation 12 When handling , storing and transporting coated steel reinforcing bars , all contact areas 13 shall be padded .
14 All bundling bands shall be padded or suitable banding shall be used to prevent damage 15 to the coating .
All bundles of coated steel reinforcing bars shall be lifted with a strong 16 back , spreader bar , multiple supports , or a platform bridge to prevent bar-to-bar abrasion 17 from sags in the bundles of coated steel reinforcing bars .
Packaging of uncoated and 18 coated bars is strictly prohibited .
When loading/unloading coated bars ; pallets , bags or 19 bundles shall not be dropped or dragged .
20 During storage , protect steel reinforcement at all times from damage and make sure it is 21 free from dirt , dust , loose mill scale , loose rust , paint , oil or other foreign materials until 22 the time of placement .
For storage outside at the fabrication shop and project site , store 23 epoxy coated reinforcing steel bars at least 1 foot above the ground on wooden or padded 24 supports placed 10 feet apart , and completely cover with an opaque cloth , canvas or 25 woven fiber reinforced polyethylene white tarp .
Storage of uncoated and coated material 26 shall not be mixed or in direct contact .
Do not use solid plastic sheeting .
Cover the bars 27 such that adequate ventilation is provided to prevent condensation from forming on the 28 material during storage , and completely protect the bars from direct sunlight .
Do not 29 allow water to pond under the epoxy coated reinforcing steel .
Do not expose epoxy 30 coated reinforcing steel to outdoor weather for more than 30 days .
If the coated steel 31 reinforcing bars are stored outdoors without cover , the date on which the coated bars are 32 placed outdoors shall be recorded on the identification tag for the bundled steel .
33 Transport the bundled bars from the producer/supplier to the project site with padding , 34 such as carpet padding , placed over each bundle of steel upon which another bundle of 35 steel is placed unless wooden spacers are placed between each bundle to prevent contact .
36 Load all bundles of bars horizontally for transporting .
Transport the bars on a flatbed 37 trailer .
Do not allow the length of bars to exceed 8 feet beyond the trailer bed .
Repair 38 coating damage associated with handling and transporting or other causes in accordance 39 to Section 1070-7 ( E ) .
Coated steel reinforcing bars should be off-loaded as close as 40 possible to their points of placement or under the crane so that the bars can be hoisted to 41 the area of placement to minimize re-handling .
If the material is being transported in 42 adverse weather conditions the producer/supplier , coater , fabricator and/or Contractor 43 shall co-coordinate a material protection plan , test for the presence of chlorides , and , if 44 necessary , clean the material as directed by the Engineer .
45 Section 1070 10-89 ( E ) Field Coating Repair 1 The maximum amount of repaired damaged coating shall not exceed 1 % of the total 2 surface area in each 0.3 m [ 1 foot ] of the bar .
This limit on repaired damaged coating 3 shall not include sheared or cut ends that are coated with patching material .
When 4 degraded coating is observed additional inspection or non-destructive testing may be 5 required by the Engineer at no additional cost to the Department .
6 Ensure the Contractor uses a Department approved patching or repair material that is 7 compatible with the coating and inert in concrete .
When repair is required , clean the 8 areas in accordance to SSPC SP-1 prior to performing additional surface preparation .
9 Surface preparation shall be in accordance with SSPC SP-11 ( Power Tool Cleaning to 10 Bare Metal ) and/or in accordance with the manufacturers recommendations .
The more 11 stringent of the two shall apply .
Ensure that the material is suitable for making repairs 12 with a minimum dry film thickness of 7 mils .
Ensure that the Contractor has a copy of 13 the manufacturer ’ s written instructions for application of the patching material and the 14 instructions are closely followed during any coating damage repair .
Do not apply any 15 patch material when the surface temperature of the steel or the air temperature is below 16 40°F .
Do not ship or place steel until the patch material is dry to the touch .

Take 1 measurements on the wrench flats .
