7 ( 4 ) Assemblies 8 Rotational-capacity tests are required to be performed by an AASHTO accredited 9 laboratory .
Ensure the manufacturer or distributor perform such tests on all black or 10 galvanized ( after galvanizing ) bolt , nut and washer assemblies before shipping .
11 Washers are required as part of the test .
12 The following applies : 13 ( a ) Except as modified herein , perform the rotational-capacity test in accordance 14 with ASTM F3125 .
15 ( b ) Test each combination of bolt production lot , nut lot and washer lot as 16 an assembly .
Where washers are not required by the installation procedures , 17 do not include in the lot identification .
18 ( c ) Assign a rotational-capacity lot number to each combination of lots tested .
19 ( d ) The minimum frequency of testing is two assemblies per rotational-capacity lot .
20 ( e ) Assemble the bolt , nut and washer assembly in a Skidmore-Wilhelm Tension 21 Indicating Device ( Calibrator ) or an acceptable equivalent device ( This 22 requirement supersedes the current ASTM F3125 requirement to perform the 23 test in a steel joint ) .
For short bolts that are too short for assembly in the 24 Skidmore-Wilhelm , see Subarticle 1072-5 ( D ) ( 4 ) ( i ) .
25 ( f ) The minimum rotation , from a snug tight condition ( 10 % of the specified proof 26 load ) , is : 240° ( 2/3 turn ) for bolt lengths less than 4 diameters ; 360° ( 1 turn ) for 27 bolt lengths greater than 4 diameters and less than 8 diameters ; 480° ( 1 1/3 turn ) 28 for bolt lengths greater than 8 diameters .
29 ( g ) These values differ from ASTM F3125 .
30 ( h ) Achieve tension at the above rotation equal to or greater than 1.15 times the 31 required installation tension .
The installation tension and the tension for the turn 32 test are shown in Table 1072-2 .

15 1072-6 WELDED STUD SHEAR CONNECTORS 16 Use Type B shear studs in accordance with the Bridge Welding Code as defined in 17 Article 1072-18 .
18 Use and install welded stud shear connectors meeting Article 1072-18 .
Ensure that shear 19 studs and the areas of beams , girders or other structural steel to which the studs are welded are 20 free of rust , rust pits , oil , grease , moisture , paint , galvanizing , loose mill scale or other 21 deleterious matter which adversely affects the welding operation .
Apply shear studs on steel 22 with tightly adhering mill scale as determined by the Engineer provided acceptable results are 23 achieved and the installed studs meet the Bridge Welding Code .
Unless otherwise directed by 24 the Contract plans , studs shall be welded with automatically timed stud welding equipment 25 connected to a suitable source connected to an electrode negative ( DCEN ) power .
Welding 26 Section 1072 10-99 voltage , current , time , and gun settings for lift and plunge should be set at optimum settings 1 based on past practice , recommendations of stud and equipment manufacturer , or both .
2 1072-7 INSPECTION 3 ( A ) General 4 Give the Materials and Tests Unit 72 hours ’ notice for in-state producers and 192 hours ’ 5 notice for producers out-of-state before beginning work in the shop .
The “ hours ’ notice ” 6 is defined as working hours ’ Monday thru Friday , 8 AM to 5 PM .
Do not manufacture or 7 fabricate any material , other than stock items , before the Materials and Tests Unit is 8 notified and the final shop drawings are reviewed , accepted and returned to the fabricator .
9 The fabricator shall have a stamped approved set of drawings assigned to the NCDOT 10 assigned inspection staff and delivered to him upon his/her arrival on site .
Shop drawings 11 shall include all current revisions .
12 The shop inspection performed by the Department or inspection agency hired by the 13 Department is intended as QA to assure to the Department that the fabricator is following 14 all quality control requirements and is providing a product conforming to the Contract 15 requirements .
The inspection is not expected to replace the fabricator ’ s quality control .
16 The inspection and acceptance of the work performed by the Department or its 17 representative does not relieve the fabricator of providing materials and finished products 18 as specified .
19 20 The Department may reject defective or non-conforming materials at any time .
Replace 21 rejected materials promptly at no additional cost to the Department .
22 The contractor/fabricator shall be responsible for and shall be required to perform all 23 quality control inspections and nondestructive testing in accordance with the Bridge 24 Welding Code as defined in Article 1072-18 and as required by the contract .
Perform all 25 quality control inspection and nondestructive testing in the presence of the Department ’ s 26 inspector unless otherwise approved by the Department ’ s inspector .
Obtain approval for 27 all quality control inspectors from the Department ’ s inspector and ensure their 28 qualification in accordance with the Bridge Welding Code and these specifications .
29 Maintain all QC reports as required by the Bridge Welding Code , including , but not 30 limited to , visual and nondestructive testing reports and all phases of coating application 31 inspection .
Provide copies of all QC reports , including all radiographic films , to the 32 Department inspector upon request .
These copies become the property of the Department 33 and shall bear certification ( written testimony ) signature of the quality control inspector .
34 No separate payment is made for this inspection and testing .

21 1072-9 HANDLING AND STORING MATERIALS 22 Load , transport , unload and store structural material so the metal is kept clean and free from 23 damage .
Repair any coating damage per Section 442 .
Do not use chains , cables or hooks 24 without softeners that could result in damage or scarring of the material .
Repair all materials 25 which are scarred or damaged and inspect at the fabricators expense as deemed necessary by 26 the Engineer .
27 Use lifting equipment and rigging equipment with adequate capacity to handle the material at 28 all times .
Do not bend , twist , damage or excessively stress any materials .
Do not perform 29 hammering which injures or distorts the members .
In the event that damage or overstressing 30 does occur , prepare and submit an inspection and testing verification plan to the Engineer for 31 approval .
Operate and maintain all lifting equipment in a safe manner and in accordance with 32 the manufacturer ’ s directions .
33 When lifting main structural steel members , use spreader bars .
Do not use one point pick-ups 34 on members over 50 feet in length .
Use two point pick-ups so the amount of overhang and 35 the distance between hooks does not exceed the distances as noted in Table 1072-5 .

Keep free from blast media , dirt , grease , vegetation and other foreign matter , 38 and protect from corrosion .
39 Keep material clean and properly drained .
Transport and store girders and beams with the 40 web in the vertical plane and the top flange up .

1 Support long members on blocking placed near enough together to prevent damage from 2 deflection .

6 1072-10 STRAIGHTNESS , CAMBER AND DIMENSIONAL TOLERANCES 7 ( A ) General 8 Ensure that rolled material , before being laid out or fabricated , is straight .
9 If straightening is necessary , use methods that do not damage the metal .
Kinks or sharp 10 bends are cause for rejection of the material .
11 Ensure that heat straightened parts are substantially free from external forces , except 12 those resulting from mechanical means used in conjunction with the application of heat .
13 Heat curving and heat cambering shall be completely free from any external forces .
Any 14 heating operation to address straightening , cambering , or curving shall be monitored by 15 the Fabricator ’ s QC department .
Personnel performing heating operations shall have 16 adequate training ( documented ) , shall possess proper temperature indicating devices and 17 shall have received instructions for appropriate use .
18 After heating , allow the metal to cool , without artificial cooling , down to 600°F .
Below 19 600°F , only dry compressed air is permitted to artificially cool steels having minimum 20 yield strength greater than 36,000 psi as indicated by a Type 1 ( Certified Mill Test 21 Report ) material certification in accordance with Article 106-3 .
22 ( B ) Straightening 23 Straighten distorted members and bent material by mechanical means or , if approved , by 24 the carefully planned and supervised application of a limited amount of localized heat .
25 Do not allow the temperature of the heated area to exceed 1,150°F as controlled by 26 temperature indicating crayons or other approved methods .
27 Following the straightening of a bend or buckle , verify the surface is free of evidence of 28 fracture as indicated by visual inspection or , if directed , by appropriate nondestructive 29 testing .
30 Shop straighten the bottom flanges of steel beams or girders at bearings as necessary to 31 provide uniform contact between the flanges and the bearings .
If bearings are to be field 32 installed , the Fabricator shall demonstrate appropriate bearing contact surfaces as defined 33 by the AWS Bridge Welding Code prior to shipping .
34 ( C ) Camber 35 Show the required camber on the drawings .
36 Make adequate provision in the fabrication of structural members to compensate for 37 change of camber due to welding of the shear connectors and other fabrication work .
38 Fabricate camber into the members on built-up plate girders and trusses .
Where camber 39 is required on rolled sections , induce it by heat cambering , except that for rolled sections 40 within the depth , length and camber ordinate range shown in Table 1072-6 , induce 41 camber by cold cambering or `` gagging '' at the mill or in the shop provided approval 42 procedures for cold cambering are employed .
43 Where reverse curvature is required in a single rolled shape , induce it by heat cambering .
44 Show camber diagrams showing the required offset at each tenth point of the span and at 45 any web splice or field splice location and blocking diagrams on the shop drawings .
46 Show additional points if desired by the fabricator .
Ensure that the beams , girders or 47 Section 1072 10-103 other members with field splices meet all of the blocking ordinates without inducing 1 stress into the members .
2 Following cambering or camber correction , correct evidence of fracture indicated by 3 visual inspection or , if directed , by appropriate nondestructive testing .
4 Show camber and blocking diagrams on the shop drawings .
Shop assemble continuous 5 beams meeting all the blocking ordinates without inducing stress into the members .
6 TABLE 1072-6 ACCEPTABLE COLD CAMBER FOR ROLLED SECTIONS Beam Length , feet Section Designation and Nominal Depth W-Shapes 14 '' to 21 '' Inclusive S-Shapes 12 '' and Over W-Shapes 24 '' and Over Over 30 through 42 3/4 '' to 2 1/2 '' inclusive 1 '' to 2 '' inclusive Over 42 through 52 1 '' to 3 '' inclusive 1 '' to 3 '' inclusive Over 52 through 65 2 '' to 4 '' inclusive 2 '' to 4 '' inclusive Over 65 through 85 2 1/2 '' to 5 '' inclusive 3 '' to 5 '' inclusive Over 85 through 100 As directed by the Engineer 3 '' to 6 '' inclusive ( D ) Heat Cambering of Rolled Beams and Welded Plate Girders 7 ( 1 ) General 8 Where heat cambering is used , only V-type heating is permitted .
Perform V-type 9 heating by the carefully planned and supervised application of a limited amount of 10 localized heat .
11 When minor corrections in camber are required , use small localized heats limited to 12 the flange material .
Perform major corrections in camber by V-type heating to 13 prevent web distortion .
14 Begin heating at the apex of the heating pattern and progress slowly towards the base 15 of the pattern as each area is brought up to temperature as stated in 16 Subarticle 1072-10 ( D ) ( 5 ) .
Do not progress the heating torches toward the base of 17 the heating pattern until the apex of the pattern is brought up to the specified 18 temperature .
Do not return the heating torch toward the apex of the heating triangle 19 after heating has progressed towards the base .
Continue heating to successive areas 20 until the base of the triangular heating pattern is brought up to the required 21 temperature across the full width of the flange .
22 ( 2 ) Heat Cambering of Rolled Beams 23 Heat cambering of rolled beams is allowed to provide the required vertical curvature .
24 Space triangular heating patterns throughout the length of the member to provide the 25 required curvature .
Locate the apex of the heating triangle at a point not less 26 than 75 % of the depth of the member measured from the flange that is concave after 27 cambering .
Limit the total included angle of the heating pattern to 20° .
28 Weld all detail material such as connection plates , bearing stiffeners and gusset 29 plates attached to the member to the rolled beam after the beam is cambered as 30 required .
31 ( 3 ) Heat Cambering of Welded Plate Girders 32 Heat cambering of welded plate girders is only permitted when approved in writing 33 as a necessary repair procedure for plate girders rejected for camber deviation .
34 When it is necessary to correct camber deviation in welded plate girders , heating is 35 permitted in V-type heating patterns centered on intermediate stiffeners and 36 connection plates .
Where necessary , add stiffeners for this purpose if approved .
37 Section 1072 10-104 Locate the apex of the heating pattern not less than 3/4 of the depth of the member 1 from the flange that is shortened after cooling .
The maximum included angle of the 2 heating pattern is 10° .
The maximum width of the base of the heating pattern is 10 3 inches .
Where shallow members or thin webs prescribe heating patterns with a 4 width substantially less than 10 inches at the junction of the web to flange , extend 5 the heating pattern in the flange at that location beyond the limits of the heating 6 pattern in the web by no more than 1 inch provided the total width of pattern in the 7 flange does not exceed the 10 inch limit stated above .
8 ( 4 ) Support of Members for Heat Cambering 9 Heat camber members with the web vertical and supports spaced to take the 10 maximum advantage of dead load in the member before applying heat .
Ensure all 11 supports are approved by the Department ’ s inspector before beginning work .
12 Do not place any combination of support system or external load on the member that 13 causes a compressive stress in the flange to exceed 20,000 psi before heating for 14 AASHTO M 270 Grades 36 , 50 and 50W steels .
15 ( 5 ) Heating Process and Equipment 16 Confine heating to the patterns described herein and conduct to bring the steel within 17 the planned pattern to a temperature between 1,100°F and 1,150°F as rapidly as 18 possible without overheating the steel .
19 Any heating procedure which causes a portion of the steel to exceed a temperature 20 greater than 1,150°F is destructive heating and is automatically cause for rejection of 21 the steel .
Steel rejected for destructive heating is investigated for re-acceptance , 22 repair or replacement if allowed by the Engineer .
Bear the cost of such tests and any 23 necessary repair or replacement .
24 ( 6 ) Heat Measurement 25 Specified temperatures are checked using portable digital pyrometers or temperature 26 indicating crayon .
When using a temperature indicating crayon , the following 27 procedure shall be employed ; mark on the surface of metal or sheet with the required 28 crayon .
Once the surface reaches the rated temperature of the crayon , the mark will 29 melt and show liquid smear appearance .
At this point , the heating operation shall 30 cease to prevent overheating .
Exceeding the specified temperature is strictly 31 prohibited .
32 ( E ) Heat Curving Girders 33 ( 1 ) Type of Heating 34 With approval , use continuous or V-type heating methods to curve girders .
For the 35 continuous method , simultaneously heat a strip along the edge of the top and bottom 36 flanges that is of sufficient width and temperature to obtain the required curvature .
37 For V-type heating , heat the top and bottom flanges simultaneously in truncated 38 triangular or wedge-shaped areas .
Position the areas with their base along the flange 39 edge and spaced at regular intervals along each flange .
Set the spacing and 40 temperatures to approximate the required curvature by a series of short chords .
Heat 41 along the top and bottom flanges at approximately the same rate .
42 For V-type heating , terminate the apex of the truncated triangular area applied to the 43 inside flange surface just before the juncture of the web and flange .
To avoid web 44 distortion , make certain that heat is not applied directly to the web when heating the 45 inside flange surfaces ( the surfaces that intersect the web ) .
Extend the apex of the 46 truncated triangular heating pattern applied to the outside flange surface to the 47 juncture of the flange and web .
Use an included angle of approximately 15° to 30° 48 in the truncated triangular pattern , but do not allow the base of the triangle to 49 Section 1072 10-105 exceed 10 inches .
Vary the patterns prescribed above only with the Engineer ’ s 1 approval .
2 For both types of heating , heat the flange edges that will be on the inside of the 3 horizontal curve after cooling .
Concurrently heat both inside and outside flange 4 surfaces for flange thicknesses of 1.25 inches and greater .
Adhere to the temperature 5 requirements presented below .
6 ( 2 ) Temperature 7 Conduct the heat curving operation so the temperature of the steel never exceeds 8 1,150°F as measured by temperature indicating crayons or other suitable means .
Do 9 not artificially cool the girder until it naturally cools to 600°F .
Below 600°F , use dry 10 compressed air to artificially cool the girder .
11 ( 3 ) Position for Heating 12 Heat-curving the girder with the web in either a vertical or horizontal position is 13 permitted .
When curved in the vertical position , brace or support the girder so the 14 tendency of the girder to deflect laterally during the heat-curving process does not 15 cause the girder to overturn .
16 When curved in the horizontal position , support the girder near its ends and at 17 intermediate points , if required , to obtain a uniform curvature .
Do not allow the 18 bending stress in the flanges to exceed 27,000 psi .
To prevent a sudden sag due to 19 plastic flange buckling when the girder is positioned horizontally for heating , place 20 intermediate safety catch blocks at the midlength of the girder within 2 inches of the 21 flanges at all times during the heating process .
22 ( 4 ) Sequence of Operations 23 Conduct the heat-curving operation either before or after completing all the required 24 welding of transverse intermediate stiffeners to the web .
However , unless provisions 25 are made for shrinkage , position and attach connection plates and bearing stiffeners 26 after heat-curving .
In any event , weld the stiffeners , connection plates , and bearing 27 stiffeners to the girder flanges after the member is curved .
If longitudinal stiffeners 28 are required , heat-curve or oxygen-cut these stiffeners separately before welding to 29 the curved girder .
30 ( 5 ) Camber and Curvature 31 Camber the girders before heat-curving .
Cut the web to the prescribed camber 32 allowing for shrinkage due to cutting welding and heat-curving .
If approved , 33 a carefully supervised application of heat is permitted to correct moderate deviations 34 from the specified camber .
35 Horizontal curvature and vertical camber is measured for final acceptance after all 36 welding and heating operations are complete and the flanges have cooled to 37 a uniform temperature .
Horizontal curvature is checked with the web in the vertical 38 position by measuring offsets from a string line or wire attached to both flanges or by 39 using other suitable means .
Camber is checked with the web in the horizontal 40 position .
Camber the girder so it meets the horizontal and vertical curvature 41 ordinates without inducing stress into the girders by mechanical force .
42 Compensate for loss of camber in the heat-curved girders as residual stresses 43 dissipate during service life of the structure .
Compute this anticipated loss of camber 44 in accordance with the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications .
45 Section 1072 10-106 ( 6 ) Procedure Specification and Shop Drawings 1 Submit structural steel shop drawings , including a detailed written procedure 2 specification for heat curving the girders , supplemented by calculations and sketches , 3 for review , comments and acceptance .
On the shop drawings , indicate the type , 4 location and spacing of heat sectors , if used , supports and catch blocking for each 5 field section of girders .
Include suitable blocking diagrams for measuring horizontal 6 curvature similar to those usually prepared for camber and vertical curvature .
7 ( F ) Camber Measurement 8 At the time of acceptance at the shop and after erection , ensure that all stringers and 9 girders for bridges meet the required camber values within the tolerances specified in 10 Subarticle 1072-10 ( G ) .
Follow the procedure for measuring camber as outlined below : 11 ( 1 ) Assemble the member at the shop as specified in Article 1072-19 and measure with 12 the member lying on its side .
13 ( 2 ) Camber repairs are only allowed when approved by the Engineer .
Camber deviation 14 is judged irreparable if corrective measures in the shop produce web buckling in 15 excess of the specified tolerance , in which case the member is rejected .
16 ( 3 ) The final camber measurement is made by the Engineer in the field after erection .
17 At the time of this measurement , ensure that the members have all of the specified 18 camber less the dead load deflection of the steel as specified in 19 Subarticle 1072-10 ( G ) .
20 ( G ) Dimensional Tolerances 21 Ensure that dimensions of all material covered by Section 1072 conform to ASTM A6 22 when received at the fabrication shop .

Dimensional tolerances not listed 25 in this subarticle shall be as specified by the Bridge Welding Code as defined in 26 Article 1072-18 and applied to rolled shapes where applicable as well as to welded 27 members .
28 Place welded butt joints no further than 1/2 inch from the point detailed .
Intermediate 29 stiffeners varying ± 1/2 inch from the point detailed are allowed .
Connector plates for 30 field connections varying ± 1/8 inch from the point detailed are allowed .
Ensure that the 31 actual centerline of bearing lies within the thickness of the bearing stiffener .
32 Members with end milled for bearing and members with faced end connection angles 33 deviating from the detailed length by -0 , +1/32 inch are acceptable .
All other members 34 varying from detailed length by ± 1/8 inch are acceptable .

16 1072-11 OXYGEN CUTTING 17 Oxygen cutting of structural steel is allowed , provided a smooth surface free from cracks and 18 notches is secured and an accurate profile is secured by the use of a mechanical guide .
Hand 19 cut only where approved and grind smooth leaving no burnt edges .
20 In all oxygen cutting , adjust and manipulate the cutting agent to avoid cutting beyond ( inside ) 21 the prescribed lines .
Provide oxygen cut surfaces meeting the ANSI surface roughness rating 22 value of 1,000 except ensure that oxygen cut surfaces of members not subject to calculated 23 stress meet the surface roughness value of 2,000 ( AWS C4.1-G Surface Roughness Gauge ) .
24 Round corners of oxygen cut surfaces of members carrying calculated stress to a 1/16 inch 25 radius , or an equivalent flat surface at a suitable angle , by grinding after oxygen cutting .
26 Fillet re-entrant cuts to a radius of not less than 1 inch .
27 Remove surface roughness exceeding the above values and occasional notches and gouges not 28 more than 3/16 inch deep on otherwise satisfactory oxygen cut surfaces by chipping or 29 grinding .
Such removal shall be faired to the material edge with a slope not steeper than one 30 in ten and with machine and grinding marks parallel to the surfaces .
31 Repair occasional gouges of oxygen cut edges more than 3/16 inch deep , but not more than 32 7/16 inch deep , by welding with low hydrogen electrodes not exceeding 5/32 inch in diameter 33 and with a minimum preheat of 250°F .
Grind the completed weld smooth and flush with the 34 adjacent surface .
Radiographically test any gouge repaired by welding .
35 1072-12 EDGE PLANING 36 Plane sheared edges of plates more than 5/8 inch in thickness that carry calculated stress to 37 a depth of 1/4 inch .
Pre-drill re-entrant cuts before cutting .
Round all edges of plates and 38 shapes parallel to calculated stress and all free edges of plates and shapes intended for coating 39 or galvanizing to 1/16 inch radius or provide an equivalent flat surface at a suitable angle .
40 Flame cut edges found to have a Rockwell Hardness Value of C 30 or greater will be 41 considered unacceptable .
A portable Rockwell Hardness Tester shall be employed by the 42 Quality Control Inspector to determine conformance with these requirements .
Unacceptably 43 hard surfaces shall be removed by grinding , machining , or approved heat treating procedures .
44 Grind edges of all other plates and shapes to remove burrs , slag or shear lip .
The ends of all 45 steel piles , intended for coating or galvanizing , are not required to be radiused , but remove all 46 burrs , slag and shear lip .

20 1072-16 HOLES FOR BOLTS AND OTHER FASTENERS 21 ( A ) General 22 Punch or drill all holes and remove any burrs .
Punching material forming parts of 23 a member composed of not more than 5 thickness of metal 1/16 inch larger than the 24 nominal diameter of the fastener is allowed whenever the thickness of the material is not 25 greater than 3/4 inch for structural steel , 5/8 inch for high-strength steel or 1/2 inch for 26 quenched and tempered alloy steel , unless subpunching and reaming is required by 27 Subarticle 1072-16 ( D ) .
28 Section 1072 10-109 When there are more than five thicknesses or when any of the main material is thicker 1 than 3/4 inch for structural steel , 5/8 inch for high-strength steel or 1/2 inch for quenched 2 and tempered alloy steel , either subdrill and ream or drill all holes full size .
3 When required by Subarticle 1072-16 ( D ) , subpunch or subdrill all holes ( subdrill if 4 thickness limitation governs ) 1/4 inch smaller and , after assembling , ream 1/16 inch 5 larger or drill full size to 1/16 inch larger than the nominal diameter of the fastener .
6 ( B ) Punched Holes 7 Do not use a diameter of the die exceeding the diameter of the punch by more than 8 1/16 inch .
If any holes require enlargement to admit the fasteners , ream such holes .
9 Clean cut holes without torn or ragged edges .
Poor matching of holes is cause for 10 rejection .
Grind all burrs smooth .
11 ( C ) Reamed or Drilled Holes 12 Make reamed or drilled holes cylindrical and perpendicular to the member complying 13 with the size requirements of Subarticle 1072-16 ( A ) .
Where practicable , direct reamers 14 by mechanical means .
Grind all burrs smooth .
Poor matching of holes is cause for 15 rejection .
Ream and drill with twist drills .
If required , take assembled parts apart for 16 removal of burrs caused by drilling .
Assemble connecting parts requiring reamed or 17 drilled holes , securely hold while reaming or drilling and match mark before 18 disassembling .
19 ( D ) Subpunching and Reaming of Field Connections 20 Subpunch or subdrill , if required according to Subarticle 1072-16 ( A ) , holes in all field 21 connections and field splices of main members of trusses , arches , continuous beam spans , 22 bents , towers ( each face ) , plate girders , and rigid frames .
Subsequently ream while 23 assembled as required by Article 1072-19 .
Subpunch and ream to a steel template or 24 ream while assembled all holes for floor beam and stringer field end connections .
Ream 25 or drill full size field connection holes through a steel template after the template is 26 located with utmost care as to position and angle and firmly bolted in place .
Use 27 templates for reaming matching members , or the opposite faces of a single member that 28 are exact duplicates .
Accurately locate templates used for connections on like parts of 29 members such that the parts or members are duplicates and require no match-marking .
30 ( E ) Accuracy of Punched and Subdrilled Holes 31 Accurately punch or subdrill all holes punched full size , subpunched or subdrilled such 32 that after assembling , and before any reaming is done , a cylindrical pin 1/8 inch smaller 33 in diameter than the nominal size of the hole enters perpendicular to the face of the 34 member , without drifting , in at least 75 % of the contiguous holes in the same plane .
If 35 the requirement is not fulfilled , the badly punched pieces are rejected .
If any hole does 36 not pass a pin 3/16 inch smaller in diameter than the nominal size of the hole , this is 37 cause for rejection .
38 ( F ) Accuracy of Reamed and Drilled Holes 39 When holes are reamed or drilled , ensure that 85 % of the holes in any contiguous group , 40 after reaming or drilling , show no offset greater than 1/32 inch between adjacent 41 thicknesses of metal .
42 Use all steel templates with hardened steel bushings in holes accurately dimensioned 43 from the centerlines of the connection as inscribed on the template .
Use the centerlines in 44 locating accurately by the template from the milled or scribed ends of the members .
45 ( G ) Alternate Methods 46 As an option , make the fastener holes by procedures other than those described in 47 Subarticles 1072-16 ( A ) through 1072-16 ( F ) provided that the requirements for quality 48 Section 1072 10-110 and for dimensional accuracy are met .
Plasma cutting of holes for high strength fasteners 1 is prohibited .
Wherever an alternate method is employed , demonstrate the ability of each 2 alternate method to produce holes and connections consistently meeting all requirements 3 for quality and dimensional accuracy for the type of joint fabricated .
When such ability 4 of an alternate method is previously demonstrated on similar work for the Department , 5 continue its use by certifying , on each subsequent project , that the procedure and 6 equipment are the same as the method previously qualified , and that the equipment 7 involved is in good repair and adjustment .
Failure of joints to meet the quality and 8 accuracy requirements is cause for rejection .
In the case of repeated failures revise 9 and/or requalify the method or discontinue its use .
10 At the time of qualification of an alternate method , submit for approval a written 11 procedure specification describing the procedures and equipment and giving upper and 12 lower value limits and tolerances for all pertinent variables .
Accurately reflect the actual 13 procedures , equipment and values used in the qualification tests .
In addition to the 14 certification on each subsequent project , the Engineer may request copies of the approved 15 procedure specification .
16 ( H ) Oversize , Short-Slotted , and Long-Slotted Holes 17 Where shown in the plans or permitted in writing , use oversize , short-slotted and long- 18 slotted holes with high strength bolts 5/8 inch and larger in diameter .
Do not allow the 19 distance between edges of adjacent holes or edges of holes and edges of members to be 20 less than permitted under the AASHTO specification .
Oversize , short-slotted and long- 21 slotted holes are defined as follows : 22 ( 1 ) Oversize holes are 3/16 inch larger than bolts 7/8 inch and less in diameter , 1/4 inch 23 larger than bolts 1 inch in diameter , and 5/16 inch larger than bolts 1 1/8 inches and 24 greater in diameter .
When oversized holes are permitted , they are allowed in any or 25 all plies of friction type connections .
Install hardened washers over exposed oversize 26 holes .
27 ( 2 ) Short-slotted holes are 1/16 inch wider than the bolt diameter and have a length that 28 does not exceed the oversize diameter requirements of Subarticle 1072-16 ( H ) ( 1 ) by 29 more than 1/16 inch .
When short-slotted holes are permitted , they are allowed in any 30 or all plies of friction-type or bearing-type connection .
Locate holes without regard 31 to direction of loading in friction-type connections , but orient normal to the direction 32 of the load in bearing-type connections .
Install hardened washers over exposed 33 short-slotted holes .
34 ( 3 ) Long-slotted holes are 1/16 inch wider than the bolt diameter and have a length more 35 than allowed in Sub-paragraph 2 but not more than 2 1/2 times the bolt diameter .
36 Structural plate washers or a continuous bar not less than 5/16 inch in thickness are 37 required to cover long slots that are the outer plies of joints .
Ensure that these 38 washers have a size sufficient to completely cover the slot after installation .
When 39 long-slotted holes are permitted , they are allowed in only one of the connected parts 40 of either a friction-type or bearing-type connection at an individual faying surface .
41 When used in slip critical connections , locate holes without regard to direction of loading 42 if one-third more bolts are provided than needed to satisfy the allowable unit stresses 43 except as herein restricted .
44 When used in bearing-type connections , orient the long diameter of the slot normal to the 45 direction of loading .
No increase in the number of bolts over those necessary for the 46 allowable unit stress is required .
47 ( I ) Misfits 48 When misfits occur for any reason , enlargement of the holes by reaming is limited to 49 1/16 inch over the nominal size hole called for unless otherwise permitted in writing .
50 Section 1072 10-111 ( J ) Erection Bolt Holes 1 At field welded connections where erection bolts are used , provide holes 3/16 inch larger 2 than the nominal erection bolt diameter .

5 1072-18 WELDING 6 ( A ) Definition 7 The Bridge Welding Code referred to herein is the edition of the 8 ANSI/AWS/AASHTO Bridge Welding Code D 1.5 and any applicable interim that is 9 current on the date of advertisement for the project , and as modified by the Standard 10 Specifications .
11 ( B ) General 12 Commercially blast clean all steel used in girders , beams and connecting members to 13 SSPC-SP 6 before welding .
With the exception of rolled beams , the Contractor at their 14 option may submit to the Department for review , an alternate cleaning method for main 15 member material exposed to welding .
16 Weld all steel in the shop or in the field for bridges , whether permanent or temporary , and 17 perform all other work related to welding including , but not limited to , testing and 18 inspection of welds , preparation of material , oxygen cutting , electrodes , shielding and 19 shear studs , meeting the Bridge Welding Code .
Weld other steel items not covered under 20 the Bridge Welding Code in accordance with the applicable AWS Welding Code .
Some 21 examples may include but not limited to ; Structural Welding Code-Steel ( AWS D1.1 ) , 22 Structural Welding Code- Aluminum ( AWS D1.2 ) , Structural Welding Code-Sheet Steel 23 ( AWS D1.3 ) , Structural Welding Code- Reinforcing Steel ( AWS D1.4 ) and Structural 24 Welding Code-Stainless Steel ( AWS D1.6 ) .

along with the appropriate symbol 32 satisfies this requirement .

2 ( G ) Welded Structural Shapes 3 Produce butt welds of flanges and webs , and fillet welds of web to flanges of plate 4 girders and haunched beams using the submerged arc process .
Produce other structural 5 shapes built up from plates and bars using the submerged arc process unless another 6 process is qualified for these joints in accordance with the Bridge Welding Code and is 7 subject to the approval of the Engineer .
8 After all shop welded splices in the flanges and webs for the full length of the field 9 section are made , tested and approved , fit the flange plates tight and square against the 10 web to leave no gap and to not bow the web .
Brace one side of each flange against the 11 web with gussets or struts and tack weld securely to the web at the stiffener locations .
12 Upon removal of the welds , grind any nicks or gouges , preheat , weld and test or 13 incorporate into the stiffener fillet weld .
14 Connect the flanges to the web by starting the fillet weld at one end of the girder and 15 proceeding to the other ends .
16 As an option , make adjacent welds simultaneously .
17 The sequence for making the flange to web fillet welds is subject only to the provisions 18 for control of shrinkage and distortion and to the position requirements of the Bridge 19 Welding Code .
20 After flange to web welds are complete , shift bracing gussets or struts if necessary , then 21 remove all temporary gussets or struts .
Remove tack welds by grinding flush with parent 22 metal .
23 Straighten any transverse warpage of the flanges if necessary by heating along the 24 centerline of the outside face .
25 Fit tight , square and tack weld stiffeners securely to the web .
With the girder in the flat 26 position ( web horizontal ) , weld the stiffeners to the web .
Do not weld or tack weld 27 stiffeners to the flanges except where noted in the plans .
Stiffeners are not to be used to 28 correct tilt of flange due to distortion associated to welding .
29 After all parts are welded into place , trim the girder to detail length with adjustments for 30 slope and end rotation exceeding 1/4 inch nett .

22 1076-3 FABRICATED PRODUCTS 23 Galvanize products fabricated from rolled , pressed and forged steel shapes , plates , bars and 24 strips 1/8 inch thick and heavier in accordance with AASHTO M 111 .
Fabricate products into 25 the largest unit that is practicable to galvanize before the galvanizing is done .
Fabrication 26 includes all operations necessary to complete the unit such as shearing , cutting , punching , 27 forming , drilling , milling , bending , welding and riveting .
Galvanize components of bolted or 28 riveted assemblies separately before assembly .
When it is necessary to straighten any 29 sections after galvanizing , perform such work without damage to the zinc coating .
30 Completely seal all edges of tightly contacting surfaces by welding and commercial blast 31 clean to SSPC-SP 6 before galvanizing .
32 Commercial blast clean components with partial surface finishes in accordance with 33 Subarticle 442-7 ( A ) before pickling .

36 1076-5 ASSEMBLED PRODUCTS 37 Completely seal all edges of tightly contacting surfaces by welding before galvanizing .
38 Galvanize assembled steel products in accordance with AASHTO M 111 .
39 1076-6 SHEETS 40 Galvanize iron or steel sheets in accordance with ASTM A653 .
41 1076-7 REPAIR OF GALVANIZING 42 Repair galvanized surfaces that are abraded or damaged at any time after the application of 43 zinc coating .
Surfaces to be repaired shall be clean , dry and free of oil , grease , pre-existing 44 Section 1077 10-121 paint , corrosion and rust .
Surface to be repaired shall be blast-cleaned to SSPC-SP 10 ( near 1 white ) .
2 Where circumstances do not allow blast or power tool cleaning to be used , then hand tools 3 may be used .
Cleaning shall meet SSPC-SP 2 , the removal of loose rust , mil scale or paint to 4 the degree specified , by hand chipping , scrapping , sanding and wire-brushing .
Surface 5 preparation shall extend into the undamaged galvanized coating .
Spray using a non-aerosol 6 spray , or brush-apply the paint to the cleaned areas with 2 coats of organic zinc repair paint 7 meeting Article 1080-9 .
Ensure that the total thickness of the 2 coats is not less than 3 dry 8 mils .
Allow adequate curing time before subjecting repaired items to service conditions in 9 accordance with the manufacturer ’ s printed instructions .
10 Application conditions shall be 40°F Air/Steel temperature and rising , steel temperature shall 11 be 5°F above the dew point and relative humidity shall be 85 % or less .
Follow paint 12 manufacturers recommendation if more restrictive than above requirements .
13 Follow paint manufacturers written instructions on storage temperatures , mixing application , 14 continuous agitation and pot life .
No thinners are to be used when applying organic zinc 15 repair paint by brush or roller .
16 Instead of repairing by painting with organic zinc repair paint , other methods of repairing 17 galvanized surfaces that are abraded or damaged are allowed provided the proposed method is 18 acceptable to the Engineer .
19 Excessive damage to galvanized surfaces as determined by the Engineer is cause for rejection .
20 Replace or re-galvanize rejected galvanized material .

25 1077-5 PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE 26 ( A ) Composition and Design 27 Portland cement concrete is composed of Portland cement , coarse aggregate ( # 67 or 28 78M ) , fine aggregate , water and unless otherwise permitted by the Engineer , an air 29 entraining agent .

Do not use 31 calcium chloride or other admixtures containing calcium chloride .
32 Section 1077 10-123 Supply concrete that develops a minimum compressive strength as shown in 1 Table 1077-1 unless other strengths are designated on the approved drawings .
When 2 required , air entrain concrete to provide an air content of 4.5 % ± 1.5 % .

Do not use concrete with a slump exceeding 6 inches .
As 5 an option , reduce the cement content of the mix design by up to 20 % and replace with fly 6 ash at a rate of 1.2 lbs .
of fly ash for each pound of cement replaced or reduce the cement 7 content up to 50 % and replace with blast furnace slag on a pound for pound basis .

9 ( B ) Testing 10 Make all representative concrete test cylinders and all testing required herein in the 11 presence of the plant inspector for items with strength requirements greater than 2,500 psi 12 in Table 1077-1 , unless otherwise approved by the Engineer .

15 Before the first load is placed , determine the air content by a calibrated Chace indicator in 16 accordance with AASHTO T 199 .
If the air content as determined by the Chace indicator 17 fails to meet the Standard Specifications , perform 2 more tests with the Chace indicator 18 on the same load and average all 3 tests .
Acceptance or rejection of the load is based on 19 the average of the 3 Chace indicator tests .
As an alternate method determine the air 20 content by AASHTO T 152 , T196 or T121 .
21 Perform temperature , air and slump tests whenever cylinders are cast .
22 Determine slump in accordance with AASHTO T 119 with no more than 3 1/2 inches 23 allowed .

These cylinders are in addition to the four 29 concrete cylinders required for each day of production .

44 Section 1077 10-127 ( 4 ) Fiber Reinforced Concrete 1 Approved structural fibers may be used as a replacement of steel reinforcement in 2 allowable structures of Roadway Standard Drawings Nos .
840.45 and 840.52 .
The 3 dosage rate , in pounds of fibers per cubic yard , shall be as recommended by the fiber 4 manufacturer to provide a minimum average residual strength of concrete , tested in 5 accordance with ASTM C1399 , of no less than that of the concrete with the steel 6 reinforcement that is being replaced and no less than 5 lb/cy .

16 1077-8 PLACING CONCRETE 17 Use the procedures and equipment for handling , placing and consolidating the concrete such 18 that a uniformly dense and high grade concrete is obtained in all parts of the unit under all 19 working and weather conditions .
Do not mix , handle , deliver , place or finish concrete using 20 devices made of aluminum or containing aluminum .
21 Internal , external or a combination of internal and external vibration is required as necessary 22 to produce uniformly dense concrete without honeycomb .
23 1077-9 CURING CONCRETE 24 ( A ) General 25 Precast units are subjected to one of the methods of curing described below or to other 26 methods or combinations of methods approved by the Engineer .
Cure the precast units 27 for a sufficient length of time so the concrete develops the specified compressive strength 28 at 28 days or less .
Do not strip forms until at least 24 hours after the concrete attains 29 initial set .
For this purpose , initial set is defined as at least 500 psi resistance to 30 a standard penetrometer .
The option to strip forms earlier is available provided concrete 31 cylinders indicate a strength of at least 75 % of the 28 day compressive strength is 32 attained before release for each day ’ s production .
Do not deface or injure the units .
33 ( B ) Curing at Elevated Temperatures 34 Cure at elevated temperatures in accordance with Subarticle 1078-10 ( B ) .
35 ( C ) Water Curing 36 Water curing of precast units is allowed as described in Subarticle 420-15 ( B ) , by 37 covering with water saturated material , or by a system of perforated pipes , mechanical 38 sprinklers , porous hoses or by any other method that keeps the units moist during the 39 specified curing period .
Do not use methods that deface or injure the precast units .
40 ( D ) Curing Compound 41 Application of a curing compound is allowed provided it is left intact until the specified 42 compressive strength is met .
Keep all surfaces moist before the application of the 43 compound and damp when the compound is applied .
Seal the surface with a single 44 uniform coating at the rate of coverage recommended by the curing compound 45 manufacturer , or as directed by the Engineer , but not less than 1 gal per 150 sf of area .
46 Section 1077 10-128 1077-10 LIFT HOLES , HANDLING 1 Do not cast or drill more than 4 holes in each unit for the purpose of handling or placing 2 unless otherwise approved by the Engineer .
Locate all lift holes and handling devices in 3 accordance with plan and design requirements .
Units damaged while being handled or 4 transported are rejected or require repair in a manner approved by the Engineer .
5 1077-11 FINAL FINISH 6 Unless otherwise required by the contract , finish all concrete in accordance with 7 Subarticle 420-17 ( B ) .
8 Do not repair units with honeycomb , cracks , or spalls until inspected by the Engineer .
Use 9 repair methods that are approved by the Engineer before their use .

44 Section 1078 10-129 SECTION 1078 1 PRESTRESSED CONCRETE MEMBERS 2 1078-1 GENERAL 3 This section covers the materials for and the production of precast , prestressed concrete 4 members produced in accordance with the contract .
5 Use prestressing of the pretensioning type in which steel prestressing strands are initially 6 stressed and anchored ; the concrete is then placed , vibrated and cured ; and when the concrete 7 reaches the required strength , the load is transferred from the anchorages to the concrete .
8 The intent of this section is to require the producer to provide prestressed concrete members 9 that meet the Standard Specifications and exhibit characteristics that are not objectionable to 10 the Department .
11 ( A ) Producer Qualification 12 Producers of precast , prestressed concrete members are required to establish proof of 13 their competency and responsibility in accordance with the Precast/Prestressed Concrete 14 Institute ’ s ( PCI ) Plant Certification Program to perform work for the project .
15 Certification of the manufacturing plant under the PCI program and submission of proof 16 of certification to the State Materials Engineer is required before beginning fabrication .
17 Maintain certification at all times while work is being performed for the Department .
18 Submit proof of certification following each PCI audit to the State Materials Engineer for 19 continued qualification .
These same requirements apply to producers subcontracting 20 work from the producer directly employed by the Contractor .
21 Employ producers PCI certified in Product Group B , Bridge Products and in one of the 22 appropriate categories as listed below : 23 ( 1 ) B2 Prestressed Miscellaneous Bridge Products includes solid piles , sheet piles and 24 bent caps ; 25 ( 2 ) B3 Prestressed Straight-Strand Bridge Members includes all box beams , cored slabs , 26 straight-strand girders and bulb-tees , bridge deck panels , hollow piles , prestressed 27 culverts and straight strand segmental components ; or 28 ( 3 ) B4 Prestressed Deflected-Strand Bridge Members includes deflected strand girders 29 and bulb-tees , haunched girders , deflected strand segmental superstructure 30 components and other post-tensioned elements .
31 Categories for elements not listed above will be as required by the project special 32 provision or plans .
33 ( B ) Working Drawing Submittals 34 Before casting girders , submit complete working drawings to the Engineer for approval .
35 The drawings shall detail the exact location and description of all casting holes , 36 attachments and inserts cast in the member for both temporary and permanent 37 applications .
The casting holes , attachments and inserts are in association with , but not 38 limited to : fall protection , overhang falsework , metal stay-in-place forms , solar platforms , 39 temporary girder bracing , transit , erection , lifting and handling .
If the plan notes indicate 40 that the structure contains the necessary corrosion protection required for a corrosive site , 41 epoxy coat , galvanize or metalize all metallic components except stainless steel and 42 malleable iron components .
Electroplating will not be allowed .

7 ( B ) Testing 8 Employ a certified concrete technician to perform all testing required by this subarticle at 9 the bed site in the presence of the plant inspector unless otherwise approved .
10 Certification of technicians is awarded upon satisfactory completion of examinations 11 prepared and administered by the Department or other approved agency .
12 ( 1 ) Air Content 13 Before allowing placement of the first load in a bed , determine the air content by 14 a calibrated Chace indicator .
During the placement of the first load , determine the 15 air content by AASHTO T 152 , T 196 or T 121 .
Determine the air content in each 16 subsequent 10 cubic yards by the Chace indicator before allowing placement .
17 Determine the air content by AASHTO T 152 , T 196 or T 121 from all loads from 18 which cylinders are made .
If the air content as determined by the Chace indicator , 19 fails to meet the specification requirements , a second test is run on material from the 20 same load and the results of the 2 tests averaged .
If the average does not meet the 21 Standard Specifications , a test on the same load is conducted using AASHTO T 152 , 22 T 196 or T 121 .
Acceptance or rejection of the load is based on the results of this 23 test .
24 ( 2 ) Slump 25 Determine slump in accordance with AASHTO T 119 .
26 ( 3 ) Strength 27 For the purpose of testing for the required 28 day compressive strength and also for 28 the required compressive strength for the transfer of load , furnish , at no cost to the 29 Department , cylinders made from a sample of concrete placed near the live end of 30 the bed and additional cylinders made from a sample of concrete placed near the 31 dead end of the bed .
Make cylinders in accordance with AASHTO T 23 , except cure 32 the cylinders in the same manner as the members represented until the strands are 33 released .
Place cylinders in clusters at random points along the casting bed .
After 34 the strands are released , air cure the cylinders in an approved common area near the 35 testing apparatus for the remainder of the 28 day curing period .
Test the cylinders in 36 accordance with AASHTO T 22 .
Provide approved apparatus for testing the transfer 37 strength of the cylinders .
Maintain this apparatus to within 1.0 % accuracy and 38 calibrate at intervals not to exceed 12 months by an approved testing company at no 39 cost to the Department .
The Engineer reserves the right to require verification 40 immediately after a testing machine is relocated and whenever there is reason to 41 doubt the accuracy of the indicated load , regardless of the time interval since the last 42 verification .
43 Section 1078 10-133 The testing requirements vary according to the 28 day compressive strength required 1 by the plans as follows : 2 ( a ) Compressive Strength ( 28 day ) of 6,000 psi or Less 3 Test a set of two cylinders , one from each end of the bed , for the purpose of 4 determining whether the concrete has reached the required strength for transfer 5 of load .
Ensure that the average of the strength tests on the two cylinders meets 6 or exceeds the required strength and the lowest cylinder is not more than 200 psi 7 below the required strength .
8 Test a set of two cylinders to determine compressive strength at the age of 28 9 days .
The strength from these two cylinders is averaged .
Ensure that this average 10 is at least 5,000 psi or such 28 day compressive strength required by the plans or 11 Standard Specifications .
Ensure that no cylinder indicates a compressive 12 strength less than 400 psi below the required 28 day compressive strength .
13 Failure to meet the above requirements is cause for rejection of the members 14 represented .
15 ( b ) Compressive Strength ( 28 day ) of Greater Than 6,000 psi 16 Test four cylinders , two sets of two cylinders from each end of the bed , for the 17 purpose of determining whether the concrete has reached the required strength 18 for transfer of load .
The strengths from the dead end cylinders are averaged and 19 the strengths from the live end cylinders are averaged .
Ensure that both of these 20 averages meet or exceed the required release strength and the lowest cylinder is 21 not more than 200 psi below the required strength .
22 Test a set of three cylinders from each end to determine the 28 day compressive 23 strength .
The strengths from the dead end cylinders are averaged and the 24 strengths from the live end cylinders are averaged .
Ensure that both of these 25 averages meet or exceed the 28 day compressive strength .
Ensure that no 26 cylinder indicates a compressive strength less than 400 psi less than the required 27 28 day compressive strength .
Failure to meet the above requirements is cause 28 for rejection of the members represented .

41 Section 1078 10-135 ( J ) Mixing and Delivery 1 ( 1 ) General 2 Mix and deliver concrete to the site of the work by one of the following methods , 3 except where other methods are approved by the Engineer .
The Engineer approves 4 the mixing of concrete by methods other than those listed below provided the 5 proposed method is capable of satisfying job requirements and there is adequate 6 evidence that the proposed method produces concrete complying with the Standard 7 Specifications .

9 Have present during all batching operations at the concrete plant a certified concrete 10 technician employed by the Contractor , prestressed concrete producer or concrete 11 supplier while concrete is batched and delivered to the site of the work .

21 ( a ) Central Mixed Concrete 22 Mix completely in a stationary mixer and transport the mixed concrete to the 23 point of delivery in a truck agitator or in a truck mixer operating at agitating 24 speed or in non-agitating equipment approved by the Engineer .
Mix within the 25 capacity and at the mixing speeds recommended by the equipment 26 manufacturer .
27 ( b ) Transit Mixed Concrete 28 Mix completely in a truck mixer while at the batching plant , in transit or at the 29 work site .
30 ( 2 ) Mixing Time for Central Mixed Concrete 31 The mixing time starts when all the solid materials are in the mixing compartment 32 and ends when any part of the concrete begins to discharge .
Charge the ingredients 33 into the mixer such that some of the water enters in advance of cement and 34 aggregate , and substantially all the water is in the drum before 1/3 of the specified 35 mixing time elapses .
Transfer time in multiple drum mixers is counted as part of the 36 mixing time .
37 Establish the minimum mixing time by one of the following : 38 ( a ) Mixer performance tests as described herein , 39 ( b ) The manufacturer of the equipment , or 40 ( c ) The requirement of one minute for mixers of 1.0 cy capacity or less with 41 an increase of 15 seconds for each cubic yard or fraction thereof in increased 42 capacity .
43 The Engineer reserves the right to require a mixer performance test at any time .
The 44 minimum mixing time as determined by the mixer performance test is that which 45 produces concrete in accordance with Table 1078-2 .

36 Section 1078 10-137 ( K ) Ready Mixed Concrete Plant 1 Ensure ready mixed concrete plants are inspected and approved by the Department before 2 they are used to produce concrete for the project .
