Reapproval after each 7 inspection is contingent on continuing compliance with the Standard Specifications 8 1078-5 CASTING BED AND FORMS 9 Use metal forms , including headers or end forms , except where other materials are approved 10 by the Engineer .
Use forms of adequate thickness , braced , stiffened , anchored and aligned 11 adequately to consistently produce members within the limits of dimensional tolerances .
12 Design and align the forms so they do not restrict longitudinal movement of the casting when 13 the prestressing force is transferred .
Provide corners and angles that are chamfered or 14 rounded .
Provide joints in forms that are smooth and tight enough to prevent leakage of 15 mortar .
Plug holes and slots in forms , pallets , headers and bulkheads neatly to prevent 16 leakage of mortar .
Make the inside surfaces of forms accessible for cleaning .
Thoroughly 17 clean the beds and forms after each use .
Before casting , clean the inside surfaces of the forms 18 from rust , grease or other foreign matter .
Remove all foreign substances from inside the 19 forms , including any standing water .
Do not allow coatings used for release of members to 20 build up .
Do not use forms that do not present a smooth surface .
21 When casting holes through the top flange of Bulb Tee Girders for overhang or interior bay 22 falsework hanger rods , use rigid PVC conduits with a wall thickness of approximately 23 1/8 inch .
Do not use thin wall material .
Secure conduits in the forms so they do not migrate 24 out of the proper location .
Other methods of forming holes may be proposed but are subject 25 to the Engineer ’ s approval .
26 When casting dowel rod holes in cored slab or box beam members , use material that creates 27 round , vertical holes of the specified diameter and in the correct location .
Do not use material 28 that deforms , collapses or shifts position during casting of the member .
29 Apply form release agents to the forms either before or after stringing of strands .
If applied 30 before stringing , provide a release agent of a type that dries to a degree so it can not 31 contaminate any strand that comes in contact with it .
If the release agent is applied after 32 stringing , exercise great care and provide a sheet metal or similar type shield for protection of 33 the strands .
34 1078-6 TENSIONING DEVICES 35 Use tensioning devices adequate to produce and maintain the required tension in all strands 36 until the concrete reaches the required transfer strength .
Equip all jacks with accurate and 37 calibrated gauges for registering jacking loads .
Calibrate gauges with the jacks with which 38 they are used .
Calibrate all jacks and gauges by an approved testing company at no cost to the 39 Department at intervals not to exceed 12 months .
During progress of the work , if gauge 40 readings and elongations indicate materially differing loads , recalibrate as required .
Use 41 gauges with a full load capacity of 1 1/2 to 2 times their normal working load , unless 42 otherwise approved .
Do not use loads less than one-fourth or more than 3/4 of the total 43 graduated gauge capacity unless calibration data clearly establishes consistent accuracy over 44 a wider range .
Use gauges with indicating dials at least 6 inches in diameter and gauge 45 pointers that do not fluctuate , preventing an accurate reading , but remain steady until the 46 jacking load is released .
Ensure that all gauges have an accuracy of reading within 2 % .
47 Provide means for measuring the elongation of strands within 1/4 inch .
48 Section 1078 10-138 1078-7 PLACING STRANDS , TIES AND REINFORCING STEEL 1 Position strands , ties , supports , reinforcing bars of the sizes shown in the plans and bearing 2 plates in accordance with the detailed dimensions shown in the plans and effectively secure 3 against displacement from their correct positions .
The use of previously tensioned strands is 4 not permitted .
For prestressing strands , do not allow deflections or displacements of any kind 5 between the end anchorages unless shown in the plans .
Place the steel reinforcing in final 6 position after tensioning of the strands .
Bend all tie wires to the inside of the member so the 7 ends are farther from the edge than the material tied .
Support bottom strands spacings not to 8 exceed 20 feet by supports meeting Article 1070-4 or by other approved means .
Plastic 9 supports may be used when approved .
10 Strands with kinks , bends , nicks , scale , excessive rust or other defects are not permitted .
No 11 more than one broken wire per casting bed is permitted .
Slight rusting is not cause for 12 rejection , provided it is not sufficient to cause visible pits .
Take precautions to prevent 13 contamination of strands and reinforcing steel .
Clean the strands and reinforcing steel to an 14 acceptable condition before pouring concrete .
Do not place concrete in the forms until the 15 strand and reinforcement condition and arrangement are inspected by the plant inspector .
16 Strand splices are only permitted at the end of a reel and when using a single strand jack .
17 Ensure that the strand lengths to be spliced together have the same lay of wire to avoid 18 unraveling and position the splice so it does not fall within a member .
Do not torch cut the 19 ends of the spliced strand lengths .
Cut by shears , abrasive grinders or other means approved 20 by the Engineer .
No more than one strand splice per bed is allowed on an individual strand 21 and the use of previously tensioned strands for splicing is not permitted .
22 Where debonding of strands is required , accomplish by encasing the strand in a tubular 23 conduit capable of resisting the pressure exerted by the concrete .
Do not use slit conduit .
Use 24 a conduit of HDPE or polypropylene with a minimum wall thickness of 0.025 inch .
Ensure 25 that the inside diameter of the conduit is of sufficient size to allow free movement of the 26 encased strand but not greater than the diameter of the strand plus 1/8 inch .
Secure the 27 conduit so longitudinal movement along the strand is prevented , and bonding of the strand is 28 prevented at the required location ± 1 inch .
Prevent concrete from entering the conduit by 29 taping .
Use tape manufactured from a non-corrosive material compatible with the concrete , 30 conduit and steel .
31 1078-8 TENSIONING PROCEDURE 32 A producer quality control representative shall be present during strand tensioning .
Tension 33 each strand to the load shown in the plans before placing the concrete .
34 Measure the load induced in the prestressing strand both by jacking gauges and strand 35 elongations on at least the first five strands and every third strand thereafter on each pour .
36 Measure loads on all other strands by either jacking gauges or strand elongations .
When both 37 methods of measurement are used , if a discrepancy between gauge and elongation of more 38 than 5 % is apparent , carefully check the entire operation and determine the source of error 39 before proceeding .
Make appropriate allowances in the computed elongation and jacking 40 loads for load losses due to friction and all possible slippage or relaxation of the anchorage .
41 Establish references periodically at each strand anchorage to indicate any yielding or slippage 42 that may occur between the time of initial tensioning and final release of the strands .
43 In determining the applied load by measuring the elongation of the strand , use a modulus of 44 elasticity taken from the typical stress-strain curve for the brand , size and type of strand 45 tensioned .
Submit stress-strain curve data for the actual heats of material used in the strands 46 to the plant inspector before using the strands .
Identify each reel or strand by tagging in 47 accordance with AASHTO M 203 .
Mark the outer layer of each reel pack of strand with a 48 wide color band .
In addition , attach a metal tag to each reel pack labeled in accordance with 49 AASHTO M 203 .
50 Section 1078 10-139 Tension strands in a group or individually .
Before full tensioning , bring each strand to 1 an initial tension of 2,000 lbs .
for all beds under 150 feet in length , 3,000 lbs .
for all beds 2 150 feet to 300 feet in length and 4,000 lbs .
for all beds longer than 300 feet in length .
3 Measure this initial tension by a calibrated gauge or other approved means , and then compute 4 the elongation due to initial tensioning .
Use the difference between the required final tension 5 and the initial tension to compute the expected additional elongation .
6 For precast prestressed deck panels , use a final prestressing force of 14,000 lbs .
per strand for 7 Grade 250 strand and 16,100 lbs .
per strand for Grade 270 strand .
8 After initial tensioning , tension the strands until the required elongation and jacking load are 9 attained and reconciled within the limits specified above .
Keep a permanent record of the 10 initial jacking load , the final jacking load , and the elongation produced thereby .
11 In single strand tensioning , rotation of the jacking ram is not allowed .
12 When draped strands are used , submit the bed layout showing the method of draping and 13 tensioning the draped strands and also calculations determining the loads required for 14 tensioning the draped strands .
Drape the strands for all members to be cast in any one 15 tensioning operation before casting any beam .
Have end templates or bulkheads at ends of 16 beams remain vertical or as otherwise shown in the plans .
Perform draping for all members 17 either simultaneously or in single or incremental lifts beginning at the center of the bed and 18 working outward toward each end of the bed .
Complete tensioning in the fully draped 19 position is not allowed unless approved in writing .
20 Use round steel rollers of a type and dimensions approved by the Engineer for deflecting the 21 draped strands .
Round the part in contact with the strand to a diameter of not less than 22 3/4 inch .
Use support and hold-down devices of sufficient rigidity with adequate support so 23 the final position of the strands is as shown in the plans .
24 With strands tensioned in accordance with the above requirements and with other 25 reinforcement in place , cast the concrete members so as to achieve the required lengths .
26 Maintain strand load between anchorages until the concrete reaches the required compressive 27 strength for transfer of load from the anchorages to the members .
28 For personnel engaged in the tensioning operation , provide protection by effective shields 29 adequate to stop a flying strand .
Provide shields produced from steel , reinforced concrete , 30 heavy timbers and other approved material at both ends of the bed .
31 1078-9 PLACING CONCRETE 32 Place concrete in accordance with Article 1077-8 and the additional requirements of this 33 article .
34 Upon completion of stressing strand , place concrete within a reasonable time to prevent 35 contamination of the strands and reinforcing steel .
36 Place concrete for girders 54 inches or less in height , and concrete for all cored slabs and box 37 beams , in two or more equal horizontal layers .
Place concrete for girders over 54 inches in 38 height in three horizontal layers .
When placing concrete in three layers locate the top of the 39 first layer approximately at the top of the bottom flange and locate the top of the second layer 40 approximately at the top of the web .
To prevent separation of surfaces between layers , do not 41 allow the time between successive placements onto previously placed concrete to exceed 42 20 minutes , unless the previously placed concrete has not yet stiffened , as evidenced by the 43 continuous effective use of vibration .
Should shrinkage or settlement cracks occur , the 44 Engineer reserves the right to require additional layers and/or vibration .
45 The requirement of the above paragraph may be waived with the permission of the Engineer if 46 self-consolidating concrete is used .
47 Internal or a combination of internal and external vibration is required as is necessary to 48 produce uniformly dense concrete without honeycomb .
49 Section 1078 10-140 Place concrete in cold weather in accordance with Article 420-7 .
1 Place concrete in daylight unless an adequate lighting system meeting the approval of the 2 Engineer is provided .
3 Do not exceed a temperature of 95°F in the freshly mixed concrete when placed in the forms .
4 Place the concrete in the bed in one continuous operation , finishing each member before 5 proceeding to the next one .
If the pour stops before the concrete in all the members in the bed 6 is placed , start curing immediately .
Do not place concrete in any remaining members in that 7 bed setup once curing at elevated temperatures has begun .
8 When cored slabs and box beams are cast , employ an internal hold-down system to prevent 9 the voids from moving .
At least 6 weeks before casting cored slabs or box beams , submit to 10 the Engineer for review and comment , detailed drawings of the proposed void material and 11 hold-down system .
In addition to structural details , indicate the location and spacing of the 12 holds-downs .
Submit the proposed method of concrete placement and of consolidating the 13 concrete under the void .
14 1078-10 CURING CONCRETE 15 ( A ) General 16 Cure concrete by steam curing , radiant heat curing or water curing , as set forth below .
17 As an option , cure concrete for prestressed piles with membrane curing compound as set 18 forth below .
Use a method or methods that prevent the concrete from losing moisture at 19 any time before curing is complete .
Use methods that do not deface or injure the 20 concrete .
Use curing procedures that prevent cracks from occurring in the members .
21 Cure all members in any one bed by the same method .
22 Continue the curing period until the concrete reaches sufficient strength to permit transfer 23 of load from the anchorage to the members .
As soon as the concrete attains release 24 strength , immediately release all forms in a continuous operation , without delay for other 25 activities such as the cleaning of forms .
Immediately following the removal of the forms , 26 de-tension the members .
27 ( B ) Curing at Elevated Temperatures 28 Perform radiant heat curing under a suitable enclosure that contains the heat and prevent 29 moisture loss .
Apply moisture by a cover of moist burlap , cotton matting , or similar 30 approved material .
Retain moisture by covering the member with an approved waterproof 31 sheeting in combination with an insulating cover .
Support the cover at a sufficient 32 distance above the member being cured to allow circulation of the heat .
33 Provide steam curing enclosures essentially free of steam leakage to minimize moisture 34 and heat losses .
Do not allow the enclosure to come in contact with the members or 35 forms for the members .
Do not direct steam jets on the forms so as to cause localized 36 high temperatures .
37 After placing and vibrating , allow the concrete to attain its initial set before the 38 application of heat or steam .
The concrete is considered to obtain its initial set when it 39 has a penetration resistance of at least 500 psi when tested in accordance with 40 AASHTO T 197 .
Take the sample of concrete tested for penetration resistance from the 41 last load cast in the bed .
Store the sample of concrete with the precast member and 42 maintain in the same condition and environment as the member except for the periods of 43 time necessary to prepare the test specimen and to perform the penetration resistance test .
44 Conduct the penetration resistance test .
45 Section 1078 10-141 As an option , submit data indicating that an approved concrete mix attains its initial set 1 after some particular time period .
Different periods may be required for different weather 2 conditions .
If such data is submitted , consideration is given to permitting heat or steam 3 introduced after the time indicated by such data instead of having to perform the 4 penetration resistance test .
Consideration is given to determining the time of initial set by 5 methods other than AASHTO T 197 provided data supporting such other methods is 6 submitted .
7 When the ambient air temperature is below 50°F , cover the forms after the placement of 8 concrete and apply sufficient heat to maintain the temperature of the air surrounding the 9 unit between 50° and 70°F .
10 When the ambient air temperature is above 70°F , start a water cure as set forth below or 11 other approved method as soon as the concrete is able to receive the water without 12 physical damage to its surface .
Discontinuation of the cure is allowed upon introduction 13 of steam , provided that a relative humidity of 100 % is maintained .
14 The temperature within the curing enclosure shall not exceed 160°F .
15 Maintain a relatively uniform rate of increase of the temperature within the curing 16 enclosure of approximately 40°F per hour , not to exceed 15°F per 15 minutes .
Ensure 17 that the temperature increase is relatively uniform throughout the length and on both 18 sides and top of the concrete unit .
Place recording thermometers within 50 feet of each 19 end of the bed and at points not to exceed 100 feet between the end thermometers .
20 Provide at least two thermometers for bed lengths of 100 feet or less .
Calibrate recording 21 thermometers at intervals not to exceed 6 months .
Ensure that the temperature differential 22 within the curing enclosure does not exceed 15°F .
Submit complete temperature records 23 for all cures before final approval of the members .
24 Continue steam curing until the concrete reaches the required transfer strength .
25 ( C ) Water Curing 26 Keep the concrete continuously wet by the application of water as soon as possible 27 without damage to the concrete surface , and before the concrete obtains an initial set of 28 500 psi .
Apply the water using soaker hoses and wet burlap or other approved means for 29 the full length of each member .
Apply water evenly along the entire length of the bed .
30 When the ambient air temperature is below 50°F cover the forms after the placement of 31 the concrete and apply sufficient heat in an approved manner to maintain the temperature 32 of the air surrounding the member between 50°F and 70°F .
After the concrete obtains 33 an initial set of 500 psi , the air temperature surrounding the member is allowed to 34 increase to 100°F while continually maintaining moisture on the surface of the concrete .
35 Whenever heat is applied to the member , place temperature recording clocks on the bed 36 as required when curing at elevated temperatures .
The requirements for rate of 37 temperature increase apply .
38 Maintain the application of heat ( if used ) and water until the concrete obtains release 39 strength .
40 ( D ) Curing with Membrane Curing Compound 41 As an option , cure prestressed concrete piles with a membrane curing compound .
Spray 42 the entire surface of the concrete uniformly with a wax-free , resin-base curing compound 43 conforming to Article 1026-2 .
Use clear curing compound to which a fugitive dye is 44 added for color contrast .
45 Section 1078 10-142 Apply the membrane curing compound after the surface finishing is complete , and 1 immediately after the free surface moisture disappears .
In the event the application of 2 curing compound is delayed , start another curing method immediately and continue until 3 the application of the curing compound is started or resumed or until the concrete reaches 4 the required detensioning strength .
5 Seal the surface with a single uniform coating of the specified type of curing compound 6 applied at the rate of coverage recommended by the manufacturer or as directed by the 7 Engineer , but not less than one gallon per 150 sf of area .
8 At the time of use , thoroughly mix the compound in a condition with the pigment 9 uniformly dispersed throughout the vehicle .
If the application of the compound does not 10 result in satisfactory coverage , stop the method and apply water curing , as set out above , 11 until the cause of the defective work is corrected .
12 At locations where the coating shows discontinuities , pinholes , or other defects , or if rain 13 falls on the newly coated surface before the film dries sufficiently to resist damage , apply 14 an additional coat of the compound immediately after the rain stops at the same rate 15 specified herein .
16 When the ambient air temperature is below 50°F , cover the forms after the application of 17 the curing compound and apply sufficient heat in an approved manner to maintain the 18 temperature of the air surrounding the member between 50°F and 70°F .
Whenever heat 19 is applied to the members , place recording thermometers on the bed as required when 20 curing at elevated temperatures .
The requirements for rate of temperature increase also 21 apply .
22 Completely remove any curing compound adhering to a surface to which new concrete is 23 bonded by sandblasting , steel wire brushes , bush hammers or other approved means .
24 Protect the concrete surfaces to which the compound is applied from abrasion or other 25 damage that results in perforation of the membrane film until the concrete achieves 26 design strength and the members are de-tensioned .
27 1078-11 TRANSFER OF LOAD 28 A producer quality control representative or equivalent qualified personnel shall be present 29 during removal of forms and during transfer of load .
30 Transfer load from the anchorages to the members when the concrete reaches the required 31 compressive strength shown in the plans .
Loosen and remove all formwork in one continuous 32 operation as quickly as possible as soon as release strength is obtained .
As soon as the forms 33 are removed , and after the Department ’ s Inspector has had a reasonable opportunity to inspect 34 the member , transfer the load from the anchorages to the members as quickly as possible in 35 one continuous operation using the approved detensioning sequence .
36 For any particular group of members cast in the same bed , do not transfer the load to any 37 concrete until the test cylinder breaks indicate that the concrete in all these members has 38 reached the required strength as outlined in Subarticle 1078-4 ( B ) ( 3 ) .
If these conditions are 39 not met , delay the transfer of the prestressing load to the concrete until tests of additional 40 cylinders show that the required strength is reached .
41 When curing at elevated temperatures , begin the procedures for transferring prestressing load 42 immediately after curing is discontinued and the forms are released , and while the concrete is 43 still hot to prevent cooling shrinkage and cracking .
If so directed by the Engineer , cover 44 members or otherwise protect so as to cool the concrete slowly after release to prevent 45 thermal shock and the evaporation of moisture in the members .
46 Section 1078 10-143 Transfer load to not cause cracks in members .
Transfer load by gradual release of the strands 1 as a group , by gradual release of part of the group , or by burning the fully tensioned strands at 2 the ends of the members .
If intending to release the strands by a method other than gradual 3 release of the entire group , submit six copies of the proposed method and pattern of release , if 4 not so shown in the plans , for approval .
Rigidly follow the approved method and pattern of 5 release .
When the fully tensioned strands are burned , burn each strand or group of strands 6 simultaneously at each end of the bed in its indicated order in the pattern and at each end of 7 each member before proceeding to the strands in the next group in the pattern at any point .
8 Because of the critical nature of the bond development length in prestressed concrete panel 9 construction , if transferring of stress by burning the fully tensioned strands at the ends of the 10 member , burn each strand first at the ends of the bed and then at each end of each member 11 before proceeding to the next strand in the burning pattern .
12 When detensioning all girders , box beams , cored slabs , piles , and panels do not burn strands 13 quickly but heat with a low oxygen flame played along the strand for at least 5 inches until the 14 metal gradually loses its strength .
Apply heat at such a rate that failure of the first wire in 15 each strand does not occur until at least 5 seconds after heat is first applied .
When 16 detensioning other members , follow the above procedure unless an alternate procedure is 17 approved .
Detensioning by arc welder is not allowed .
18 Incorporate the following in the method for single strand detensioning of members having 19 draped strands : 20 ( A ) Release the pair of straight strands located in the uppermost position in the lower flange 21 first .
22 ( B ) Then release the tension in the draped strands at the ends and uplift points in accordance 23 with an approved pattern .
24 ( C ) Disengage all hold-down devices for draped strands and release the hold-downs .
25 ( D ) Then release the pair of straight strands located in the upper flange .
26 ( E ) Release the remaining straight strands of the pattern in accordance with an approved 27 sequence .
28 ( F ) Release all strands in a manner meeting the Engineer ’ s approval that will cause 29 a minimum shock and lateral eccentricity of loading .
30 Failure to follow the above procedures for transfer of load is ground for rejection of the 31 members involved .
32 1078-12 VERTICAL CRACKS IN PRESTRESSED CONCRETE GIRDERS BEFORE 33 DETENSIONING 34 This section addresses prestressed concrete members that have vertical casting cracks before 35 strand detensioning .
Certain types of these cracks have been determined by the Department to 36 render the girders unacceptable .
37 Unacceptable cracked members are those with two or more vertical cracks spaced at a 38 distance less than the member depth which extend into the bottom flange .
Such members are 39 not serviceable and will be rejected .
Members with two or more vertical cracks spaced at a 40 distance less than the member depth but do not extend into the bottom flange are subject to 41 an engineering assessment .
Such members may not be serviceable and may be rejected .
42 Members with one or more vertical cracks that extend into the bottom flange and are spaced 43 at a distance greater than the member depth are subject to an engineering assessment to 44 determine their acceptability .
If this engineering assessment is required , submit , at no 45 additional cost to the Department , a proposal for repairing the member and a structural 46 evaluation of the member prepared by an engineer licensed by the State of North Carolina .
47 Section 1078 10-144 In the structural evaluation , consider the stresses under full service loads had the member not 1 cracked and the effects of localized loss of prestress at the crack as determined by methods 2 acceptable to the Department .
3 All members , except those defined as unacceptable , which exhibit vertical cracks before 4 detensioning , shall receive a 7 day water cure as directed by the Engineer .
The water cure 5 shall begin within 4 hours after detensioning the prestressing strands and shall be at least 6 3 feet beyond the region exhibiting vertical cracks .
7 The Department has the final determination regarding acceptability of any members in 8 question .
9 1078-13 PRESTRESSED CONCRETE GIRDER WEB SPLITTING 10 After detensioning of certain girders with draped strands , cracks occasionally occur in the 11 webs at the ends of the girders .
12 Repair all cracks located in the web of girders appearing after detensioning that are 13 0.010 inches ( 0.25 mm ) or greater in width by means of epoxy injection in accordance with 14 the Standard Specifications and as approved by the Engineer .
15 Repair any web cracks that are less than 0.010 inches ( 0.25 mm ) and greater than 0.005 inches 16 ( 0.15 mm ) in width by coating them with an approved clear , water based alkylalkoxysilane 17 ( silane ) penetrating sealant having a minimum 40 percent solids .
Use a sealant that meets the 18 requirement of NCHRP 244 and Federal AIM VOC emissions standards and has been 19 approved by the Engineer .
Coat web cracks between 0.005 inches ( 0.15 mm ) and 0.010 inches 20 ( 0.25 mm ) in width with silane within 2 weeks after they appear or before shipment to the site 21 whichever occurs soonest .
22 Cracks located in the web less than or equal to 0.005 ( 0.15 mm ) in width need not be coated .
23 Do not repair or coat any cracks without prior approval of the Engineer .
No separate payment 24 will be made for the treatment of cracks , as payment is included in the contract unit price bid 25 for prestressed concrete girders .
26 Repair of web cracks shall not be a substitute for using an approved debonding pattern for 27 future girders as described below .
28 If such cracks occur , employ a method to remedy this condition on all subsequent girders of 29 the same type and strand pattern .
If debonding of strands is used , satisfy the following 30 criteria : 31 ( A ) Do not debond the two straight strands in the top of the girder .
Debond 1/2 of the straight 32 strands , as nearly as possible , in the bottom flange .
As nearly as possible , debond 1/4 of 33 the straight strands in the bottom of girder 4 feet from each end of the girder and debond 34 1/4 of the straight strands 2 feet from each end of the girder .
35 ( B ) Use a debonding pattern that is symmetrical about the vertical axis of the girder .
36 ( C ) Debond strands so the center of gravity of the strands in the bottom of the girder remain 37 within 1 inch of their original location at the end of the girder .
38 ( D ) Debond strands in accordance with Article 1078-7 .
39 No separate payment is made for debonding strands as payment is included in the contract 40 unit price bid for prestressed concrete girders .
41 Section 1078 10-145 1078-14 HANDLING , TRANSPORTING AND STORING 1 Members damaged while being handled or transported are rejected or require repair in 2 a manner approved by the Engineer .
All members are allowed to be handled immediately 3 after transfer of load from the anchorages to the members is complete .
4 Store all prestressed members on solid , unyielding , storage blocks in a manner to prevent 5 torsion or objectionable bending .
In handling prestressed concrete girders 54 inches or less in 6 height , including cored slabs and box beams , maintain them in an upright position at all times 7 and pick them up within 5 feet of the points of bearing and transport and store supported only 8 within 3 feet of points of bearing .
In handling prestressed concrete girders greater than 54 9 inches in height , maintain them in an upright position at all times and submit for approval the 10 proposed method of lifting , transporting , and storing the girders .
When requested , provide 11 calculations to confirm girders are not overstressed by such operations .
12 Prestressed concrete panels are weak in the direction perpendicular to the prestressing strands , 13 therefore , they are subject to breakage during handling , storing or transporting .
Provide 14 adequate blocking during all of these construction phases .
15 In handling , transporting , and storing prestressed members , use the number and location of 16 supports in accordance with the plan requirements for the sizes , lengths and types of members 17 involved , or as approved .
18 When handling the prestressed concrete members , a temporary stress of cif 5 is permitted , 19 where cif is the strength of concrete at release , in pounds per square inch .
20 Do not transport members away from the casting yard until the concrete reaches the minimum 21 required 28 day compressive strength and a period of at least 5 days elapses since casting , 22 unless otherwise permitted .
23 Do not transfer any member from the plant to the job site before approval of that member by 24 the plant inspector .
This approval is stamped on the member by the plant inspector .
25 1078-15 FINAL FINISH 26 Finish prestressed concrete members that are intended for composite action with subsequently 27 placed concrete or asphalt with a roughened surface for bonding .
Make sure that no laitance 28 remains on the surfaces to be bonded .
29 Rough float the tops of girders .
Broom finish the top surface of the cored slab and box beam 30 sections receiving an asphalt overlay .
Rake the top surface of cored slab and box beam 31 sections receiving a concrete overlay to a depth of 3/8 inch .
No surface finish is required for 32 sides and bottom of the slab and beam sections except the exposed side of the exterior unit as 33 noted below .
Provide a resulting surface finish essentially the same color and surface finish 34 as the surrounding concrete .
35 Provide a 3/4 inch chamfer along the bottom edges on ends and sides of all box beam and 36 cored slab sections , top outside edges of exterior sections and acute corners of sections .
37 Round the top edges on ends of all sections with a 1/4 inch finishing tool .
Provide square 38 corners along top edges on all sections along shear keys .
Do not chamfer vertical edges at 39 ends of sections .
40 Fill all voids in the diagonal face of the bottom flange of prestressed concrete girders and the 41 outside face of exterior cored slabs and box beams with a sand-cement or other approved 42 grout .
Fill all voids in piles greater than 1/2 inch in diameter or depth as above .
Provide 43 a resulting surface finish essentially the same color and surface finish as the surrounding 44 concrete .
Repair voids greater than 1/4 inch in diameter or depth in other faces of these and 45 other members except piles in a like manner .
Where an excessive number of smaller voids 46 exist in any member , the Engineer requires a similar repair .
47 Section 1078 10-146 Repair honeycomb , excessively large fins , and other projections as directed .
Submit , at no 1 additional cost to the Department , a proposal for repairing members with honeycomb , cracks 2 or spalls .
Do not repair members containing honeycomb , cracks , or spalls until a repair 3 procedure is approved and the member is inspected by the Engineer .
Any appreciable 4 impairment of structural adequacy that can not be repaired to the satisfaction of the Engineer is 5 cause for rejection .
6 Clean and fill holes caused by strand hold downs upon removal from the casting bed .
Use 7 patches of materials approved by the Engineer that develop strength at least equal to the 8 minimum 28 day strength requirement for the concrete before approval of the member .
9 Ensure that members are clean and surfaces have a uniform appearance .
10 Give the top surface of prestressed concrete panels a raked finish or other approved finish to 11 provide an adequate bond with the cast-in-place concrete .
As soon as the condition of the 12 concrete permits , rake the top surface of the concrete making depressions of approximately 13 1/4 inch .
Take care when raking not to catch and pull the coarse aggregate .
14 Clean reinforcing bars exposed on the tops of girders and exterior cored slabs or box beams of 15 mortar build up and excessive rust .
16 Apply epoxy protective coating to the ends of prestressed members as noted in the plans .

19 Section 1079 10-154 1079-2 ELASTOMERIC BEARINGS 1 ( A ) General 2 Provide elastomeric bearings that meet the requirements of AASHTO M251 , except as 3 specified herein .
4 Manufacturers shall be pre-qualified by the Department and shall submit working 5 drawings for approval .
Refer to Subarticles 1079-2 ( D ) and 1079-2 ( E ) .
Furnish a Type 3 6 certification in accordance with Article 106-3 certifying that elastomeric bearings satisfy 7 this Specification and all design criteria .
Include the lot number , description and test 8 results in the certification .
9 ( B ) Elastomer Properties 10 The elastomer for all bearings shall be classified as Grade 3 .
11 The shear modulus of the elastomer for laminated ( reinforced ) bearings shall be 160 psi , 12 unless otherwise noted in the plans .
13 Provide Grade 50 or Grade 60 durometer hardness elastomer in all ( unreinforced ) 14 bearings , unless otherwise noted in the plans .
15 ( C ) Testing 16 The optional test procedures of AASHTO M 251 are not required , except as specified 17 herein .
18 Determine the shear modulus of the elastomer for laminated ( reinforced ) bearings in 19 accordance with ASTM D4014 .
20 At the Manufacturer 's option , plain ( unreinforced ) bearings may be tested using the 21 methods of Appendices X1 and X2 of AASHTO M 251 .
22 Test at least two bearings per lot or as directed by the Engineer .
Define a “ lot ” as a group 23 of 100 or less bearings with or without holes or slots , which are : 24 ( 1 ) Manufactured in a reasonably continuous manner from the same batch of elastomer 25 and cured under the same conditions , and 26 ( 2 ) Of the same type ( plain or laminated ) and of similar size ( no dimensions shall vary 27 by more than 40 % ) .
28 A lot may include bearings from multiple projects and purchasers .
29 ( D ) Working Drawings 30 Submit six sets of detailed fabrication drawings of laminated ( reinforced ) bearings to the 31 Engineer for review , comments and acceptance .
Show complete details and all material 32 specifications .
Clearly identify any proposed deviations from details shown in the plans 33 or requirements of the Standard Specifications .
Obtain drawing approval before 34 manufacturing of the bearings .
35 Section 1080 10-155 SECTION 1080 PAINT AND PAINT MATERIALS 1 1080-1 GENERAL 2 All batches or lots of paint products shall be Department approved prior to use .
Self-curing 3 inorganic zinc paint shall also be pre-qualified as required in Section 1080-5 .
Deliver all 4 Department approved paints to the point of application in sealed and original containers 5 clearly marked with the type of paint and batch or lot numbers clearly labeled on the 6 container .
At the point of application all paints shall arrive ready to be mixed for use without 7 additional oil or thinner .
Mix all paints in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s printed 8 instructions .
All paints or paint components that harden or curdle in the container and will not 9 break up with a paddle to form a smooth , uniform consistency will be rejected .
Any thinning 10 necessitated by weather conditions shall be approved in writing and use only those thinners 11 approved by the manufacturer .
Thinning of any waterborne paints shall be prohibited .
Upon 12 receipt at the point of application , store all paint materials in a moisture free environment 13 between 40°F and 110°F or at such temperatures within this range recommended by the 14 manufacturer of which the more stringent shall apply .
The storage areas shall be equipped 15 with a device capable of recording daily high and low temperatures .

21 22 1080-12 ABRASIVE MATERIALS FOR BLAST CLEANING STEEL Select the gradation of the abrasive to impart the anchor profile specified .

shop or contractor ) , shall 29 provide the Department with the abrasive conformance testing certificate as required in 30 SSPC AB-1 and perform field quality control testing immediately prior to use at the 31 minimum frequency specified in SSPC AB-1 .
32 ( B ) Ferrous Metallic Abrasives 33 Ferrous metallic abrasives are new and previously unused material .
The end user 34 e.g .
shot or contractor ) of the abrasive shall provide the Department with the abrasive 35 conformance testing certificate as required by SSPC AB-3 and perform the abrasive 36 cleanliness testing and conductivity testing immediately prior to use when not recorded 37 on the manufacturer ’ s certification .
The frequency for this testing is once per 55 gallon 38 barrel of abrasive .
39 Section 1081 10-163 ( C ) Cleanliness of Recyclable Ferrous Metallic Abrasives 1 Shop facilities shall annually acquire a composite sample of their recycled abrasive ( work 2 mix ) in the Department ’ s presence .
A composite sample is a mixture of individual samples 3 taken from a minimum of three separate areas of the work mix .
The composite sample is to be 4 tested at an accredited laboratory and provide the Department with a TCLP analysis and 5 sulfate and chloride testing .
The shop shall provide annually , the Department with a notarized 6 Type 3 certification certifying the plant location has not used their facilities or equipment for 7 the removal of lead based coatings .
Prior to starting work , field contractors recycled work 8 mix used shall meet the requirements of SSPC AB-2 prior to first use for each Department 9 project .
10 Shop and Field Contractors cleaned work mix shall meet the requirements of SSPC AB-2 and 11 maintain the size and shape of the abrasive to impart the specified profile .
The quality control 12 inspector shall document and test the cleaned work mix prior to starting work once every 13 12 hours or once every work shift whichever period is shorter .
Abrasive testing shall meet 14 and be performed in accordance with SSPC AB-2 , ASTM D4940 ( Water Soluble 15 Contaminants ) , ASTM D7393 ( Oil Content ) , SSPC PA-17 ( Particle Size Distribution ) and the 16 Contract documents .
17 Nonconforming work mix shall not be used , shall be removed from equipment and shall be 18 disposed of in accordance with federal , state , and local regulations and project specification 19 requirements .
If non-compliant work mix is detected during continuous recycling following 20 three failing testing attempts blasting and handling equipment shall be checked for residual 21 contamination after removal of the contaminated media .
Following cleaning , new compliant 22 media should be fed through the equipment and shall be tested for compliance with 23 requirements of SSPC-AB 2 before production work resumes .
24 25 1080-13 FIELD PERFORMANCE AND SERVICE Do not use paint products inspected by the Engineer and found to exhibit poor performance in 26 similar North Carolina environments .
Poor performance is defined as any coating failing to 27 meet ASTM D610 , Grade 5 , or having greater than 3 % rusting or disbonding before attaining 28 5 years of service .
29 SECTION 1081 30 EPOXY AND ADHESIVES 31 1081-1 EPOXY RESIN SYSTEMS 32 ( A ) Classification 33 The types of epoxies and their uses are as shown below : 34 Type 1 - A low-modulus , non-sag gel adhesive used to bond or repair damp , vertical or 35 overhead surfaces .
Typical applications include walls , concrete foundations , concrete 36 pipe , conduit and ceilings .
37 Type 2 - A low-modulus , general-purpose adhesive used in epoxy mortar repairs .
It may 38 be used to patch spalled , cracked or broken concrete where vibration , shock or expansion 39 and contraction are expected .
Feather-edged patching is not recommended with this 40 material ; instead , the adjacent concrete perimeter should be sawed at least 1/4 inch to 41 1/2 inch deep and any remaining concrete chipped away to provide a vertical interface 42 between the epoxy mortar and concrete .
43 Type 3 - A high-modulus general-purpose adhesive used to bond plastic concrete or 44 hardened concrete to hardened concrete or other structural materials .
It may be used to 45 produce a high-strength epoxy mortar grout bed for equipment or to patch interior spalls , 46 cracks or broken concrete .
It is not recommended for exterior patching because its rate of 47 thermal expansion and contraction differs too greatly from concrete .
It may be used for 48 anchoring bolts where a flowable adhesive is required .
49 Section 1081 10-164 Type 3A - A gel-like version of Type 3 , used specifically for embedding dowel bars , 1 threaded rods , rebars and other fixtures in hardened concrete .
2 Type 4A - A gray protective coating for concrete , wood , steel and other structural 3 materials .
It is typically used as a topcoat in waterproofing concrete exposed to splash 4 zones and tidal water .
5 Type 4B - A red primer coating used with Type 4A .
6 Type 5 - A high modulus , low viscosity adhesive suitable for pressure injection into 7 cracks in concrete .
For some non-structural crack repairs , Type 5 epoxy may be poured 8 on the surface to penetrate cracks by gravity .
This may be beneficial before 9 waterproofing and skid proofing .
10 ( B ) Requirements 11 Epoxies shall conform to the requirements shown in Table 1081-1 using the test methods 12 described in Article 1081-3 .
13 For epoxy resin systems used for embedding dowel bars , threaded rods , rebar , anchor 14 bolts and other fixtures in hardened concrete , the manufacturer shall submit test results 15 showing that the bonding system will obtain 125 % of the specified required yield 16 strength of the fixture .
Furnish certification that , for the particular bolt grade , diameter 17 and embedment depth required , the anchor system will not fail by adhesive failure and 18 that there is no movement of the anchor bolt .
For certification and anchorage , use 19 3,000 psi as a minimum Portland cement concrete compressive strength used in this test .
20 Use adhesives that meet Section 1081 .
21 List the properties of the adhesive on the container and include density , minimum and 22 maximum temperature application , setting time , shelf life , pot life , shear strength and 23 compressive strength .
24 ( C ) Properties of Epoxy Resin Systems 25 ( 1 ) All integral fillers , pigments and thixotropic agents shall be fine enough to not 26 separate , settle or cause skinning during storage of the epoxy components .
Do not 27 use abrasive fillers such as alumina and silica flour .
Do not use solvents .
When 28 mineral fillers are to be added during mixing , they shall be inert , readily dispersible 29 and except for sand , have fineness such that 99 % of the material will pass 30 a No .
325 sieve .
31 ( 2 ) The coefficient of expansion of cured epoxy is 6 times greater than that of concrete .
32 Therefore , to reduce spalling and peeling during temperature changes , avoid thick 33 layers of pure epoxy .
A 4:1 by weight sand-epoxy mortar has approximately the 34 same coefficient of expansion as concrete .
35 ( 3 ) The shelf life of parts A and B shall be at least one year from the date of 36 manufacture .
37 ( 4 ) Types 1 through 5 epoxy resin systems are moisture insensitive and can be applied 38 on clean , dry or damp surfaces free of standing water .

8 Section 1081 10-166 ( 3 ) Compressive Strength of Epoxy Mortar 1 Determine the compressive strength of epoxy mortar in accordance with 2 ASTM C109 except as follows : 3 Use mortar consisting of one part epoxy and 3 parts standard graded Ottawa sand 4 except for Types 1 and 3A , which shall be tested neat .
Mix epoxy 5 components A and B at the recommended proportions for 2 minutes , add the sand , 6 and mix for 3 minutes .
Pour the mortar into the cube molds in two layers , and tamp 7 each layer 50 times with a spatula and 25 times with a hammer handle .
Make 8 six specimens , and cure all in air at 77°F ± 2°F for 24 hours .
Test three specimens 9 for compressive strength at the end of this curing period .
Immerse the remaining 10 three specimens in water at + 77°F for 6 days , after which immediately test them for 11 compressive strength in the wet condition .
12 ( 4 ) Tensile Strength and Tensile Elongation 13 Determine the tensile strength and tensile elongation of the mixture in accordance 14 with ASTM D638 .
15 ( 5 ) Absorption 16 Determine the water absorption of the mixture in accordance with ASTM D570 .
17 ( 6 ) Bond Strength 18 Determine the bond strength of the moist-cured mixture at 14 days by the slant shear 19 test in accordance with ASTM C882 .

7 ( G ) Supply 8 Supply epoxy resin in two components , labeled as “ Component A - Contains Epoxy 9 Resin ” and “ Component B - Contains Curing Agent ” , for combining immediately before 10 use in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s instructions .
Mark each container with the 11 manufacturer ’ s name , NCDOT type , lot or batch number , quantity , date of manufacture , 12 shelf life or expiration date , color , mixing instructions , usable temperature range and 13 hazards or safety precautions .
14 Furnish the two components in separate non-reactive containers .
Provide containers of 15 such size that the proportions of the final mix can be obtained by combining a single 16 container of one component with one or more whole containers of the other component .
17 ( H ) Notes on Use of Epoxies 18 ( 1 ) Safety 19 Epoxies can irritate the eyes , skin and respiratory tract .
Therefore , wear chemical 20 splash goggles , chemically-resistant gloves and protective clothing and boots when 21 handling epoxies .
Respiratory protection is usually not needed if epoxies are mixed 22 and applied in well-ventilated areas , but avoid prolonged breathing of vapors .
23 Follow all MSDS instructions for proper use of these materials .
24 ( 2 ) Mixing 25 Stir parts A and B individually until each component is homogeneous .
Use a separate 26 stirrer for each component .
27 Combine parts A and B , either by weight or volume , as specified in the 28 manufacturer ’ s instructions .
Stir the mixture vigorously , periodically scraping the 29 sides and bottom of the container .
Small quantities of epoxy usually require 2 to 30 3 minutes to mix homogeneously ; 5-gallon quantities can take up to 10 minutes of 31 mixing .
32 Temperature affects the viscosity and pot life of epoxies .
Most laboratory tests are 33 conducted at 77°F .
Higher temperatures render epoxies thinner and faster setting ; 34 lower temperatures induce higher viscosities and longer pot lives .
35 Add sand or other fillers to liquid epoxies only after parts A and B have been 36 thoroughly mixed .
Stir in the sand or filler until all particles are completely coated .
37 ( 3 ) Storage and Substrate Temperature 38 Store epoxies at temperatures between 50°F and 90°F .
Epoxy components exposed 39 to the extremes of this range or outside this range should be conditioned to 77°F 40 before mixing and blending .
If heat is necessary , always use indirect methods such 41 as hot water , a heated room or a microwave oven to condition components .
42 When applying epoxy to a cold substrate , preheat the components approximately 1°F 43 above 77°F for every 2°F of substrate temperature below 77°F .
44 Seal previously opened containers to be airtight .
Unsealed containers can absorb 45 moisture from the atmosphere , which can alter the chemical reaction of the mixture .
46 Section 1081 10-168 1081-2 POLYESTER RESIN EPOXY ADHESIVE 1 ( A ) General 2 Polyester resin is used specifically for embedding dowel bars , threaded rods , rebars and 3 other fixtures in hardened concrete .
4 Have the manufacturer submit test results showing that the bonding system will obtain 5 125 % of the specified yield strength of the anchor fixture in concrete with a minimum 6 compressive strength of 3,000 psi .
Field testing may be required for adhesively anchored 7 fixtures .

A self-contained cartridge or capsule 14 will consist of two components which will be automatically mixed as they are dispensed , 15 as in the case of a cartridge , or drilled into , as in the case of a capsule .
16 Clearly label each container with the manufacturer ’ s name ; date of manufacture ; batch 17 number ; batch expiration date ; all directions for use and such warning of precautions 18 concerning the contents as may be required by Federal or State laws and regulations .

100 100 % - ( B ) Test Methods 1 ( 1 ) Flow 2 Determine flow according to Section 6 of ASTM D5329 with the exception that the 3 oven temperature shall be 158°F ± 2°F and sample preparation done according to 4 Section 7.1 of ASTM D5 .
5 ( 2 ) Viscosity 6 Viscosity is to be determined according to ASTM D2669 or ASTM D4402 using 7 a spindle speed of 10 rpm .
Heat the adhesive to approximately 410°F and allowed to 8 cool .
Determine viscosity at 400°F ± 1°F .
9 ( 3 ) Asphalt Properties 10 Properties of the base asphalt are to be determined on the material obtained from the 11 following extraction and Abson recovery methods .
Extract the asphalt by heating the 12 adhesive just to the point where it will easily flow and then transfer 125 to 150 g into 13 400 ml of trichloroethylene with a temperature of 125°F to 150°F .
Thoroughly stir 14 this mixture to dissolve the asphalt .
Decant the trichloroethylene-asphalt mixture 15 decanted and the asphalt recovered using the Abson recovery method , ASTM D1856 16 as modified by the following .
The extraction methods of ASTM D2172 do not apply 17 and there will be no filtration of the solvent asphalt mixture .
The extraction solution 18 of trichloroethylene and asphalt shall be centrifuged for at least 30 minutes at 19 770 times gravity in a batch centrifuge .
Decant this solution in the distillation flask , 20 taking care not to include any filler sediment .
Apply heat and bubble carbon dioxide 21 solution slowly to bring the solution temperature to 300°F .
At this point the carbon 22 dioxide flow is increased to 800 ml to 900 ml per minute .
The solution temperature 23 is maintained at 320°F to 335°F with this carbon dioxide flow for at least 20 minutes 24 and until the trichloroethylene vapors have been completely removed from the 25 distillation flask .
Repeat the above extraction-recovery method as necessary to 26 obtain the desired quantity of asphalt .
Use the asphalt recovered to determine 27 penetration , 275°F viscosity , and 275°F viscosity ratio .
28 ( 4 ) Viscosity Ratio 29 Determine the 275°F viscosity ratio by comparing the 275°F viscosity on the base 30 asphalt before and after the thin-film oven test .
Perform the thin-film oven test in 31 accordance with ASTM D1754 .
Determine the specific gravity by pycnometer as in 32 ASTM D70 for use in the thin-film oven test .
Calculate the 275°F viscosity ratio by 33 dividing the viscosity after the thin-film oven test by the original 275°F viscosity .
34 ( 5 ) Filler Material 35 Separate the filler material from the asphalt to determine Filler Content and Filler 36 Fineness .
Determine the portion by weight of the adhesive insoluble in 37 1,1,1 trichloroethane by weighing 10.00 ± 0.01 grams of solid adhesive into 38 Section 1081 10-170 a centrifuge flask with approximately 100 ml volume such as that specified in 1 ASTM D1796 .
Add 50 ml of 1,1,1-trichloroethane to the adhesive , which should be 2 broken up in small pieces to speed up the dissolution solids .
Place the sample flask 3 in a balanced centrifuge and spin using a minimum relative centrifugal force of 4 150 in accordance with ASTM D1796 for 10 minutes .
Remove the sample flask and 5 decant the solid , taking care not to lose any solids .
Repeat the application of solvent 6 and centrifuging until the solvent becomes clear and the filler is visually free of 7 asphalt .
Dry the filler at 160°F ± 5°F to remove solvent and weigh the resulting 8 filler .
Filtration of the decanted solvent may be performed to verify there is no loss 9 of filler .
Percent filler content is calculated as follows : 10 Filter Content , % by Weight = Filler Weight , grams x 100 Original Adhesive Weight , grams Determine Filler Fineness according to ASTM C430 using number 325 , 200 and 11 100 sieves .
This method is to be modified by using a water soluble non-ionic 12 wetting agent , such as Triton X-100 , to aid the wetting action .
Concentration of the 13 surfactant solution shall be approximately 1 % by weight .
Thoroughly wet the one- 14 gram dry sample in the surfactant solution and allowed to soak for 30 minutes .
15 Transfer the filler completely into the sieve cup and apply water spray for 2 minutes .
16 Surfactant solution may be added as needed and physical means used to disperse any 17 clumped particles .
Dry the sample and handle as described in ASTM C430 .
18 ( C ) Prequalification 19 Bituminous adhesives are required to be pre-qualified by the Department ’ s 20 Transportation-Traffic Engineering Branch .
Interested parties shall submit a sample to 21 a qualified independent testing laboratory for testing in accordance with 22 Subarticle 1081-3 ( A ) at no cost to the Department .
Submit a Type 2 materials 23 certification in accordance with Article 106-3 with the results and the name of the testing 24 laboratory along with a qualification sample ( s ) of the same lot to the Department for 25 evaluation .
For more information on the pre-qualification process , contact the 26 Work Zone Traffic Control Unit .

to 60 lbs .
and contain two to four 30 subcompartments .

32 ( E ) Certification 33 A certification from the manufacturer showing the physical properties of the bituminous 34 adhesive and conformance with the Specifications shall be required before use .
35 ( F ) Application 36 Apply the adhesive according to the manufacturer ’ s requirements and the following 37 requirements .
38 Apply the adhesive when the road surface , ambient air and pavement marker 39 temperatures are in the range of 50°F to 160°F on dry pavement .
40 The composition of the adhesive shall be such that its properties will not deteriorate when 41 heated to and applied at temperatures up to 425°F using either air or oil-jacketed melters .
42 Melt and heat the bituminous adhesive in either thermostatically controlled double boiler 43 type units using heat transfer oil or thermostatically controlled electric heating pots .
Do 44 not use direct flame units .
45 Section 1081 10-171 Heat the adhesive to between 375°F and 425°F and applied directly to the pavement 1 surface from the melter/applicator by either pumping or pouring .
Maintain the 2 application temperature between 375°F and 425°F as lower temperatures may result in 3 decreased adhesion while higher temperatures may damage the adhesive .
4 Use sufficient adhesive to insure total contact with the entire bottom of the pavement 5 marker .
Apply pavement markers to the adhesive immediately ( within 5 seconds ) to 6 assure bonding .
Place the pavement marker in position by applying downward pressure 7 until the marker is firmly seated with the required adhesive thickness and squeeze-out .
8 Remove excessive adhesive squeeze-out from the pavement and immediately remove 9 adhesive on the exposed surfaces of pavement markers .
Soft rags with mineral spirits 10 conforming to Federal Specifications TT-T-291 or kerosene may be used if necessary , to 11 remove adhesive from exposed faces of pavement markers .
No other solvent may be 12 used .
13 Do not waste or spill any excess adhesive on Department right of way .
Remove and 14 properly dispose of any adhesive spilled or dumped at such location .
The Contractor , at 15 no cost to the Department , shall correct any damage incurred to the Department , highway 16 or appurtenances as a result of misplaced adhesive .
17 The adhesive may be reheated and reused .
However , the pot life at application 18 temperatures shall not exceed the manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
19 Clean out of equipment and tanks may be performed using petroleum solvents such as 20 diesel fuel or similar materials .
All solvents shall be removed from the equipment tanks 21 and lines before the next use of the melter .
22 1081-4 EPOXY RESIN ADHESIVE FOR BONDING TRAFFIC MARKERS 23 ( A ) General 24 This section covers epoxy resin adhesive for bonding traffic markers to pavement 25 surfaces .
26 ( B ) Classification 27 The types of epoxies and their uses are as shown below : 28 Type I 29 Rapid Setting , High Viscosity , Epoxy Adhesive .
This type of adhesive provides rapid 30 adherence to traffic markers to the surface of pavement .
31 Type II 32 Standard Setting , High Viscosity , Epoxy Adhesive .
This type of adhesive is 33 recommended for adherence of traffic markers to pavement surfaces when rapid set is not 34 required .
35 Type III 36 Rapid Setting , Low Viscosity , Water Resistant , Epoxy Adhesive .
This type of rapid 37 setting adhesive , due to tis low viscosity , is appropriate only for use with embedded 38 traffic markers .
39 Type IV 40 Standard Set Epoxy for Blade Deflecting-Type Plowable Markers .
41 ( C ) Requirements 42 Epoxies shall conform to the requirements set for in AASHTO M237 .

Uniformly disperse the pigment , beads , 6 media and filler in the binder .
7 The Alkyd/maleic binder shall consist of a mixture of synthetic resins ( at least one 8 synthetic resin shall be solid at room temperature ) and a high boiling point plasticizers .
9 At least 1/2 of the binder composition shall be 100 % maleic-modified glycerol of resin 10 and be no less than 15 % by weight of the entire material formulation .
The binder shall 11 contain no petroleum hydrocarbon resins .
Use resins/rosins that are maleic-modified 12 glycerol esters .
13 The thermoplastic material shall be free of contaminates and be homogeneously dry- 14 blended or hot mixed from 100 % virgin stock using no reprocessed materials , ( excluding 15 the requirement to use reprocessed glass ) .
16 The thermoplastic material shall not deteriorate or discolor when held at the application 17 temperatures for at least 4 hours or upon repeated reheating ( at least 4 times ) .
18 The color , viscosity and chemical properties versus temperature characteristics of the 19 thermoplastic material shall remain constant for up to 4 hours at the application 20 temperature and be the same from batch to batch .
21 The thermoplastic material shall be readily applicable at temperatures between 400°F and 22 440°F from the approved equipment to produce lines and symbols of the required above 23 the pavement thickness .
24 ( D ) Cold Applied Plastic Composition 25 The cold applied plastic pavement marking shall consist of a mixture of high quality 26 polymeric materials , pigments and glass beads distributed throughout its base cross- 27 sectional area , with a reflective layer of beads bonded to the top surface .
28 The cold applied plastic markings shall adhere to the pavement by a pressure-sensitive 29 pre-coated adhesive .
30 The cold applied plastic shall conform to pavement contours , breaks , faults , etc .
through 31 the action of traffic at normal pavement temperatures .
The film shall have resealing 32 characteristics such that it is capable of fusing with itself and previously applied marking 33 tape of the same composition under normal conditions of use .
The cold applied plastic 34 pavement marking shall be patchable .

37038 1087-4 GLASS BEADS 39 ( A ) Composition 40 The silica content of the glass beads shall be at least 60 % .
41 Manufacture the beads from 100 % recycled non-pigmented glass from a composition 42 designed to be highly resistant to traffic wear and to the effects of weathering .
All 43 Section 1087 10-182 standard intermix and drop-on glass beads shall be manufactured using 100 % North 1 American recycled glass cullet .
2 All intermixed and drop-on glass beads shall not contain more than 75 ppm arsenic or 3 200 ppm lead .
4 ( B ) Physical Characteristics 5 Use glass beads that are colorless , clean , transparent and free from milkiness , excessive 6 air bubbles , skins and foreign objects .
Use glass beads with a minimum refractive index 7 of 1.50 when tested by the liquid immersion method at 77°F ± 9°F in accordance with 8 ASTM D1214 using the Becke Line Method or an equivalent method .
Use glass beads 9 that are spherical in shape and essentially free of sharp angular particles or particles 10 showing surface scarring or scratching .
11 All intermixed and drop-on glass beads shall comply with NCGS § 136-30.2 and 23 USC 12 § 109 ( r ) .
13 ( C ) Gradation & Roundness 14 Use drop-on and intermixed glass beads in all pavement markings with at least 80 % true 15 spheres when tested in accordance with ASTM D1155 .
Drop-on and intermixed glass 16 beads used on any pavement markings shall meet Table 1087-2 .
17 TABLE 1087-2 GLASS BEAD GRADATION REQUIREMENTS Sieve Size Gradation Requirements Minimum Maximum Passing # 20 100 % -- Retained on # 30 5 % 10 % Retained on # 50 40 % 80 % Retained on # 80 15 % 40 % Passing # 80 0 % 5 % Retained on # 200 0 % 5 % ( D ) Chemical Resistance 18 Conduct the following chemical resistance test on all glass beads : 19 Place 3 to 5 g portions of the same glass bead batch to be tested in three separate glass 20 beakers or three porcelain dishes .
Cover one sample with distilled water , cover the 21 second sample with 3N solution of sulfuric acid and cover the third sample with 50 % 22 solution of sodium sulfides .
After one hour of immersion , examine the glass bead 23 samples microscopically for evidence of darkening or frosting .
All three samples shall 24 show no evidence of darkening or frosting .
25 ( E ) Moisture Resistance 26 Conduct the following moisture resistance test on drop-on glass beads : 27 Place a 2 lb .
minimum sample of glass beads in a clean , washed cotton bag with a thread 28 count of 50 warp , 50 woof .
Immerse the bag containing the sample in a container of 29 water for 30 seconds or until the water covers the spheres , whichever is longer .
Remove 30 the bag from water and force excess water from the sample by squeezing the bag .
31 Suspend the bag and allow to drain for 2 hours at room temperature 70°F to 72°F .
Then 32 mix the sample in the bag by shaking thoroughly .
Transfer the sample slowly to a clean 33 dry glass funnel having a stem of 4 inches in length with 1/4 inch inside diameter .
The 34 entire sample shall flow freely through the funnel without stoppage .
When first 35 introduced in the funnel , if the spheres clog , it is permissible to lightly tap the funnel to 36 start the flow .

14 1087-7 TESTS TO BE PERFORMED 15 When independent test laboratory tests are required , perform them on samples taken by 16 an agency certified by the Department from the same process , batch or lot number as the 17 material shipped to the project .
The test reports shall contain the lot number .
Use Department 18 approved independent test laboratories .
19 Perform the following tests on thermoplastic pavement marking materials , intermixed glass 20 beads and drop-on glass beads unless prescribed otherwise by the Engineer : 21 ( A ) Intermixed and Drop-on Glass Beads 22 Use X-ray Fluorescence for the normal sampling procedure for intermixed and drop-on 23 beads , without crushing , to check for any levels of arsenic and lead .
If any arsenic or 24 lead is detected , the sample shall be crushed and repeat the testing using X-ray 25 Fluorescence .
If the X-ray Fluorescence test shows more than LOD of 5 ppm , test the 26 beads using United States Environmental Protection Agency Method 6010B , 6010C or 27 3052 for no more than 75 ppm arsenic or 200 ppm lead .

32 ( 4 ) % Glass Beads tested in accordance with ASTM D4797 .
33 Except ash , use a 100 gram sample rather than a 10 gram sample to allow for testing of 34 gradation and percent of rounds .
Provide the results of sieve analysis and % rounds .
35 ( C ) Flash Point 36 The thermoplastic shall have a flashpoint of no less than 500°F when tested in 37 accordance with ASTM D92 COC .
38 ( D ) Requirements 39 The thermoplastic material after heating for 240 ± 5 minutes at 425 ± 3°F and cooled to 40 77 ± 3°F shall meet the following : 41 Section 1087 10-184 ( 1 ) Color 1 ( a ) White 2 Daylight reflectance 2° Standard observer and CIE illuminant 3 Using XYZ scale D65/10° - 80 % minimum 4 ASTM E1349 5 Yellowness Index - The white thermoplastic shall not exceed a yellowness index 6 of 0.12 7 ( b ) Yellow 8 Daylight reflectance at 2° Standard observer and CIE illuminant 9 Using XYZ scale D65/10° - 45 % minimum =Y 10 ASTM E1349 11 ( 2 ) Bond Strength 12 The bond strength shall be 200 psi or greater in accordance with ASTM D4796 .
13 ( 3 ) Cracking Resistance at Low Temperatures 14 After applying a 4 inches , 125 mil draw-down to concrete blocks and cooling to 15 ± 15 3°F , the material shall show no cracks at an observation distance of 12 inches .
16 ( 4 ) Specific Gravity 17 The specific gravity shall be 1.95-2.20 in accordance with ASTM D792 .
18 ( 5 ) Softening Point 19 The softening point shall be 215 ± 15°F in accordance with ASTM D36 .
20 ( 6 ) Drying Time 21 When applied at a thickness of 125 mils , the material shall set to bear traffic in no 22 more than 2 minutes when air and substrate temperature is 50°F ± 3°F ( and no more 23 than 10 minutes when the air and substrate temperature is 90°F ± 3°F when applied 24 at temperature of 412.5 ± 12.5°F in accordance with AASHTO T 250 .
25 ( 7 ) Alkyd Binder Determination 26 The thermoplastic material shall immediately dissolve in diacetone alcohol .
Slow 27 dissolution is evidence of the presence of hydrocarbon binder components .

load applied shall be between 40 and 30 75 units after 15 seconds at 115°F in accordance with ASTM D2240 .

9 ( B ) Reflective Elements 10 ( 1 ) Prismatic Plastic Type 11 ( a ) General 12 Use an acrylic plastic prismatic reflector hermetically sealed to an acrylic plastic 13 back .
The reflector shall consist of a clear and transparent face , herein referred 14 to as a lens , with an acrylic plastic back fused to the lens under heat pressure 15 around the entire perimeter of the lens .

25 TABLE 1088-1 OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF PRISMATIC PLASTIC TYPE REFLECTORS Observation Angle ( Degrees ) Entrance Angle ( Degrees ) Minimum Specific Intensity ( Candlepower per Footcandle ) Crystal Yellow Red 0.1° 0° 119 71 29 0.1° 15° 119 28 -- 0.1° 20° 47 28 11 0.1° 35° 50 30 -- Locate the prismatic plastic type reflector to be tested at a distance of 100 feet 26 from a single light source having an effective diameter of 2 inches operate the 27 light source at approximately normal efficiency .
Measure the return light from 28 the reflector by a photoelectric photometer having a minimum sensitivity 29 of 1 x 10 footcandles per mm scale division .

34 Section 1088 10-186 If a test distance other than 100 feet is used , modify the source and aperture 1 dimensions , and the distance between source and aperture , in the same 2 proportion as the test distance .
3 ( c ) Durability 4 ( i ) Seal Test 5 Use the following test to determine if a reflector is adequately sealed 6 against dust and water : 7 Submerge 50 samples in water at room temperature .
Subject the submerged 8 samples to a vacuum of 5 inches gauge for 5 minutes .
Restore atmospheric 9 pressure and leave the samples submerged for 5 minutes , then examine the 10 samples for water intake .
Evidence of any water is a failure .
Failure of 11 more than 2 % of the number tested will be cause for rejection .
12 ( ii ) Heat Resistance Test 13 Test three reflectors for 4 hours in a circulating air oven at 175°+5°F .
Place 14 the test specimens in a horizontal position on a grid or perforated shelf , 15 permitting free air circulation .
At the conclusion of the test , remove the 16 samples from the oven and permit them to cool in air to room temperature .
17 The samples , after exposure to heat , shall show no change in shape and 18 general appearance when compared with unexposed control standards .
Any 19 failures will be cause for rejection .

Straight is 39 defined as no point along its length any more than 1 inch away from a perfectly straight 40 edge placed longitudinally along any side of the post .

25 ( a ) Sandbag Ballast Method 26 Supply a sandbag with 50 lb .
of sand with each drum .
Place the sandbag inside 27 the body on top of the detachable base .
Upon impact the main body of the drum 28 shall deform and become detached from the base , allowing vehicles to easily 29 pass over the remaining base .
30 ( b ) Tire Sidewall Ballast Method 31 Design the base of the drums to accommodate no more than two tire sidewalls 32 that when combined will have a weight of at least 30 lb and no more than 50 lb .
33 Use the manufacturer ’ s required tire sidewall ballast .
Upon impact the main 34 body of the drum shall deform and become detached from the tire sidewalls , 35 allowing vehicles to easily pass over the tire sidewall ballasts .
36 ( c ) Preformed Weighted Base Ballast Method 37 Supply a preformed base specifically designed for the model drum .
The weight 38 of each drum ’ s preformed base will be self-certified by the manufacturers .
Each 39 drum with preformed bases shall be approved by the Work Zone Traffic Control 40 Unit .
Upon impact , the main body of the drum shall deform and become 41 detached from the base allowing vehicles to easily pass over the remaining base .
42 ( 5 ) Material Certification 43 Furnish a Type 3 material certification in accordance with Article 106-3 for all new 44 drums and a Type 7 material certification for all used drums before use .
45 ( 6 ) Approval 46 All materials are subject to the approval of the Engineer .
47 Section 1089 10-194 ( B ) Skinny Drums 1 ( 1 ) General 2 Provide skinny drums composed of a body , alternating orange and white stripes of 3 Type III-High Intensity or higher prismatic retroreflective sheeting and ballasts 4 evaluated by NTPEP .
5 ( 2 ) Body 6 Provide a skinny drum made of orange , impact resistant , ultraviolet plastic material 7 capable of maintaining its integrity upon impact throughout a temperature range of 8 - 20°F to 125°F .
When struck , the skinny drum shall not permanently distort to 9 a degree that would prevent reuse , nor roll excessively after impact .
Design the 10 skinny drum to prevent water from accumulating and freezing in the top or bottom .
11 Provide a skinny drum that is cylindrical in shape with the following dimensions ; 12 a minimum height of 42 inches , a minimum top outer diameter of 4 inches and a 13 bottom outer diameter of 7.5 inches .
The top outer diameter shall not exceed the 14 bottom outside diameter .
Provide closed tops on drums to prevent accumulation of 15 debris .
16 ( 3 ) Retroreflective Stripes 17 Provide at least four retroreflective bands with two orange and two white alternating 18 horizontal circumferential bands for each skinny drum .
The top band shall always be 19 orange .
Use a 6 inch to 8 inch wide band Type III–High Intensity or higher 20 prismatic retroreflective sheeting that meets Article 1092-2 for each band .
Do not 21 exceed 2 inches for any non-retroreflective spaces between orange and white stripes .
22 Do not splice the retroreflective sheeting to create the 6 inch band .
Apply the 23 retroreflective sheeting directly to the skinny drum surface .
Do not apply the 24 retroreflective sheeting over a pre-existing layer of retroreflective sheeting .
Do not 25 place bands over any protruding corrugation areas .
No damage to the reflective 26 sheeting should result from stacking and unstacking the skinny drums , or vehicle 27 impact .
28 ( 4 ) Ballast 29 Ballast skinny drums using a preformed base specifically designed for the model 30 skinny drum .
Each base shall be at least 15 lb and circular or polygonal with equal 31 sides .
When properly ballasted , the skinny drums shall be wind resistant to the 32 extent of withstanding wind created by traffic under normal roadway conditions , 33 including high speed truck traffic in close proximity to the skinny drums .
Do not 34 place ballast on top of the drum .
Upon impact , the main body of the drum shall 35 deform and become detached from the base allowing vehicles to easily pass over the 36 remaining base .
37 ( 5 ) Material Certification 38 Furnish a Type 3 material certification in accordance with Article 106-3 for all new 39 skinny drums and a Type 7 material certification for all used skinny drums before 40 use .

The retroreflective 4 sheeting shall consist of white or colored sheeting having a smooth outer surface and the 5 property of a retroreflector over its entire surface .
6 Retroreflective sheeting shall meet ASTM D4956 and are listed on the NCDOT APL .
7 The reflective material specified herein is intended for use on surfaces of various traffic 8 control devices , including drums , barricades , traffic cones and highway signs , to assure their 9 adequate visibility at all times upon exposure to a light source when totally dry or wet .
10 Provide reflectorization that produces a wide-angle retroreflectivity , enhancing nighttime 11 visibility .
This retroreflective sheeting shall consist of encapsulated , enclosed lens or 12 prismatic with a transparent plastic having a smooth , flat outer surface .
Provide material that 13 is flexible , of good appearance , free from ragged edges , cracks and extraneous materials , and 14 exhibits good quality workmanship .

per yard or 24 greater .
Proportion the cross section so a moment of 1,450 ft-lb , applied to the cross 25 section normal to the flanges , will produce an extreme fiber stress no greater than 26 39,500 psi .
Use posts that weight 3 lbs/lf .
Punch or drill all posts with 3/8 inch diameter 27 holes on the centerline , spaced 1 inch on centers , starting 1 inch from the top and 28 extending to the bottom of the posts .

23 1098-8 INDUCTIVE DETECTION LOOPS 24 ( A ) Loop Sealant 25 Provide loop slot sealant that completely encapsulates loop wire when installed according 26 to manufacturer ’ s instructions .
Provide loop sealant that does not generate temperatures 27 greater than 220°F .
Ensure sealant bonds with asphalt and concrete pavement saw slots 28 so sealant and encapsulated loop wire do not come out of slot .
Ensure sealant is self- 29 leveling , but with sufficient viscosity to prevent exit from saw slot when installed along 30 a 10 % grade .
31 Provide sealant that protects loop wire by preventing the entrance of dirt , water , rocks , 32 sticks , and other debris into saw slot , and is resistant to traffic , water , gasoline , chemical 33 and chemical fumes , mild alkalis , oils and mild acids .
Ensure sealant will not be affected 34 by water and sealant does not chemically interact with pavement and loop wire 35 insulation .
36 Ensure loop sealant has sufficient flexibility to permit expected pavement expansion and 37 contraction due to weather and to permit pavement movement due to traffic without 38 cracking for a temperature range of -40 to 160°F .
39 Provide sealant with a usable life of at least ten minutes once mixed , when the ambient 40 temperature is 75°F .
Ensure sealant dries to tack free state in less than 2 hours , and does 41 not flow within or out of saw slot after exposed surface has become tack free .
Tack free 42 time will be determined by testing with a cotton ball until no sealant adheres to cotton 43 ball and no cotton adheres to sealant .
44 Section 1098 10-216 Ensure 2 part sealant cures within 48 hours to attain 95 % of published properties for the 1 cured material .
2 Ensure one part sealant cures within 30 days to attain 95 % of published properties for the 3 cured material .
