43 Furnish individual fibers manufactured from silica and dopant materials with each fiber 44 having a color coated finish that is compatible with local injection detection ( LID ) 45 devices .
Distinguish each fiber from others by color coding that meets EIA/TIA-598 .
46 Section 1098 10-217 Furnish single mode fiber that does not exceed attenuation ratings of 0.25 dB/km at 1 1550 nm and 0.35 dB/km at 1310 nm and complies with ITU G.652D and 2 IEC 60793-2-50 Type B.1.3 industry standards for low water peak , single mode fiber .
3 Provide fibers that are useable and with a surface , sufficiently free of imperfections and 4 inclusions to meet optical , mechanical and environmental requirements .
5 Ensure the core central strength member is a dielectric glass reinforced rod and that the 6 completed cable assembly has a maximum pulling rating of 600 lbf during installation 7 ( short term ) and 180 lbf long term installed .
8 Construct buffer tubes ( nominal size of 2.5 mm ) manufactured from a polypropylene 9 copolymer material to provide good kink resistance and allows the buffer tube to 10 maintain flexibility in cold temperature over the expected lifetime of the cable .
Ensure 11 that buffers tubes contain no more than 12 fibers per buffer tube unless specified 12 otherwise , and that all buffer tubes are filled with a water blocking gel or water swellable 13 material .
Construct the cable such that the buffer tubes are stranded around the central 14 strength member in a reverse oscillating arrangement to allow for mid-span entry .
15 Distinguish each buffer tube from others by color coding that meets EIA/TIA-598 .
Use 16 filler tubes to maintain a circular cross-section of the cable .
Ensure the filler tubes are the 17 same nominal size as the buffer tubes of 2.5 mm .
Apply binders ( water swellable yarn , 18 kevlar , etc . )
with sufficient tension to secure buffer tubes and filler tubes to the central 19 member without crushing the buffer tubes .
Ensure that binding material is 20 non-hygroscopic , non-wicking and dielectric with low shrinkage .
Ensure the binders are 21 of a high tensile strength that is helically stranded evenly around cable core .
22 Ensure the cable core is protected from the ingress of moisture by a water swellable 23 material or that is filled with a water blocking compound that is non-conductive .
Ensure 24 the water swellable material ( when activated ) or the water blocking compound is free 25 from dirt and foreign matter and is removable with conventional nontoxic solvents .

8 ECTION 1074 Section 1101 11-1 DIVISION 11 WORK ZONE TRAFFIC CONTROL SECTION 1101 1 WORK ZONE TRAFFIC CONTROL GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 2 1101-1 TRANSPORTATION MANAGEMENT PLAN ( TMP ) 3 Maintain traffic through work zones in accordance with these Specifications , the MUTCD , 4 Roadway Standard Drawings , 23 CFR 630 Subparts J and K and the Transportation 5 Management Plan ( TMP ) .
6 Below is a list of the possible TMP components : 7 ( A ) Temporary Traffic Control Plan ( TTC ) , 8 ( B ) Transportation Operations Plan ( TO ) , and 9 ( C ) Public Information Plan ( PI ) .
10 A TMP will always have a TTC component .
The TTC will contain the project notes , phasing , 11 detail sheets and other supporting information typically found in a TMP , per TMP Guidelines 12 found on the Department ’ s web site .
13 1101-2 TEMPORARY TRAFFIC CONTROL PLAN ( TTC ) 14 ( A ) General 15 Typically , phasing and drawings govern over project notes , and local notes govern over 16 general notes .
If a conflict arises in the TTC , refer to Article 105-4 .
17 ( B ) Phasing 18 Complete the requirements of each phase before proceeding to the next phase and the 19 requirements of each step before proceeding to the next step , unless the plans permit 20 work to be performed concurrently .
21 If a TTC phasing is broken into areas , work may be performed in more than one area 22 simultaneously as described in the plan .
23 ( C ) Project Notes 24 Two types of project notes may be included in the TTC : 25 ( 1 ) General Notes apply at all times during the project , and 26 ( 2 ) Local Notes apply only for the specific times and locations that they are referred to 27 in the phasing and detail sheets .
28 ( D ) Alternate to Transportation Management Plan 29 If desired , submit an alternate TMP a minimum of 30 calendar days in advance of the 30 anticipated implementation to allow for adequate review time .
Do not implement 31 alternate plans for traffic control until approved in writing and properly sealed .
32 No adjustment in compensation or extension of the completion date ( s ) will be allowed 33 due to the review time of the alternate .
If an alternate TMP is implemented , the 34 Contractor shall be responsible for any unanticipated changes to subsequent phases and 35 steps .
36 Section 1101 11-2 ( E ) Temporary Traffic Control Plan Not Fully Covered in the Contract 1 When the TTC does not cover a particular work function , notify the Engineer to allow for 2 the development or modification of a sealed set of the Temporary Traffic Control Plans .
3 1101-3 BLASTING ZONE 4 When blasting operations are within 1,000 feet of a travelway , provide the appropriate traffic 5 control as shown in the plans and/or the Roadway Standard Drawings .
6 1101-4 CONSTRUCTION VEHICLE CROSSINGS 7 Do not cross the median , ramps or loops with vehicles or equipment unless a specific location 8 for crossing is approved and required traffic control devices are used as shown in the 9 Roadway Standard Drawings .
10 1101-5 ON-ROAD CONSTRUCTION VEHICLES 11 When operating outside of a closed lane or haul road crossing in a work zone , on-road 12 construction vehicles are subject to the Department ’ s Division of Motor Vehicle weight and 13 safety regulations as commercial vehicles .
Work vehicles must always use warning lights 14 with at least 50 % being amber in color attached to the vehicle as high as possible and in a 15 manner such that they are not obscured by equipment or supplies .
Vehicle hazard signals or 16 lights may be used to supplement this requirement .
This requirement applies to all work 17 vehicles and equipment not inside lane closures or behind barriers .
This requirement does not 18 apply to dump trucks but it is encouraged .
19 1101-6 EXCAVATIONS WITHIN TRAVELWAY 20 During the process of excavating in a travelway where traffic is to be later maintained , make 21 provisions to backfill and repair any excavated or damaged pavement before allowing traffic 22 to proceed over the affected lanes .
In low speed areas ( 35 mph or less ) , metal plates may be 23 used to cover excavated areas .
24 1101-7 HAULING OPERATIONS 25 Comply with the multiple and single vehicle hauling restrictions as shown in the TMP when 26 performing hauling of equipment or materials to or from the project .
27 Define “ Multiple Vehicle Hauling ” as the hauling of equipment or materials to or from the 28 project with delivery at intervals of less than 5 minutes or results in more than one vehicle at 29 a particular work site at a time .
30 Define “ Single Vehicle Hauling ” as the hauling of equipment or materials to or from the 31 project with delivery at intervals of more than 5 minutes and results in no more than one 32 vehicle at a particular work site at a time .
33 1101-8 MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT STORAGE 34 When work is not in progress , keep all personnel , equipment , machinery , tools , construction 35 debris , materials and supplies at least 40 feet away from active travel lanes .
When vehicles , 36 equipment and materials are protected by concrete barrier or guardrail , they shall be offset at 37 least 5 feet from the barrier or guardrail .
38 1101-9 PARKING OF PERSONAL VEHICLES 39 Provide staging areas for personal vehicle parking a safe distance , at least 40 feet , from open 40 travel lanes or as directed by the Engineer before use .. 41 1101-10 PROTECTION OF HAZARDS 42 Mark all hazards with signs , barricades , drums or other warning devices .
43 At each location where work is started which creates a safety hazard , continue the work until 44 completed to the extent that the safety hazard is eliminated .
If the work is not pursued in 45 Section 1101 11-3 a continuous manner the Engineer will not allow any other work on the project to be 1 performed until the existing safety hazard is eliminated .
2 1101-11 TEMPORARY LANE CLOSURES 3 ( A ) General 4 Operate all equipment and personnel within the designated work area during lane 5 closures .
Do not impede or stop traffic for the purpose of performing construction related 6 work on the traffic side of the lane closure , except when called for in the TMP .
7 Install lane closures with the traffic flow , beginning with devices on the upstream side of 8 traffic .
Remove lane closures against the traffic flow , beginning with devices on the 9 downstream side of traffic .
10 Vehicles used to install or remove lane closures shall have vehicle warning lights as 11 described in 1101-5 .
12 ( B ) Intersections 13 When construction proceeds through an intersection , provide flaggers and all other 14 necessary traffic control as required by the TMP to direct the traffic through the 15 intersection .
When an intersection is signalized , place the signal in flash mode and 16 provide law enforcement or other adequate traffic control measure to direct traffic 17 through the intersection before beginning work in the intersection .
18 1101-12 TEMPORARY ROAD CLOSURES 19 ( A ) Traffic Pattern Alterations 20 Notify the Engineer 30 calendar days before altering the existing traffic pattern , unless 21 otherwise stated in the TMP .
22 Plan all traffic pattern alterations and meet with the Engineer to discuss the 23 implementation strategy before altering traffic .
The Engineer will notify the proper 24 authorities and other affected parties as necessary .
25 ( B ) Detour 26 Ensure that all required detour signing and delineation , including work done by others , 27 are in place before placing traffic onto a detour .
28 ( C ) Traffic Stoppage 29 Limit the stoppage of traffic to times specified in the TMP .
Provide time between 30 consecutive stoppages to allow the traffic queue to deplete .
31 1101-13 TRAFFIC CONTROL SUPERVISION 32 Provide the service of at least one qualified work zone supervisor .
The work zone supervisor 33 shall have the overall responsibility for the proper implementation of the TMP and ensure all 34 employees working inside the NCDOT right of way have received the proper training 35 appropriate to the job decisions each individual is required to make .
36 The work zone supervisor is not required to be on site at all times but shall be available to 37 address concerns of the Engineer .
The name and contact information of the work zone 38 supervisor shall be provided to the Engineer prior to or at the preconstruction conference .
39 Qualification of work zone supervisors shall be done by an NCDOT approved training agency 40 or other approved training provider .
For a complete listing of these , see the Work Zone 41 Traffic Control ’ s webpage .
42 Coordinate with and cooperate with work zone supervisors of adjacent or overlapping 43 construction projects to ensure safe and adequate traffic control is maintained throughout the 44 Section 1105 11-4 projects at all times including periods of construction inactivity in accordance with 1 Article 105-7 .
2 1101-14 VEHICULAR ACCESS 3 Maintain continuous and safe vehicular access , including but not limited to , all residences , 4 businesses , schools , police and fire stations , hydrants , other emergency services , hospitals and 5 mailboxes .
Conduct operations so as to limit the inconvenience to property owners .
6 1101-15 PEDESTRIAN ACCESS 7 Maintain pedestrian access at all times as shown in the TMP .
When existing pedestrian 8 facilities are disrupted , closed or relocated , provide temporary facilities that are detectable and 9 include accessibility features consistent with the features present in the existing pedestrian 10 facility .
The work zone supervisor is responsible for the implementation of the TMP , and 11 installation and maintenance of the pedestrian devices .
The work zone shall be inspected 12 weekly or as directed by the Engineer .
When pedestrian movement through or around a work 13 zone is necessary , provide a separate usable footpath .
If the previous pedestrian facility was 14 accessible to pedestrians with disabilities , provide a footpath during temporary traffic control 15 that is comparable .
Do not have any abrupt changes in grade or terrain that could cause a 16 tripping hazard or could be a barrier to wheelchair use .
Provide channelizing devices that are 17 detectable to pedestrians who have visual disabilities .
Provide temporary pedestrian facilities 18 that are made of concrete , asphalt or other suitable material as approved by the Engineer , at 19 all locations where the existing sidewalks have been removed for construction operations .
20 Do not sever or move pedestrian facilities for non-construction activities such as parking for 21 vehicles and equipment .
Separate pedestrian movements from both work zone activity and 22 vehicular traffic .
23 SECTION 1105 24 TEMPORARY TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 25 1105-1 DESCRIPTION 26 Furnish , install , maintain , relocate and remove temporary traffic control devices .
All 27 temporary traffic control devices furnished by the Contractor shall remain the property of the 28 Contractor , unless otherwise specified in the contract .
29 1105-2 MATERIALS 30 Refer to Division 10 .
31 Provide temporary traffic control devices that are listed on the NCDOT Approved Product 32 List .
33 1105-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 34 Ensure all temporary traffic control devices are inspected and approved before using them on 35 the project .
Install temporary traffic control devices before construction operations begin and 36 during the proper phase of construction .
Maintain and relocate temporary traffic control 37 devices during the time they are in use .
Keep these devices in place as long as they are 38 needed and immediately remove thereafter .
When operations are performed in stages , install 39 only those devices that apply to the present conditions .
40 Section 1110 11-5 1105-4 MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION 1 Submit a proposed traffic control device maintenance schedule and checklist for approval 2 before construction .
Perform continuous maintenance and daily scheduled inspections of 3 temporary traffic control devices .
Review and maintain all traffic handling measures to 4 ensure that adequate provisions are in place for public and workers ’ safety .
5 Maintenance activities include cleaning , repair , or replacement , and prompt disposal of 6 temporary traffic control devices that are damaged , torn , crushed , discolored , displaced or 7 deteriorated beyond effectiveness .
8 Replace work zone traffic control devices deemed unacceptable according to the guidelines 9 set forth in the American Traffic Safety Service Association ’ s ( ATSSA ) Quality Guidelines 10 for Work Zone Traffic Control Devices .
11 If the name and telephone number of the agency , Contractor or supplier is shown on the 12 non-retroreflective surface of all channelizing devices , use letters and numbers that are 13 non-reflective and not over 2 inches in height .
14 1105-5 FAILURE TO MAINTAIN TRAFFIC CONTROL 15 Failure to maintain acceptable traffic control measures or temporary traffic control devices 16 may result in formal notification of noncompliance .
Implement remedial action immediately 17 for imminent danger situations as directed by the Engineer .
Implement remedial action within 18 48 hours after notification of a safety issue that is not an imminent danger .
See Articles 107- 19 21 and 108-7 .
20 Failure to comply may result in having the work performed with available forces and 21 equipment .
In cases of willful disregard for the safety of the public , the Engineer may 22 proceed immediately to implement the measures necessary to provide the appropriate level of 23 traffic control to ensure that the safety of all concerned parties is maintained .
24 1105-6 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 25 Payment at the contract unit prices for the various items in the contract will be full 26 compensation for all work covered by this specification .
27 If the Contractor fails to maintain acceptable traffic control measures or temporary traffic 28 control devices and the Engineer implements measures necessary to provide the appropriate 29 level of traffic control , the actual cost of performing said work will be deducted from the 30 monies due the Contractor on the contract .

9 1110-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 10 ( A ) Work Zone Signs ( Stationary ) 11 All stationary Advance/General warning work zone signs require notification to existing 12 utility owners per Article 105-8 within 3 to 12 working days prior to installation .
13 Install work zone signs ( stationary ) to stand within 2° of plumb in all directions and 14 under all conditions .
Erect signs per Roadway Standard Drawings .
15 Splicing of work zone sign ( stationary ) posts is acceptable .
Splice work zone sign 16 ( stationary ) posts according to Roadway Standard Drawings .
Remove entire post when 17 removing signs with spliced posts .
18 When required , cover work zone signs with an opaque material that prevents reading of 19 the sign at night by a driver using high beam headlights .
Use material that does not 20 damage the sign sheeting .
21 Any damage incurred from the covering of work zone signs will be determined using 22 Article 901-5 .
Replace or repair any damaged signs due to the covering .
23 ( B ) Work Zone Signs ( Barricade Mounted ) 24 Mount approved composite or roll up signs to barricade rails so the signs do not cover 25 more than 50 % of the top 2 rails or 33 % of the total area of the 3 rails .
Mount signs at 26 least one foot from the ground to the bottom of the sign .
27 ( C ) Work Zone Signs ( Portable ) 28 Install the portable work zone sign and sign stand to stand plumb within 10° left and 29 right , within 20° front and back and be capable of standing erect in windy conditions .

11 1120-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 12 Mount all portable changeable message signs on a trailer or truck so as to support the message 13 board in a level position and in accordance with the plans .
Align and sight the portable 14 changeable message sign to provide optimal driver visibility .
Messages on a portable 15 changeable message sign shall consist of no more than 2 phases , and a phase shall consist of 16 no more than 3 lines of text .
Each phase shall be capable of being understood by itself , 17 regardless of the order in which it is read .
Messages shall be centered and uppercase within 18 each line of the legend .
If more than one portable changeable message sign is simultaneously 19 legible to road users , then only one of the signs shall display a sequential message at any 20 given time .
As guidance , the display time for each phase shall be at least 2 seconds , and 21 the sum of the display times for both of the phases shall be no more than 8 seconds .
Sign 22 operator will adjust the display rate so the 2 phase message can be understood by the motorist 23 twice when approaching the sign at the posted speed limit .
Relocate the units for the various 24 stages of construction as shown in the plans or as needed to inform the motorists .
25 Provide an experienced operator for the portable changeable message sign during periods of 26 operation to ensure that the messages displayed on the sign panel are in accordance with the 27 plans and Article 1089-7 ( D ) .
Periodically change the controller password to deter 28 unauthorized programming .
Using two levels of password security is recommended such that 29 operators at one level may only change message sequences displayed using preprogrammed 30 sequences and operators at a higher level may create and store messages or message 31 sequences .
32 Ensure that the message sign is illuminated properly to meet the existing light conditions , and 33 that all adjustments for operation of the sign are made as needed to properly guide motorists .
34 Expedite repairs due to failure , malfunction or damage to a portable changeable message sign .
35 Furnish another changeable message sign during the repair time .
Repair or replace portable 36 changeable message sign immediately ; otherwise , suspend all construction activities requiring 37 the use of the sign until the sign is restored to operation .

19 1170-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 20 ( A ) General 21 Place all types of portable concrete barrier or water filled barrier as shown in the contract .
22 When required by the plans , anchor portable concrete barrier by an approved method as 23 shown in the Roadway Standard Drawings .
24 Use one type of barrier on any continuous run of barrier within the project .
25 Barrier shall be placed on an asphalt or concrete surface .
Barrier should not be placed on 26 cross slopes steeper than 6:1 .
27 Use portable concrete barrier that avoids trapping water in sags , vertical curves , areas of 28 wedging and paving where super-elevations have been changed and other low spots as 29 directed .
Provide adequate drainage behind the portable concrete barrier .
30 Lift , place and reset portable concrete barrier units using a two-point pick up , or other 31 acceptable method , which does not over-stress , damage or mar the surface of the 32 roadway .
Do not use connection points for lifting purposes .
33 Do not use any barrier units that are cracked , damaged , chipped or otherwise 34 nonfunctional .
35 Place and install water filled barrier units as shown in the plans and per manufacturer 36 specifications .
37 In work zones with speed limits of 45 mph and less , use Test Level II barrier units .
38 Water filled barrier at a 36 inch height is preferred to limit sight distance impairment .
If 39 devices taller than 36 inches are used in this situation , transition down to 36 inches or 40 shorter on the intersection approaches to provide proper sight distance .
41 In work zones with speed limits over 45 mph , use Test Level III barrier units .
The units 42 shall be evaluated on a case by case basis to ensure ample space is available for device 43 deflection .
Follow the manufacturer ’ s specifications and recommendations .
44 Furnish barrier delineators for portable concrete and water filled barrier .
45 Furnish delineators for barrier in accordance with the Roadway Standard Drawings .
46 Section 1170 11-16 Once temporary barrier is installed at any location and no work is performed behind the 1 temporary barrier for a period longer than 2 months , remove or reset temporary barrier at 2 no cost to the Department unless otherwise stated in the TMP , temporary barrier is 3 protecting a hazard , or as directed by the Engineer .
4 ( B ) Securing Barrier On Concrete and Asphalt Pavement Surfaces 5 Use anchoring methods shown in Roadway Standard Drawings .
6 ( 1 ) Anchoring Method for Asphalt Pavements 7 Drill anchor holes normal to the surface of installation using a pneumatic drill with 8 a depth indicator , unless another drilling method is allowed .
Make sure that the 9 diameter of the hole is in strict conformance with the Roadway Standard Drawings 10 or the manufacturer 's recommendations .
When directed , use a jig or fixture to ensure 11 correct positioning of the holes and proper alignment during the drilling process .
12 Adjust hole locations , as necessary , to avoid encountering reinforcing steel .
13 Immediately after drilling , brush the holes with a stiff-bristled brush of a sufficient 14 size to effectively remove dust from the sides of the hole , and blow all holes free of 15 all dust and debris using oil free compressed air .
Repeat this procedure until the hole 16 is completely clean .
17 Inspect each hole immediately before placement of the anchor .
Rework any hole 18 found to deviate from these requirements to ensure that an acceptable hole is 19 achieved .
20 Check each hole with a depth gauge to ensure proper embedment depth , if required .
21 Satisfactorily repair all spalled or damaged pavement .
22 Once the barrier and anchors are removed , fill the holes with grout .
These 23 requirements may be waived if the bridge or roadway will no longer be used by 24 traffic .
25 ( 2 ) Adhesive Anchoring Method for Concrete Surfaces 26 Comply with Subarticle 1170-3 ( B ) ( 1 ) .
27 Mix adhesives in strict conformance with the manufacturer 's instructions .
28 Pour the mixed adhesive into the hole .
Agitate or rotate anchors to ensure complete 29 wetting and encapsulation .
Insert the anchors to the specified depth .
Completely fill 30 the anchor hole with adhesive and remove any excess adhesive flush with the 31 pavement .
Do not disturb any anchors while the adhesive is hardening .
32 Coat all anchors to be adhesively bonded with a debonding agent to ease removal .
33 Formulate the debonding agent such that it does not reduce the strength of the anchor 34 system .
35 ( 3 ) Through the Deck Anchoring Method 36 Comply with Subarticle 1170-3 ( B ) ( 1 ) .
37 Anchor barrier to bridge decks as shown in Roadway Standard Drawings .
Do not 38 use this method on prestressed concrete bridge deck panels .
39 ( C ) Resetting Barrier 40 Reset portable concrete barrier as defined by the TMP .
41 ( D ) Stockpiling 42 Stockpile the portable concrete barrier when the barrier is not used on the project or it 43 becomes necessary to stockpile units between 2 separate installations .
Stockpile the 44 Section 1170 11-17 barrier at a location off the project of your choosing , unless otherwise noted in the TMP , 1 or to a location within the project limits , if provided .
2 ( E ) Barrier Delineators 3 Use top mounted delineators for barrier throughout the project .
Side mounted delineators 4 may be used to supplement the top mounted delineators .
5 The delineators consist of a reflector and base or casing .
Attach the delineator to the 6 barrier as shown in the Roadway Standard Drawings .
7 Position delineators perpendicular to the centerline of the road .
Use yellow delineators in 8 the median and on the left side of one-way ramps , loops or other one-way facilities .
Use 9 crystal delineators on the right side of divided highways , ramps , loops and all other one- 10 way or two-way facilities .
In all cases , the color of the delineator shall supplement the 11 color of the adjacent edgelines .
12 Barrier delineators shall be spaced according to the chart as shown in the Roadway 13 Standard Drawings .

13 1205-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 14 Do not use handliners or any other non-truck mounted pavement marking machine to install 15 pavement markings for long line applications of any one line longer than 1,000 feet .
16 Use heated in place thermoplastic with skid resistant media for bike lane symbols .
17 ( A ) Testing Procedures 18 All pavement marking materials and placement will be tested by the Department .
Install 19 pavement markings in order to meet the retroreflectivity requirements as measured by 20 a Department approved 30 m mobile or handheld retroreflectometer .
21 ( B ) Application Equipment 22 ( 1 ) General for all Application Equipment 23 Use pavement marking application equipment such that all parts that come in contact 24 with pavement marking material are constructed for easy accessibility during 25 cleaning and maintenance .
26 Keep the marking guns of the application device in full view of the operators at all 27 times .
Use applicators that are mobile and maneuverable to the extent that straight 28 lines can be followed and all standard curves can be made in true arcs .
29 ( 2 ) Glass Bead and Highly Reflective Media Dispensing Equipment 30 Apply glass beads and highly reflective media to the surface of pavement long line 31 markings using an automatic high pressurized bead and media dispenser or a 32 pressurized mechanical feed , attached to the marking equipment .
Hand liner type 33 equipment is exempt from this requirement .
Locate the bead and media applicator at 34 the proper distance behind the application of pavement marking material to provide 35 the proper amount of retroreflectivity .
Equip the bead and media applicator with an 36 Section 1205 12-2 automatic cut-off control synchronized with the cut-off control of the marking 1 material .
2 Spread the beads and reflective media uniformly over the entire surface of the 3 pavement marking material such that they are partially embedded in the pavement 4 marking .
A 60 % bead and media embedment depth provides optimum 5 retroreflectivity .
6 ( C ) Weather Limitations and Seasonal Limitations for All Markings 7 Do not place pavement markings when moisture tests conducted on the pavement show 8 signs of moisture presence on the pavement or when it is anticipated that damage caused 9 by moisture may occur during the installation and drying periods .
10 ( D ) Time Limitations for Replacement 11 TABLE 1205-1 TIME LIMITATIONS FOR REPLACEMENT Facility Type Marking Type Replacement Deadline Full-control-of-access multi-lane roadway ( 4 or more total lanes ) and ramps , including Interstates All markings By the end of each workday 's operation if the lane is opened to traffic Multi-lane roadways ( 3 or more lanes ) and ramps Center Line , Lane Line , Railroad symbols , Stop bars , and school symbols By the end of each workday 's operation if the lane is opened to traffic ( temporary paint with beads may be used ) Edge Lines , gore lines and all other symbols By the end of the 3rd calendar day after obliteration Two-lane , two-way roadways All centerline markings , railroad , Stop bars and school symbols By the end of the 5th calendar day after obliteration Edge Lines and all other symbols By the end of the 15th calendar day after obliteration A multilane facility is defined as any roadway having more than two lanes to include 12 a two-lane / two-way roadway with a center two-way left turn lane .
13 ( E ) Premarking/Interim/Temporary Markings 14 Premarking ( or layout markings ) are small paint spots used by striping contractors to 15 establish locations of pavement markings .
Premark each installation of the final 16 pavement marking materials before application on new pavement and when required to 17 replace existing pavement marking , except when existing markings are visible .
Get the 18 premarking inspected and approved by the Engineer before placing the pavement 19 marking materials .
20 Interim paint is a thin layer of pavement marking paint applied at the striping contractor ’ s 21 option to maintain traffic , instead of durable pavement markings .
Apply interim paint to 22 comply with time limitations for placement if final pavement markings can not be placed .
23 Interim markings shall be no more than 1/4 inch less than the specified line width of the 24 existing markings .
25 Place temporary paint markings for detours , lane shifts , milled surfaces and lifts of 26 asphalt other than the final pavement surface .
27 Section 1205 12-3 Review and record the existing pavement markings before resurfacing and reestablish the 1 new pavement markings using the record of existing markings in conjunction with the 2 Roadway Standard Drawings , unless otherwise directed .
Submit the record of the 3 existing pavement markings 7 calendar days before the obliteration of any pavement 4 markings .
5 ( F ) Surface Preparation and Curing Compound Removal 6 Prepare the pavement to accept pavement markings to insure maximum possible 7 adhesion .
Clean , seal and remove curing compound as necessary to insure that the 8 markings adhere to the pavement .
Obtain approval for all surface preparation methods 9 before implementing .
10 Pavements shall be free of grease , oil , mud , dust , dirt , grass , loose gravel , winter surface 11 treatments and other deleterious material , before applying pavement markings .
12 Prepare the pavement surface , including removal of curing compound , at least 2 inches 13 wider than the pavement markings to be placed , such that , an additional 1 inch of 14 prepared area is on all sides of the pavement markings after they are applied .
15 Remove the groves caused by concrete grinders before installing the polyurea pavement 16 marking .
17 Remove all curing compound and surface laitance on Portland cement concrete 18 pavements where long-life pavement markings will be placed .
Perform curing compound 19 removal by high-pressure water blasting or grinding methods .
Ensure that the surface is 20 free of all residue , laitance and debris before applying the pavement marking .
When 21 surface preparation and curing compound removal operations are completed , blow the 22 pavement surface clean by compressed air immediately before installing the pavement 23 markings .
24 If required , apply a primer sealer to pavement surfaces before applying pavement 25 marking material as recommended by the manufacturer .
Apply primer sealer in 26 a continuous film at least 2 inches wider than the pavement markings in such a way as 27 not to cause any noticeable change in the appearance of the pavement markings .
28 Conduct all pavement surface preparation including curing compound removal in such 29 a manner that the pavement or joint material is not damaged or left in a condition that 30 will mislead or misdirect the motorist .
Repair any damage caused to the pavement , or 31 joint materials caused by surface preparation or the removal of curing compound by 32 acceptable methods and at no additional cost to the Department .
33 Surface preparation and removal of bridge laitance shall be considered incidental to the 34 installation of pavement marking with the exception of curing compound removal .
35 Where pavement surface preparation results in obscuring existing pavement markings of 36 a lane occupied by traffic , immediately remove the residue , including dust , by approved 37 methods .
38 ( G ) Application of Pavement Markings 39 ( 1 ) General for all types of Pavement Markings 40 Install pavement marking material that has a uniform thickness , smooth surfaced 41 cross section throughout its entire length , width and length not less than the 42 dimensions specified in the plans and that does not exceed the dimension by more 43 than 1/2 inch .
44 Do not apply pavement marking materials over a longitudinal joint .
Mask all bridge 45 joints for removal of surface laitance , existing markings and application of new 46 markings as directed by the Engineer .
This work will be incidental to the installation 47 of the pavement markings .
48 Section 1205 12-4 Install pavement marking lines that are straight or have uniform curvature and 1 conform to the tangents , curves and transitions as specified in the plans .
2 Produce finished lines that have well defined edges and are free of horizontal 3 fluctuations .
Do not exceed 1/2 inch in lateral deviation from the proposed location 4 alignment at any point .
Any greater deviations may be cause for requiring the 5 material to be removed and replaced at no additional cost .
6 Apply all longitudinal pavement marking lines 8 inches or less in width with one 7 pass of the pavement marking equipment .
Pavement marking lines greater than 8 8 inches in width and pavement marking symbols may be applied with multiple passes 9 of the pavement marking equipment .
10 Install all pavement marking lines , stop bars , characters and symbols that require 11 multiple passes of the application equipment such that there are no gaps separating 12 the application passes .
13 Install characters and symbols so that they conform to the sizes and shapes shown in 14 the plans .
15 Protect the pavement markings until they are track free .
Repair any markings 16 tracked by a vehicle by acceptable methods .
17 Remove all pavement marking materials spilled on the road surface by acceptable 18 methods .
19 Use yellow , white and black pavement markings , without glass beads and reflective 20 media that visually match the color chips that correspond to the Federal Test 21 Standard No .
595a for the following colors .
Use markings that when subjected to 22 accelerated weathering as described in U.S. Federal Specification No .
TTP-1952F 23 are within the tolerance limits of the color chips listed below : 24 White : Color No .
17886 Yellow : Color No .
13538 Black : Color No .
37038 ( 2 ) Highly Reflective Media Application 25 “ Drop-on ” is the method where glass beads and highly reflective media are 26 dispensed by a pressurized mechanical feed or high pressure means onto the 27 pavement marking as it is applied to the pavement .
Drop-on bead and media 28 dispensing for symbols stop bars and characters may be accomplished by 29 gravitational methods .
30 ( H ) Observation Period 31 Maintain responsibility for debonding and color of the pavement markings during 32 a 12 month observation period beginning upon final acceptance of the project as defined 33 under Article 105-17 .
Guarantee the markings under the payment and performance bond 34 in accordance with Article 105-17 .
35 During the 12 month observation period , provide pavement marking material that shows 36 no signs of failure due to blistering , chipping , bleeding , discoloration , smearing or 37 spreading under heat or poor adhesion to the pavement materials .
Pavement markings 38 that bonded during application and were approved , but debond due to snowplowing will 39 not be considered a failed marking .
Replace , at no additional expense to the Department , 40 any pavement markings that do not perform satisfactorily under traffic during the 41 12 month observation period .
42 Section 1205 12-5 ( I ) Removal of Pavement Markings 1 This work includes the removal of all types of pavement marking lines , symbols and 2 characters including removal for long life marking preparation .
This work does not 3 include removal of removable tape pavement markings .
4 Remove pavement marking lines , characters and symbols by acceptable methods to the 5 Engineer that will not materially or structurally damage the surface or the texture of the 6 pavement .
Leave the pavement surface in a condition that will not mislead or misdirect 7 the motorist .
8 Where existing pavement markings are to be removed and replaced by other pavement 9 markings , do not begin removal until adequate provisions have been made to complete 10 the installation of the replacement markings .
Remove pavement markings such that the 11 surface is in proper condition for adequate bonding of the new markings .
12 Promptly remove any material deposited on the pavement as a result of 13 removing pavement markings as the work progresses by acceptable methods .
14 Provide the equipment necessary to control dust and the accumulation of debris resulting 15 from the removal process .
The removal equipment shall provide dust control and the 16 capture of the removed material shall be done using a separate vacuum equipped vehicle 17 or other approved system .
Perform the recovery process within the same operation as the 18 removal .
Do not let traffic use the lane where the removal is taking place until the 19 recovery system is finished .
Should the recovery system fail , cease removal operations 20 until the recovery system is properly operating .
The Contractor is responsible for all 21 cleanup and proper disposal of all removed debris from the project site .
22 When using a grinding method for pavement marking removal , the equipment shall have 23 multiple heads working in tandem or have a removal head with operator dialed controls 24 to result in a planed surface and provide adequate preparation of the surface to accept the 25 new marking material .
26 Do not use high pressure water blasting on asphalt .
27 Application of polyurea over existing pavement marking materials will require at least 28 95 % of the existing pavement marking material to be removed ; however , if one 15 mil 29 application of paint was placed on asphalt pavement less than 6 months old , do not 30 remove the existing paint pavement markings .
31 Thermoplastic may be installed over existing thermoplastic on asphalt .
Application over 32 existing pavement marking materials other than thermoplastic will require the existing 33 pavement marking material to be removed so that at least 85 % of the existing pavement 34 marking surface is removed .
Before applying thermoplastic pavement markings over the 35 existing thermoplastic pavement markings , remove at least 25 % of the oxidized existing 36 thermoplastic .
On newly installed failed thermoplastic that is to be removed and replaced , 37 remove a minimum of 85 % of the existing thermoplastic .
However , if one 15 mil 38 application of paint was placed on asphalt pavement less than 6 months old , do not 39 remove the existing paint pavement markings .
40 Use black color # 37038 in paint or tape , as determined by Contractor , to cover any 41 remaining conflicting pavement marking after removal from asphalt pavement surfaces .
42 Do not use black paint or tape on concrete pavement surfaces .
The black paint will not 43 have a defined shape or edges with a width not exceeding double of the existing lines .
44 ( J ) Pavement Marking Installer Qualifications 45 Ensure at least one member of every pavement marking crew is certified through the 46 NCDOT Pavement Marking Technician Certification Process .
Keep the certification 47 current throughout the life of the project .
A certified crewmember shall be present 48 anytime this work is being performed .
The certified crewmember is not required to be 49 the same person throughout the life of the contract .
50 Section 1205 12-6 1205-4 THERMOPLASTIC ( ALKYD/MALEIC ) 1 ( A ) Application Equipment 2 ( 1 ) General 3 Use application equipment constructed to assure continuous uniformity in the 4 thickness and width of the thermoplastic pavement marking .
Use application 5 equipment that provides multiple width settings ranging from 4 inches to 12 inches 6 and multiple thickness settings to achieve the pavement marking thickness ranging 7 from 0.090 inch to 0.120 inch .
Special thickness equipment may be required for in 8 lane or shoulder transverse rumble strip pavement markings .
9 Do not use spray thermoplastic unless approved by NCDOT ’ s Signing and 10 Delineation Unit .
11 ( 2 ) Premelting Kettle 12 Use equipment to install hot thermoplastic pavement marking material that includes 13 an oil-jacketed or air-jacketed premelt kettle for uniform heating and melting of the 14 thermoplastic material .
Use a kettle that is equipped with an automatic thermostat 15 control device to provide positive temperature control and continuous mixing and 16 agitation of the thermoplastic material .
Do not premelt thermoplastic material in 17 handliner type equipment .
18 ( 3 ) Applicator Storage Kettle 19 Equip long line pavement marking vehicles with an automatic thermostat control 20 device to maintain the thermoplastic material at the application temperature and 21 provide continuous mixing and agitation of the thermoplastic material during 22 installation .
Construct the equipment so that all mixing and conveying parts , up to 23 and including the application apparatus , maintains the thermoplastic pavement 24 marking material at the specified installation temperature and which has a capacity 25 of at least 1,500 lbs .
of molten thermoplastic pavement marking material .
Hand 26 transfer is not allowed .
27 Handliner type application vehicles may contain the premelting and applicator 28 storage functions in the same kettle .
Agitation and mixing can be done manually .
29 Drag box type and bucket type application is not allowed .
30 Use premelting and applicator storage kettles that meet the requirements of the 31 National Board of Fire Underwriters , the National Fire Protection Association and 32 State and local authorities .
33 ( B ) Weather Limitations and Seasonal Limitations 34 Do not apply thermoplastic pavement markings on existing or new pavements unless the 35 ambient air temperature and the temperature of the pavement is 50°F or higher .
36 Do not apply thermoplastic pavement markings between the dates specified below : 37 East of I-95 December 15 and the following March 16 East of I-77 to and including I-95 November 30 and the following April 1 West of and including I-77 November 15 and the following April 16 Exception to the above : When traffic is maintained on a portion of roadway and 38 thermoplastic pavement marking will not be placed within 30 calendar days due to 39 seasonal limitations , place pavement marking paint and beads in accordance with 40 Subarticle 1205-8 ( C ) .
41 Section 1205 12-7 ( C ) Application 1 Use only thermoplastic markings that are of the hot , machine applied type .
Apply 2 alkyd/maleic thermoplastic pavement markings by extrusion methods only .
Extrusion 3 may be accomplished using either conventional extrusion equipment or ribbon gun 4 extrusion devices .
5 The stem portion of straight arrows shall be applied in a single pass and the stem portion 6 of turn arrows is to be applied in no more than 2 passes of the application equipment .
7 Arrowheads may be applied by multiple passes of the application equipment , not to 8 exceed 3 passes .
9 Apply drop-on beads and/or highly reflective media uniformly to the surface of the 10 molten thermoplastic material so the beads and highly reflective media are partially 11 embedded and at a rate recommended by the manufacturer to obtain the minimum 12 reflectance values .
For highly reflective markings , a double drop system consisting of 13 glass beads and highly reflective media is required .
Produce in place markings with 14 minimum retroreflective values shown in Table 1205-2 , as obtained with a Department 15 approved 30 m mobile or handheld retroreflectometer .
Retroreflective measurements 16 will be taken within 30 days after final placement of the pavement marking .

6 1205-5 POLYUREA 7 ( A ) Weather Limitations and Seasonal Limitations 8 Do not apply polyurea pavement markings on existing or new pavements unless the 9 ambient air temperature and the temperature of the pavement is 40°F or higher .
10 Do not apply polyurea pavement marking between November 15 and the following 11 February 28 unless the surface is free from winter surface treatment applications .
12 ( B ) Application 13 Produce polyurea pavement marking lines that have a minimum dry thickness of 20 mils 14 when placed on concrete and asphalt pavements .
Apply 30 mils on textured surfaces 15 such as OGFC .
16 Using the polyurea application equipment , apply the pavement marking materials 17 simultaneously .
Apply the polyurea resin , mixed at the proper ratio according to the 18 manufacturer ’ s recommendations , to the pavement surfaces within the proper application 19 temperatures as determined by the material manufacturer .
Inject reflective glass beads 20 and highly reflectivemedia into the molten ( liquid ) polyurea pavement markings .
For 21 highly reflective markings , a double drop system consisting of glass beads and highly 22 reflective media is required .
23 Wait at least 15 days before applying polyurea on new asphalt .
Place a thin layer of 24 pavement marking paint at the proper width before applying the polyurea markings 25 during the 15 day waiting period .
Apply the thin layer of pavement marking paint and 26 beads at the rate necessary to produce a dry film thickness of 5 to 8 mils .
Apply drop-on 27 beads at a rate of 1 to 3 lbs/gal of paint .
Direct payment for the pavement marking paint 28 will not be made .
Cover any such thin layer of paint with polyurea pavement marking 29 within 30 calendar days of placement .
If paint is placed on concrete before applying 30 polyurea , remove 100 % of the paint before installing polyurea .
Payment for the paint and 31 removal shall be made under Article 1205-10 .
32 Apply drop-on beads and/or highly reflective media uniformly to the surface of the 33 polyurea material so that the beads and reflective media are partially embedded and at a 34 rate recommended by the manufacturer to obtain the minimum reflectance values .
35 Produce in place markings with minimum retroreflective values shown in Table 1205-4 , 36 as obtained with a Department approved 30 m mobile or handheld retroreflectometer .
37 Retroreflective measurements will be taken within 30 days after final placement of the 38 pavement marking .
39 Produce marking that , upon curing , is uniformly reflectorized and has the ability to resist 40 deformation caused by traffic throughout its entire length .

32 1205-8 PAINT 33 ( A ) Application Equipment 34 The equipment to apply paint to pavements shall be a truck mounted pneumatic or airless 35 spray machine with suitable arrangements of atomizing nozzles and controls to obtain the 36 specified markings .

capacity .
The spray guns used 43 for hand held paint pavement marking application shall be operable from the application 44 truck .

The paint trucks shall be equipped with quick action valves .
The required 1 gauges and pressure regulators shall be conveniently located and in full view and reach of 2 the operator .
Paint strainers are required in paint supply lines .

Provide a glass bead dispenser that operates automatically and 5 simultaneously with the paint applicator through the same mechanism and that is capable 6 of adjustment and designed to provide uniform flow over the full length and width of the 7 stripe as specified in Subarticle 1205-3 ( G ) ( 2 ) .
8 Provide spray guns for hand application of detail markings , symbols and legends .
A hand 9 operated push type applicator with a glass bead dispenser may be used for radii and/or 10 parking spaces .
11 ( B ) Weather Limitations 12 Apply paint only when the ambient air temperature and pavement surface temperatures 13 are at least 40°F and rising and no more than 160°F .

2 1205-10 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 3 ____ Pavement Marking Lines will be measured and paid as the actual number of linear feet 4 of pavement marking lines satisfactorily placed and accepted by the Engineer .
In addition , 5 Paint Pavement Marking Lines will be paid per linear foot for each 15 mil application placed 6 in accordance with Subarticle 1205-8 ( C ) .
The quantity of solid lines will be the summation of 7 the linear feet of solid line measured end-to-end of the line .
The quantity of skip or broken 8 lines will be the summation of the linear feet derived by multiplying the nominal length of 9 a line by the number of marking lines satisfactorily placed .
10 ____ Pavement Marking Symbols will be measured and paid as the actual number of 11 pavement marking symbols satisfactorily placed and accepted by the Engineer .
In addition , 12 Paint Pavement Marking Symbols will be paid for each 15 mil application placed in 13 accordance with Subarticle 1205-8 ( C ) .
14 ____ Pavement Marking Characters will be measured and paid as the actual number of 15 characters satisfactorily placed and accepted by the Engineer .
A character is considered to be 16 one letter or one number of a word message .
In addition , Paint Pavement Marking 17 Characters will be paid for each 15 mil application placed in accordance with Subarticle 18 1205-8 ( C ) .
19 Removal of Pavement Marking Lines will be measured and paid as the actual number of linear 20 feet of pavement marking lines satisfactorily removed and accepted by the Engineer .
The 21 quantity of solid lines will be the summation of the linear feet of solid line measured end-to- 22 end of the line .
The quantity of skip or broken lines will be the summation of the linear feet 23 derived by multiplying the nominal length of a line by the number of marking lines 24 satisfactorily removed .
No payment will be made for the removal of removable pavement 25 marking tape .
26 Removal of Pavement Marking Symbols & Characters will be measured and paid as the actual 27 number of pavement marking symbols and characters satisfactorily removed and accepted by 28 the Engineer .
29 Curing Compound Removal , Lines will be measured and paid as the actual number of linear 30 feet of pavement surface from which the curing compounds are satisfactorily removed .
All 31 other surface preparation will be incidental to the work covered by this section .
Measurement 32 will be made along the surface of the pavement .
33 Curing Compound Removal , Symbols & Characters will be measured and paid as the actual 34 number of symbols and characters for which the curing compound has been satisfactorily 35 removed .
All other surface preparation will be incidental to the work covered by this section .
36 Payment at the contract unit price for the various items in the contract will be full 37 compensation for all the items covered by this section .
No direct payment will be made for : 38 the work involved in applying the lines , including surface preparation ; reapplication of molten 39 pavement marking crossed by a vehicle ; removal of all pavement marking materials spilled on 40 the roadway surface ; and repair of markings tracked by a vehicle .
41 Premarking will be incidental to other items in the contract .
Unless directed by the Engineer , 42 there will be no direct payment for interim paint .
No direct payment will be made for black 43 paint or tape .

6 1250-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 7 ( A ) Weather Limitations 8 Do not install pavement markers or replacement reflectors if moisture tests performed on 9 the pavement indicate the presence of moisture on the pavement surface or on the 10 pavement marker .
Install all pavement marker adhesives as required by the 11 manufacturer 's specifications for weather and temperature limitations .
12 ( B ) Preparing for installation 13 Ensure that the pavement , pavement markers and replacement lens are free of dirt , dust , 14 oil , grease , moisture , curing compound , loose or unsound layers or any other material that 15 would interfere with proper bonding of the marker to the pavement or the lens to the 16 marker .
Use methods approved by the Engineer for this preparation .
17 ( C ) Removal of Existing Pavement Markers 18 Remove the existing raised pavement markers or the snowplowable pavement markers 19 including the castings , before overlaying an existing roadway with pavement .
Repair the 20 pavement by filling holes as directed by the Engineer .
21 When traffic patterns are changed in work zones due to construction or reconstruction , 22 remove all raised pavement markers or snowplowable markers including castings that 23 conflict with the new traffic pattern before switching traffic to the new traffic pattern .
24 Lens removal in lieu of total casting removal is not an acceptable practice for 25 snowplowable markers .
26 Properly dispose of the removed pavement markers .
No direct payment will be made for 27 removal or disposal of existing pavement markers or repair of pavement , as such work 28 will be incidental to other items in the contract .
29 ( D ) Installation 30 ( 1 ) General 31 Install all pavement markers and adhesives per manufacturer 's specifications .
32 ( 2 ) Color 33 Ensure that the color of the reflector corresponds to the pavement marking that the 34 marker supplements .
Red reflectors may be required in combination with crystal or 35 yellow reflectors to indicate wrong way movement when viewed in the direction 36 opposing the flow of traffic .
37 ( 3 ) Appearance 38 Remove any adhesive from the reflective lens of the marker ; otherwise , replace the 39 reflector lenses of a snowplowable pavement marker or the entire raised pavement 40 marker .
41 ( 4 ) Spacing 42 Space pavement markers as shown in the plans .
Position pavement marker lenses 43 perpendicular to the flow of traffic as shown in the Roadway Standard Drawings .
44 Adjust marker longitudinal spacing up to 1 foot in either direction and/or adjust 45 Section 1251 12-15 marker lateral spacing up to 3 inches to avoid installation of the marker at a 1 pavement construction joint or surface defect .
If a marker can not be relocated as 2 described above , do not install the affected marker .

8 1253-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 9 ( A ) General 10 Bond marker castings to the pavement with epoxy adhesive .
Mechanically mix and 11 dispense epoxy adhesives as required by the manufacturer 's specifications .
Place the 12 markers immediately after the adhesive has been mixed and dispensed .
13 Install snowplowable pavement marker castings into slots sawcut into the pavement .
14 Make slots in the pavement to exactly duplicate the shape of the casting of the 15 snowplowable pavement markers .
16 Promptly remove all debris resulting from the saw cutting operation from the pavement 17 surface .
Install the marker castings within 7 calendar days after sawcutting slots in the 18 pavement .
Remove and dispose of loose material from the slots by brushing , blow 19 cleaning or vacuuming .
Dry the slots before applying the epoxy adhesive .
Fill the 20 cleaned slots totally with epoxy adhesive flush with the surface of the existing pavement .
21 Install snowplowable pavement markers according to the manufacturer ’ s 22 recommendations .
23 Protect the snowplowable pavement markers until the epoxy has initially cured and is 24 track free .

This work will be paid for under the pay item for the type of 31 reflector replacement if the damage occurred after the initial installation of the 32 snowplowable pavement marker .
33 Missing castings shall be replaced .
Broken castings shall be removed and replaced .
In 34 both cases the slot for the castings shall be properly prepared prior to installing the new 35 casting .
Removal of broken castings and preparation of slots will be considered 36 incidental to the work of replacing castings .

31 ( B ) Conduit 32 Use conduit and duct that is either metallic ( Rigid Metallic Conduit ) or non-metallic 33 ( PVC or HDPE ) , as noted in the plans .

Use 36 wire and cable which conforms to Insulated Cable Engineers Association ( ICEA ) 37 Section 1400 14-2 specifications and has marks for identification ( manufacturer 's name , type insulation and 1 gauge of conductor ) and the UL label .

5 ( D ) Grounding and Bonding Equipment 6 All grounding and bonding equipment shall conform to UL Standard 467 .
Use ground 7 rods which are 5/8 inch diameter x 10 feet copper clad steel .
Permanently bond 8 grounding conductor to ground rod using an irreversible compression ground connector .
9 Unless the irreversible compression connectors are designed for use with more than one 10 conductor , only one conductor shall be placed under each irreversible compression 11 ground connector .
Ensure all connections are made using a hydraulic , power or 12 ratcheting type crimper with appropriate dies .
Use of handheld pliers for crimping is 13 prohibited .
14 For ease of inspection , the top of ground rods shall be no more than 6 inches below 15 finished grade and shall remain exposed until electrical inspection is complete .
16 ( E ) Fuseholders 17 Provide fused overcurrent protection in the base of each light standard and other locations 18 as noted .
Use a fuseholder rated at least 600 VAC and 30 A approved for wet locations , 19 constructed so the fuse will be disconnected from the line side power every time the 20 fuseholder is opened .
The fuseholder may be made of molded plastic or rubber and have 21 insulating boots .
Use terminals which are specifically rated for the size and number of 22 conductors required .
23 Use fuses which have 5,000 A minimum interrupting capacity at the supply voltage , are 24 rated 10 A or as noted in the plans and are not glass type unless specified different in the 25 contract .
Use the same type fuse in all fuseholders on a project unless specified 26 differently at specified locations .
27 Use fuseholders specifically designed as breakaway devices in fiberglass standards and 28 standards with breakaway bases .
Use fuseholders designed to disconnect line side power 29 without damage to the terminals or conductors every time sufficient pulling force is 30 placed on the line and load side conductors .
31 ( F ) Hardware 32 Use mounting or attachment hardware including bolts , nuts , washers , straps , clamps and 33 hangers which is made of stainless steel , hot dipped galvanized or of equal corrosion 34 resistance .
Use bolts , which are minimum length and are not less than one nominal size 35 smaller than the opening being used .
36 ( G ) Duct and Conduit Sealer 37 Use duct and conduit sealer or mastic which is a putty-like compound and complies with 38 the following : 39 ( 1 ) Is permanently non-hardening , non-oxidizing and non-corrosive to metals , rubber , 40 plastic , lacquer and paints ; 41 Section 1400 14-3 ( 2 ) Is readily workable for thumbing into openings and forming into seals around wires 1 inside conduits and openings around conduits ; 2 ( 3 ) Has a service temperature range of minus 30°F to 200°F ; 3 ( 4 ) Is clean , non-poisonous and non-injurious to human skin ; and 4 ( 5 ) Seals against water , dust and air and shall adhere to wood , glass , plastics , metal , 5 rubber and painted surfaces .
6 ( H ) Pull Lines 7 Place pull lines specifically designed for pulling a rope in all empty conduits and 8 electrical duct so that electrical circuits can be installed in the future .
Use pull lines 9 which are 2 ply with a tensile strength of at least 240 lb .
and resistant to tangling , rot and 10 mildew .

18 1400-4 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 19 ( A ) Location Surveys 20 All light standards , high mount foundations and electrical duct will be located unless 21 indicated differently elsewhere in the contract .

24 The plan locations of the light standards and high mounts may be adjusted to be behind 25 guardrail , to avoid obstructions or to avoid undesirable foundation conditions .
Ensure 26 location changes are approved before construction .
Light standards can be moved no 27 more than 10 feet longitudinally and 2 feet laterally unless approved by the Department .
28 High mast light standards can be moved no more than 25 feet radially unless approved by 29 the Department .
Verify project dimensions on the site , actual measurement always taking 30 precedence over scaled plan dimensions , with every part of the work fitted to actual 31 conditions at the site .
32 ( B ) Damage to Facilities 33 Take all precautions necessary to avoid damage to existing underdrains and other buried 34 facilities located in certain areas .
Hand trenching may be required to avoid damage to the 35 underdrains , storm sewer systems and other facilities .
Construct light pole foundations 36 with a minimum horizontal clearance of 10 feet to storm sewers or other underground 37 installations which might affect the foundation stability .
Make lateral and longitudinal 38 changes in pole locations in the field to provide the required clearance , as directed .
39 Trenching and construction operations may require the removal of , or result in damage 40 to , existing shoulders and paved ditches .
Restore all disturbed portions of the project to 41 their original condition or as approved .
42 Installation of conductors may require trenching through existing guardrail locations .
43 Trenching may be done beneath the guardrail in a manner that will not disturb the 44 guardrail installation or the Contractor may remove short sections of guardrail to 45 facilitate mechanical trenching .
Reinstall all removed guardrail by the end of the day 's 46 Section 1400 14-5 work .
Permission is required before removal of any guardrail .
Repair any damage to the 1 guardrail installation or to the galvanizing of the material as directed .
2 Repair all trenched , excavated , or otherwise damaged earth surface areas by shaping , 3 smoothing , seeding and mulching the damaged areas as required by the Specifications 4 and as directed .
5 ( C ) Existing Utilities 6 Water , sewer , telephone , fire alarm , traffic signal and power lines may be located in the 7 same area that lighting standards and circuits are to be installed .
8 Locate these lines before operations are begun .
Field changes approved by the Engineer 9 may be made to provide clearance required by the NESC .
10 Foundations or other construction which is installed in conflict with existing utilities will 11 not be acceptable .
Remove unacceptable conflicting construction and repair damage to 12 utilities at no cost to the Department .
13 When the work involves replacing or renovating existing lighting , make all reasonable 14 efforts to prevent dark spots in the lighting system .
Phase lighting construction to allow 15 existing lighting to remain in operation as long as possible .
16 ( D ) Operation of Equipment 17 Use a bucket truck to raise workers into position to install and/or adjust luminaires and 18 lamps after the initial setting of the standards .

20 Install all bore pits outside the clear zone .
21 ( E ) Conduit Installation 22 Install conduit continuous , watertight , free of kinks and make all runs with as few 23 couplings as standard lengths will permit .
Do not exceed a total angle of 270° between 24 outlets unless otherwise approved .
Conduit bodies with covers and neoprene gaskets 25 may be used to facilitate the installation of the wires at locations indicated in the plans .
26 Provide protection at all times against the entrance of water or other foreign matter into 27 the conduit .
Plug or cap conduit when work is temporarily suspended , including nightly 28 stoppage of work .
29 Clean all conduits before installation and upon completion of the system .
Snake an 30 approved cleaner with a diameter not less than 85 % of the nominal diameter of the 31 conduit through each conduit before installing the wire .
32 Install the conduit in such a manner that temperature changes will not cause elongation or 33 contraction that might damage the system .
Provide expansion fittings where conduit 34 crosses structure expansion joints and at other locations shown in the plans .
35 Avoid short radius bends in non-metallic conduit to prevent burn-through of the pulling 36 cable or conductors during pulling operations .
37 Install caps or plugs on stub-outs for future use .
Caps and plugs shall be made of the 38 same material as the conduit .
Where non-metallic conduit is joined to metallic conduit , 39 use a transition adapter .
Install bushings on all conduit ends projecting into panels , boxes , 40 or other enclosures .
Provide pull lines in all conduits for future installation of circuitry .
41 Coat field cut threads and other uncoated metal or damaged galvanizing with organic zinc 42 repair paint .
Securely fasten conduit .
For the spacing of fasteners , do not exceed 4 feet 43 for 1 1/2 inches conduit and larger or 6 feet for 1 1/4 inches conduit and smaller .
Use 44 fasteners that are hot dipped galvanized or stainless steel .
Provide backs with all conduit 45 straps installed on flat surfaces .
Rotary-impact drills may be used for installing expansion 46 anchors in concrete .
Do not use powder explosion type units .
47 Section 1400 14-6 Do not install underground conduit until the area has been brought to final earth grade .
1 Give careful attention to the vertical and horizontal alignment of the conduit to provide 2 the smoothest installation .
3 ( F ) Wiring Methods 4 Do not pull wire through a conduit system until the system is complete and has been 5 cleaned .
Use approved wire pulling lubricants .
Pull conductors by hand , or use 6 motorized cable-pulling equipment designed for pulling multiple cables into conduit .
7 Use sheaves or rollers , as required to prevent damage to conductor insulation .
Use a 8 dynamometer ( clutch device ) so as not to exceed maximum allowable pulling tension if 9 conductor is pulled by mechanical means .
Do not use a motorized vehicle or heavy 10 equipment to generate pulling forces .
Color code all conductors per the NEC ( grounded 11 neutral is white , grounding is bare or green ) and use phase conductors which are black 12 and red .
Approved marking tape , paint , or sleeves may be used instead of continuous 13 colored conductors for No .
8 AWG and larger .
White , red or black conductor may be 14 stripped at all accessible points and used as a bare equipment grounding conductor .
15 Joints , taps and splices will only be permitted at locations indicated in the plans and by 16 the following method .
17 Install UL Listed manufactured set screw type connectors , suitable for connecting 18 multiple wires for all phase conductor splices .
These precise fit connectors are insulated 19 with high–strength dielectric material and have removable access plugs over the set 20 screws .
Direct buried and/or submersible versions of these connectors ( UL486D ) , 21 equipped with factory made waterproof insulating boots , are required for splicing inside 22 junction boxes .
Non-direct buried and/or non-submersible connectors ( UL486A and 23 UL486B ) may be used for phase conductor splicing in normally dry areas such as inside 24 poles and transformer bases .
After tightening set screw , tape down the access plugs to 25 keep them securely in place .
Split-bolt connectors may be used for ground wire splicing .
26 Wire nut and compression type connectors will not be allowed .
27 Cut conductor so that 3 feet of spare conductor is available for splicing from the end of 28 each respective conduit .
Neatly coil extra conductor in junction box .
29 All splices inside light standards shall be easily accessible through handholes unless 30 standard is mounted on breakaway transformer base .
31 ( G ) Grounding Electrodes 32 Install grounding electrodes at each light standard , high mast light standard and control 33 system as shown in the plans .
The rod shall be driven vertically until the top is 6 inches 34 below the ground surface .
The grounding conductor must be connected to the grounding 35 electrode by an irreversible compression ground connector .

41 ( I ) Base Protection 42 For median mounted light standards , use a protective metal shroud installed underneath 43 the light standard base plate to protect the exposed anchor bolts and lighting circuitry 44 segments between the base plate and the top of the concrete median barrier .
The metal 45 shroud shall be fabricated of either galvanized steel , minimum gauge 22 , or aluminum , 46 minimum gauge 18 , to match the material type of the light standard .
The metal shroud 47 shall be composed of two overlapping pieces , and attached with two self-tapping stainless 48 steel or galvanized machine screws at each overlap point .

Attach welded wire reinforcement to anchor 2 bolts with size AWG 14 copper wire or small gauge galvanized wire .
3 ( J ) Galvanizing Repair 4 Repair any damaged galvanized components in accordance with Article 1076-7 .

13 1400-5 ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS AND TESTING 14 Comply with all local ordinances and regulations .
Apply for and obtain all permits and/or 15 licenses required by local regulation .
16 Provide a calibrated MegOhmMeter , with certification that calibration was done within one 17 year of use .
Provide a meter manufactured by Fluke , Amprobe , Biddle or Engineer approved 18 equal .
Present the meter for inspection , at the Pre-Lighting-Work meeting described in 19 Section 1400-11 .
20 During project construction perform an insulation resistance test on each feeder circuit 21 conductor .
The insulation resistance for each conductor shall exceed 5 megaohms after 22 charging for 30 seconds at 500 VAC or 1000 VDC .
The Contractor Meg Circuit Data Form is 23 available on the Department website .
Submit the data form to the Engineer for review before 24 final inspection .
25 If the insulation resistance test of any conductor indicates a value of less than 5 megaohms , 26 locate the fault .
If the fault is in a conductor between terminal connections , replace the 27 conductor .
If the fault is at a terminal connection , repair or replace the terminal device .
28 Removing water from the conduit of a faulty circuit is not considered a repair .
Water in the 29 conduit allows electric current to flow between skinned places in the conductor ’ s insulation .
30 If a circuit fails the insulation resistance test and removing water allows the circuit to pass , 31 replace the conductors and re-test the new circuit .
32 After all control system cabinet wiring has been installed and connected in the proposed 33 permanent manner the Contractor will contact the Office of State Fire Marshall of the 34 Department of Insurance , or local authority having jurisdiction , to perform an electrical 35 inspection of the lighting system .
Upon satisfactory testing , the Contractor will be issued 36 a Certificate of Inspection for the lighting system .
The Contractor may then arrange with the 37 power company to provide the necessary power service .
The Certificate of Inspection will be 38 turned over to the Engineer before project acceptance .
Inspection by local authorities will 39 neither eliminate nor supersede the final inspection by the Engineer to ensure compliance with 40 the contract .
41 Have all work inspected and approved by the Engineer before concealment .
An inspection 42 will be made during the progress and after the work has been completed .
It will also include 43 an inspection made at night to determine the optical qualities of each luminaire .
Adjust all 44 luminaires having unsatisfactory qualities as directed .
45 Provide the necessary personnel and equipment for aiming luminaires during nighttime 46 inspections by the Engineer .
47 Section 1400 14-8 Contact the Department to schedule a final inspection of lighting systems at least 2 weeks 1 before the requested inspection date .
The Lighting and Electrical Squad will perform an 2 insulation resistance test as described above , inspect the system for adherence to contract 3 requirements and prepare a lighting inspection memo based on the Lighting System 4 Inspection Checklist .
The inspection checklist is available on the Department ’ s website .
5 Provide the personnel and equipment necessary for removing and replacing fuseholders 6 and/or operating circuit breakers to facilitate the insulation resistance test performed by the 7 Lighting and Electrical Squad .
8 1400-6 BURN-IN TEST 9 After all the issues mentioned in the lighting inspection punchlist are addressed to the 10 satisfaction of the Engineer , the lighting system will undergo a 2 week burn-in test .
The burn- 11 in test consists of normal dusk to dawn operation of all lighting system control equipment and 12 apparatus , without interruption or failure attributable to poor workmanship or defective 13 material .
At the end of the burn-in test , all lights and equipment will be inspected for normal 14 operation .
The Contractor will make any necessary repairs or replacements at no cost to the 15 Department .
16 Conduct the burn-in test at the same time for all lights which are energized from the same 17 utility company service point .
18 Burn-in tests of individual circuits or groups of lights will not be acceptable .
19 The Contractor is responsible for all maintenance of the lighting system ( s ) installed or 20 renovated as part of the contract until project final acceptance .

24 Test all base plate to upright welds using magnetic particle testing ( MPT ) before 25 galvanizing .
All base plates must be tested at 100 % .
Radiographically test the 26 longitudinal seam welds within 6 inches of the base plate and within 6 ” of the larger end 27 of the outer tube of the slip fit joint area .
28 Hot dip galvanize metalwork after fabrication has been completed .
Ensure the 29 galvanization conforms to ASTM A153 for fasteners and ASTM A123 for other 30 structural steel .
All welds shall be abrasive blasted to an SSPC SP6 condition before 31 galvanizing .
32 Partial penetration longitudinal groove welds on shaft sections , having a minimum throat 33 of 60 % of the thickness of material being joined , will be acceptable provided the 34 qualification requirements of the Structural Welding Code - Steel , AWS D1.1 are met .
35 However , full penetration will be required on longitudinal groove welds within 6 inches 36 of circumferential welds and in areas where a shaft section telescopes over another shaft 37 section .
No field welding of any part of the assembly will be permitted .

45 Section 1401 14-11 ( B ) Lowering Device 1 Electronically submit complete detailed drawings of the lowering device with manuals 2 describing the assembly , erecting and operating procedures .
Include precise instructions 3 on stringing the cables and leveling the carrier ring .
4 Each high mount lighting standard shall have a device to lower the luminaires from the 5 operating position at the top of the standard to a service position approximately 3 feet 6 above the base of the standard .
Include on the device a head-frame , top latching carrier 7 ring and winch assembly .

Maximum high mast luminaire weight and effective projected area 9 are shown in the contract .
10 Mount the head frame on the standard with a slipfitter and set screws , and have sheaves 11 or rollers for the lifting and power cables .
Ensure sockets automatically secure the carrier 12 ring at the top in the raised position and provide a hood on the entire assembly for 13 protection from the weather .
Attain latching and unlatching by alternately raising and 14 lowering the carrier ring .
Use sheaves that are non-corrosive materials with bronze 15 bushings and stainless steel shafts .
Provide suitable retainers to assure that the cables 16 stay in correct position .
17 Have slipfitter tenons equally spaced for mounting the luminaires on the carrier ring .
The 18 tenons shall be a suitable length to allow the installation of the LED luminaires .
Have the 19 carrier ring automatically latched to the head frame when raised into position by suitable 20 pins and sockets which will prevent the luminaires from swaying , turning , vibrating , or 21 otherwise moving out of proper position .
Include on the carrier ring spring loaded roller 22 arms to guide the ring during raising and lowering operations .
Use springs made of 23 stainless steel and rollers made of nylon .
Mount a metal NEMA 3R weatherproof 24 junction box on the ring for connection of individual luminaire circuits to the electrical 25 power supply cable .
Include in the junction box a flanged inlet for connection of the 26 power supply cable .
Use an inlet and cable connector which is of the locking type and 27 weatherproof .
28 Use a winch assembly that is a self-locking worm gear type designed for operation with 29 a portable power unit .
Have the winch drum automatically reverse the lay of the hoist 30 cable and prevent uneven build-up or tangling .
31 Provide a terminator for joining the hoist cable and three suspension or lifting cables .
32 Provide the means to compensate for variations in the lengths of the 3 lifting cables .
Use 33 hoist and lifting cables made of stranded high strength stainless steel extra flexible 34 aircraft type .
Use hoist and lifting cables that meet structural requirements of Military 35 Specification MIL-W-83420E and have the center strand not protruding more than 36 0.06 inch after the cable is cut .
37 Use a power supply cable that is rated for suspension and has approved strain relief 38 fittings at each end .
