39 Section 1413 14-24 1413-3 TOWER LIGHT 1 Use tower lights which consist of mercury vapor , metal halide , high pressure sodium or low 2 pressure sodium fixtures mounted on a tower approximately 30 feet in height .
Use tower light 3 fixtures which are heavy duty flood , area , or roadway style with wide beam spread , have 4 an output of 50,000 lumens minimum , have the combined outputs of all fixtures on each 5 tower light not exceed 460,000 lumens , and are weatherproof and supplied with attached 6 waterproof power cord and plug .
Use a sturdy tower which is freestanding without the aid of 7 guy wires or bracing .
Provide sufficient capacity in the power supply to operate the light ( s ) 8 and locate it for the shortest safe routing of cables to the fixtures .
A tower light consisting of 9 the combined fixture ( s ) , tower and power supply is preferred .
10 Provide tower lights of sufficient wattage and/or quantity to provide an average maintained 11 horizontal illuminance greater than 20 footcandles over the work area .
12 Aim and position the lights to illuminate the area for construction work .
Make sure that there 13 is not any disabling glare to the motorist .
In no case should the main beam of the light be 14 aimed higher than 60° above straight down .
The lights should be set as far from traffic as 15 practical and aimed in the direction of , or normal to , the traffic flow .
16 1413-4 MACHINE LIGHTS 17 Use machine lights which have mercury vapor , metal halide , high pressure sodium or low 18 pressure sodium conventional roadway enclosed fixtures mounted on supports attached to the 19 construction machine at a height of approximately 13 feet .

Use a power supply with 21 sufficient capacity to operate the light ( s ) and securely mount on the machine .
Perform 22 electrical grounding of generators to frames of machines on which they are mounted in 23 conformance with the NEC .
24 Use machine light fixtures with sufficient wattage and/or quantity to provide an average 25 maintained horizontal illuminance greater than 10 footcandles on the machine and the 26 surrounding work area .
Machine lights are in addition to conventional automotive type 27 headlights which are necessary for maneuverability .
28 Balloon lights are an acceptable alternate luminaire for machine lights .
29 1413-5 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 30 Use tower lights when the night work is confined to a fairly small area and is essentially 31 a stationary operation .

At any spacing , 33 the required 20 footcandles of light will be the determining factor .
34 Use machine lights when the night work is not confined to a small area and is essentially 35 a continuous moving construction operation .

Use 37 of tower lights instead of machine lights will be considered when the number of machines , 38 type of work , or need for inspection justify their use as decided by the Engineer .

7 1500-2 COOPERATION WITH THE UTILITY OWNER 8 The utility owner owns the existing utility facilities and will own the new utility facilities after 9 acceptance by the Department .
The Department owns the construction contract and has 10 administrative authority .
Communications and decisions between the contractor and utility 11 owner are not binding upon the Department or this contract unless authorized by the Engineer .
12 Agreements between the utility owner and contractor for work that is not part of this contract 13 or is secondary to this contract are allowed , but are not binding upon the Department .

Notify Department personnel and the utility owner 2 weeks before 16 commencement of any work and one week before service interruption .
Keep utility 17 owners ’ representatives informed of work progress and provide opportunity for inspection of 18 construction and testing .

33 1500-5 RELATION OF WATER MAINS TO SEWERS 34 Lay water mains at least 10 feet laterally from existing or proposed sewers .
If local 35 conditions or barriers prevent a 10 foot separation , lay the water main with at least 18 inches 36 vertical separation above the top of the sewer pipe either in a separate trench or in the same 37 trench on a bench of undisturbed earth .
38 Section 1500 15-2 When a proposed water main crosses over a proposed or existing sewer , lay the water main 1 with at least 18 inches vertical separation above the top of the sewer .
If local conditions or 2 barriers prevent an 18 inch vertical separation , construct both the water main and the sewer 3 for a distance of 10 feet on each side of the point crossing with ferrous pipe having water 4 main quality joints .
5 When a proposed water main crosses under a proposed or existing sewer , construct both the 6 water main and the sewer of ferrous materials with joints that are equivalent to water main 7 standards for a distance of 10 feet on each side of the point of crossing .
Center the section of 8 water pipe at the point of crossing .

3 ( C ) Bedding 4 Provide excavations with sufficient width for placing and compacting bedding around the 5 utility .

10 ( D ) Pipe Laying 11 Lay pipe in accordance with the specifications and the manufacturer 's recommendations .

Provide secure watertight seals on pipe when work is not in progress .
18 Lay gravity sewer pipe upgrade with the spigot ends pointing in the direction of flow .

21 ( E ) Thrust Restraint 22 Provide thrust restraint for pressurized pipelines and appurtenances .
When shown in the 23 plans , construct as specified with modifications to match the actual field conditions .
24 When not shown , engineer the thrust restraint system with a factor of safety of 1.25 for 25 the test pressure specified and for the actual field conditions .
26 Provide thrust restraint on the existing piping system as necessary .
27 Use joint restraint methods , such as integral restraining bells and spigots , restraining 28 retainer glands , restraining gaskets or restraining clamps and lugs with tie rods .
Use 29 concrete reaction backing and thrust collars where joint restraint is impractical .
30 Where any section of a main is provided with concrete thrust restraint for fittings , 31 controls or hydrants , perform the hydrostatic pressure test after the concrete reaches 32 appropriate strength .
33 ( F ) Backfilling 34 Backfill in accordance with Article 300-7 and compact to the density required by 35 Subarticle 235-3 ( C ) .

4 1510-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 5 ( A ) General 6 Meet the installation standards of AWWA or ASTM for water line construction .

22 ( B ) Testing and Sterilization 23 Perform pressure and leakage tests and sterilization on newly installed water mains and 24 altered water mains prior to placing such pipelines into service .
Provide all equipment , 25 piping , controls , pumps , water and safety devices necessary for performing the tests and 26 sterilization .
27 Obtain clean water for cleaning , testing and sterilization from approved sources .
Provide 28 connections to potable water sources with approved backflow preventors until acceptance 29 of all test results .
30 Perform tests using clean water and provide certified results demonstrating leakage less 31 than the following amount when pressurized at 200 ± 5 psi for 2 hours .
32 W = P ÷148,000 LD Where : W = allowable leakage in gallons per hour L = length of pipeline tested , in feet D = nominal diameter of the pipe , in inches P = average test pressure during the leakage test , in lb/sq.in .
Repair using approved methods or replace pipe , controls or appurtenances as necessary to 33 reduce leakage below acceptable levels .
Additionally , repair any leaks that are visible 34 after 2 hours duration .
35 Clean water lines by flushing with water at least 2.5 feet per second velocity .
Remove all 36 debris and dirt from water mains larger than 4 inches by passing a medium density foam 37 pig with abrasive strips through the lines .
38 Sterilize water lines in accordance with Section 1003 of the Rules Governing Public 39 Water supply and AWWA C651 Section 4.4.3 , the Continuous Feed Method .
Provide a 40 Section 1515 15-7 chlorine solution with between 50 parts per million and 100 parts per million in the initial 1 feed .
If the chlorine level drops below 10 parts per million during a 24 hour period , then 2 flush , refill with fresh chlorine solution , and repeat for 24 hours .
Provide certified 3 bacteriological and contaminant test results from a state-approved or state-certified 4 laboratory .
Operate all valves and controls to assure thorough sterilization .
Testing , 5 cleaning and sterilization shall be performed consecutively .
6 Dispose of waste water in accordance with all environmental regulations .
7 For short sections ( less than 100 feet ) and tie-in sections of water lines perform visual 8 tests for leakage after installation instead of separate pressure and leakage tests .
Sterilize 9 according to AWWA C651 Sections 4.6 and 4.7 .
10 Provide copies of the test results to the Engineer and to the water line owner .
11 Flush with clean water until the residual chlorine is reduced to the same level as in the 12 existing water mains .
13 Place new water lines into service after approval of all testing and flushing and 14 authorization by the Engineer .

11 ( A ) Gravity Sanitary Sewer 12 Construct gravity sanitary sewers in conformance with NCDEQ Gravity Sewer Minimum 13 Design Criteria .
14 ( 1 ) Pipe Installation 15 Use fittings or saddles to connect service lines to the sewer main .
16 Maintain sewer flow at all times .
Use temporary diversions or pumping to maintain 17 flow when connecting proposed sewers to existing sewers .
Use engineered 18 temporary pumping systems capable of handling full pipe flow .
Use pumping 19 systems with automatic reliable operation or constantly tended manual operation .
20 ( 2 ) Testing 21 Perform tests on newly installed sewers and altered sewers before placing into 22 service .
Provide all equipment , piping , controls , pumps , water and safety devices 23 necessary for performing the tests .
24 Test all 24 inches and smaller gravity sewer lines for leakage using infiltration , 25 exfiltration , or air test .
Perform visual inspection on gravity sewer lines larger than 26 24 inches .
Perform line and grade testing and deflection testing on all gravity sewer 27 lines .
28 ( a ) Infiltration 29 For sewer lines greater than 3 feet below groundwater , measure the amount of 30 water infiltrating into the pipeline between manholes in at least 24 hours .
Repair 31 leaks or replace piping when the rate of infiltration exceeds the following 32 equation : 33 W = .0 000789LD Where : W = maximum allowable leakage in gallons per hour L = length of pipeline tested , in feet D = nominal diameter of the pipe , in inches ( b ) Exfiltration 34 For sewer lines above groundwater , perform an exfiltration test on the pipeline 35 between manholes .
Repair leaks or replace piping when the rate of exfiltration 36 exceeds maximum allowable leakage calculated in Subarticle 1520-3 ( A ) ( 2 ) ( a ) .
37 The exfiltration test shall consist of securely plugging the pipe at the lower 38 manhole and filling the pipeline with water .
Allow the water to sit for 24 hours 39 in clay or concrete pipes .
Raise the water level in the upstream manhole 40 Section 1520 15-12 to 3 feet above the top of pipe .
After 4 hours , measure the amount of water 1 required to bring the water level back to the level at the start of the test and 2 record the time .
3 Perform exfiltration tests through a series of manhole to manhole segments to 4 limit the length of pipe tested to between 300 feet and 1,500 feet .
Shorter 5 sections may be tested with longer test times .
No additional leakage allowance 6 for manholes permitted .
7 ( c ) Air Test 8 Instead of hydrostatic testing , sewer lines 24 inches in diameter or smaller may 9 be air tested in accordance with ASTM C828 , ASTM C924 and the following .
10 Securely plug the sewer pipe at the manholes .
Fill the pipe with air to 4.0 psi 11 and hold this pressure for 5 minutes .
Reduce the pressure to 3.5 psi .
Measure 12 the time for the pressure to drop 1.0 psi to the new pressure of 2.5 psi .
Exceed 13 the minimum test time in Table 1520-1 for the appropriate nominal pipe 14 diameter .
15 TABLE 1520-1 AIR TEST TIME Pipe Size ( Inches ) Test Time ( Minutes/100 ft ) Pipe Size ( Inches ) Test Time ( Minutes/100 ft ) 8 1.2 18 2.4 10 1.5 21 3.0 12 1.8 24 3.6 ( d ) Visual Inspection 16 Visually inspect sewer lines larger than 24 inches from the inside using 17 approved cameras .
Correct any leakage , rolled gaskets or defects .
18 ( e ) Line and Grade 19 Test all sewers for straight alignment by lamping or using a laser .
20 ( f ) Deflection Testing 21 Perform deflection tests on all flexible pipes .
Conduct the test after the final 22 backfill has been in place at least 30 days to permit stabilization of the soil-pipe 23 system .
As an alternative to waiting 30 days to permit stabilization of the 24 soil-pipe system , provide certified soil testing verifying the backfill of the trench 25 has been compacted to at least 95 % maximum density .
26 No pipe shall exceed a deflection of 5 % .
If deflection exceeds 5 % , relay the 27 pipe .
28 The rigid ball or nine-point mandrel used for the deflection test shall have 29 a diameter not less than 95 % of the base inside diameter or average inside 30 diameter of the pipe depending on which is specified in the ASTM , to which the 31 pipe is manufactured .
The pipe shall be measured in compliance with 32 ASTM D2122 .
The test shall be performed without mechanical pulling devices .

28 Payment will be made under : 29 Pay Item Pay Unit __ '' Encasement Pipe Linear Foot Section 1550 15-19 SECTION 1550 1 TRENCHLESS INSTALLATION OF UTILITIES 2 1550-1 DESCRIPTION 3 Install pipe using a trenchless method .
Pipe refers to the specified pipe , which may be the 4 primary carrier pipe or an encasement pipe .
Shoring means the earth support system used for 5 installing the pipe .
The terms for encasement , casing , encasement pipe and casing pipe are 6 interchangeable .
7 An engineer licensed by the State of North Carolina shall design the method and certify the 8 work will not damage the roadway above or endanger the roadway user .
9 1550-2 MATERIAL 10 Refer to Division 10 .
11 Item Section Concrete 1000 Encasement Pipe 1540 Flowable Fill 1000-6 Structural Timber 1082 Structural Steel 1072 Treated Timber 1082-3 Use pipe joints that are modified to suit the installation method .
Provide engineering 12 calculations for piping and shoring .
Submit material certifications and obtain approval from 13 the Department ’ s Engineer before installation .
14 Use steel or concrete liner plates .
Steel tunnel liner plates shall meet Sections 16 and 25 in 15 AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications .
Concrete liner plates shall meet 16 AASHTO specifications .
17 Drilling fluids consist of water , bentonite and polymer additives .
18 Other materials will be considered with adequate design and quality control .
19 1550-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 20 ( A ) General 21 Apply Section 1505 for excavation , trenching , pipe laying and backfill .
22 Install the pipe to the lines and grades shown in the plans .
Use workers that are skilled in 23 the method of construction .
Construct with good workmanship by skilled workers along 24 with proper safety precautions .
25 Locate ends of trenchless construction and pits beyond the vehicle recovery area of the 26 roadway .
The vehicle recovery area may be reduced using acceptable traffic control 27 methods .
28 ( B ) Design 29 Contract plans will show a trenchless method including but not limited to length , profile 30 and bore pit locations based on available information .
The Contractor ’ s design shall 31 confirm this method is appropriate for the field conditions and for the specified pipe .
32 Subsurface information in the vicinity of the trenchless installation may be available in 33 accordance with Section 102-7 .
34 Assess soil conditions expected during trenchless operations .
35 Design the method to minimize the vertical movement of the pipe or the completed 36 roadway section .
Use methods of construction and installation that will not disturb the 37 soils outside of the immediate vicinity of the pipeline or pits .
38 Section 1550 15-20 Before construction , provide detailed plans for the method of installation certified by 1 an engineer licensed by the State of North Carolina .
Provide certified calculations 2 demonstrating the method of installation as safe and of minimal risk .
Provide certified 3 calculations of the structural adequacy of all materials .
The design shall meet 4 AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications .
An engineer licensed by the State of 5 North Carolina shall certify changes or modifications to the designed method as needed 6 for actual field conditions .
7 ( C ) Water Control 8 Provide groundwater control and removal as appropriate for the method of excavation 9 and installation .
Remove the groundwater using an engineered dewatering system 10 provided in the design submittal .
Keep surface waters out of the excavation and pits .
11 ( D ) Shoring 12 Provide temporary or permanent shoring , as needed .
Provide temporary shoring to 13 maintain the hole or pit excavation for the duration of the work .
Casing pipe 24 inches 14 and larger , tunnel liner , and shoring that is not certified for permanent use is considered 15 temporary .
Fill the annular space between the specified pipe and temporary shoring .
16 Provide permanent shoring when desired or specified to maintain the open hole for an 17 indefinite time .
Permanent shoring requires certification of durability and a design life of 18 100+ years .
19 Fill all voids around the excavation and shoring with structural fill material as work 20 progresses .
21 Either work continuously ( 24 hours/day and 7 days/week ) on the operations from the 22 time the excavation begins through the filling of voids or use an engineered system for 23 shoring the excavation during work stoppage .
24 ( E ) Pre-Construction Meeting 25 The Contractor shall conduct a pre-construction meeting with the Department ’ s Engineer 26 to review the proposed method for installation of the pipe .
Conduct the meeting at least 27 48 hours before beginning installation .
The meeting shall consist of , but is not limited to : 28 ( 1 ) Presentation of the construction methods for understanding by all involved , 29 ( 2 ) Presentation of methods for filling any potential voids around the pipe , 30 ( 3 ) Demonstrating that appropriate equipment and materials are on site , 31 ( 4 ) Providing a progress schedule , and 32 ( 5 ) Demonstrating ability to react to failures or roadway settlement or heave .
33 1550-4 TRENCHLESS METHODS 34 ( A ) Bore and Jack 35 For bore holes up to 6 inches in diameter in stable ground , the hole may be augured and 36 the pipe pushed or jacked through the cleaned out hole .
For bore holes greater than 6 37 inches , provide continuous support of the hole by simultaneously jacking the pipe or 38 casing into the hole .
39 Use equipment suitably sized and designed to simultaneously bore or drill the soil or rock 40 while pushing or jacking pipe on a controlled grade .
Position the cutter head within one 41 diameter of the leading edge of the pipe .
In cohesive , dense and dry soils and rock , 42 position the cutter head in front of the leading edge .
In non-cohesive or loose soils , 43 position the cutter head inside the pipe .
44 Section 1550 15-21 Dry bore only , do not use jetting or wet boring methods .
Use drilling fluids only on the 1 outside of pipe for lubrication or hole stabilization .
2 Minimize over bore , match cutter diameter to the outside diameter of the encasement 3 pipe .
Limit overbore to the O.D .
+ 2 inches .
4 Provide steering controls as necessary to maintain line and grade .
5 If conditions allow and with the approval of the Engineer , the Contractor may elect to use 6 the pipe ramming method in lieu of bore and jack .
Payment for the pipe ramming 7 method will be paid as bore and jack .
8 ( B ) Directional Drilling 9 For drilled holes up to 6 inches in diameter in stable ground , the hole may be drilled and 10 reamed followed by pulling the pipe into the hole within 8 hours .
For drilled holes 11 greater than 6 inches , simultaneously pull the pipe or casing into the hole as reaming 12 occurs 13 When under pavement or within a one horizontal to one vertical distance from pavement , 14 maintain the depth of cover in Table 1550-1 .
15 TABLE 1550-1 DEPTH OF COVER FOR DIRECTIONAL DRILLING Drilled Hole Diameter Minimum Depth of Cover 2 '' to 6 '' 6 ft > 6 '' to 15 '' 12 times the hole diameter > 15 '' to 36 '' 15 ft Begin bores at locations that allow transitioning the bore to meet the above depths .
16 Use drilling fluids as appropriate for the type soils .
Pump drilling fluids only while 17 drilling or reaming .
Monitor flow rates to match the amount leaving the bore hole .
Do 18 not increase pressure or flow to free stuck drillheads , reamers or piping .
19 Limit drilled or reamed holes to 1.5 x O.D .
for pipe 12 inches or less and O.D .
+ 6 inches 20 for pipes larger than 12 inches .
21 ( C ) Tunneling 22 Tunnel using hand mining , mechanical excavation , tunnel boring machine ( TBM ) , 23 microtunneling , or other accepted tunneling method .
Use tunnel shields or fore poling 24 along with benched excavation and breast boarding as appropriate for the field 25 conditions .
Alternatively , the Contractor ’ s engineer may certify that the soils are 26 self-supporting of the dead and live loads and design tunneling methods as appropriate .
27 Provide active support to the tunnel walls .
Shore tunnel walls using liner plates , steel ribs 28 with lagging or other engineered method or by jacking piping into place .
29 Limit over excavation to 2 inches larger than the liner or shield .
Grout the external voids 30 as work progresses and as specified by the Contractor ’ s engineer .
31 ( D ) Pipe Ramming 32 Use pipe ramming only where soils are homogeneous and free of rock , boulders , stumps 33 and debris .
Do not use in the vicinity of quick or liquefiable soils .
34 Steel bands 1/2 inch thick are allowed on the outside of the leading edge of the pipe or 35 casing to oversize the hole to reduce friction .
Steel bands 1/2 inch thick may be used on 36 the inside to compact the spoil and to prevent plugging .
37 Install at the following minimum depth of cover .
38 Section 1550 15-22 TABLE 1550-2 DEPTH OF COVER FOR PIPE RAMMING Pipe or Casing Diameter Minimum Depth of Cover 2 '' to 6 '' 4 ft > 6 '' to 14 '' 6 pipe diameters > 14 '' to 72 '' 8 ft Contain spoil within the casing during ramming .
After completion , use compressed air or 1 augers to remove the spoil .
Clean the interior using a pig .
Provide appropriate safety 2 devises .
Limit air pressure to less than the rating of the pipe or casing .
3 Use lubricants and surfactants as needed and ensure vibration induced consolidation of 4 soils does not result in settlement greater than 0.02 feet .
5 ( E ) Other Methods 6 Other methods will be considered on a case by case basis when thoroughly engineered .
7 ( F ) Lubrication and Drilling Fluids 8 Use drilling fluids for lubrication .
Do not use water alone .
9 1550-5 QUALITY CONTROL 10 The Contractor , at no cost to the Department , shall replace or repair damaged or defective 11 installations .
The method to be used shall be designed by the Contractor ’ s engineer and 12 approved by the Engineer .
13 ( A ) Ground Movement 14 Before excavation , establish control points for measuring vertical movement of the road 15 at 10 feet intervals along the centerline and 10 feet each side of the pipeline .
A land 16 surveyor licensed in the State of North Carolina shall monitor these points daily until 17 construction is complete .
18 Cease trenchless operations when measured movement exceeds 0.02 feet .
Determine 19 cause of settlement and repair as necessary .
Modify trenchless methods as needed .
20 ( B ) Leakage 21 Limit leakage through tunnel walls to minor seepage .
All leaks in pipes , casing or other 22 permanent shoring shall be sealed .
23 ( C ) Roundness 24 Provide permanent shoring maintaining at least 95 % of nominal diameter in all 25 directions .
26 ( D ) External Voids 27 Fill all external voids greater than 2 inches high or 2 feet wide .
Fill with flowable fill , 28 grout or Class II or III select material .

23 Item Section Matting for Erosion Control 1060-8 Staples 1060-8 1631-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 24 Place matting immediately following seeding .
Provide a smooth soil surface free from stones , 25 clods or debris that will prevent the contact of the matting with the soil .
Preserve the required 26 line , grade and cross section of the area covered .
27 Unroll matting in the direction of the flow of water and apply without stretching so that it will 28 lie smoothly but loosely on the soil surface .
Bury the up-channel or top of slope end of each 29 piece of matting in a narrow trench at least 6 inches deep and tamp firmly .
Where one roll of 30 matting ends and a second-roll begins , overlap the end of the upper roll over the buried end of 31 the second roll so there is a 4 inch overlap .
Construct staple checks 4 inches on center and 32 every 30 feet longitudinally in the matting or as directed .
Fold over and bury matting to the 33 full depth of the trench , close and tamp firmly .
Overlap matting at least 4 inches where 2 or 34 more widths of matting are laid side by side .
35 Place staples across matting at ends , junctions and check trenches approximately 10 inches 36 apart .
37 Place staples along the outer edges and down the center of each strip of matting 3 feet apart .
38 Place staples along all lapped edges 10 inches apart .
39 Install product with netting on the top side when excelsior or straw matting is used .
40 Section 1632 16-10 The Engineer may require adjustments in the trenching or stapling requirements to fit 1 individual cut or fill slope conditions .

4 1660-3 COORDINATION WITH GRADING OPERATIONS 5 Perform seeding and mulching operations on a section by section basis immediately upon 6 completion of earthwork sections in accordance with Article 225-2 .
7 When grading operations have been suspended , and seeding and mulching has been 8 performed on areas where work has been suspended , include in the work of seeding and 9 mulching of the adjacent sections any necessary overlapping of operations on previously 10 established vegetative cover .
11 When the Contractor fails or neglects to coordinate grading with seeding and mulching 12 operations and to pursue diligently the control of erosion and siltation , the Engineer may 13 suspend the Contractor 's grading operations until such time as the work is coordinated in 14 a manner acceptable to the Engineer .
Such suspension will be in accordance with 15 Article 108-7 .
16 1660-4 SEEDBED PREPARATION 17 Cut and satisfactorily dispose of weeds or other unacceptable growth on the areas to be 18 seeded .
Shape and smooth uneven and rough areas outside of the graded section , such as crop 19 rows , farm contours , ditches and ditch spoil banks , fence line and hedgerow soil 20 accumulations and other minor irregularities which can not be obliterated by normal seedbed 21 preparation operations , to provide for more effective seeding and for ease of subsequent 22 mowing operations .
23 Scarify or otherwise loosen the soil to a depth of not less than 5 inches except as otherwise 24 provided below or otherwise directed .
Break clods and work the top 2 inches to 3 inches of 25 soil into an acceptable seedbed by the use of soil pulverizers , drags or harrows ; or by other 26 approved methods .
Remove all rock and debris 3 inches or larger on median , shoulder and 27 ditch cut or fill slopes which are 3:1 or flatter , before the application of seed and fertilizer .
28 Remove rock 6 inches and larger displaced during seeding operations .
29 Scarify , groove , trench or puncture all slope surfaces .
The depth of preparation and the 30 degree of smoothness of the seedbed may be reduced on cut slopes that are 2:1 and steeper , as 31 permitted by the Engineer .
32 On cut slopes that are either 2:1 or steeper , the Engineer may permit the preparation of 33 a partial or complete seedbed during the grading of the slope .
If at the time of seeding and 34 mulching operations such preparation is still in a condition acceptable to the Engineer , 35 additional seedbed preparation may be reduced or eliminated .
36 Limit seedbed preparation to within 2 feet of the edge of any pavement to a depth of 2 inches 37 to 3 inches .
38 Do not prepare seedbed when the soil is frozen , extremely wet or when the Engineer 39 determines that it is an otherwise unfavorable working condition .
40 Section 1660 16-24 1660-5 APPLYING AND COVERING LIMESTONE , FERTILIZER AND SEED 1 ( A ) General 2 The contract will state the seasonal limitation for seeding operations ; the kinds of grades 3 of fertilizers ; the kinds of seed ; and the rates of application of limestone , fertilizer and 4 seed .
5 Obtain approval from the Engineer before using equipment for the application , covering 6 or compaction of limestone , fertilizer and seed .
Approval may be revoked at any time if 7 equipment is not maintained in satisfactory working condition , or if the equipment 8 operation damages the seed .
9 Apply limestone , fertilizer and seed within 24 hours after completion of seedbed 10 preparation unless otherwise permitted by the Engineer .
When the Engineer determines 11 that weather and soil conditions are unfavorable , do not distribute any limestone or 12 fertilizer and do not sow any seed .
13 Take adequate precautions to prevent damage to traffic , structures , guardrails , traffic 14 control devices or any other appurtenances during the application of fertilizer .
Provide 15 adequate covering or change methods of application as required to avoid such damage .
16 Repair any damage that occurs , including any cleaning that may be necessary .
17 ( B ) Limestone and Fertilizer 18 Limestone may be applied as a part of the seedbed preparation , provided it is 19 immediately worked into the soil .
If not so applied , distribute limestone and fertilizer 20 uniformly over the prepared seedbed at the specified rate of application and then harrow , 21 rake or otherwise thoroughly work or mix into the seedbed .
22 ( C ) Seed 23 Distribute seed uniformly over the seedbed at the required rate of application , and 24 immediately harrow , drag , rake or otherwise work so as to cover the seed with a layer of 25 soil .
Cover to a depth as directed by the Engineer .
If two kinds of seed are to be used 26 which require different depths of covering , sow separately .
27 When a combination seed and fertilizer drill is used , drill fertilizer with seed after 28 applying and incorporating limestone into the soil .
If using two kinds of seed requiring 29 different depth of cover , the seed requiring the lighter cover may be sown broadcast or 30 with a special attachment to the drill , or drilled lightly following the initial drilling 31 operation .
32 When using a hydraulic seeder for application of seed and fertilizer , do not allow the seed 33 to remain in water containing fertilizer for more than 30 minutes before application 34 unless otherwise permitted .
35 Compact the seedbed immediately after seed has been properly covered in the manner 36 and degree approved by the Engineer .
37 ( D ) Modifications 38 When adverse seeding conditions are encountered due to steepness of slope , height of 39 slope or soil conditions , the Engineer may direct or permit that modifications be made in 40 the above requirements which pertain to incorporating limestone into the seedbed ; 41 covering limestone , seed and fertilizer ; and compaction of the seedbed .
42 Such modifications may include but not be limited to the following : 43 ( 1 ) The incorporation of limestone into the seedbed may be omitted as follows : 44 ( a ) On cut slopes steeper than 2:1 ; 45 Section 1660 16-25 ( b ) On 2:1 cut slopes when a seedbed has been prepared during the excavation of 1 the cut and is still in an acceptable condition ; or 2 ( c ) On areas of slopes where the surface of the area is too rocky to permit the 3 incorporation of the limestone .
4 ( 2 ) The rates of application of limestone , fertilizer and seed on slopes 2:1 or steeper or 5 on rocky surfaces may be reduced or eliminated .
6 ( 3 ) Compaction after seeding may be reduced or eliminated on slopes 2:1 or steeper , on 7 rocky surfaces or on other areas where soil conditions would make compaction 8 undesirable .
9 1660-6 MULCHING 10 ( A ) General 11 Mulch all seeded areas unless otherwise indicated in the contract or directed by the 12 Engineer .
13 Use grain straw as mulch at any time of the year .
If permission to use material other than 14 grain straw is requested and the use of such material is approved by the Engineer , the 15 seasonal limitations , the methods and rates of application , the type of binding material or 16 other conditions governing the use of such material will be established by the Engineer at 17 the time of approval .
18 ( B ) Applying Mulch 19 Apply mulch within 24 hours after completion of seeding unless otherwise permitted .
20 Exercise care to prevent displacement of soil or seed or other damage to the seeded area 21 during the mulching operations .
22 Spread mulch uniformly by hand or by approved mechanical spreaders or blowers which 23 will provide an acceptable application .
An acceptable application will be that which will 24 allow some sunlight to penetrate and air to circulate but also partially shade the ground , 25 reduce erosion and conserve soil moisture .
26 ( C ) Holding Mulch 27 Hold mulch in place by applying a sufficient amount of undiluted emulsified asphalt or 28 other approved binding material .
The Engineer will approve the rate and method of 29 application of binding material .
Apply the binding material directly with the mulch or 30 immediately following the mulch application .
31 Take adequate precautions to prevent damage to traffic , structures , guardrails , traffic 32 control devices or any other appurtenances during the application of asphalt binding 33 material .
Provide adequate covering or change methods of application as required to 34 avoid such damage .
Repair any damage that occurs , including any cleaning that may be 35 necessary .
36 Take sufficient precautions to prevent mulch from entering drainage structures through 37 displacement by wind , water or other causes and promptly remove any blockage to 38 drainage facilities which may occur .
39 1660-7 MAINTENANCE OF SEEDING AND MULCHING 40 Maintain areas where seeding and mulching have been performed in a satisfactory condition 41 until final acceptance of the project .
42 Mow at the location and times as directed .
43 Correct areas of damage or failure due to any cause by repairing or completely reworking as 44 directed .

9 1664-3 SODDING 10 ( A ) Handling and Storing Sod 11 Exercise extreme care during all operations of loading , transporting , unloading , storing , 12 placing , tamping and staking sod , to prevent breaking the sod sections and to prevent the 13 sod from drying out .
Any sod that is torn , broken or too dry will be rejected .
Torn or 14 broken sod , if kept moist , may be used for filling unavoidable small gaps in sod cover as 15 permitted .
16 Place sod on the designated areas within 48 hours after being cut unless otherwise 17 directed .
18 ( B ) Soil Preparation 19 Remove litter and other debris .
Mow and satisfactorily dispose of weeds or other 20 unacceptable growth on the areas to be sodded .
21 Bring the area to be sodded to a firm uniform surface at such elevation that the surface of 22 the complete sodding conforms to the finished grade and cross section as shown in the 23 plans .
24 Scarify or otherwise loosen soil to a depth of not less than 5 inches .
Break clods and 25 work the top 2 inches to 3 inches of soil into an acceptable soil bed by using soil 26 pulverizers , drags or harrows .
27 Place limestone and fertilizer before placing the sod .
The contract will state the kind and 28 grade of fertilizer , and the rates of application of limestone and fertilizer .
Distribute the 29 limestone and fertilizer uniformly over the area and thoroughly mix in the top 5 inches of 30 the soil by discing , harrowing or other approved methods .
31 Prepare the area by harrowing , dragging , raking or other approved methods to give 32 a lawn type finish .
Remove all trash , debris and stones larger than 1 ½ inches in diameter 33 or other obstructions that could interfere with the placing of the sod .
Moisten the finished 34 surface with water before placing the sod .
35 ( C ) Placing Sod 36 The contract will state the seasonal limitations for sodding and the kind of sod to use .
37 Sod handling and placement will be a continuous process of cutting , transporting and 38 installing without appreciable delays .
Install sod within 48 hours after being cut and 39 water immediately after installation .
40 Section 1664 16-30 Place sod firmly and carefully by hand within 24 hours after soil preparation is completed 1 and accepted by the Engineer .
Pack each piece of sod tightly against the edge of adjacent 2 pieces so that the fewest possible gaps will be left between the pieces .
Close unavoidable 3 gaps with small pieces of sod .
4 When placing sod on a slope , begin at either the top or the toe of the slope .
Place sod 5 with the long edge horizontal and with staggered vertical joints .
Turn the edge of the sod 6 slightly into the ground at the top of a slope and place a layer of earth over it and compact 7 so as to divert the surface water over and onto the top of the sod .
8 Stake sod in place by driving stakes flush with the sod , on all slopes 2:1 or steeper , in 9 drainage channels , on other areas shown in the plans , and on any areas that are in such 10 condition that there is danger of sod slipping .
Perform staking concurrently with sod 11 placement and before tamping with sound wooden stakes which are approximately one 12 inch square or one inch in diameter and not less than 12 inches in length .
Place enough 13 stakes to prevent slipping or displacement of the sod .
Drive stakes perpendicular to the 14 slope .
Where backfill is necessary on cut slopes to obtain a uniform sodding area , 15 provide stakes of sufficient length to reach at least 3 inches into the solid earth 16 underneath the backfill .
17 On all other areas , use metal staples in place of wooden stakes .
The metal staples should 18 be 12 inches long , made of 11 gauge new steel wire so as not to bend when pinned or 19 driven through the sod .
Shorter staples may be used with the approval of the Engineer .
20 Place , stake and staple the sod where necessary , then tamp or roll carefully and firmly by 21 acceptable means .
If rolled , roller shall weigh 150 lbs .
per foot of roller width .
Take 22 extreme care to prevent the installed sod from being torn or displaced .
23 Do not place sod when the atmospheric temperature is below 32°F .
Do not use frozen 24 sod or place on frozen soil .
25 ( D ) Watering Sod 26 Water carefully and thoroughly after sod has been placed and tamped .
Perform watering 27 as directed until final acceptance .
Application of water may be made by the use of 28 hydraulic seeding equipment , farm type irrigation equipment or by other acceptable 29 means .

1 1670-3 WEATHER AND SEASONAL LIMITATIONS 2 Perform planting operations only between the dates shown in the contract except where 3 otherwise permitted in writing .
4 Do not plant when the temperature is below 32°F , when the plant hole is frozen or when soil 5 to excavate and fill the plant hole is frozen or too wet .
6 Apply post-emergent herbicide when the weeds are near maturity but not when the weeds are 7 under stress from drought , disease , insect damage or any other cause .
8 Do not apply post-emergent herbicide when rain is likely within the next 6 hours or as 9 restricted on the product label .
10 1670-4 CARE AND HANDLING PLANTS 11 ( A ) General 12 Exercise utmost care in digging , loading , transporting , unloading , planting or otherwise 13 handling plants and use adequate precautions to prevent injury to or drying out of the 14 trunk , branches or roots ; and to prevent freezing of the plant roots .
Heel-in plants within 15 48 hours of delivery from the nursery , if they can not be planted within that time .
16 Properly maintain all heeled-in plants until planted .
Do not have plants remain heeled-in 17 for more than 30 days .
Open plants immediately when delivered in boxes or wrapped in 18 bundles or other forms of closed packages and inspect and dampen if necessary .
19 ( B ) Balled and Burlapped Plants 20 Protect the roots of balled and burlapped plants , if not immediately planted after delivery , 21 by adequately covering with a soil , mulch or sawdust that is kept moist constantly in 22 an acceptable manner appropriate to weather or seasonal conditions .
Preserve the solidity 23 of the plant ball carefully .
24 ( C ) Bare Rooted Plants 25 Refrigerate or immediately heel-in all plants , if not promptly planted , in moist soil , mulch 26 or sawdust in an acceptable manner corresponding to generally accepted horticultural 27 practice .
28 Protect the plants from drying out by means of wet canvas , burlap or straw or by other 29 means acceptable while being transported or planted .
30 ( D ) Geophytes 31 Geophytes ; bulbs , corms and tuberous plants ; that are being shipped shall be packaged in 32 containers that meet industry standards and have been pre-approved by the engineer .
All 33 individual packages shall be clearly labeled with quantity and cultivar name .
34 While bulbs , corms and tuberous plants are being transported or are being distributed in 35 planting beds , or are awaiting planting after distribution , protect them from drying out by 36 means of wet canvas , burlap , or straw , or by other means acceptable to the Engineer and 37 appropriate to weather conditions and the length of time they will be out of the ground .
38 Care shall be taken to avoid unnecessary injury to the bulbs before planting .
39 Pre-plant cool treatment is required for plants planted in a USDA Climatic Zones 9 40 and 10 .
Storage of bulbs , corms and tuberous plants which do not require pre-plant cool 41 treatment shall be stored in open trays and placed in a 55°F - 65°F , dry place away from 42 frost and heat and never allowed to dry out to the point of shriveling .
Packing in slightly 43 moist peat is preferred .
The storage area shall be well-ventilated and ethylene-free .
Do 44 not store bulbs with fruit such as apples or pears which produces ethylene gas which can 45 cause problems with flowering .
Do not store bulbs in paper or plastic bags unless 46 Section 1670 16-34 otherwise specified or approved .
If a refrigerator is used it shall be frequently ventilated .
1 1670-5 PLANT LOCATION 2 Locate and mark on the ground locations for plants and outlines for areas to be planted or 3 reforested and obtain approval before digging plant holes for beds .
4 Where so directed , furnish and install standard identification wires with plastic flags to 5 designate individual plants in major planting areas .
6 Flags will not necessarily be needed for all plants required by the contract , but use these flags 7 on portions of the project until plant locations in these portions are approved .
8 Unforeseen conditions may make it necessary to make minor adjustments in plant locations 9 due to utility lines , traffic signs , rock , drainage , etc. , and such adjustments will be permitted 10 subject to approval .
11 1670-6 PRUNING 12 Prune shrubs and trees after planting as shown in the plans or as directed by the Engineer .
13 Pruning done at any time in no way alters the Department 's right to reject plant material .
14 Prune in accordance with the International Society of Arboriculture pruning techniques , and 15 according to shape , size and condition of the individual plant .
16 1670-7 PLANT BED TREATMENT 17 ( A ) General 18 Treat plant beds by application of herbicides where called for by the plans or directed .
19 ( B ) License 20 Make pesticide applications by or under the direct supervision of an applicator licensed 21 by the North Carolina Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services .
22 ( C ) Post-Emergent Herbicidal Treatment 23 Post-emergent herbicidal treatment includes applications of a systemic post-emergent 24 total vegetation control herbicide .
25 The contract will state the rates of application of the post-emergent herbicides .
26 Apply all herbicides in accordance with the manufacturer 's instructions on the product 27 label .
28 Apply post-emergent herbicide when the weeds are near maturity but not when the weeds 29 are under stress from drought , disease , insect damage or any other cause .
If cloudy 30 weather or other poor growing conditions are present , extend this 7 day period until there 31 are visible signs of herbicidal activity .
Reapply if necessary to achieve a thorough 32 control .
33 ( 1 ) Post-Emergent Application for Plant Bed Preparation 34 Apply a systemic post-emergent total vegetation control herbicide to the bed area 35 before any tilling or mowing is performed .
Perform no tilling or mowing for at least 36 7 days after the application .
Thoroughly till the bed after the waiting period , or when 37 injury to the vegetation appears .
Prepare the soil in good tilth with no clods over one 38 inch present and before planting .
39 ( 2 ) Post-Emergent Application for Plant Bed Maintenance 40 Apply a systemic post-emergent herbicidal treatment in accordance with product 41 label in a manner to ensure no damage to planted material .
Perform no mowing or 42 vegetation removal by other means for at least 7 days after the application .
43 Section 1670 16-35 ( D ) Pre-Emergent Herbicidal Treatment 1 Pre-emergent herbicidal treatment includes the application of a pre-emergent herbicide .
2 Apply a pre-emergent herbicide to the plant bed after the existing vegetation has been 3 completely controlled by a post-emergent herbicide application as specified in herein and 4 after installation of planting and mulching as described in Articles 1670-9 and 1670-10 .
5 Apply pre-emergent herbicide following planting and mulching of plant bed before 6 germination of weed seeds .
An additional application of post-emergent herbicidal 7 treatment may be necessary to control emerged weeds , as directed , if sufficient time has 8 lapsed between tillage and installation of plant material and mulch .
No direct payment 9 will be made for additional post-emergent herbicidal work if such work is due to 10 carelessness or neglect on the part of the Contractor .
11 Apply herbicide evenly over the soil surface with properly calibrated equipment at the 12 specified rate .
13 If at least 0.5 inches of rainfall does not occur within 15 days of application of pre- 14 emergent herbicidal treatment , apply at least 0.5 inches of water ( 2.8 gal/sy ) uniformly 15 over the planting area to activate the herbicide .
16 1670-8 EXCAVATION OF PLANT HOLES 17 Provide cylindrical shaped plant hole excavations for plants other than reforestation plants , 18 with the plant location stake marking the center of the circle and with the sides of the hole 19 being approximately vertical .
When mechanical means are used which make digging of 20 cylindrical holes impractical , the complete hole shall have the minimum dimensions as shown 21 in the plans .
22 When plants are to be grouped together in a plant bed as contrasted to widely separated 23 individual plants , and when so indicated in the plans , loosen and pulverize clods to a depth of 24 not less than 5 inches for the entire area of the plant bed by means of a scarifier , disc , spade or 25 other appropriate means before plant holes are dug .
26 Plant reforestation plants in holes made by a planting spade , planting bar or other means 27 which meet the approval of the Engineer .
Make the hole of sufficient size to accommodate 28 the entire extended root system of the plant without cramping .
29 When geophytes ; bulbs , corms and tuberous plants ; are to be grouped together in a plant bed 30 as contrasted to widely separated individual plants , and when so indicated in the plans , loosen 31 and pulverize clods to a depth of not less than 8 inches , or as indicated in the plans , for the 32 entire area of the plant bed by means of a scarifier , disc , spade or other appropriate means 33 before plant holes are dug .
34 Place plants in holes made by a planting spade , planting bar or other means which meet the 35 approval of the Engineer .
Make the hole of sufficient size to accommodate the entire plant 36 structure without cramping .
Take care to plant all plants at a uniform depth as indicated in the 37 plans or directed by the Engineer .
38 When geophytes are to be planted separately as individual plants or in small separated groups , 39 loosen and pulverize clods with a spade , auger or other means which meet the approval of the 40 Engineer .
Individual planting holes shall be to a depth of not less than 8 inches , or sufficient 41 size to accommodate the entire plant structure without cramping or to a depth as indicated in 42 the plans or directed by the Engineer .
43 1670-9 PLANTING , BACKFILLING AND WATERING 44 ( A ) General 45 The plans will state the kind and rate of application of fertilizer .
Apply fertilizer during 46 backfilling operations in a manner that will ensure proper placement of the fertilizer and 47 avoid injury to the roots .
48 Section 1670 16-36 Scarify the walls and floor of the plant hole after the plant hole is dug .
Place the plant in 1 the prepared plant hole at the proper position as regards to depth , alignment , final grade 2 of the surrounding ground level and vertical placement of the trunk .
Maintain this 3 position during all subsequent backfilling and watering operations .
Set plants with the 4 root collar at the same depth as grown in the nursery or raise above grade as indicated in 5 the plans .
6 Moisten the soil with water after one-half to two-thirds of the backfilling and tamping has 7 been completed , if the soil in the plant holes is not sufficiently moist .
Apply water to 8 moisten all soil but not a quantity that will saturate the soil to the extent of excluding all 9 air from around the roots .
Place the remainder of the backfill after complete absorption 10 of water .
11 Construct water rings around all plants , except reforestation plants , in accordance with 12 details shown in the plans .
A water ring consists of a ridge of firmed soil in a ring around 13 the plant and of a minimum inside diameter equal to the diameter of the plant hole .
This 14 ridge is approximately 6 inches high and is compacted firmly enough to hold water .
15 ( B ) Balled and Burlapped Plants 16 Handle balled and burlapped plants by the ball and place in the plant hole so that the soil 17 of the ball will not be loosened from the roots .
After the hole has been almost completely 18 backfilled and the soil thoroughly firmed under and around the ball , cut the burlap away 19 and remove from around the stem of the plant .
Complete backfilling so as to avoid 20 loosening of the soil of the root ball .
21 ( C ) Container Grown Plants 22 Planting requirements for container grown plants are the same as applicable to balled and 23 burlapped plants .
Remove container immediately before planting .
During the removal of 24 the container , take sufficient precautions to ensure that the soil and roots inside the 25 container are undisturbed .
Scarify roots when directed .
26 ( D ) Bare Rooted Plants 27 Before the plant is placed in the plant hole , cut off smoothly any bruised or broken parts 28 of roots .
Place the plant in its proper position in the hole and backfill .
Carefully place 29 the backfill material , worked around and under the roots and compacted in a manner that 30 avoids bruising or breaking the roots .
31 ( E ) Reforestation Plants 32 Reforestation includes tree reforestation and shrub reforestation .
Type , mixture , size , 33 furnish description and spacing will be as shown on the reforestation detail sheet in the 34 plans .
35 Before beginning reforestation , each area to be reforested will be measured by the 36 Engineer to determine the exact number of acres for tree reforestation or shrub 37 reforestation therein and the quantity of each species of seedling to be planted within the 38 area .
39 Where structures or plantings do not adequately delineate the outline of the area to be 40 reforested , stake the outline of the area as directed by the Engineer .
Furnish cypress , 41 cedar , oak , locust or other wood stakes approved by the Engineer .
Provide stakes with 42 a minimum industry standard of 2 inches x 2 inches ( nominal ) size and approximately 43 30 inches in length with a 15 inch white top .
Drive stakes in the ground with 44 approximately 18 inches remaining above the ground line and place as necessary to 45 define and delineate the reforestation outline .
46 Ensure sample stock of reforestation seedlings are inspected by the Engineer , for general 47 health and moisture content , within 24 hours before planting .
48 Section 1670 16-37 After the plant hole has been prepared , place the plant upright in the hole at the correct 1 depth without crowding or bunching the roots .
Firm the soil around the root system from 2 the bottom of the plant hole to natural ground elevation .
3 Upon completion of planting the required number of seedlings within all areas to be 4 reforested , the Contractor will be relieved of further responsibility in connection with 5 reforestation except for damage caused directly by the Contractor .
6 ( F ) Geophytes 7 When planting geophytes ; bulbs , corms and tuberous plants ; take care to place all plants 8 at a uniform depth as indicated in the plans or directed by the Engineer .
All plants shall 9 be set upright as originally grown and at the proper spacing and depth from the natural 10 ground elevation .
Soil that is backfilled into the hole to obtain the proper depth shall be 11 firmed before plant placement .
Soil backfilled over the plant shall be firmed .
12 Planting shall be accomplished when the soil temperature is 40°F to 45°F or as directed 13 by the Engineer .
No phase of this work shall be performed when the temperature is 14 below 32°F , when the plant holes are frozen or when soil to excavate and fill the plant 15 hole is frozen or too wet .
16 Geophytes shall be watered as stated in the contract or as directed by the Engineer .
17 Watering will be required for geophytes if the soil in the plant hole is not sufficiently 18 moist .
Apply water to moisten all soil , but not in a quantity that will create standing 19 water or saturate the soil to the extent of excluding all air from around the plant .
20 1670-10 MULCH FOR PLANTING 21 Place mulch within 7 days of initial planting as a top layer on the backfilled plant hole and 22 water ring .
Place mulch approximately 4 inches deep as shown in the plans or as directed .
23 Place additional mulch as directed during establishment .
24 No mulching will be required for reforestation plants .
25 1670-11 WATER FOR PLANTING 26 Water at the time of planting as specified in Article 1670-9 and at the Contractor ’ s election 27 and the Engineer ’ s approval .
Water with gravity flow or low pressure applicators which have 28 been approved , and which will not erode soil around the plant root system or damage to 29 plants .
Saturate the soil around each plant thoroughly at each watering .
30 1670-12 STAKING OR GUYING 31 Stake or guy plants as shown in the plans or as directed to prevent damage .
32 Ensure that the plant is attached and held rigid to the support in a manner that will prevent 33 chafing or other injury to the bark , and that will permit normal development of the trunk or 34 branch .
35 1670-13 INITIAL PLANTING 36 Initial planting will be complete when the plants have been placed in the plant hole , 37 backfilled , fertilized , watered , mulched , staked and guyed , and the plants are in an acceptable 38 condition .
39 1670-14 ESTABLISHMENT 40 Begin establishment for all initial or replacement plants immediately after they are planted .
41 Maintain trees , shrubs , vines and groundcovers , and the area of planting until final acceptance 42 of the project .
Mow and maintain the area around trees and shrubs for a distance of 6 feet 43 beyond the outside limits of water rings or 6 feet beyond the limits of the guy stakes , 44 whichever is greater ; within shrub beds ; and for a distance of 6 feet outside the perimeter of 45 the shrub beds .
Establishment includes cutting of grass and control of weeds ; watering ; 46 Section 1670 16-38 fertilization ; replacement of mulch ; repair or replacement of guy stakes , guy wires and water 1 rings ; and other work as directed to ensure the survival and growth of plant material and the 2 satisfactory appearance of the project .
Remove dead plant material from the project during 3 the establishment period .
4 1670-15 REPLACEMENT PLANTING 5 Replacement planting of trees , shrubs and ground cover consists of replacing those plants 6 which are not in a living , healthy condition or do not conform to the Specifications contained 7 in American Standard for Nursery Stock or damaged or stolen .
Replacement of reforestation 8 plants will not be required .
9 Perform replacement planting within the planting season specified in the contract .
10 1670-16 FINAL INSPECTION 11 All planting shall be completed and all plants shall be in a living and healthy condition at the 12 time of final inspection .
13 1670-17 MEASUREMENT AND PAYMENT 14 ( Plant Species and Size Indicated in Contract ) will be measured and paid in units of each , 15 other than reforestation plants , planted and accepted .
16 Reforestation will be measured and paid in acres of land measured along the surface of the 17 ground .
18 Wetland Reforestation will be measured and paid in acres of land , measured along the surface 19 of the ground .
20 Post-emergent Herbicidal Treatment will be measured and paid in square yards of plant bed 21 measured along the surface of the ground .
22 Pre-emergent Herbicidal Treatment will be measured and paid in square yards of plant bed 23 measured along the surface of the ground .
24 Geophytes ( plant species and size indicated in contract ) will be measured and paid in units of 25 each that have been planted and accepted .
26 Mulch for Planting will be measured and paid in cubic yards .
Where mulch is furnished in 27 bales or bags , the number of cubic yards in each bale or bag will be determined and then 28 multiplied by the number of bales or bags of the same size which have been acceptably 29 furnished and placed .
Where mulch is furnished in trucks , each truck will be measured by the 30 Engineer and shall bear a legible identification mark indicating its capacity .
Load each truck 31 to at least its measured capacity at the time it arrives at the site of the work .
32 Water for Planting will be measured and paid in units of 1,000 gallon units .
Measurement of 33 water will be made by means of an approved metering device at the source of supply , or by 34 determining the volumetric capacity of tank trucks used to deliver water to the project and 35 recording the number of loads delivered by each truck .
36 No payment will be made for plant bed preparation , tillage , staking or guying and 37 fertilization , for this work will be incidental to other work in the contract .

9 1700-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 10 ( A ) General 11 Before beginning signal work , verify all existing signal equipment is in satisfactory 12 working order .
Report all defective signal equipment to the Engineer so as not to be held 13 responsible for defects .
14 Locate existing conduit , cable runs , inductive detection loops , lead-in cable , junction 15 boxes and detection equipment before installing or using equipment that can damage or 16 interfere with such facilities .
The locations of existing inductive detection loops shown 17 are approximate .
18 Locate all underground utilities before beginning drilling , digging or trenching 19 operations .
20 Ensure that an IMSA certified , or equivalent , Level II traffic qualified signal technician is 21 standing by to provide supervision and emergency maintenance services whenever work 22 is being performed on traffic signal controller cabinets and traffic signal controller 23 cabinet foundations .
Stand by status is defined as being able to arrive , fully equipped , at 24 the work site within 30 minutes ready to provide services .
25 Immediately cease work and notify the Engineer and affected owners if damage to 26 existing utilities , cables or equipment occurs .
Make all required repairs and 27 replacements .
28 ( B ) Regulations and Codes 29 Comply with NCGS § 87 , Article 4 , Electrical Contractors .
Comply with all regulations 30 and codes imposed by the owner of affected utility poles .
31 Notify the Engineer , local traffic enforcement agency , local utility company and affected 32 railroad companies 7 business days before operational shutdowns to coordinate 33 connection or disconnection to an existing utility or system .
34 Section 1700 17-2 Install standoffs , meter bases and service disconnects as required by the NESC , NEC , 1 local utility companies and local ordinances .
2 ( C ) Utility Services 3 Coordinate all work to ensure electrical power of proper voltage , phase , frequency and 4 ampacity is available to complete the work .
Use electrical services cables with 5 THWN insulation .
6 When electrical , telephone and telecommunication service is not furnished by the 7 Department and is required , contact the utility company and make application to ensure 8 all work can be completed .
Obtain authorization for service in the Department ’ s name 9 and make application for service in the Department ’ s name along with the associated 10 NCDOT Asset Inventory Number shown in the contract .
Notify the Engineer 11 immediately if this number is not shown in the contract .
12 The Department will be responsible for direct payment of monthly utility company usage 13 charges .
The Contractor will be responsible for all expenses associated with utility 14 installation costs , hookups , etc .
15 ( D ) Maintenance and Repair of Material 16 Furnish the Engineer with the name , office telephone number , cellular ( mobile ) telephone 17 number and pager number of the supervisory employee who will be responsible for 18 maintenance and repair of equipment during all hours .
19 Maintain and repair all signal and communications related equipment within the project 20 construction limits until completion of the observation period and receipt of written 21 notification of final acceptance of the project .
22 For all failures , malfunctions or damages to equipment , begin necessary repairs within 23 4 hours of notification .
Complete repairs within 8 hours of notification .
Comply with 24 Section 150 for maintenance of traffic flow .
The inability to contact the supervisory 25 employee or prearranged alternate will not extend repair time requirements .
26 Remove and replace all signal and communications related equipment that fails .
The 27 Department will furnish the Contractor replacement equipment for Department-furnished 28 equipment that fails .
29 Except for damages and malfunctions caused by the Contractor ’ s work activities , the 30 Contractor will not be held responsible for pre-existing conditions reported to the 31 Engineer before starting traffic signal work at the specific intersection .
The Contractor 32 will assume responsibility for all maintenance and emergency services necessary once 33 traffic signal work has begun at the specific intersection and for all damages and 34 malfunctions caused either directly or indirectly by the Contractor ’ s work activities .
35 Perform maintenance ( testing ) on all Traffic Signal Conflict Monitors every 12 months 36 for the life of the project beginning with the initial test and every 12 months thereafter .
37 Provide the initial test date via the manufacturer ’ s certification or via testing prior to 38 installation of the conflict monitor at an intersection .
Use the ATSI Incorporated Model 39 PCMT-2600 Conflict Monitor Tester or an Engineer approved equivalent .
Ensure that 40 the Conflict Monitor Tester is maintained and calibrated per the manufacturer ’ s 41 recommendation .
Provide to the Engineer a copy of the manufacturer ’ s certification that 42 the Conflict Monitor Tester is in proper working order before testing the Traffic Signal 43 Conflict Monitors .
Perform the test on the Traffic Signal Conflict Monitors per the 44 manufacturer ’ s recommendation .
For each Traffic Signal Conflict Monitor tested , 45 provide 2 dated copies of the test results : one copy for the Engineer and one copy for the 46 traffic signal cabinet .
47 Section 1700 17-3 In the event the Contractor fails to perform in accordance with the plans and Standard 1 Specifications within the time frame specified , the Department reserves the right to 2 perform maintenance and emergency service necessary to ensure continuous traffic signal 3 operation .

17 ( G ) Railroad Preemption 18 Where railroad preemption is required , coordinate all work with the railroad company .
19 Do not place signals into operation until signal equipment has been interconnected with 20 required railroad-highway crossing devices and railroad preemption is working properly .
21 Ensure preemption sequences begin immediately after activation of train detection .
22 Contact and coordinate with the railroad company to schedule interconnection of the 23 signal to the railroad controller cabinet .
Install lead-in cable from the signal controller 24 cabinet to a railroad company furnished and installed lockable junction box .
25 Interconnection will be made by the railroad company .
26 Provide fail-safe operation such that removal of voltage from the railroad side of the 27 isolation relay will initiate the railroad preemption sequence .

Coordinate vehicle 30 preemption work with the proper operating authority .
Contact the proper operating 31 authority and schedule installation of preemption equipment .

Modify proposed phasing and timing of 34 existing controllers .
35 Reinstall all existing time-based coordination .
As directed , make modifications to 36 existing coordination to account for changes in signal phasing .

40 ( J ) Wire and Cable 41 For installation in a conduit system , lubricate cable and wires before installing in conduit .

44 Section 1700 17-4 Terminate all electrical wire and cable at recessed-screw or barrier type terminal blocks .
1 Unless specifically allowed , connect no more than 2 conductors to the same terminal 2 screw .
3 Splice electrical wire and cable in junction boxes or condulets .
Maintain color coding of 4 wires throughout each splice .
5 Protect ends of wire and cable from water and moisture .
6 ( K ) Electrical Service and Grounding 7 Where electrical services do not include an external electrical service disconnect , modify 8 service to include electrical service disconnect and a new grounding electrode system .
9 Provide a grounding electrode system at all new electrical services .
In addition to 10 NEC requirements , test grounding electrode resistance for a maximum of 20 ohms .
11 Furnish and install additional ground rods to grounding electrode system as necessary to 12 meet test requirements .
13 Modify existing electrical services , as necessary , to meet the grounding requirements of 14 the NEC , these Standard Specifications and the project plans .
Remove any ground rods 15 in the cabinet foundation and install a new grounding electrode system .
Cut off 16 abandoned ground rods in the cabinet foundation flush with the foundation surface .
17 Where a grounding electrode system is connected to the electrical service in accordance 18 with the NEC , test grounding electrode resistance for a maximum of 20 ohms .
19 Grounding electrode resistance test shall be verified or witnessed by the Engineer or the 20 Engineer ’ s designated representative .
Furnish and install additional ground rods to 21 grounding electrode system as necessary to meet the Standard Specifications and test 22 requirements .
23 Follow test equipment ’ s procedures for measuring grounding electrode resistance .
When 24 using clamp-type ground resistance meters , readings of less than one ohm typically 25 indicate a ground loop .
Rework bonding and grounding circuits as necessary to remove 26 ground loop circuits and retest .
If a ground loop can not be identified and removed to 27 allow the proper use of a clamp-type ground resistance meter , use the three-point test 28 method .
29 Submit a completed Inductive Loop & Grounding Test Form available on the 30 Department ’ s website .
31 Provide a length of marker tape 6 inches to 12 inches below finished grade directly over 32 grounding electrodes and conductors .
33 ( L ) Electrical Bonding 34 Using an approved termination means , connect a # 14 AWG minimum , 19-strand copper 35 conductor ( Type THWN ) with green insulation to serve as an equipment grounding 36 conductor to metal poles , vehicular and pedestrian signal pedestals and other metallic 37 components .
Use messenger cables on wood poles and metal strain poles to provide 38 effective ground fault current path to cabinet ground .
39 ( M ) Traffic Signal Activation 40 Do not place signal in steady ( stop-and-go ) mode until inspected and authorized by the 41 Engineer .

18 1710-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 19 Install guy assemblies before installing messenger cable .
20 Use 3/8 inch messenger cable for spans supporting vehicle signal heads and/or signs .
21 Use 1/4 inch messenger cable for spans supporting only cables unless otherwise specified .
22 For messenger cable crossing over railroad tracks , provide a minimum of 27 feet of vertical 23 clearance , unless otherwise specified .
24 For permanent installations , install messenger cable in continuous lengths with no splices 25 except where an insulator is required .
With prior approval , existing messenger for temporary 26 installations may be extended instead of installing new messenger cable .
27 Tension messenger cable to eliminate appreciable sag and to match sag of surrounding 28 utilities .
Otherwise , allow 3 % to 4 % sag of the span length between poles .
29 For mid-run spans using wood poles , attach messenger cable to the pole with a 3-bolt cable 30 clamp with J-hook consisting of 5/8 inch diameter machine bolts , J-hooks , washers and square 31 nuts to attach messenger cable to wood poles .
Provide machine bolts that are 3 inches longer 32 than the pole diameter .
For mid-run spans using metal or other Department-approved poles , 33 attach messenger cable to the pole with a 3-bolt clamp with J-hook secured to the metal pole 34 via a pole band clamp .
Refer to Metal Pole Standard Drawing Sheets in effect on the date of 35 advertisement .
36 Section 1715 17-10 When terminating spans at wood poles , connect messenger cable to a deadend strandvise 1 attached to the pole via a 5/8 inch diameter shoulder eye bolt or 5/8 inch diameter shoulder 2 angle bolt with 5/8 inch eye nut as shown in Roadway Standard Drawings .
When terminating 3 spans at metal or other Department-approved poles , connect messenger cable to a deadend 4 strandvise attached to the pole via a pole attachment clamp .
Refer to Metal Pole Standard 5 Drawing Sheets as shown in the previous paragraph .
Do not install more than one messenger 6 cable and strandvise assembly to a single metal or other Department-approved pole 7 attachment clamp .
During installation , ensure that messenger cable is centered and directly 8 aligned at the pole clamp ’ s attachment point such that the cable does not exert forces on the 9 sides of the clamp ’ s attachment point .
10 Maintain electrical continuity at all splices .
11 ( A ) Messenger Cable for Signal Heads or Lead-In Cable 12 For messenger cable attached to joint use poles , install a new grounding system that 13 complies with Article 1720-3 for bonding messenger cable .
If a pole ground exists on the 14 joint use pole , bond new pole grounding system to existing pole ground using # 6 AWG 15 minimum solid bare copper grounding wire terminated with split bolt connectors or 16 parallel groove clamp at each end .
If existing poles do not have a grounding system , 17 install new grounding system that complies with Article 1720-3 .
18 ( B ) Messenger Cable for Communications Cable 19 For messenger cable attached to joint use poles , bond messenger cable to existing pole 20 ground at each end and at 1,300-foot intervals .
Install bond using # 6 AWG minimum 21 solid bare copper grounding wire terminated with split bolt connectors or parallel groove 22 clamp at each end .
If existing poles do not have a grounding system , install new 23 grounding system that complies with Article 1720-3 .
24 ( C ) Messenger Cable for Multiple Cables 25 On multiple messenger cable arrangements , connect all messenger cable ends with 26 # 6 AWG minimum solid bare copper wire and bond with split bolt connectors or parallel 27 groove clamp and terminate to pole ground .
