4 1715-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 5 ( A ) General 6 Ensure conduit is free of moisture and debris before pulling cables .
7 Following installation of conduit where cable is not immediately installed or conduit is 8 for future use ( spare ) , seal the ends of the conduit with a conduit plug .
Secure a pull line 9 to the conduit plug in such a manner that it will not interfere with installation of the 10 conduit plug and provides a watertight seal .
11 Extend ends of conduit 2 inches to 4 inches above concrete surfaces and 4 inches above 12 crushed stone bases .
For metallic conduit , install metallic bushings and bond conduits .
13 ( 1 ) Conduit 14 ( a ) Conduit Entering Junction Boxes 15 Terminate conduits installed for communications cables ( fiber optics , twisted 16 pair , ethernet and coaxial ) in oversized junction boxes .
Do not install other 17 conduits in the oversized junction box unless otherwise specified .
18 Terminate conduits installed for signal wiring , including lead-in cable , in 19 standard size junction boxes unless otherwise specified .
20 For all conduits entering junction boxes , seal spare conduits with approved 21 conduit plugs .
Seal conduits containing fiber-optic communications cable , 22 signal cable and lead-in cable with duct and conduit sealer .
23 ( b ) Conduit Entering Cabinet Foundations 24 For all conduits entering the cabinet through the cabinet foundation , seal spare 25 conduits with approved conduit plugs .
Seal conduits containing fiber-optic 26 communications cable , signal cable and lead-in cable with duct and conduit 27 sealer .
28 ( 2 ) Tracer Wire 29 Install tracer wire in all conduits containing fiber-optic cable .
Pull tracer wire 30 simultaneously in a continuous length with the fiber-optic cable .
Where multiple 31 pulls of fiber-optic cable are required and conduit is placed in the same trench , only 32 one tracer wire is required .
Where multiple pulls of fiber-optic cable are required 33 and conduits may separate into individual trenches , install a tracer wire in each 34 conduit run .
Provide waterproof butt splices where tracer wire is spliced .
Splicing 35 will be allowed only in cabinets and junction boxes .
Label all tracer wires entering 36 the equipment cabinet .
37 Section 1715 17-12 ( 3 ) Plan of Record Drawings 1 Upon completion of the conduit system for communications , furnish the Engineer 2 with a plan of record drawing detailing the locations of the conduit system .
3 ( B ) Trenching 4 In certain cases the Contractor may use an alternate material and method of installation 5 between trenching and plowing based on existing field conduits and preferences .
Obtain 6 approval before proceeding .
7 ( 1 ) General 8 Install PVC , HDPE or rigid metallic conduit for all underground runs .
Install rigid 9 metallic conduit for all underground runs located inside railroad right-of-way .
Clean 10 existing underground conduit to be incorporated into a new system .
Bond all 11 metallic conduit .
12 If more than one conduit is required between the same points , install conduit in one 13 common trench .
Install non-detectable marker tape .
14 Install longitudinal runs of conduit a minimum of one foot from back of curb or 15 6 feet from edge of pavement in the absence of curb .
If ditches are present , install 16 conduit a minimum of 4 feet from the bottom of the ditch line .
17 Maintain a minimum trench depth of 30 inches ( or 12 inches in areas blocked by 18 rock or impenetrable obstructions ) below finished grade or 6 inches below roadway 19 subbase , whichever is deeper .
Upon completion , restore surface to like-original 20 condition within 7 calendar days of occurrence of damage .
Remove all rock and 21 debris from backfill material .
Remove excess material from site and compact area 22 according to Article 300-7 .
Backfill with excavated material and compact to 95 % of 23 original density .
24 Backfill trench at locations along the trench path where non-movable objects , such as 25 rocks and boulders , can not be avoided .
The purpose of the backfill is to provide 26 a gradual change in elevation of the trench , so that excessive bending and stress will 27 not be transferred to conduits once underground conduit system is installed .
28 After installation of conduits and upon completion of tamping and backfilling , 29 perform a mandrel test on each conduit to ensure no conduit has been damaged .
30 Furnish a non-metallic mandrel having a diameter of approximately 50 % of the 31 inside diameter of the conduit in which it is to be pulled through .
If damage has 32 occurred , replace the entire length of conduit .
Ensure pull line is re-installed .
33 ( 2 ) Unpaved Trenching 34 Install conduit in all unpaved areas for all cable including permanent traffic signal 35 installations .
36 As shown in plans or as directed by the Engineer , direct bury lead-in cable for 37 temporary traffic signal installations .
38 Rake smooth the top 1 1/2 inches and seed with same type of grass as surrounding 39 area .
Finish unpaved areas flush with surrounding natural ground .
40 ( 3 ) Paved Trenching 41 On concrete surfaces , replace the entire joint of concrete unless otherwise specified .
42 On all other surfaces , neatly cut and replace the width of trench with like material .
43 Section 1715 17-13 Finish paved areas with materials matching damaged areas .
For conduit installed 1 under roadways , cut neatly and replace the width of paved area damaged by 2 trenching .
For conduit installed under sidewalks and walkways , remove entire 3 section of slab from joint to joint and replace .
Place graded stone material to 4 temporarily maintain traffic where repairs can not be performed immediately .
5 Comply with Article 545-4 .
6 ( C ) Plowing ( HDPE Conduit Only ) 7 Direct plow HDPE ducts simultaneously using chute plow method .
Direct plow ducts at 8 a minimum depth so the top of the highest duct is 30 inches deep unless otherwise 9 approved .
10 Provide sufficient personnel to feed chute , operate prime mover and equipment carrying 11 reels ( if separate equipment is used ) , observe chute feeding , observe plowing and observe 12 reel payout .
Use chute with adequate dimensions to allow for passage of duct without 13 damage .
During plow operation , continuously check chute opening and path to be sure 14 there are no obstructions and monitor payout reels to be sure reels are turning at a steady 15 rate .
16 With prior approval , install a junction box at locations where splicing or coupling of the 17 underground polyethylene conduits is necessary .
Otherwise , splicing or joining of 18 underground polyethylene conduit is prohibited .
19 ( D ) Directional Drilling 20 ( 1 ) Pre-Approvals and Minimum Depth Requirements 21 Obtain approval before beginning drilling operations .
22 At all points where HDPE conduit will traverse under roadways , driveways , 23 sidewalks or Controlled Access Areas including entrance/exit ramps , maintain 24 a minimum depth of 4 feet or 8 times the back reamer ’ s diameter , whichever is 25 deeper .
For an installation that runs parallel to a controlled access area or 26 entrance/exit ramps maintain a minimum depth of 30 inches below finished grade .
27 Maintain a minimum clearance of 30 inches below finished grade when crossing 28 ditch lines .
For the following structures , the minimum clearance requirements are : 29 TABLE 1715-1 MINIMUM CLEARANCE REQUIREMENTS FOR STRUCTURES Man-made Structure Minimum Clearance Requirement Bridge Foundation 5 ft horizontal and 4 ft vertical ( clearances greater than minimum horizontal should continue to use the 4V:5H ratio , i.e. , 10 ft horizontal should be no deeper than 8 ft ) Drainage Pipes 60 '' or Less 1 ft above or below [ while maintaining a minimum depth of 30 '' below grade ] Drainage Pipes Greater than 60 '' 1 ft above or 4 ft below [ while maintaining a minimum depth of 30 '' below grade ] Box Culverts 1 ft above or 4 ft below [ while maintaining a minimum depth of 30 '' below grade ] Slope Protection 2 ft below Slope Protection Foundation Footing 5 ft below Guarantee the drill rig operator and digital walkover locating system operator are 30 factory-trained to operate the make and model of equipment provided and have at 31 least one year experience operating the make and model of drill rig .
Submit 32 documentation of the operators ' training and experience for review at least 2 weeks 33 before start of directional drilling operations .
34 Section 1715 17-14 Provide a means of collecting and containing drilling fluid/slurry that returns to the 1 surface such as a slurry pit .
Provide measures to prevent drilling fluids from entering 2 drainage ditches and storm sewer systems .
Prevent drilling fluid/slurry from 3 accumulating on or flowing onto pedestrian walkways , driveways and streets .
4 Immediately remove all drilling fluids/slurry that are accidentally spilled .
5 ( 2 ) Directional Drill Operations 6 Provide grounding for the drill rig in accordance with the manufacturer ’ s 7 recommendations .
8 Place excavated material near the top of the working pit and dispose of properly .
9 Backfill pits and trenches to facilitate drilling operations immediately after drilling is 10 completed .
11 Use drill head suitable for type of material being drilled and sized no more than 12 2 inches larger than the outer diameter of the conduit .
Direct drill to obtain proper 13 depth and desired destination .
Pressure grout with an approved bentonite/polymer 14 slurry mixture to fill all voids .
Do not jet alone or wet bore with water .
15 During drilling operation , locate drill head every 10 feet along drill path and before 16 traversing underground utilities or structures .
Use digital walkover locating system 17 to track drill head during directional drilling operation .
Ensure locating system is 18 capable of determining pitch , roll , heading , depth and horizontal position of the drill 19 head at any point .
20 Once drill head has reached final location , remove head and install back reamer of 21 appropriate size ( no more than 2 inches larger than outer diameter of conduits ) to 22 simultaneously facilitate back reaming of drill hole and installation of conduit .
Back 23 reamer is sized larger than actual conduits to ensure conduits are not adversely 24 subjected to deviations caused by the original drill operation and are as straight as 25 practical in their final position .
26 The intent of these Specifications is to limit the diameter of the actual drill shaft/hole 27 so that it is no more than 2 inches larger than the conduit outer diameter .
The 2 28 inches larger diameter may be accomplished during the original bore or during the 29 back reaming/conduit installation process .
30 Once installation of conduit has started , continue installation without interruption so 31 as to prevent conduit from becoming firmly set .
Apply bentonite/polymer slurry 32 mixture during conduit installation .
33 Upon completion of conduit installation , perform a mandrel test on conduit system to 34 ensure conduit has not been damaged .
Furnish non-metallic mandrel with a diameter 35 of approximately 50 % of the inside diameter of the conduit in which it is to be pulled 36 through .
If damage has occurred , replace the entire length of conduit and ensure that 37 pull line is re-installed .
38 ( 3 ) Drilling Fluids 39 Use lubrication for subsequent removal of material and immediate installation of the 40 conduit .
The use of water and other fluids in connection with directional drilling 41 operations will be permitted only to the extent necessary to lubricate cuttings .
Do 42 not jet alone or wet bore with water .
Use drilling fluid/slurry consisting of at 43 least 10 % high-grade bentonite/polymer slurry to consolidate excavated material and 44 seal drill hole walls .
45 Transport waste drilling fluid/slurry from site and dispose of in a method that 46 complies with Federal , State and local laws and regulations .

Otherwise , splicing or joining of HDPE conduit is prohibited .

Use a heat source that will provide even heat 19 distribution around tubing .
Ensure no damage occurs to any cables .
20 Bond new risers , a minimum of 10 feet above grade , to the pole ground using a # 6 AWG 21 minimum solid bare copper wire and an approved pipe clamp , a split bolt connector or 22 parallel groove clamp .
On pole mounted cabinets where the riser are connected to the cabinet , 23 bond risers in the cabinet using ground bushings with a # 6 AWG minimum solid bare copper 24 wire to the cabinet ground bus .
25 If a pole ground exists on the joint use pole , bond new riser to existing pole ground using 26 # 6 AWG minimum solid bare copper wire terminated with split bolt connectors or parallel 27 groove clamp .
28 If existing poles do not have a grounding system , install new grounding system that complies 29 with Article 1720-3 for bonding messenger cable .
30 Transition from rigid galvanized steel risers to underground PVC conduits using an approved 31 rigid galvanized steel sweeping elbow with PVC female adaptor .

7 Item Section Inductive Detection Loops 1098-8 Furnish material , equipment and hardware under this section that is pre-approved on the 8 ITS and Signals QPL .

11 1725-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 12 All work performed in this section shall be done in the presence of the Engineer .
13 Notify Engineer one week before installing inductive detection loops .
14 Coordinate sawcutting and loop placement with pavement markings .
For new construction or 15 for resurfacing , install inductive detection loops before placing final layer of surface course .
16 On unmarked pavement , pre-mark locations of stop lines and lane lines before locating 17 inductive detection loops .
18 Before sawcutting , pre-mark inductive detection loop locations and receive approval .
Sawcut 19 pavement at approved pre-marked locations .
Do not allow vehicles to travel over unsealed 20 loop slots .
21 Install conduit with bushings from edge of pavement to junction box .
Ensure conduit 22 maintains a minimum 30 inches of cover from the edge of pavement structure to the junction 23 box .
Do not sawcut through curb .
24 Remove all loose material and wash saw slots with a high-pressure method using an air and 25 water mixture .
Dry saw slots with compressed air .
Clear saw slots of jagged edges and 26 protrusions .
Seat loop conductor at bottom of saw slot without damaging loop wire .
27 Before sealing loop conductors , test that impedance from the loop wire to ground is at 28 least 100 megaohms .
For each location with inductive loops , submit a completed Inductive 29 Detection Loop & Grounding Test Results form and place copy in controller cabinet .
Ensure 30 all loops are included on form .
The form is located on the Department ’ s website .
31 Embed loop conductors in saw slot with loop sealant .
Seal saw slot and dispose of excess 32 sealant in an environmentally safe manner .
33 Between where loop conductor pairs leave saw cut in pavement and junction boxes , twist loop 34 conductor pairs a minimum of 5 turns per foot .
Permanently label each twisted pair in the 35 junction box with nylon cable tie using indelible ink .
Indicate loop number and loop polarity 36 on the tie .

10 1730-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 11 ( A ) General 12 Provide cable manufacturer ’ s attenuation and Optical Time Domain 13 Reflectometer ( OTDR ) testing data for each reel of cable upon request .
14 Install SMFO communications cable , snow shoes , communications cable identification 15 markers , lashing wire and all necessary hardware .
16 Comply with manufacturer ’ s recommendations .
Install communications cable on signal 17 poles , utility poles , messenger cable and in conduits as required to bring the fiber-optic 18 cable into and , if necessary , out of each splice enclosure .
19 Take all precautions necessary to ensure cable is not damaged during storage , handling 20 and installation .
Do not violate minimum bending radius of 20 times the radius of cable 21 diameter or manufacturer ’ s recommendation , whichever is greater .
Do not step on cable 22 nor run over cable with vehicles or equipment .
Do not pull cable over or around 23 obstructions or along the ground .
24 Determine lengths of cable necessary to reach from termination-point to termination- 25 point .
Install cable in continuous lengths between approved splicing facilities .
26 Additionally , provide a sufficient amount of slack cable to allow for an additional 20 feet 27 of cable to be present after removal of outer sheath for termination .
Measure slack cable 28 by extending cable straight out of cabinet door .
29 Keep cable ends sealed at all times during installation to effectively prevent the ingress of 30 moisture .
Use approved heat shrink cable end cap .
Do not use tape to seal cable ends .
31 Before installing cable , provide 3 copies of cable manufacturer 's recommended and 32 maximum pulling tension .
Do not exceed manufacturer ’ s recommended pulling tension .
33 Use pulling grips containing a rotating swivel .
Coil cable in a figure-8 configuration 34 whenever cable is unreeled for subsequent pulling .
35 Install fiber-optic cable in separate 2 inch risers with heat shrink tubing or conduits .
Do 36 not share risers or conduits containing fiber-optic cable with other type cable .
37 Section 1730 17-24 ( B ) Aerial Installation 1 Double lash fiber-optic cable to messenger cable with one 360° spiral per foot .
2 Use pole attachment hardware and roller guides with safety clips to install aerial run 3 cable .
4 Maintain tension during the pulling process for aerial run cable by using an approved 5 mechanical clutch ( dynamometer ) device .
Do not allow cable to contact the ground or 6 other obstructions between poles during installation .
Do not use a motorized vehicle to 7 generate cable pulling forces .
8 Use a cable suspension clamp when attaching cable tangent to a pole .
Select and place 9 cable blocks and corner blocks so as not to exceed the cable ’ s minimum bending radius .
10 Do not pull cable across J-hooks .
11 Store 100 feet of each fiber-optic cable on all cable runs that are continuous without 12 splices where specified .
Obtain approval for spare cable storage locations .
Store spare 13 fiber-optic cable on fiber-optic cable storage racks ( snow shoes ) .
Locate spare cable 14 storage in the middle of spans between termination points .
Do not store spare fiber-optic 15 cable over the roadway or driveways .
16 Install one communications cable identification marker within 36 inches of pole 17 attachment points and at locations where more than one cable originates or terminates .
18 ( C ) Underground Installation 19 Install fiber-optic cable underground in conduit using cable pulling lubricants 20 recommended by the fiber-optic cable manufacturer .
21 Obtain approval of cable pulling lubricant and method of pulling before installing 22 underground fiber-optic cable .
23 Use a dynamometer ( clutch device ) so as not to exceed maximum allowable pulling 24 tension if cable is pulled by mechanical means .
Do not use a motorized vehicle to 25 generate cable pulling forces .
26 Keep tension on cable reel and pulling line at start of each pull .
Do not release tension if 27 pulling operation is halted .
Restart pulling operation by gradually increasing tension 28 until cable is in motion .
29 For pulling cable through manholes , junction boxes and vaults , feed cable by manually 30 rotating the reel .
Do not pull cable through intermediate junction boxes , handholds or 31 openings in conduit unless otherwise approved .
32 Install communications cable identification markers on each communications cable 33 entering a junction box .
34 ( D ) Installation of Drop Cable Assembly 35 Determine length of drop cable needed , including slack , to reach from termination point 36 to termination point .
37 At aerial splice enclosures , store 100 feet of slack cable on cable storage racks .
At below 38 ground splice enclosures , coil 100 feet of slack cable in manhole or junction box where 39 enclosure is located .
40 At equipment cabinet end of drop cable assembly , terminate all fibers with 41 ST-PC connectors to the connector panel .
Label all connectors , pigtails and the 42 connector panel .
At the aerial splice enclosure location , cap off all unused fibers and 43 label to correspond with the connector panel .

24 1731-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 25 ( A ) General 26 Include on the cover of each splice tray in a legible format the following information : 27 ( 1 ) Splice location reference number or identification information 28 ( i.e .
06-1011 tray 1 of 3 , 06-1011 tray 2 of 3 , etc . )
29 ( 2 ) Date the splice was made 30 ( 3 ) Company name of individual performing the splicing 31 ( 4 ) Name of individual performing the splicing 32 Section 1731 17-26 ( B ) Workmanship 1 Upon cutting the cable and removing the outer jacketing material down to the individual 2 buffer tubes , secure the central strength member to the enclosure so that no tensile force 3 is applied to the fibers .
Secure the individual buffer tubes to the splice trays by a method 4 recommend by the manufacturer .
Determine the length of each buffer tube needed to 5 ensure the buffer tube can be looped a minimum of two times around the inside the splice 6 tray .
Upon determining the length of buffer tube needed remove the buffer tube to 7 expose the individual fibers for fusion splicing .
Adjust individual fiber lengths as 8 necessary to ensure that once the fusion splicing process is completed that the finished 9 splices will align with the “ splice block organizer ” supplied within the splice tray .
10 Ensure the slice block organizer has individual fusion splice space holders for each fiber 11 splice .
12 While prepping the individual fibers for splicing install the heat shrink protecting tube 13 over the fiber and then perform the splicing operations , following the manufacturer ’ s 14 instructions .
Verify the newly formed splice does not exceed 0.05 dB of attenuation .
15 If the attenuation is more than 0.05 dB then remake the splice until it meets the 0.05 dB 16 or less requirement .
Finish the splicing operation by sliding the heat shrink tube over the 17 splice and applying heat to activate the heat shrink tubing .
Secure the finished splice in 18 the splice block organizer .
Ensure each splice is properly secured in a space holder in the 19 splice block organizer .
Multiple splices secured to the same space holder are 20 unacceptable .
21 Ensure all buffer tubes are contained within splice trays so no bare fibers are outside tray 22 and do not damage the fiber or violate the minimum bending radius of the fiber .
23 Prior to installing the cover over the splice tray and placing it in its final resting location , 24 take a mandatory digital photograph of the splice tray that shows the final workmanship .
25 Ensure the photograph shows the “ Workmanship Identification Information ” as well as 26 the workmanship associated with installing and terminating the fiber .
Include digital 27 copies of each photograph on a compact disk as part of the OTDR Test Results submittal .
28 ( C ) Termination and Splicing within Interconnect Center 29 Install interconnect centers with connector panels , splice trays , storage for slack cable or 30 fibers , mounting and strain relief hardware and all necessary hardware .
31 Terminate and splice all fibers including unused fibers .

Obtain approval of fiber-optic connector 34 labeling method .
35 For all fibers designated for termination to connector panel within interconnect center , 36 fusion splice fibers to pigtails .
37 For all cut fibers designated to pass through interconnect center , fusion splice fibers .
38 For all buffer tubes designated to pass through interconnect center , neatly coil excess 39 tubing inside interconnect center .

46 For all buffer tubes designated to pass through splice enclosure , neatly coil excess tubing 47 Section 1731 17-27 inside basket provided with enclosure .
1 Label all fiber-optic splices .

18 ( F ) Testing 19 Provide written notification a minimum of 10 days before beginning OTDR tests .
20 After splicing is completed , perform bi-directional OTDR tests on each fiber , including 21 unused fibers .
Install a 1,000 foot pre-tested launch cable between the OTDR and fiber 22 optic cable to be tested and a 1,000 foot pre-tested destination cable on the end of the 23 fiber optic cable to be tested .
Ensure each launch cable has been tested and is compatible 24 with the fiber being installed .
Provide Engineer with test results of the launch cable 25 before use .
Re-test or replace launch cable at Engineer ’ s request .
26 Ensure fusion splice losses do not exceed 0.05 dB and connectors have a loss of 0.5 dB or 27 less .
If any fiber exceeds maximum allowable attenuation or if fiber properties of the 28 cable have been impaired , take appropriate actions up to and including replacement of the 29 fiber cable .
30 Clearly label each OTDR trace identifying a starting and ending point for all fibers being 31 tested .
Record the attenuation level of each fiber and clearly indicate OTDR trace results 32 in report format .
Furnish 2 hard copies of each of the OTDR trace results and electronic 33 copies of all trace results along with digital photographs showing workmanship for each 34 splice on a compact disk .
Furnish the manufacturer ’ s make , model number and software 35 version of the OTDR used for testing .
36 Furnish to the Engineer 2 copies of the software needed to view the OTDR traces 37 electronically .

18 Pedestals are defined as follows : 19 ( A ) Type I - Pedestrian Pushbutton Post 20 ( B ) Type II - Normal-Duty Pedestal 21 ( C ) Type III - Heavy-Duty Pedestal 22 1743-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 23 ( A ) Type I Pedestrian Pushbutton Post 24 Install pushbutton post for mounting pedestrian pushbutton or an accessible pedestrian 25 signal ( APS ) assembly ( refer to Section 1705 ) .
26 Install underground conduit for pushbutton lead-in cable in the pushbutton post ’ s 27 foundation .
28 Attach or anchor pushbutton post to the top of foundation via a breakaway support in 29 a vertical plumb orientation .
Ensure post is of sufficient length to accommodate the 30 pushbutton , accessible pedestrian signals and any associated pedestrian informational 31 signing at the mounting heights shown in the plans or Roadway Standard Drawings .
32 ( B ) Type II and III Pedestals 33 Locate foundations , determine elevation and submit findings for normal-duty and 34 heavy-duty pedestals .
Obtain the Engineer ’ s approval of foundation locations and 35 elevations before constructing foundations .
36 Excavate in accordance with Section 410 .
If encountered , remove rock or boulders to 37 a sufficient depth to obtain stability necessary to support the structure for design loads .
38 Ensure ground is level before installing foundations .
39 Construct foundations in accordance with Section 825 .
Cast concrete for pole 40 Section 1743 17-34 foundations against undisturbed soil unless otherwise permitted .
Provide forms with 1 chamfer strips that measure one inch along diagonal face at all corners above ground 2 level .
Do not install foundations over uncompacted fill or muck .
3 Install conduit in foundations .
4 Securely place , position and align anchor bolts symmetrically about the center of 5 foundation .
6 Give exposed vertical concrete surfaces a broom finish .
Give exposed horizontal 7 surfaces a float finish .
8 Level tops of concrete foundations .
Do not allow tops to exceed 4 inches above adjacent 9 ground surface .
Pour and finish foundation to a level that is flush with the surrounding 10 sidewalk when possible .
11 Do not erect pedestals until concrete has attained a minimum compressive strength of 12 2,500 psi as determined by cylinder breaks .
13 Refer to Roadway Standard Drawings .
14 ( C ) Screw-In Helical Foundation Anchor Assembly : 15 Advance or mechanically screw foundation into soil until top of attachment plate is level 16 with finished grade .
Slide the anchor bolt heads through the keyhole openings and under 17 the attachment plate with threads pointing up .
Bolt the pedestal base to the foundation 18 attachment plate .
19 For further construction methods , see manufacturer ’ s installation drawings .

) , 34 install communications interface equipment and hardware for signals .

43 Section 1752 17-39 ( C ) Workshop 1 Provide enclosed workshop to set up and test new controllers and cabinets before 2 installation .
Locate workshop within Division responsible for project administration .
3 Ensure workshop provides protection from weather and sufficient space to house 2 test 4 observers , all necessary test equipment and material , controllers and cabinets .
5 Configure and test each controller and cabinet to match the proposed signal design .
6 Ensure all equipment furnished and installed or modified by the Contractor at each 7 location operates in full compliance with the plans and project special provisions .
Test 8 each controller and cabinet for proper color sequence , flashing operation , phase timings , 9 preemption , coordination and conflict monitor programming or malfunction management 10 unit programming .
Ensure that simultaneous conflicting phase outputs will cause the 11 cabinet to revert to flashing operation .
For intersections with any type of preemption , 12 submit a completed Preemption Test Procedure Checklist .
The checklist is located on the 13 Department ’ s website .
14 Test the cabinet and controller for eight hours minimum .
Following this test and before 15 installation , the Engineer will inspect the equipment in operation .
The Engineer may 16 require other tests to ensure proper operation .
These tests shall be at no additional cost to 17 the Department .

35 1752-3 CONSTRUCTION METHODS 36 ( A ) Install Conduit Entrance into Existing Foundation 37 Install Conduit Entrances into existing cabinet foundations by core drilling foundations to 38 install additional conduit .
39 Maintain a minimum of 3 inches of cover between new conduit and edge of foundation .
40 Maintain minimum clearances of 1 inch from the flange of the base adapter and 2 inches 41 from existing conduits .
Avoid damaging existing conduit , conductors and anchor bolts .
42 Repair all such damages .
Where approved by the Engineer , the foundation may be 43 Section 1752 17-40 chipped instead of drilled for conduit entrance .
When possible , maintain traffic signal 1 operations while drilling is performed .
2 Bond new metallic conduit to the equipment ground bus .
3 After installation of conduit , place grout to seal around conduit and return the foundation 4 to normal appearance .
5 ( B ) Modify Foundation 6 Enlarge existing cabinet foundations to accommodate the new cabinet and/or to provide 7 a maintenance technician pad .
8 Excavate the ground around the existing foundation to a depth sufficient to expose 9 a minimum of 4 inches of the foundation below existing grade .
10 Rough the sides of the existing foundation from the top to a point 4 inches below grade 11 by means of a chisel or other method approved by the Engineer .
12 Wash the sides of the foundation with water pressurized at 50 psi and thoroughly dry 13 with compressed air .
14 Drill holes approximately 12 inches deep on 12 inches centers into the existing 15 foundation .
Install # 4 dowels and epoxy into place .
Provide dowels of the lengths in 16 Table 1752-1 .
17 TABLE 1752-1 LENGTH OF DOWEL Foundation Extension Length of Dowel > 16 '' 24 '' > 6 '' and < 16 '' 17 '' = 6 '' 14 '' Use concrete to install the maintenance technician pad .
18 Form the sides of the modified foundation to a minimum depth of 4 inches below grade .
19 Position forms so that all existing exposed foundation surfaces at or above grade level 20 will be matched .
21 Apply a coating of approved epoxy bonding agent to all exposed roughened concrete 22 surfaces as recommended by the manufacturer .
23 Enlarge the foundation to the distance specified for new cabinet foundations .
Provide 24 a one inch chamfer on all new outside edges .
25 Maintenance technician pads should be added to the foundation to provide a minimum 26 work area of 24 inches [ length ] x 30 inches [ width ] from both the front and rear doors of 27 the cabinet .

31 Section 1757 17-43 ( B ) Removal 1 Dismantle and remove existing traffic signal equipment and material , excluding joint use 2 poles .
Disconnect and remove all Department equipment from joint use poles in 3 a manner that will not damage the poles or existing utilities .
Cut electrical conduit and 4 remove to at least 18 inches below finished ground elevation unless otherwise directed by 5 the Engineer .
6 Install the required regulatory signs in accordance with Sections 900 , 901 and 903 of the 7 Standard Specifications before deactivating the traffic signal .
Cover the signs with 8 burlap bags until the traffic signal is removed or put into flashing operation .
9 If necessary to flash the traffic signal before removal of the signal equipment , 10 immediately uncover the signs before placing the traffic signal into flashing operation .
11 Operate the flashing operation for a period of time as directed by the Engineer .
12 Deactivate , dismantle and remove the traffic signal after the period of flashing operation 13 or as directed by the Engineer .
14 Use methods to remove the traffic signal that will not result in damage to other portions 15 of the project or facility .
Repair damage that results from the Contractor 's actions at no 16 additional cost to the Department .
17 Final acceptance of the project is contingent upon the removal of the existing traffic 18 signal .
Removal of the existing traffic signal is part of the work required by the final 19 completion date .

Return all other traffic signal equipment and material to the Traffic 25 Services Office within the Division responsible for the administration of the project .
26 Return the removed equipment and material between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 27 12:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday or at a time mutually agreed upon by the 28 Contractor and the Engineer .
